webTitle: Brightening up city centres is not enough

fields.headline: Resurrecting the city
fields.standfirst:
Brightening up the centre is not enough
SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers, the chairman of the urban task force, got it right: yesterday's white paper on urban renaissance was a welcome advance, but only a start on a very long journey. It offers a vision of what our towns and cities, where 80% of us live, could be like in 20 years, but on a succession of crucial issues - land assembly, land clean-up, resource allocation and statutory powers - it falls short, as he said, of what is going to be required to engender a real urban renaissance.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers, the chairman of the urban task force, got it right: yesterday's white paper on urban renaissance was a welcome advance, but only a start on a very long journey. It offers a vision of what our towns and cities, where 80% of us live, could be like in 20 years, but on a succession of crucial issues - land assembly, land clean-up, resource allocation and statutory powers - it falls short, as he said, of what is going to be required to engender a real urban renaissance.

The challenge is familiar. A country with the world's first industrial cities has seen them in steep and accelerating decline as successive governments promoted new towns, out-of-town shopping malls and M4 golden corridor development. The population of Manchester and Liverpool has fallen by a third in the last 25 years. Over 500,000 jobs have been lost in 20 major cities. All is not bleak. Town centres are being revived. The first new homes for years are being provided for affluent single people by converting central warehouses. It is just beyond the centre that the trouble really sets in. Read Peter Hetherington's account today of east Manchester: derelict land, falling population, plummeting property prices. Yet this is where redevelopment must take place if the switch from greenfield to brownfield sites is to be made. The urban task force warned what would happen unless that is done: with 3.8m new homes needed by 2021, an area bigger than Exmoor would be concreted over.

Yesterday's white paper was the first on this theme for 23 years. Although delayed, many earlier government initiatives are more important than yesterday's, including the 10-year £180bn new transport strategy, the drive to raise inner-city school standards (vital if families are to be attracted back), the reduction in property and car crime. There is the promise of stricter planning laws and 12 new urban regeneration "companies". What is missing is a sense of whole-hearted commitment. Last week's tax concessions on urban redevelopment have shrivelled with the release of the details. There is no promise of a renaissance bill, to avoid piecemeal legislation and end the bickering between departments; planning obligations have still to be "reviewed". Not so much a renaissance, then, as a reawakening.

webTitle: Artisan Thorpe makes toilers of Pakistan

fields.headline: Artisan Thorpe makes toilers of Pakistan
fields.standfirst:
England on top after a record stand and an epic century of only one four
England 393-6
Scoreboard
fields.trailText: England finished the second day on top after a record stand and a century by Graham Thorpe that included only one four.
fields.body:
This was a day when the words "hoist" and "petard" came readily to mind. Intent on producing a dust bowl on which to subject England to ordeal by spin, Pakistan found their spinners and seamers alike neutered by its lack of pace.

The ball turned all right, but not hugely and with the rapidity of the Millennium Eye, allowing England's batsmen time to play. There was also the unusual sight of a local umpire, Riazuddin, who not only does not give visiting batsmen out when they are not, but fails to do so even when they ought to be. Things have come an awfully long way since 1987.

So far from polishing off the England innings in the opening session, as they had confidently expected, Pakistan were forced to spend a second day in the field, chasing shadows and regretting the chance spurned by slip when Graham Thorpe had only two to his name, before tea on the first day.

By the close yesterday, six overs early because of bad light, the Surrey man's seventh and most industrious Test century, plus a sparky unbeaten 89 from Craig White - full of confidence despite surviving a number of credible lbw shouts, an edge off bat and pad to silly point and a return catch to Saqlain Mushtaq - had put England in the driving seat.

With the tourists moving from 195 for four overnight to what already looks an unassailable total of 393 for six, Pakistan appeared to read the race early and by mid-afternoon had apparently thrown in the towel at least as far as winning the game was concerned. Moin Khan set his field back, slowed the over-rate down to West Indian torpor and bantered good-naturedly with the batsmen.

At square leg, while the spinners twirled and toiled, Wasim Akram, one of the game's great bowlers, had his hands thrust deep into his pockets, his contribution to the day only seven overs, four of them at the start of play, when he could have taken the second new ball, and another three after lunch when Moin finally decided the time was ripe - 115 overs after the first ball had been removed from its wrapper. In not launching Wasim and the new ball at White when he first came in, Moin surely missed a huge trick.

As it is, only Saqlain has cut the mustard for Pakistan and he must have been a weary worker at stumps. Both wickets to fall yesterday went to him, giving him all six, for 131, from a mammoth 57 overs. All the tricks came out of the box but even he, by late on, was reduced to bowling wide of off stump to Thorpe with a packed off-side field in an effort to force an indiscretion. Indiscretion?

Thorpe, who came to the crease half an hour before tea on the first day, batted for 10 minutes over seven hours for his 118 and, before top-edging a sweep back to the bowler 10 minutes before the day's end, allowed himself all the frivolity of a puritan tax inspector.

On Wednesday, when he had barely reached double figures, he smacked a full toss from Mushtaq Ahmed to the boundary, an event so uninteresting at the time that only the scorers made a note. Yet it was 234 deliveries and more than 24 hours later, by which time he had completed his hundred, before he hooked a bouncer from Abdur Razzaq for another. In Durban 61 years ago Paul Gibb opened for England and made 120, also hitting only two boundaries; the records do not show whether one or both came before he had passed three figures, but no century-makers have hit fewer in total than this pair - and in reaching the boundary only the once en route to his century, Thorpe may very well be unique in Test history.

Thorpe is an artisan cricketer, a craftsman doing a job. Whether he is hitting a boundary, clutching a slip catch or reaching a landmark, his nature is to keep his emotions in check. But even he allowed himself a hop and skip of delight when he scampered the three runs that took him to his century here.

There was a hug, too, from White, who, arriving to join him after Graeme Hick had been pinned back on his stumps to fall leg-before on the hour, had seized the initiative in such a compelling manner that it removed the imperative from the senior partner to take control himself. They ended up sharing a sixth-wicket partnership of 166, a record for England against Pakistan home or away.

White came into this game with a hamstring niggle that might just have kept him out. But he has played all the games on this tour nonetheless, hitting 120 in the first warm-up match in Rawalpindi.

Disarmingly, in the euphoria of that, which was his first big innings for England, he hinted that he would try to replicate his aerial bombardment of the spinners in the Test. That, some feared, might come back to haunt him. But he was as good as his word yesterday, hitting Saqlain fearlessly over the off-side - something Fred Titmus used to hate above all else - and once swinging him over the midwicket rope for six.

Earlier the Yorkshire all-rounder strode down the pitch to Shahid Afridi's brisk and bouncy leg-spin and deposited it yards over the long-off boundary. He swept emphatically and hard, too, good calculated shots, and in all hit eight fours as well as the sixes in a stay of some 4 hours.

webTitle: Opportunity wasted to pass on the good news

fields.headline: Opportunity wasted to pass on the good news
fields.standfirst: The ECB's attitude to the media is damaging the image of English cricket, writes  Paul Allott
fields.trailText: After it denied access to Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick, it is clear that the ECB's attitude to the media is damaging the image of English cricket, writes Paul Allott.
fields.body:
England exceeded all expectations, even their own, in Lahore yesterday as they ground Pakistan into the dust. Four big innings have cheered the nation as England continue to improve their standing on the world stage. What an opportunity, even before halfway in this Test, for the England and Wales Cricket Board to show off the team in the best light.

Unfortunately this is where the ECB continually seems to let itself down. At tea yesterday, with England on 341 for five and playing gloriously, a request by Sky Television to talk to Mike Atherton or Marcus Trescothick, two of Wednesday's heroes, was turned down by the media relations manager of the ECB, Andrew Walpole, on the ground that it did not want to over-expose Trescothick. This was rubbish. Cricket, particularly English cricket, and its players need all the good publicity they can get at the moment.

As things stand, we still await news of a sponsor for next year's seven Test matches in England, two domestic competitions are without sponsors, and there has been a financial shortfall on Test-match receipts last summer, which will have dire consequences for the counties.

Let us not blame the players here, they are contracted employees and will do as they are told. Their interest in interviews is weak at times but primarily this is down to a lack of enthusiasm by the ECB to latch on to a good thing when it stares it in the face.

The media, especially television, are interested in interviewing successful individuals and congratulating them on their efforts. As well, captains and coaches take the rap when things go badly and, however much they dislike giving interviews in those situations, it goes with the job. Basically it is a simple matter of giving the people what they want.

Should the media relations men at the ECB need any pointers they need only look to other sports, some far more successful in attracting the sponsors' dollar. Golfers are made immediately available to the media as soon as they leave the 18th green, tennis players after they leave the court, rugby and football players as they go up the tunnel to the dressing room. Martin Brundle interviews drivers on the grid before formula one races, and the 500cc grand prix motorcyclists are told to keep their helmets off until the last possible moment before the start so that they can be more publicly recognisable.

Yesterday's refusal by the ECB is not an isolated incident. Last December in Durban Gary Kirsten, after scoring a double hundred for South Africa and saving the Test match, was declared joint man of the match with Andrew Caddick. The South African cricket board's media man brought Kirsten up to the studio and offered him for interview. Where was Caddick? On the team bus, of course. Again, this was not the player's fault but showed a complete lack of awareness by the media relations men of when to capitalise on a positive.

The great majority of the England team are good in front of the camera and welcome the opportunity to promote themselves and the game. But, even when they are doing well, they need encouragement to do so. Graham Thorpe's interview was informative and sparky after his 118, he even dedicated his century to his son Jack, but he wouldn't have been allowed to talk to the media if he'd been 118 not out at the close of play. The ECB says so.

The time has come for a television media relations manager, appointed by the television companies and the ECB, to take control of this aspect and help promote the game of cricket in the best possible way. Yesterday seemed an ideal opportunity to begin the process.

webTitle: Stubbs suffers cancer relapse

fields.headline: Stubbs suffers cancer relapse
fields.trailText: Celtic's Alan Stubbs has returned to hospital for further treatment after a relapse in the cancerous growth for which he had surgery earlier this year.
fields.body:
Celtic last night confirmed that Alan Stubbs has returned to hospital for further treatment after a relapse in the cancerous growth for which he had surgery earlier this year.

Stubbs had an operation in June after a routine drugs test revealed the condition. He was cleared, but must now undergo a further three chemotherapy sessions at the Beatson oncology unit in Glasgow's Western infirmary.

A spokesman said: "Following a routine examination, it has been confirmed that Alan Stubbs has suffered a relapse in his condition and has been re-admitted to hospital for a course of chemotherapy. The club would like to request that the privacy of Alan and his family be properly respected."

Stubbs added: "I would like to thank everyone concerned, especially my family and colleagues at the club and the Celtic supporters in particular.

"I have come to terms with the fact that I have suffered a relapse and I intend to face the challenge of getting back to full health head on."

The Scotland coach Craig Brown banned further World Cup warm-up friendlies after the dismal 2-0 defeat by Australia on Wednesday. Scotland have turned down a lucrative tournament in India and an offer from Wales to play in Cardiff before the next qualifier against Belgium in March.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland, yesterday reduced from nine months to six a Uefa ban on Portugal's Abel Xavier for grabbing a referee during the Euro 2000 semi-final against France. The Everton defender will have a knee operation on Friday that will rule him out for a month.

Norwich and Blackpool have been fined by the Football Association's disciplinary committee for failing to control their players. A mass confrontation between the sides took place during their Worthington Cup second-round tie at Carrow Road on September 19. Norwich have been fined £30,000 and Blackpool £6,000.

Ariel Ortega and Claudio Husain gave Argentina a 2-0 win over Chile to leave them five points clear at the top of the World Cup qualifying group.

webTitle: City dramas hit the big screen

fields.headline: City dramas hit the big screen
fields.standfirst: Fan-cum-writer Colin Shindler tells  Jim White  about the filming of his ruined life
fields.trailText: City die-hard Colin Shindler, writer of an infamous Red-bashing tome, tells Jim White about the filming of his ruined life as the first Mancunian derby in five years approaches.
fields.body:
Colin Shindler, the best-selling author of the Manchester City fan's chronicle, Manchester United Ruined My Life, has been looking forward for ages to this Saturday and the first Mancunian derby in five years. The theatre, the drama, the memories stirred of ancient rivalries; there are so many things to savour. The result, however, isn't one of them.

"Is that thing on?" he says, eyeing with suspicion the tape recorder placed in front of him, as if his reputation as a City die-hard will disappear into its reels. "Well, all right, you want my prediction? United will win comfortably. 3-1. There, happy?"

All this is said with a smile. Indeed a grin is rarely off Shindler's lips these days. The irony of his book's title is that far from his life falling apart around him, it all seems to be going very well since his Red-bashing tome appeared. He has written a novel - High on a Cliff - and another of the non-fiction variety, to be published in June, called Football, Fathers and Sons, which traces three generations of the Summerbee family.

What's more, the renewal of hostilities with United coincides with the first day of filming of the movie version of his first book. His amiable account of growing up on the wrong side of the Mancunian footballing tracks struck so many chords with so many fans it is to be made into a feature film, starring Alfred Molina and Caroline Quentin. Tomorrow Maine Road will bristle with cameras shooting atmospheric footage.

"The financiers said to us, we want Billy Elliot, we want the Full Monty, we want the triumph of the human spirit over adversity," he says of his latest project. "Which is not easy in a film about City." Nevertheless Shindler came up with a script which backers queued to support, once there had been some minor tinkering with the source material.

"When we first pitched the idea, you could see eyes glazing over at the title," he says. "What they didn't want is yet another football film, because we all know, by and large, they don't work. But, really, it's not about football, it's aboutfamily, it's about roots, it's about a particular time in British history. So we changed the title. It's now called Seeing Red, Feeling Blue."

That phrase presumably covers the author's anticipated emotions tomorrow lunchtime. Indeed, these past few weeks have seen wholesale failure in many a City fan's legendary sense of humour, with bad defeats at Arsenal and latterly West Ham. "The way they collapsed on Saturday was bloody outrageous, I paid huge sums of money to watch and I reserve the right to be very critical," Shindler says of the 4-1 defeat at Upton Park.

"But, that said, I do get the feeling there is a plan at City. To me this feels more like '65-66, when we came up and seemed to be building something for the future, rather than '84-85, when we were promoted as a patched-up side that you just knew would unravel, and soon did.

"For the first time in 30 years everyone seems to be pulling together at the club. David Bernstein [the City chairman] is a very clever guy. They are all now very professional. When I meet the bunch now running the place I am constantly impressed."

Which makes a change for a long-time City fan. Despite the title, Shindler's real target in his book was actually those in charge of his own club who had let him down so comprehensively. The text was infused with rage at an incompetent regime which had reduced the object of his unconditional love to disarray.

webTitle: Daum's hair passes drug test

fields.headline: Daum's hair passes drug test
fields.trailText: The soap opera continues. A second test for Cocaine use has cleared Cristoph Daum's hair, while one of Daum's biggest critics, Bayern Munich general manager Uli Hoeness, is being investigated over alleged irregularities at his sausage factory.
fields.body:
England's recent managerial history may be convoluted but German deliberations over who should lead their national team have turned into a soap opera with storylines centred on cocaine and sausages. The day after the caretaker coach Rudi Völler suffered his first defeat, the man who had been due to succeed him before a failed drug test said a second test in the United States had been negative.

"This shows clearly I'm clean," Christoph Daum told Bild newspaper. "The result was a foregone conclusion for me because I knew the first test did not apply to me."

Daum had taken the original test after Uli Hoeness, the general manager of Bayern Munich, suggested that rumours about Daum's private life made him unsuitable as Germany's manager in waiting. Yesterday Hoeness called a press conference to insist he would not resign his club post after police raided his sausage factory near Nuremberg following an anonymous tip-off that he was employing workers illegally.

The former Germany midfielder, who was on the panel that originally appointed Daum, said many people were out to ruin his reputation. "I will not let people who are not courageous enough to tell their names have any influence on me," Hoeness said.

He has also claimed to have received a car bomb threat and that a website had offered a prize for "whoever shoots him from the bench" during a recent game.

Asked to comment on reports of Daum's second drug test, Hoeness replied: "I'm here to talk about sausages, not about Christoph Daum."

Daum, who had been due to take charge of Germany next July, resigned as coach of Bayer Leverkusen and fled to Florida after a sample of his hair tested positive for cocaine. Now, in the land of the recount, he claimed a second test had vindicated him.

Others may take more convincing. Prosecutors in Koblenz said they were investigating Daum as part of an inquiry into a ring of suspected cocaine dealers.

webTitle: England invigorated by fresh air

fields.headline: England invigorated by fresh air
fields.standfirst: After Turin Eriksson can breathe again,  David Lacey  reports
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson will have received no revealing insight after Wednesday's match, but he will surely be pleased that he has something half-decent to build on, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Friendly internationals are football wars continued by diplomatic means. This needs to be remembered in assessing the true merits of England's performance in losing 1-0 to Italy in Turin on Wednesday.

Italy's approach to the game would have been markedly less casual had this been a World Cup qualifier. Certainly Kevin Keegan's side would have experienced a less sanguine encounter with the Italians in Brussels in the Euro 2000 quarter-finals had Phil Neville not conceded the late penalty against Romania in Charleroi.

That said, the game in the Stadio delle Alpi confirmed the wisdom of Peter Taylor in choosing a squad designed to give youth its fling. The team he fielded had a better shape and balance than the sides picked by Keegan either in Euro 2000 or the fateful World Cup qualifier against Germany, when a 1-0 defeat prompted his resignation.

Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Swedish coach of Lazio who is due to take charge of England next July but who may be involved part-time for the World Cup games against Finland and Albania in March, will not have been given any revealing new insight into English football by Wednesday's game. At the same time he will be content with evidence that England are not so bad as they have been painted.

This is often the way of it. An England flop in a major tournament is followed by a better display in their next friendly, witness the 1-1 draw with France, the world and European champions, in Paris this season.

This was followed by a desperately bad performance against the Germans at Wembley and now further evidence that, given a sensible format, England can still pass the ball properly and move off it with some idea of where they should be going.

Nevertheless a true judgment on the virtues of Taylor's caretakership should be delayed until after England resume against Spain at Villa Park in another friendly at the end of February. Assuming Taylor is still in charge he will doubtless put out a side with the qualifier against Finland a month later in mind.

Though the team performed well enough on Wednesday to suggest they would achieve rather more against the Finns at Anfield than some of the seniors did under Howard Wilkinson a month ago in the scoreless draw in Helsinki, it is hard to imagine Martin Keown not being recalled to the defence or Graeme le Saux not resuming at left wing-back, the role that found Gareth Barry, playing out of position, so ill at ease against Italy.

Places will be found for Paul Scholes, obviously, and Steven Gerrard, probably, allowing Kieron Dyer to switch to right wing-back, if required. Emile Heskey, a less gauche footballer now that he has joined Liverpool, was one of England's successes on Wednesday and would presumably be partnered by Michael Owen at Anfield, although Nick Barmby provided a tidy reminder of his value as a support for the main striker.

Taylor was pleased with the authority of Beckham, the new captain, in central midfield but added that he did not want to lose the quality of the Manchester United player's crosses. This is surely the point. Heskey would have given Italy's world-class defenders even more problems had he been rising among them to meet Beckham's centres. Beckham spraying elegant long passes from midfield is a pretty sight but less of a threat to a defence of this quality.

The ease with which Rio Ferdinand played as a sweeper in Taylor's back three was one of the more encouraging aspects of Wednesday's match, although with Beckham dropping deep the West Ham man was less inclined to bring the ball out from the back to set up movements.

"Rio is a good passer but David is even better," said Taylor. "I love defenders who can pass, and Rio showed he could do that as well as defend. All I said to him before the game was 'Get something out of it, be a good defender or play some tremendous passes'. He did both."

In the longer term, whether England adhere to Taylor's 3-5-2 system will depend on Eriksson, who tends to favour 4-4-2 but may be swayed by the present shortage of English full-backs of genuine international quality. But at least the Swedish technocrat now knows that he has something to build on.

A depressing aspect of the Turin match was the booing and jeering of Heskey by Italian fans because he is black. He bore it with dignity but in Europe nothing seems to have improved racially since Ron Greenwood's black players received similar treatment in Denmark in 1978. The FA intends to take up the matter with Uefa.

 The Football Association has made an official approach to Alan Curbishley to become involved in the group of emerging English coaches.

"Alan Curbishley has been approached by the Football Association with Charlton's approval with a view to him joining the FA's coaching programme at all levels," a spokesman said. "No decision has yet been taken as to what exactly his involvement would be."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Should Beckham be Eriksson's middleman?

fields.headline: Should Beckham be Eriksson's middleman?
fields.standfirst:
Ron Atkinson says yes
Richard Williams says no
fields.trailText: Yes. After watching England against Italy I remain convinced that the team should be built around David Beckham in central midfield.
fields.body:
After watching England against Italy I remain convinced that the team should be built around David Beckham in central midfield. All he needs to do now is take a leaf out of the Bryan Robson or Bobby Charlton books.

That means learning to push on more. He did well in Turin but tended to drop too deep and pull towards the back players to receive possession before moving things on. If he wants to dictate matches he's got to make more adventurous, gambling runs off the ball.

Robbo was fantastic at that. He had the quality to pull towards the ball but once he'd dropped it off somewhere he got on his bike again. There's no doubt Beckham can do it, because he has great energy, decent pace and he's strong enough to hurt people in the top half of the field. In fact that's where he is most dangerous.

If I was managing a team against Beckham the last thing I'd want to see would be him running beyond us with or without the ball. It's important that he doesn't become an out-and-out sitting player for England. I wouldn't like to see him take on the Ray Wilkins role too early.

Yes, he should be the fulcrum but he should be an attacking fulcrum in the way Charlton was. In his World Cup years, Bobby was as close as we got to a playmaker but he had the ability to go on and cause defenders problems.

When Beckham gets the playmaker role he tends to drop deep. He did it in the European Cup final. Of course he has to join up the play but I'd like to see him quickly get on his way again or sometimes even ignore the players at the back. Let someone else pick up possession while he makes some forward runs off the ball.

When he's on the right flank for Manchester United he does make those stretching runs, looking to get beyond without the ball rather than just wanting it to feet. That sets defenders another problem, and on Wednesday he made one good run in the first half and nearly got to the near post.

I can understand if he was worried about vacating the central area and allowing Italy to strike. But that is not how players like him are most effective. I never minded playing against Arsenal when Liam Brady went deep in his own half and got possession. But I worried about Brady when he was in the last third of the field, because he could take you on, produce something special or score. I recall when I had a very good West Bromwich Albion team and Brady opted to play very deep in the first half. We were 2-0 up but in the second half Arsenal pushed him to centre-forward and he frightened us to death. He was doing his work just outside the danger zone. Somehow we managed to hang on.

To give Beckham the best chance of causing that sort of problems with England I would play Steve Gerrard alongside him, or if Gerrard is not fit then Nicky Butt. It would be nice to have Paul Scholes filling the third midfield place with Kieron Dyer as a right wing-back.

It certainly wouldn't worry me if Beckham dropped into the middle for England, having played on the right for United. With United he comes off the line a lot and I would like to see him gamble and pick up his natural right-sided position now and again with England.

As for the captaincy, Beckham seemed to enjoy the extra responsibility. The genuine enthusiasm he showed when he was told was great. It's nice when a lad responds that way, particularly when he has so much going for him materially.

If Tony Adams or Martin Keown returns I'd make either the skipper, but I'd have no hang-ups about Beckham as captain in the long-term. Whoever wears the armband, though, Beckham has to be the middleman, and I hope Sven-Goran Eriksson also sees it that way.

fields.headline: Should Beckham be Eriksson's middleman?
fields.standfirst:
Richard Williams says no
Ron Atkinson says yes
fields.trailText: No. Ultimately, the cost to his effectiveness as a player is unacceptable. Too slow, not inventive enough and more useful elsewhere.
fields.body:
David Beckham made a decent fist of captaining Peter Taylor's first England side from the centre of midfield on Wednesday night, for which he deserves respect and thanks. The cost to his effectiveness as a player, however, was unacceptable.

He clipped two or three fine passes from around the centre circle up to his forwards, but they were of the kind that requires a virtuoso technique or a piece of luck to turn the opening into a goal. Emile Heskey and Nick Barmby almost produced the necessary response, but not quite. Otherwise Beckham contented himself with picking up the ball from his defenders and moving it on, usually to the flanks, without any great show of imagination. His sudden run into the area after five minutes, when Alessandro Nesta narrowly beat him to Gareth Barry's cross, was never repeated.

A further danger of putting Beckham in a central position was exposed by the contrast when both he and his marker, Gennaro Gattuso, attempted long-range shots. When Beckham took aim from 30 yards out, he found Gattuso closing him down so quickly that the strike had neither the power nor the direction to beat Gianluigi Buffon. When Gattuso tried the same thing, Beckham was a couple of seconds too slow to recognise the danger and a couple of yards too far away to do anything about preventing a marvellous goal.

Two strikes, then, against the notion that Beckham should be running the game from central midfield. For as long as he remains among the most dangerous crossers of the ball in the game, it seems ridiculous to deprive England of that automatic source of danger to opponents. Heskey, surely, would prefer to have a higher percentage of balls coming from the flanks, rather than over his shoulder.

This is not to suggest that Beckham should be restricted to patrolling the touchline. One of the pleasing features of Wednesday's performance was the impression that each player had a clear idea of his role, which is a tribute to the clarity of Taylor's thinking and his communication skills. But the reality of modern football demands flexibility, and England have several midfield players capable of using the flank whenever Beckham chooses to come inside.

One of those players is, of course, Joe Cole, who enjoys nothing more than moving out of the middle and looping around the flank to beat a defender and measure a lethal cross. Cole's game is based on leaps of the imagination which are made possible not just by a superlative technique but by a broader vision of the game than Beckham can command. This is not to say that one is better than the other. They are simply different, and it would be a mistake to try and squeeze the talent of one in order to fit a hole tailor-made for the other.

English players capable of producing the unexpected at this level come along once a decade, if that. The last one was undone by mental indiscipline. Joe Cole has Paul Gascoigne's gift for outrageous improvisation, but he also seems to have a sound temperament, and Taylor - if he remains in temporary charge - would be unwise to delay Cole the opportunity to try his tricks alongside Beckham, Steven Gerrard and Kieron Dyer.

Those who believe that the team's future lies with youth will have noted that the least effective player on either side on Wednesday night was also the oldest. Angelo di Livio has grown his hair to match the luxuriant locks of his younger colleagues, but there was no disguising the fact that, at 34, the former "little soldier" found the game passing him by. The lesson should not have been lost.

Least of all, one hopes, on Sven-Goran Eriksson, who left the stadium without comment or contact with the England squad, pausing only to collect his Lazio players. Whether or not the coach-in-waiting takes part in the selection and preparation for England's next batch of fixtures, there will be calls to bring back various members of the senior division discarded by Taylor. They should be firmly resisted. No one would claim that on Wednesday night we saw the future of English football. But at least we were not forced to gaze yet again upon its past.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Charities' lottery birthday verdict

fields.headline: Charities' lottery birthday verdict
fields.standfirst: Voluntary organisations give their views on the national lottery as it reaches its sixth anniversary
fields.trailText: Juliet Shedden seeks the views of voluntary organisations on the national lottery as it reaches its sixth anniversary
fields.body:
This Saturday marks the sixth anniversary of the national lottery. A total of £10bn has been raised since it began, with £1.76bn going to the National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB). Martin Valentine, NLCB's media manager, said 35,000 groups nationwide have benefited from the lottery money. But are the charities happy?

Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, points out that independent research has shown that in the mid-90s, charitable giving from the public dipped sharply. This coincided with the launch of the national lottery. He believes medium-sized voluntary organisations have been hit hardest, suffering a real decline since 1992-93. "They do not have the resources to launch large scale fundraising campaigns and are often overlooked by funders who favour funding smaller voluntary organisations. This makes them particularly susceptible to the effects of a fall in individual charitable giving," he says.

Sue Spurrier, funding services officer for the Welsh Council for Voluntary Action (WCVA), agrees. She is concerned about the amount of lottery money received in Wales this year. According to an NLCB spokesperson, the amount available to distribute has dropped by 11.6% from £23.1m in April 1999-00 to £20.4m in April 2000-01. "The decrease in lottery money has had a knock on effect on the amount charities can apply for from the European funding programme," she says. The European funding programme will give up to 50% of the money a charity has already raised. "Less lottery money means less European money, and this compounds the problem for charities," Spurrier says.

Chris Holloway, director of the London Voluntary Service Council (LVSC), said the NLCB does its best to make sure that its grants reach communities in the greatest need. Holloway believes the NCLB has the right approach, but needs to improve the way the scheme is administered. "I wish they'd change their policy on what their grants will pay for," she says. "At the moment, they won't pay the full costs of a project when it's part of a larger organisation. If the project rents a room, the board will pay. If it uses part of a room that other projects in the same organisation are already using, the board won't pay."

Parts of the lottery do receive praise. The piloting of the small grant scheme Awards for All in Wales has been hugely successful, according to Lynn Reynolds, also of WCVA. The scheme uses much simpler application forms, and provides smaller grants of anything from £500 - £5,000 to community based groups. The small grants scheme is now being run nationwide and Chris Holloway from LVSC "strongly supports the NLCB efforts to help small groups".

Martin Valentine from NLCB highlights some of the effect the lottery money has had on communities. In Leicester last week, Princess Anne opened a community centre bought with a £300,000 grant from the NLCB. A community group called Baby Gear recruits long-term unemployed and mentally ill people to repair and restore baby clothes and toys that the public donates. The workers are supervised and are taught the skills that they need to renovate the old baby toys. They then sell the goods on to single parents and those who cannot afford to buy them new. "It is a real community affair, it is what the NLCB is about, helping all members of society to benefit from the lottery money," says Mr Valentine.

webTitle: Lottery grant winners share their tips

fields.headline: Lottery grant winners share their tips
fields.standfirst: Toby Butler asks charities that have been successful in getting lottery grants for their advice
fields.trailText: Toby Butler asks charities that have been successful in getting lottery grants for their advice
fields.body:
To the uninitiated, the process for raising lottery funding can seem very daunting, but according to Bryony Pogson, a fundraiser for the National Foster Care Association, all the information necessary is freely available.

"Some charities pay £5,000 to get an application done, which is ludicrous. They believe they can't do it themselves - but they can," she insists.

Apart from the advice given in application packs, the National Lottery Charities Board will answer specific queries by phone. NLCB also organises regular training days all over the country which are free of charge. Pogson strongly recommends attending. "I go to one every time I do an application - it really does pay," she says.

Delegates ask questions others might not think of, or dare ask, and it is possible to check if a project idea matches what the board is willing to fund. "You also get to know what the buzz words are - if they are talking about social inclusion, think about social inclusion and use those words in the application," she adds.

Her approach seems to have paid dividends - so far she has helped to win four lottery grants, the largest of which was awarded to recruit more foster carers and was worth £220,000.

On a much smaller scale, another successful applicant has been the Withy Bush pain support group based in Haverford West in Wales. The group helps people suffering with long-term chronic pain. Its first application to the small grant programme for a computer and a scanner failed. However, a slightly more ambitious application to finance social outings and a Christmas lunch, as well as the computer, was successful and the group was awarded £3,500.

Group secretary Margaret Povey says her applications for funding failed more often than not, but perseverance and effort pay off eventually. "Don't give up, and whatever you don't let rejections get on top you. Keep the standards of your applications up," she says.

She also got some help from the Pembrokeshire association of voluntary services (PAVS). She and the treasurer took a draft application and up-to-date accounts to a meeting with an adviser at PAVS, who then filled in the form for them. Ms Povey said the application process took her five full days of work to gather the accounts, information required and write a first draft. "You can't do it quickly," she warns.

Roundabout Dramatherapy, a charity based in Croydon, has also made a successful application to the NLCB. The charity provides creative experiences for people with special needs, exploring issues using drama. Roundabout had made an unsuccessful lottery application once before and, as a result, project director Deborah Haythorne decided to attend a NLCB training day. She said the session helped to demystify the application form, and gave her a chance to see if her project was appropriate for NLCB funding.

Both the staff and the management committee were involved in writing the application, but the draft application was shown to people outside the organisation for comment. "The form asks for a lot of information - it is difficult to step away far enough from what you have written to be critical," she explains.

While the form is the longest she has encountered, Haythorne says groups should not be put off by the work involved, even if they have failed in the past. She argues that the application system makes the applicant think deeply about what they want to achieve which, she believes, can be a useful process in its own right. "If you see the form as helpful rather than intrusive, it will probably come through in what you are writing," she says. Roundabout won £57,000 to expand its drama therapy work into north London.

webTitle: How to net lottery funding

fields.headline: How to net lottery funding
fields.standfirst: Rejected applicants are being urged not to give up - the number of success stories is increasing, writes Toby Butler
fields.trailText: Rejected applicants are being urged not to give up - the number of success stories is increasing, writes Toby Butler
fields.body:
Since 1995, the Charities Board has awarded over £1.7bn to more than 35,000 groups. That sounds like a lot of success stories, but far more applications have been rejected than accepted.

National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB) forms were criticised, in the early days at least, for being too onerous, particularly for smaller groups. The results of a grant round two years ago suggested some applicants had severe difficulty filling in the application form correctly - 40% of applications were rejected because they were incomplete, ineligible or outside the funding policy.

Since then, success rates have dramatically improved - in the early days fewer than one in five applications was successful; today the rate nationally is almost one in two.

In part, this is due to better feedback from the board - after a long struggle with the sector, the NLCB now gives specific reasons why an application fails so that applicants can learn from their mistakes. The scrapping of deadlines for applications has taken the time pressure out of the process, but the major reason that the odds are improving is simply that there are fewer applicants.

Better communication
This is particularly the case with the Awards for All programme. To apply, a group must have an income of less than £15,000 a year and awards range from £500 to £5,000. In Scotland, a staggering two in three applicants succeed. Critics say such figures show that the programme is not publicised enough, but NLCB director for Scotland Adrienne Kelbie said the high success rate has more to do with better communication between the board and applicants, which has meant fewer inappropriate bids.

Whatever the reason, those applying for NLCB funding have a far better chance of succeeding. According to Luke Fitzherbert, researcher at the Directory of Social Change and co-author of the National Lottery Yearbook, charities that applied and failed in the early years have been reluctant to try again. "Not all of them have realised how much greater the chances of success are now. If you meet the published criteria, you will probably get a grant," he said.

He advises applicants to make a large A3 photocopy of the grant programme criteria, then note how the project meets each one. The final step is to make sure each element is included somewhere on the form. "Excellence in things not covered by the criteria doesn't help," he said.

The NLCB website has a great deal of information to help in this process. It includes descriptions of past grant awards and even the grant assessment manual, given to application assessors. It includes an outline of the scoring system the NLCB uses and lists by category why applications fail.

According to Kelbie, the most common problems with applications these days are a lack of detailed project planning, vague budget estimation and over ambition. "People see the Dome and think we can shell out £20m for community facilities," she said. The average NLCB award in Scotland is £100,000. Although the board cannot say it officially, massive bids have no chance. And smaller organisations are in with a very good chance. Nationally, 40% of applications come from organisations with less than £20,000 in income each year.

In April, the board will make some important changes in April, Kelbie says. The NLCB will change its name to something snappier, grant programmes will be merged for simplicity and a new application form will be piloted in Scotland. Designed for applicants requiring less than £60,000, the new form will be far shorter than the existing one. As a result, competition could get stiffer next year.

 NLCB advice line: 020 7747 5299
 Scottish helpline 0870 240 2391

webTitle: US election fiasco prompts exit poll rethink

fields.headline: US election fiasco prompts exit poll rethink
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: The American election fiasco has prompted the BBC and ITV to rethink their use of exit polls, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC and ITV may stop using exit polls in their coverage of elections, following the US networks' mistakes in reporting the US election 10 days ago.

BBC head of current affairs Peter Horrocks said he would approach Steve Anderson, ITV's head of news, current affairs, religion and arts, about thrashing out an agreement to reduce broadcasters' reliance on exit polls to call election results.

The system was blamed by American Network News for errors during the US election campaign.

Mr Horrocks said that BBC and ITN had in the past discussed creating a pooled exit poll service but had decided against it, preferring to hang on to their competitive edge.

Mr Anderson said he disagreed with a pooled exit poll system, but said: "We have to consider whether exit polls are really viable. Is it a price worth paying if we risk tearing our reputations to shreds?"

News chiefs in America are still conducting post-mortems on the election fiasco, which saw several networks inaccurately reporting victory for George W Bush after Fox Network called the result based on an exit poll.

Delegates at the Newsworld conference in Barcelona agreed that over-reliance on exit polls which were "badly flawed" had been disastrous.

Speaking on a live link from Atlanta, CNN president of international networks Eason Jordan said that an inquest was taking place as to how the error was made, and added that CNN would be testifying before a congressional hearing.

Mr Jordan admitted that CNN had "a lot of egg on our faces".

"CNN made the call and we have to be held accountable for that."

He said the incident had called for a reappraisal of news values in election coverage. "The real value of being first and getting it wrong is not good," he added.

webTitle: Nice summit: countdown to a European milestone

fields.headline: Nice summit: countdown to a European milestone
fields.standfirst:
Ian Black explains the key issues that will dominate talks to hammer out a new EU treaty.

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
Ian Black in Brussels explains the key issues that will dominate talks to hammer out a new EU treaty.

Special report: European integration
fields.body:
It's still three weeks away, but anticipation is mounting as the European Union prepares for the Nice summit, which will be much more than the usual well-catered talkfest - and a key milestone in ensuring that creaking decision-making machinery and institutions can take the strain in the years to come.

From Madrid to Helskini, Athens to Amsterdam, VIP flights come and go as alliances are forged, compromises hammered out and draft after draft of complex treaty text adjusted.

Translated from French into English and a host of other languages, the latest documents are then slipped to journalists, usually in Brussels, fuelling the growing interest across the union in what will happen on the Riviera from December 7-10.

Leaders who cannot manage face-to-face meetings do it by video conferencing, a relative novelty: Tony Blair talked that way to France's Jacques Chirac and then had dinner with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

Pavo Lipponnen, the Finnish prime minister, has been to London. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, visited Denmark; France's European affairs minister, Pierre Moscovici - a key player in his country's stewardship of the union's rotating presidency - has been jetting all over the place. Nice is the only thing on their minds.

So far, only two things are certain: by the end of the summit, there will be a new EU treaty, And the 15 leaders, joined by the European commission president, Romano Prodi, will be up very late, bargaining over the final words. For, as in the bad old days of the Soviet Union, nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.

Nice is happening because the EU needs reforming if it is to work when it expands to take in up to 12 new members, mostly from eastern Europe, over the next decade. Arrangements drawn up in 1957, when just six member states created the EEC, have long been in need of an overhaul to stop the mechanism seizing up.

On the face of it, everything is highly technical, even impenetrable. But in the final analysis it is about raw power: who has the most votes, how decisions are made, what constitutes a majority. Because this is about writing a new treaty - and thus changing existing ones - no one has to agree. Every single leader can, in theory, veto proposals he does not like. And nearly every one will find something. But the pressure for a deal will be enormous.

Viewed from Brussels, Nice looks like being a cliffhanger over the re-weighting of votes between the member states - though the matter of the national veto that so excites British eurosceptics is likely to prove only marginally less difficult.

Diplomats on all sides predict a deal in the small hours, after sleep deprivation and peer pressure works its magic. But on the votes question the wild card is the position of Jacques Chirac. With the Gaullist president facing his own prime minister, Lionel Jospin, in the next battle for the Elysée, the question is how far he can go in giving Germany's Chancellor Schröder the edge he requires. "It's a domestic issue for Chirac," said one observer. "And anyway, if things go wrong he can always blame the British."

Since there are 59m Frenchmen and 82m Germans there should be a substantial differential between them (both currently have 10 votes, as do Britain and Italy, which have populations similar to France's.)

In the end, many EU-watchers predict, there is likely to be a symbolic margin for Germany. Another alternative, favoured by smaller members led by Finland, is a system in which each member state has one vote but a majority exists only when there is a majority both of population and of states.

Hopes for reducing the size of the supranational European commission (currently 20 members) seem certain to be dashed, because small countries are unwilling to surrender their commissioner. A likely deal will give more powers to the commission president to create an internal hierarchy. There could be agreement to cap its size in future, say from 2010.

On the veto question, where half a dozen proposed treaty changes are highly controversial, Britain is resisting majority voting on tax, social security, border controls and defence. But other countries have distinct red lines too.

Ireland, Luxembourg and Sweden agree with Britain - so far - on tax, though so far only Britain has refused even to discuss moving from unanimity to majority voting. Tony Blair could end up isolated on that, though he will work hard to keep some allies on board.

The French are virtually alone in opposing majority voting on commercial policy to protect their cinema industry. Interestingly, they also refuse to put to the vote decisions on the siting of EU institutions. This is because everyone else would demand that the European parliament shut down its costly headquarters in Strasbourg, chosen in a classic backroom deal some years ago.

Germany is happy to "communitise" trade and some tax matters relating to the single market. But it refuses to do so on immigration and justice. Spain fights its corner with legendary ferocity, and is thus a highly valued ally.

Britain also firmly opposes abandoning its veto on social affairs, though diplomats from other EU countries say its tone on that article has softened in recent meetings.

New arrangements for "flexibility" ("two-speed Europe" in the jargon) will not in the end be that controversial. Britain has agreed to ease off the "emergency brake" to allow integrationists to forge ahead, but France now accepts there must be strict limits to what they can do.

Under likely agreements at the summit, the 12 members of Euroland (all 15 EU members minus the UK, Sweden and Denmark) will not be able to set up their own group.

Overall, despite the rising political temperature, Nice will not be a great leap forward in European integration; rather a modest series of long-overdue reforms that will - just about - allow the EU to take in new members from about 2005.

So Poland, for example, is likely to have the same weight, however expressed, as Spain; Hungary as Portugal, and so on.

Defence will not form part of the new treaty, but there will be ringing statements - and much eurosceptic pontificating - about pledging troops for a European rapid reaction force to lessen dependence on the US, though still designed to work closely with Nato. The new force is not intended - certainly by Britain, which has pioneered the idea with France - to be the "European army" so feared by the Conservatives.

Another Tory bugbear, the EU's charter of fundamental rights, has no chance of being incorporated into the Nice treaty, though supporters hope it will get into a future one. It may, however, come to influence future rulings by the European court of justice in Luxembourg, meaning that decisions there may eventually have their effect on the nooks and crannies of national life.

So, Europeans everywhere be warned: you will be hearing a good deal about all this - and more - in the weeks ahead, as the countdown to Nice gets under way.

webTitle: Analysis: Urban regeneration

fields.headline: Unsafe as houses
fields.standfirst:
A significant number of people live in unfit dwellings. This is unlikely to change without investment from public and private landlords

SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: A significant number of people live in unfit dwellings. This is unlikely to change without investment from public and private landlords.
fields.body:
Richard Rogers's report on our urban condition, the intellectual basis of the white paper out yesterday, asked why our cities could not be more like Barcelona or Amsterdam. His answer was public spending, which is why the government took such a long time to respond.

But there is another reason why urban renaissance will always be more difficult to effect in this country: we are "old" in the sense that a large proportion of infrastructure, especially housing, was built a long time ago and, despite the best efforts of Herr Goering and the Luftwaffe, is still standing.

London housing is seriously dated compared to England at large, all those suburban drives in Pinner built when Stanley Baldwin was prime minister and, still striding across Streatham, nearly a quarter of the stock belongs to the era of Victoria and her son. The east of England is much newer by comparison but even there, in Norwich, Ipswich and the villages there is a substantial pre-1900 heritage.

Older homes cost more to maintain and that is one reason why a new Joseph Rowntree Foundation report* says nearly a third of all dwellings in England urgently need at least £1,000 spent on them. In Scotland things are worse, a third of dwellings need £3,000 of repairs. In Wales, where one in 25 dwellings needs more than £5,000 worth of urgent repairs, the problem is one of unfitness: one home in 12 lacks something as fundamental as hygienic means of preparing food - a proper kitchen.

Unfitness, not surprisingly, is most evident in 19th century terraces and conversions - detached dwellings in Northern Ireland - and in property left vacant. One reason why you can buy up streets in the Rhondda for the price of a Kensington broom cupboard is that they were jerry-built then and have not enjoyed much investment since.

Housing's glory days as a policy priority - remember Harold Macmillan staking his name on building 300,000 homes a year - are long gone. The very phrase slum clearance speaks of a bygone era; only about 1,000 houses are knocked down each year as a matter of public policy compared with 80,000 in the early 70s. With right to buy, housing became privatised and the trend continues as council estates are transferred to autonomous not-for-profit trusts and associations, some of them with sharp commercial instincts. On what they still have councils proportionately spend a lot more than owner occupiers or private landlords.

It is, however, private owners who have the key to our "crumbling castles". They often have neither the means nor the will to maintain their property. They may miss more complex technical problems or delay too long; research shows widespread misapprehension about likely costs.

People rarely seek the help of architects or structural engineers on repairs possibly because they would bring more problems to their attention; they rely instead on "informal repair diagnosis" by themselves, relatives, friends, contacts in the building trade, or Bill the bodger. Bill, researchers note, has an obvious conflict of interest if he is also asked to provide a quotation.

The psychology of house purchase is puzzling: many buy without a detailed survey and most owners have no long-term maintenance plan or any specific financial provision for future repair costs. Recent movers and others without a network of contacts are most likely to have problems finding a builder. Few people regularly check for repair problems, most just respond when the roof leaks or the ceiling falls in.

None the less home owners spend a huge amount - over £35bn a year - on DIY and builders. (Tenants, inevitably, are disinclined to spend). That is at least £354 per household per year, But do you include paint and light fittings in "repair"; does a new phone socket count towards enhancing a property's life?

We know poor owner-occupiers live in the worst conditions. More than one in 10 households with an income below £4,000 live in unfit dwellings; they are mainly older people, often women by themselves and young people setting up on their own. For households with £24,000 coming in each year the figure is one in 24.

Home owners can still get improvement grants, but only about 35,000 a year are now given out - half to elderly people - compared with 300,000 in the early 80s before the Tory pruning. Oddly, grant levels dropped much less elsewhere in the UK: it is a lot easier to get grants in Glasgow, Cardiff and Belfast than in London. Shetland with the Orkneys are the most generous areas.

Improvement comes in many forms - councils have been providing more help to adapt buildings for people with disabilities. Local authorities still operate area renewal where whole streets are scheduled - the most recent count showed 160,000 dwellings in such areas, mainly in the north and Midlands.

Experts are unsure about the long-run outlook. When does extensive disrepair make a house uninhabitable or fit only for demolition? There is, we know, no causal relationship between house price and house condition, especially in London. Disrepair is an instance of market failure. That is to say, the market would work better if a lot of old and poor people could be put out on the streets and their homes flattened or sold to developers.

*Housing conditions in 2000 www.jrf.org.uk Kerry Revell and Philip Leather, The state of UK housing, Policy Press, direct.orders@marston.co.uk

webTitle: Sketch: Beware of capital ideas

fields.headline: Sketch: Beware of capital ideas
fields.trailText: John Prescott paid a welcome visit to the House of Commons yesterday to launch his department's new white paper, Our Towns And Cities: The Future.
fields.body:
John Prescott paid a welcome visit to the House of Commons yesterday to launch his department's new white paper, Our Towns And Cities: The Future.

This is a classic New Labour document, being printed on glossy paper and illustrated with colour pictures of the Elysium which is the new Britain. Happy people, many from ethnic minorities, gaze productively at computer screens. Pensioners get off a gleaming streamlined tram which has just delivered them promptly and inexpensively to their grandchildren.

In New Labour's dream world, canals are for strolling by, past bustling pavement cafes where laughing groups of people drink cappuccino in the sun. And they're definitely not full of dead cats, condoms or rusted supermarket trollies.

The prose has the same unreal quality. Nothing actually happens, nothing tangible is planned. But, we are promised, there will be "innovative developments", "local strategic partnerships" and "urban policy units".

Town councils will have "new powers to promote wellbeing". As members of society, people will need to be able "to achieve their full potential" while "protecting the environment, both local and global." To make sure this happens, the government's "policies and programmes are the building blocks," and just in case we might think this may never happen, we're promised that "visions for the future will be developed".

There will be a "key focus" here and a "coordinated effort" there. The government, in its wisdom, has "established a framework". The whole thing resembles those fantastical architect's drawings, in which slim, well-dressed figures stroll across tree-festooned piazzas, with no mention of empty burger boxes or gangs of glowering youths.

But Mr Prescott's statement, far from being the jumble of words we have come to expect, was an oral version of the same thing. I have noticed that the time to become suspicious about this government is when it breaks into capital letters. This invariably represents not the real world, but some new initiative, programme or quango.

He is setting up Regional Centres of Excellence. He has established a Neighbourhood Renewal Fund. He is considering an Urban Policy Board, and a Cabinet Committee is to hold an Urban Summit in the year 2002. Let's not forget the Integrated Transport White Paper, the New Deal for Communities and the Social Exclusion Unit. Capital letters were all over the shop, each in charge of a resonant abstraction.

We hacks were abjured yesterday by Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary to mark the difference between scepticism and cynicism. My attitude to Mr Prescott's statement was a balanced mixture of both.

At one point, for example, he reminded us that Lord Rogers had said, "people make cities, but cities make citizens". Tories giggled at this, crying "wozzat mean?"

"Think about it!" he bellowed back, though I'm afraid I was none the wiser. You could say, "people make cars, but cars make drivers", or "people make alcohol, but alcohol makes alcoholics".

This kind of talk spreads among the very people who use it. Mr Prescott got confused about the technical terms for a city. "The city of York already is a city, as is my own city of Hull is a city, and that I think is the definition of city and town."

Faced with these massive piles of abstract thought, there was little the Tory spokesman, Archie Norman could say or do. "The only time we ever see the deputy prime minister," he grumped, "is when he has a glossy brochure or a disaster to announce."

Or, I reflected yesterday, possibly both at the same time.

Or, I reflected yesterday, possibly both at the same time.

webTitle: Hackney might lose 'deeply depressing' education services

fields.headline: Hackney might lose 'deeply depressing' education services
fields.trailText: The London borough of Hackney may be forced to cede control of more of its education responsibilities to schools or the private sector after an Ofsted report said the council's services were in a "deeply depressing" state.
fields.body:
The London borough of Hackney may be forced to cede control of more of its education responsibilities to schools or the private sector after an Ofsted report said the council's services were in a "deeply depressing" state.

Education secretary David Blunkett is discussing two possible solutions with the council. Either schools could be allowed to buy more services or areas such as building services could be taken over by private companies or better performing local education authorities.

The borough has already been forced to outsource its school improvement and ethnic minority support services.

The government has insisted that this latest privatisation threat is not the first step towards a large-scale outsourcing of the borough's failing services.

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) said ministers were seeking a "mixed solution" to the problems faced by Hackney's weakest services, which include its financial management, housing benefit, refuse collection and street cleaning.

This could involve public and private partnerships being set up to administer failing services and will certainly mean greater involvement of the private and voluntary sectors.

The spokesman said the government is keeping its options open and is preparing to send consultants to the borough who will support Hackney staff and examine the future of their services.

"The consultants will be in very soon and working in individual services across the board, but the key message here is that it's not a privatisation agenda" the spokesman said.

The borough will not be forced to externalise its finance department but the government will be offering support including extra personnel to finance officers.

The borough's housing benefit contract with private sector firm ITnet has collapsed, but the DETR says it does not want to see services brought fully back in house. Hackney is running a backlog of 17,000 housing benefit applications.

Refuse collection and street cleaning have already been outsourced but on an unusually short 18-month contract, giving the borough time to examine its options.

Relevant government departments and the Audit Commission will meet with representatives from Hackney next week to discuss how the council can meet the milestones set out in the commission's best value inspection report, released last week.

These include gaining a realistic picture of the council's deficit, which could total up to £40m and agreeing a balanced budget for the next financial year by February 2001.

webTitle: Arts and humanities research must improve, says new chief

fields.headline: Arts and humanities research must improve, says new chief
fields.trailText: You know who you are..the Arts and Humanities Research Board is about to publish the list of departments where PhD completion rates have fallen below 50 per cent. This blacklisting will be serious for the departments involved, cutting them off from the board's funding of postgraduate students but it is the price of taking arts and humanities research seriously. The upside is the chance of more money for departments that do perform well.
fields.body:
You know who you are..the Arts and Humanities Research Board is about to publish the list of departments where PhD completion rates have fallen below 50 per cent. This blacklisting will be serious for the departments involved, cutting them off from the board's funding of postgraduate students but it is the price of taking arts and humanities research seriously. The upside is the chance of more money for departments that do perform well.

True, the board's £52m budget is puny compared with the big science research councils' but in two years of existence under the leadership of Paul Langford it has established itself firmly on the scene, raising the profile of this kind of research and raising the morale of academics, believes the new chief executive David Eastwood.

He and his heavily oversubscribed budget are now in the sights of about 12,000 staff and researchers in the arts and humanities. An Oxford historian like Langford, Eastwood even shares the same specialism of 18th and early 19th century English history (perhaps a thorough grounding in the intricacies of patronage and politics is deemed essential to dispensing grants?) He says he has three rules in life - never draw up a seating plan (he was a senior tutor at an Oxford college), never choose a menu and never follow someone who has done a really good job. "I have broken that spectacularly following Paul," he smiles. He comes to the job from Swansea where he has been head of the history department and pro-vice chancellor.

The board - chaired by Sir Brian Follett, the retiring vice-chancellor of Warwick University - is to become a company limited by guarantee from April 1 - at present it is not a legal entity - it doesn't employ its own staff or have a bank account. In the new year Eastwood will unveil an innovation fund which he hopes will foster the equivalent of blue skies research in the sciences. He is thinking not only of international collaboration, but interdisciplinary work between, for instance, cultural and environmental fields. (He is discussing joint funding with the Natural Environment Research Council.) "We want new ways of researching new forms of knowledge. We want something that will make people sit up."

The board will also consider bids for another five or six research centres to add to the 10 existing ones. This continues the policy of promoting collaboration and research teams in the arts and humanities - for so long the preserve of the lone scholar - on the model of the sciences, although Eastwood insists the lone scholar is still catered for in the board's research leave scheme.

He is also committed to continuing the fight for the arts as well as the humanities. Widespread scepticism, if not downright hostility, to the whole idea of arts research had to be confronted by the board as it established itself. How do you research a performance? Was this "flaky arts stuff" serious research? Eastwood argues that arts research is like engineering which investigates processes. The arts are a major, and growing, contributor to the UK economy "I think if you put some of our creative and performing arts and design people in a synergistic relationship not just with the humanities but with other parts of the research domain all sorts of interesting things will come out of it."

In the longer term he wants to see the board become a fully-fledged research council. "We should be a research council because it gives our subject domain parity of esteem and a seat at every table as of right."

Status and money for the arts and humanities are linked, he believes - not that they will ever command the sums going to the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council. "We are perceived as a research council in all but name. The principle difference is I wish I had as much money as the EPSRC."

webTitle: TheStreet.com 'will struggle to raise extra cash' says rival

fields.headline: TheStreet.com 'will struggle to raise extra cash' says rival
fields.standfirst:
Nov 16: Street boss 'baffled' by closure
Nov 16: Management blamed after collapse
Nov 16: TheStreet.co.uk shuts down
fields.trailText:
Friday 6pm: TheStreet.com will struggle to raise finance in the wake of the collapse of its UK website, claims the editor of the Wall Street Journal's online operation. By Dan Milmo
Nov 16: Street boss 'baffled' by closure
Nov 16: Management blamed after collapse
Nov 16: TheStreet.co.uk shuts down
fields.body:
The editor of the Wall Street Journal's online operation has said that rival website TheStreet.com will struggle to raise extra finance in the wake of the collapse of its UK site, TheStreet.co.uk,

Neil F Budde, editor of WSJ.com, said: "The flaw is in trying to build a large staff operation in anticipation of making higher revenues, which have not come along.

"TheStreet.com built its revenues on the back of the venture capitalists giving it money, but to go back to them in today's climate is a little harder."

Mr Budde added that TheStreet's next challenge, if it becomes profitable, is to be a buyer or be bought.

"There has to be some level of consolidation within these sites, because there are thousands of them competing with each other."

WSJ.com made revenues of $36m last year, and has over 500,000 subscribers, giving it the rare accolade of a content provider which makes money.

Mr Budde shrugged off the suggestion that WSJ.com's financial backing from parent company Dow Jones gives it a huge financial advantage over its rivals. The site has yet to make profit, and will not issue operating profit figures

"No one at Dow Jones would let me spend another $90m before I make profit. The tolerance level from your investors can only be so much," he added.

webTitle: Peers told to list business interests

fields.headline: Peers told to list business interests
fields.standfirst:
Lords reform Standards committee report says lobbying jobs can be retained and recommends 'light touch' regulation for upper house
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Lord Neill's proposals for a new code of conduct and compulsory register of business interests for peers are likely to be accepted by the government, Lady Jay, the leader of the Lords, indicated yesterday.
fields.body:
Lord Neill's proposals for a new code of conduct and compulsory register of business interests for peers are likely to be accepted by the government, Lady Jay, the leader of the Lords, indicated yesterday.

The report by the committee on standards in public life recommends said the Lords, as a vital institution in public life and one in which the public and the media were likely to show a growing interest, should adopt greater transparency.

But Lord Neill said his committee had decided to recommend "a light touch" in dealing with transgressions by peers, believing that it was possible to rely on the peers' sense of honour and their desire to avoid being "named and shamed" rather than any system of penalties. It would anyway not be legally possible to threaten peers with expulsion or suspension from the upper house, he said. "There were no cases of abuse or scandal in the House of Lords and it seemed to us it was not necessary to put in place an elaborate regime to deal with constant allegations of abuse."

The changes Lord Neill has recommended are likely to be opposed by Lord Strathclyde, the Tory leader in the Lords, who reiterated his party's support for the status quo.

Lord Neill's committee has been looking at the Lords in the aftermath of the departure of 600 hereditary peers last November. There have been worries that the remaining life peers, bishops and elected hereditaries are more vulnerable to robust lobbying by single issue pressure groups.

The report defended the present system that allowed peers to keep lobbying jobs provided they did no paid advocacy work and declared all clients. But the committee said peers should have to register, like MPs in the Commons, details of all consultancy contracts for public inspection. They should also refrain from participating in parliamentary business when the affairs of personal clients were affected.

The report rejected banning the opposition front bench from having paid outside interests and said a parliamentary standards commissioner to investigate peers was not necessary. Any inquiries should be dealt with by a committee, with the appointment of a special investigator only if there were a very complex case of allegations of breaches of the rules.

Lady Jay said the government welcomed Lord Neill's recommendations. "I will be consulting opposition peers very soon to decide how to take this forward."

But Lord Strathclyde warned against turning the Lords into "a house of full-time paid politicians".
