webTitle: No cure in sight for Hackney's education troubles

fields.headline: No cure in sight for Hackney's education troubles
fields.standfirst: Education secretary David Blunkett has announced that more of Hackney's education services are to be privatised but, asks education editor Will Woodward, is that the answer?
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett has announced that more of Hackney's education services are to be privatised but, asks education editor Will Woodward, is that the answer?
fields.body:
Those of us who live in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney, where rubbish bags piling up outside people's houses are a superficial but eerie reminder of the winter of discontent, are pleased nevertheless to know that the borough's schools have actually improved their performance.

No less a figure than Chris Woodhead, HM chief inspector of schools, has praised their efforts.

However, it comes as no surprise that Mr Woodhead finds that the improvements are in spite of and not because of the council. In his considered opinion, Hackney is the worst education authority in England.

"The efforts to restore this LEA to health have clearly foundered, yet again, on the rock of corporate incompetence," he said. He attacked the council for triggering the resignation of the "highly effective" director of education, Elizabeth Reid, and several of her senior colleagues.

Hackney's GCSE results were better this year, although still only one in three students achieved five A*-Cs or better. That figure is better than neighbouring Islington and the rate of improvement was three times the national average. Key Stage 2 English results have improved by 8%, double the national average.

Mr Woodhead said he was frustrated that Ofsted had issued three reports on the LEA since 1997, outlining much the same problems every time. To which the government's response was oxymoronic - David Blunkett promised radical steps, but first he had to consider them.

Senior government sources insisted it was impossible to act without evidence - they didn't even have the power to intervene in the running of LEAs until 1998.

They have already brought in private contractors Nord Anglia to run some services. Mr Woodhead wants them to go further and contract out more services. Yet as the Ofsted report points out, Nord Anglia have been far from perfect, delivering improvements too slowly.

Contracting out, with all its attendant loss of accountability, is far from ideal. We may know what the disease is, but can we be sure we know the cure?

webTitle: 'Deeply depressing' Hackney faces more privatisation

fields.headline: 'Deeply depressing' Hackney faces more privatisation
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett announced plans to privatise more education services in the London borough of Hackney today - despite Ofsted criticism of the performance of existing private firm Nord Anglia - after the inspectorate described it as in a "deeply depressing" state.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett announced plans to privatise more education services in the London borough of Hackney today - despite Ofsted criticism of the performance of existing private firm Nord Anglia - after the inspectorate described it as in a "deeply depressing" state.

Describing a third of the council's education provision as "unsatisfactory", Ofsted highlighted the support for headteachers, financial management and support for children's education as still below par. However, some areas, such as truancy rates and the attainment of ethnic minority pupils, are starting to improve.

"I urge the government to rescue the education of some of Britain's most deprived children from the malign influence of Hackney council," departing Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead said in a statement today.

Schools in Hackney had been making good progress under former education director Elizabeth Reid, Mr Woodhead told the Today programme this morning, but the council had mishandled her resignation.

The education secretary confirmed that at least partial privatisation of Hackney's education services would take place, saying that head teachers "needed an anchor" in order to carry on. Either schools could jointly buy in more services, he suggested, or areas such as building services and school improvement could be taken over by better-performing LEAs or private companies.

According to Ofsted, "too much has happened too slowly" under Nord Anglia's leadership. "The outsourced school improvement functions have been too slow to take effect and are currently, with the exception of support for ethnic minority children, literacy and numeracy, still discharged in an unsatisfactory way."

But Mr Blunkett said the company was about to improve its performance and it was now "right that we should consider what further radical steps are needed".

A recent Audit Commission report described the council's financial affairs as "in a state of collapse".

Mr Woodhead, who leaves his job in two weeks' time, said that he "felt a sense of failure" at failing to persuade the government earlier that Hackney needed "radical intervention".

"The authority is doing a considerable number of things wrong. It is failing to implement a schools improvement strategy, it has failed to monitor and support and intervene appropriately with schools, it has failed to support school management. There is a failure of leadership from elected members, a failure to target resources on priorities," he said.

Jules Pipe, leader of the beleaguered council, admitted to the Today programme that the lack of overall control by any party for four years had led to "chaos and a lack of political leadership".

Hackney is one of England's poorest boroughs and Ofsted inspectors have visited its schools three times in the past three years.

Hackney is one of England's poorest boroughs and Ofsted inspectors have visited its schools three times in the past three years. Useful links Ofsted Hackney Education Nord Anglia

webTitle: US acclaim leads to UK rerelease for Croupier

fields.headline: US acclaim leads to UK rerelease for Croupier
fields.trailText: FilmFour are to rerelease the British-made Croupier, following acclaim and box-office success in the US
fields.body:
It seems that we don't know a good thing when we see it. Since its US premiere in April, British-made Croupier has received the acclaim, box-office success and awards that it was denied in its native Britain. As we reported last summer, the movie made almost no impact on its June 1999 release in the UK, but was hailed by Stateside critics almost a year later, and has sustained a wide following during its six-month run.

FilmFour has wisely decided that we should get a second look at this underappreciated movie by Get Carter director Mike Hodges, and Croupier is to be rereleased early next year.

Said Hodges: "I'm very gratified by the response to Croupier in North America, but its most important benefit may be the new opportunity to reach an audience in my own country."

Croupier tells the story of Jack Manfried (Clive Owen), an aspiring writer who takes a job as a croupier. Drawn irrevocably into the sleaze and intrigue of the casino world, his relationship with his girlfriend (Gina McKee) disintegrates, and he finds himself involved with a glamorous gambler (Alex Kingston).

webTitle: Fresh domain names as dot.coms run out

fields.headline: Fresh domain names as dot.coms run out
fields.standfirst: Special report: net news
fields.trailText: Net regulators in California have approved seven new domain names to ease the pressure on the dwindling stock of dot.com addresses.
fields.body:
Net regulators in California have approved seven new domain names to ease the pressure on the dwindling stock of dot.com addresses.

The suffixes, which include '.biz' for businesses, are the first major addition to the internet since the domain system was developed in the 1980s.

Alongside the new dot.biz addresses, web developers will be able to register '.info' for general use, '.name' for individuals, '.pro' for professionals, '.museum' for museums, '.coop' for business cooperatives and '.aero' for the aviation industry.

Esther Dyson, chair of the internet corporation for assigned names and numbers (ICANN), said the new domains were only an "initial sampling" but the body had chosen to reject some proposals such as '.health' '.kids' and '.web'.

New domains have been under discussion since mid-1990 but their introduction has been delayed by disputes. Experts say the move, similar to creating new telephone dialing codes, is needed to increase the capacity of the domain name system despite fears that new suffixes could trigger a fresh outbreak of cybersquatting, as speculators snap up well-known addresses with new suffixes to sell on for huge profits.

The United States commerce department appointed ICANN to oversee domain names and online addresses in 1998. However, private companies are paying the regulator $50,000 (£ 30,000) to become registry operators of the individual addresses with the prospect of charging millions for the most sought after names.

webTitle: Slap heads, Cup Deeds and Rap Fiends

fields.headline: Slap heads, Cup Deeds and Rap Fiends
fields.trailText: HAIR AND HARTSON
fields.body:
HAIR AND HARTSON

It's difficult to know which has depreciated faster in recent months: John Hartson's hairline or his value. Back in March, Big John resembled a modern day Henry VIII: rather rotund, rather hairy and rather desperate to score. "Come to Spurs in a £7m deal then," cried Arsenal's George Graham, the Tottenham manager, only for a pesky injury to get in the way of John's destiny. Then, in August, history repeated itself, but with strangely diminishing returns. Hartson's hair was now thinner, and so was the Pope's Rangers £5.5m offer! Scientists the world over might have scoffed, but the eagle-eyed Fiver knew a correlation when it saw one. It was obvious: the less hair John had, the less clubs were prepared to bid for him.

So when our source at Selhurst Park told us yesterday that Big John was combing his hair over, a la Bobby Charlton circa 1965, we knew it was just a matter of time before some club offered a lowly sum - perhaps £4m (plus Kevin Lisbie) - for him. And surprise, surprise, that's exactly what Charlton did today. However before we telephone Frank Leboeuf to warn him to pack his shoulder pads for tomorrow's game, up popped the Addicks' manager Frank "Alan Curbishley" Warren to claim the deal was far from done.

"I have had a couple of conversations with Terry and obviously we know each other well," Curbishley waffled, before finally getting to some sort of point, "He asked after young Kevin and I told him we had lots of injury problems with our strikers. I said if you want Kevin I will take John." So why isn't the deal complete? According to Curbishley, he only made a tentative enquiry, so there is still much work to do. "I'm a bit surprised this has come out - I haven't even mentioned it to Kevin," he continued sheepishly. "I spoke to Terry and that's how it was left. Something needs to be done now that it is out in the open," he added non-commitally - realising, no doubt, that if waits just a bit longer, Hartson's hair loss will surely bring the price down even further.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CUP FEVERISH

It starts quietly, with the odd down-page story on a club from the Screwfix Direct League. Then 'On The Ball' reports on an oddball club from the Bloxwich Combination. But by January you will not be able to stomach another story about window cleaners who refuse to be daunted by murky prospects, milkmen who have lots of bottle and computer programmers who have all the answers. Yep it's that time of year again: when the Cup clichés pour out in an unstoppable stream.

So well done to all 34 non-League clubs who have got to the first round. And we promise not to call you "brave" just because you dare to turn up at a Third Division ground, or "romantic" just because you did not kick your way through the qualifying rounds, or "modest" just because you are so non-League you play in the Conference.

Instead, we salute clubs like Barrow, who boast a squad that can call on more than 1,000 League games' worth of experience - while gently pointing out that if you can find any romance in these bunch of old pros then you are even sicker than you realised. And we also take our hats off to Radcliffe Borough, who play York City at Gigg Lane. Bernard Manning is their club president and his son is the chairman. Modesty is not quite the first word you would associate with Bernard. And as for romance well, you really are sick.

Beware of this line: "Even if Borough lose, they'll be laughing." And here's a few more you should watch out for: "When we go to big clubs our lads raise their game and I'm sure Bracknell will do the same", "We would be silly not to show them some respect" and, yes, "It's an FA Cup final for them". Congratulations to George Foster, Lincoln's assistant manager, who has already set the standard dauntingly high for most Cup clichés per interview answer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It seems clear Keane is quite happy to take home £50,000-a-week. But then he moans about the corporate fans, who are basically paying his wages. Perhaps Roy could offer to have his pay halved and let a load of more passionate fans in for free - but somehow I doubt that would happen."

Manchester City's Alfie Haaland gets the ball rolling nicely for tomorrow's Manchester derby.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BOYOKASHA!

"In our area two lay dead, both of them killed by captain Whitehead,
They come again to try a goal search, then get a good whipping with the Birch,
They decide to play a different way,
The wild boy Thurston say 'Make my day ...',
Bad man Stevens say: 'I have enough of this!'
He goes up there and takes the shit,
Shimmy and Shammy kick them down,
Him and Dobie fire in four,
Manager Atkins say you have completed your mission.
Respect!!!!"

No, the Fiver hasn't gone mad, or let the local primary school run riot for the day. Instead we've decided to repeat in full the rap of Carlisle chairman Albert "Ali D" Doweck that inspired his side to their first home win of the season.

"It's just a bit of fun. I went into the dressing room and put my hand over Ian's mouth," Doweck told the Newcastle Journal. "I started rapping and at the end I put my hands out like Ali G. I suppose I am Carlisle's answer to him - Ali D."

Meanwhile, Carlisle manager Ian Atkins agreed - well, his side are bottom of the League - claiming: "It was the funniest thing I have ever seen." And we don't think he was joking either, because he went on to say: "It completely broke the ice and my team talk went out the window. He deserves a slap on the back for his Jamaican rap." Wonder if Alan Sugar will try a similar approach at Spurs?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough are chasing Hannu Tihinen, a Finnish defender known as the "Iron Mountain", from Viking Stavanger, according to reports.

Barcelona are ready to ring the changes after elimination from the Champions League, with Carlos Bianchi, the former Reims and Nice coach currently in charge of Boca Juniors, due to take over as manager from Lorenzo Serra Ferrer, Onefootball reports.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has made his peace with Spain's captain Fernando Hierro, the Real Madrid defender claimed today. Both men were sent off during Holland's 2-1 win over Spain in Seville on Wednesday after the Chelsea striker aimed a kick at the Madrid defender and Hierro appeared to headbutt the Dutchman in retaliation. Hasselbaink then said that Hierro was not worthy of the Spanish captaincy. "We've spoken to one another and it's been resolved," Hierro said today. "He says he doesn't believe what he said after the game and that's that."

Fulham have signed the Latvian international striker Andrey Stolcers from Shakhtar Donetsk for £2m. The 26-year-old is on loan at Spartak Moscow and is set to play for the Russian champions against Arsenal on Wednesday before joining up with Fulham.

Christoph Daum will have another drugs test in Germany after disparities between his tests in Cologne and Florida.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Live FA Cup Football: Luton Town v Rushden and Diamonds

Live and direct from Kenilworth Road.

Hold the back page (10.15pm)

Live and direct from a specially installed camera in Brian Woolnough's lacquered bouffant.

Sky 1: Premier League Review (12.30am, 4.30am)

OK, so we're making it up. But how long before fantasy becomes fact?

webTitle: Management blamed after TheStreet.co.uk collapse

fields.headline: Management blamed after TheStreet.co.uk collapse
fields.standfirst: Nov 16: TheStreet.co.uk shuts down
fields.trailText:
Friday 5.30pm: Staff made redundant at TheStreet.co.uk, are blaming "management arrogance" for the online finance site's abrupt demise.
Nov 16: TheStreet.co.uk shuts down
fields.body:
Staff made redundant at TheStreet.co.uk, are blaming "management arrogance" for the online finance site's abrupt demise.

Journalists who were told on Thursday afternoon that they no longer had jobs today expressed bitterness that more hadn't been done to save the site.

One said: "There was a lot of tension between the UK and US sites. When it came down to the wire, the US office thought 'well, sod them'. The guys in the UK were too arrogant.

"The UK people had not been co-operative. It was the whole attitude of thumbing your nose at 'those damn yanks'. They did not realise that by being so arrogant the US would pull the plug."

However, Claudia Jay, managing director of the UK site, hit back at the claims, saying that there was close co-operation between management and editorial on both sides of the Atlantic.

"There was no certainly no arrogance in the UK office to my knowledge," she said. "I know that TheStreet.com were extremely hurt that they had to make the decision to close us down. It was a purely financial thing."

Ms Jay added that the company came close to securing a rescue package over the past few months, but turbulent market conditions caused the deals to fall through.

TheStreet.com yesterday bought out the UK site's backers and shut down the operation to cut losses. The site, which has spent more than £9.6m since launch, has promised an "orderly collapse".

All 64 UK staff have lost their jobs, including editor Nils Pratley who had joined from Sunday Business. A further 40 staff were made redundant in the US.

webTitle: Law casts himself as troubled Beatles manager

fields.headline: Law casts himself as troubled Beatles manager
fields.trailText: Jude Law's production company Natural Nylon is to produce a film about the troubled Beatles manager Brian Epstein, with Law in line for the lead role
fields.body:
Natural Nylon, the British production company that has been conspicuous in its failures to date, with James Joyce biopic Nora and lame gangster flick Love, Honour and Obey to its name, is to produce a film about the troubled Beatles manager Brian Epstein.

Gossip site therumour.com reports that the production company owned by Jude Law, Sadie Frost, Ewan McGregor, Jonny Lee Miller and Sean Pertwee has turned its attention to the Beatles manager Brian Epstein who died aged 33. Jude Law will take the read role of the homosexual Epstein, who died of a suspected drugs overdose in 1967 when the band were at the height of their fame.

Law found fame playing Oscar Wilde's lover Bosie in 1997's Wilde. The actor told reporters he is more than happy to take on another homosexual role. "It's a great role," he said, "and as with every heterosexual man, every homosexual man is different, and they approach their sexuality very differently."

The story of Epstein's colourful life has been previously presented in Christopher Munch's 1991 feature, The Hours and Times. A fictionalised account of what may have happened when John Lennon and Epstein went on holiday to Spain in 1963, Munch's film focused on rumours that Epstein was in love with Lennon.

Law is in big demand since his Oscar-nominated role in The Talented Mr Ripley. Variety reports today that the British actor is considering an offer to star alongside Tom Hanks in Sam Mendes depression-era epic, The Road to Perdition. The film, due to start shooting in early 2001 concerns a hitman who wreaks revenge on the murderer of his wife and son.

Furthermore, as we reported last week, Law and Natural Nylon are also eyeing a biopic of Elizabethan poet Christopher Marlowe. Although Johnny Depp is rumoured to be interested in the lead role, Law is also expected to star.

Currently in Los Angeles working on the Stanley Kubrick-scripted A1 with Steven Spielberg, Law is one of Hollywood's hottest British exports. It seems that the actor will soon be facing a decision whether to base himself and his family in California, or remain at their Primrose Hill home in North London and continue a commitment to low-budget British productions.

 More information about Natural Nylon.

webTitle: Putting children first - at last

fields.headline: Putting children first - at last
fields.standfirst: Lambeth is prioritising children's welfare through the establishment of a commission, in an effort to deal with years of negligence
fields.trailText: Lambeth is prioritising children's welfare through the establishment of a commission, in an effort to deal with years of negligence
fields.body:
What is a community to do if its children's services have been widely condemned and it wants to restore public faith in its ability to put things right? Set up a squeaky clean independent commission, of course, and make its findings as public as possible.

The London borough of Lambeth has an appalling record of negligence when it comes to looking after the children in its care. A report by specialist John Barratt, commissioned by the council's social services department, revealed "inexcusable delay and inaction" in dealing with child abuse claims; a failure to police-check foster carers; infrequent inspections of children's homes and respite units and an organisational structure that had "decayed and disintegrated". A recent social services inspectorate report confirms more of the same.

Heads have rolled in Lambeth, a new social services director, Lisa Christensen, has been appointed and an improvement plan is under way. The authority is one of two (with Hackney) which have been issued with "directions" or statutory instructions to clean up their act by health minister John Hutton. It's also one of a dozen currently on special measures, meeting monthly with the Department of Health's social services inspectorate which monitors its progress. Now, in a borough that seemed to have put children's interests last for decades - well behind street lighting and emptying the bins - an independent Children First commission has been set up to scrutinise the process.

"Lambeth's social workers are no better or worse than anywhere else," says Ms Christensen, a former health service manager. "But they have suffered from dysfunctional management and a very inward looking regime where things could go undetetected for years. As the Barratt report points out, even basic data on the children being looked after was hard to find. It's been a complete shambles." She believes that reforming children's services is now a possibility, and that the Children First commission will be crucial in creating an open and honest culture.

With the stakes so high, how well equipped is the commission - the first of its kind - to deliver the goods? Set up in June, with £45,000 from the government's Quality Protects child care improvement programme, it will report in autumn 2001. Only one of its four members, Melissa Berry, has any expertise in the care system, having been in care herself. But, says its chairwoman, journalist Sara Nathan, this was a conscious choice. "The whole point is to have non-social services people, who will talk in upfront, layman's language, and make sure Lambeth's services have a very public face."

So far they have held three meetings, drawn up a 1- point list of quality benchmarks against which the council's performance will be judged and plan to talk to children, carers and frontline staff. The inclusion on the commission of TV and radio presenter, Lisa I'Anson, is expected to help it connect with hard-to-reach youth.

Bernie Baker, project leader of Lambeth children's rights service - another new initiative run for the council by the Children's Society - welcomes the commission, but warns that problems are so profound that it will be "up against it" to get results. Many children in care do not get statutory reviews or have a designated social worker, he says. And vulnerable groups such as the borough's large population of asylum seeker children are the responsibility of a "non-existent asylum seeking team".

The commission's benchmarks go some way towards addressing these issues and include targets for education, health and the way children are moved about and treated in care. However a spokesperson from the Children's Rights alliance questioned how much credibility a commission without roots in the local community will have with people in Lambeth and what kind of teeth it has to ensure its targets are met.

The answer, probably, is not that much. However, Ms Christensen and the councillors who are backing the commission are hopeful that sheer determination - and the oxygen of publicity - will help to spark things up. The alternative - staring Lambeth in the face over the river in Hackney - may be direct government control of its children's services. But the community should opt for whatever it takes finally to put children first.

The London borough of Lambeth has an appalling record of negligence when it comes to looking after the children in its care. fields.headline: House of Leaves by Mark Z Danielewski
fields.trailText: While enthusiasts and detractors will continue to empty entire dictionaries attempting to describe or deride it, "authenticity" still remains the word most likely to stir a debate. In fact, this leading obsession-to validate or invalidate the reels and tapes-invariably brings up a collateral and more general concern: whether or not, with the advent of digital technology, image has forsaken its once unimpeachable hold on the truth
fields.body:
I saw a film today, oh boy ...

- The Beatles

While enthusiasts and detractors will continue to empty entire dictionaries attempting to describe or deride it, "authenticity" still remains the word most likely to stir a debate. In fact, this leading obsession-to validate or invalidate the reels and tapes-invariably brings up a collateral and more general concern: whether or not, with the advent of digital technology, image has forsaken its once unimpeachable hold on the truth.

For the most part, skeptics call the whole effort a hoax but grudgingly admit The Navidson Record is a hoax of exceptional quality. Unfortunately out of those who accept its validity many tend to swear allegiance to tabloid-UFO sightings. Clearly it is not easy to appear credible when after vouching for the film's verity, the discourse suddenly switches to why Elvis is still alive and probably wintering in the Florida Keys. One thing remains certain: any controversy surrounding Billy Meyer's film on flying saucers has been supplanted by the house on Ash Tree Lane.

Though many continue to devote substantial time and energy to the antinomies of fact or fiction, representation or artifice, document or prank, as of late the more interesting material dwells exclusively on the interpretation of events within the film. This direction seems more promising, even if the house itself, like Melville's behemoth, remains resistant to summation.

Much like its subject, The Navidson Record itself is also uneasily contained - whether by category or lection. If finally catalogued as a gothic tale, contemporary urban folkmyth, or merely a ghost story, as some have called it, the documentary will still, sooner or later, slip the limits of any one of those genres. Too many important things in The Navidson Record jut out past the borders. Where one might expect horror, the supernatural, or traditional paroxysms of dread and fear, one discovers disturbing sadness, a sequence on radioactive isotopes, or even laughter over a Simpsons episode.

In the 17th century, England's greatest topographer of worlds satanic and divine warned that hell was nothing less than "Regions of sorrow, doleful shades, where peace/ And rest can never dwell, hope never comes/ That comes to all" thus echoing the words copied down by hell's most famous tourist: "Dinanzi a me non fuor cose create/ Se non etterne, e io etterna duro./ Lasciate ogni speranza, voi ch'entrate."

Even today many people still feel The Navidson Record, in spite of all its existential refinements and contemporary allusions, continues to reflect those exact sentiments. In fact a few eager intellectuals have already begun to treat the film as a warning in and of itself, perfectly suited for hanging whole above the gates of such schools as Architectonics, Popomo, Consequentialism, Neo-Plasticism, Phenomenology, Information Theory, Marxism, Biosemiotics, to say nothing of psychology, medicine, New Age spirituality, art and even Neo-Minimalism. Will Navidson, however, remains stalwart in his insistence that his documentary should be taken literally. As he himself says, "... all this, don't take it as anything else but this. And if one day you find yourself passing by that house don't stop, don't slow down, just keep going. There's nothing there. Beware."

Considering how the film ends, it is not surprising that more than a handful of people have decided to heed his advice.

The Navidson Record did not first appear as it does today. Nearly seven years ago what surfaced was "The Five and a Half Minute Hallway" - a five and a half minute optical illusion barely exceeding the abilities of any NYU film school graduate. The problem, of course, was the accompanying statement that claimed all of it was true.

In one continuous shot, Navidson, whom we never actually see, momentarily focuses on a doorway on the north wall of his living room before climbing outside of the house through a window to the east of that door, where he trips slightly in the flower bed, redirects the camera from the ground to the exterior white clapboard, then moves right, crawling back inside the house through a second window, this time to the west of that door, where we hear him grunt slightly as he knocks his head on the sill, eliciting light laughter from those in the room, presumably Karen, his brother Tom, and his friend Billy Reston - though like Navidson, they too never appear on camera-before finally returning us to the starting point, thus completely circling the doorway and so proving, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that insulation or siding is the only possible thing this doorway could lead to, which is when all laughter stops, as Navidson's hand appears in frame and pulls open the door, revealing a narrow black hallway at least ten feet long, prompting Navidson to re-investigate, once again leading us on another circumambulation of this strange passageway, climbing in and out of the windows, pointing the camera to where the hallway should extend but finding nothing more than his own backyard-no ten foot protuberance, just rose bushes, a muddy dart gun, and the translucent summer air - in essence an exercise in disbelief which despite his best intentions still takes Navidson back inside to that impossible hallway, until as the camera begins to move closer, threatening this time to actually enter it, Karen snaps, "Don't you dare go in there again, Navy," to which Tom adds, "Yeah, not such a hot idea," thus arresting Navidson at the threshold, though he still puts his hand inside, finally retracting and inspecting it, as if by seeing alone there might be something more to feel, Reston wanting to know if in fact his friend does sense something different, and Navidson providing the matter-of-fact answer which also serves as the conclusion, however abrupt, to this bizarre short: "It's freezing in there."

Dissemination of "The Five and a Half Minute Hallway" seemed driven by curiosity alone. No one ever officially distributed it and so it never appeared in film festivals or commercial film circles. Rather, VHS copies were passed around by hand, a series of progressively degenerating dubs of a home video revealing a truly bizarre house with notably very few details about the owners or for that matter the author of the piece.

Less than a year later another short surfaced. It was even more hotly sought after than "The Five and a Half Minute Hallway" and resulted in some fervent quests for Navidson and the house itself, all of which, for one reason or another, failed. Unlike the first, this short was not a continuous shot, prompting many to speculate that the eight minutes making up "Exploration #4" were in fact bits of a much larger whole.

The structure of "Exploration #4" is highly discontinuous, jarring, and as evidenced by many poor edits, even hurried. The first shot catches Navidson mid-phrase. He is tired, depressed and pale. "- days, I think. And, I ... I don't know." [Drink of something; unclear what.] "Actually I'd like to burn it down. Can't think clearly enough to do it though." [Laughs] "And now ... this."

The next shot jumps to Karen and Tom arguing over whether or not to "go in after him." At this point it remains unclear to whom they are referring.

There are several more shots.

Trees in winter.

Blood on the kitchen floor.

One shot of a child (Daisy) crying.

Then back to Navidson: "Nothing but this tape which I've seen enough times, it's more like a memory than anything else. And I still don't know: was he right or just out of his mind?"

Followed by three more shots.

Dark hallways.

Windowless rooms.

Stairs.

Then a new voice: "I'm lost. Out of food. Low on water. No sense of direction. Oh god ..." The speaker is a bearded, broad shouldered man with frantic eyes. He speaks rapidly and appears short of breath: "Holloway Roberts. Born in Menomonie, Wisconsin. Bachelor's from U. Mass. There's something here. It's following me. No, it's stalking me. I've been stalked by it for days but for some reason it's not attacking. It's waiting, waiting for something. I don't know what. Holloway Roberts. Menomonie, Wisconsin. I'm not alone here. I'm not alone."

Thus bringing to an end this strange abstract which as the release of The Navidson Record revealed was sparingly incomplete. Then for two years nothing. Few clues about who any of these people were, though eventually a number of photographers in the news community did recognize the author as none other than Will Navidson, the prize-winning photojournalist who won the Pulitzer for his picture of a dying girl in Sudan. Unfortunately this discovery only generated a few months of heated speculation, before, in the absence of press, corroboration, the location of the house or for that matter any comment by Navidson himself, interest died out. Most people just wrote it off as some kind of weird hoax, or, because of the unusual conceit, an aberrant UFO sighting. Nevertheless the deteriorating dubs did circulate and in some trendy academic circles a debate began: was the subject a haunted house? What did Holloway mean by "lost"? How could anyone be lost in a house for days anyway? Furthermore, what was someone with Navidson's credentials doing creating two strange shorts like these? And again, was this artifice or reality?

Certainly a good deal of the debate was sustained by a bit of old fashioned cultural elitism. People talked about the Navidson pieces because they were lucky enough to have seen them. Lee Sinclair suspects a majority of professors, students, SoHo artists and avant-garde filmmakers who spoke-and even wrote-so knowingly about the tapes, more than likely had never even viewed one frame: "There just weren't that many copies available."

While "The Five and a Half Minute Hallway" and "Exploration #4" have been respectively called a "teaser" and a "trailer", they are also, in their own right, peculiar cinematic moments. On a purely symbolic level, they afford a vast potential for examination: the compression of space, the power of the imagination to decompress that space, the house as trope for the unlimited and the unknowable etc., etc. On a strictly visceral level, they provide ample shocks and curiosities. However, the most unnerving aspect about both pieces is their ability to convince us that everything really happened, some of which can be attributed to the verifiable elements (Holloway Roberts, Will Navidson et al.), but most of which must be chalked up to the starkness of the production-the absence of make-up, expensive sound tracks, or crane shots. Except for framing, editing, and in some cases sub-titles, there is virtually no room for creative intrusion.

Who would have suspected that almost three years after "The Five and a Half Minute Hallway" began appearing on VHS, Miramax would quietly release The Navidson Record in a limited run and almost immediately unsettle audiences everywhere. Since the opening three years ago last April in New York and Los Angeles, The Navidson Record has been screened nationwide, and while hardly a blockbuster, the film continues to generate revenues as well as interest. Film periodicals frequently publish reviews, critiques and letters. Books devoted entirely to The Navidson Record now appear with some regularity. Numerous professors have made The Navidson Record required viewing for their seminars, while many universities already claim that dozens of students from a variety of departments have completed doctoral dissertations on the film. Comments and references frequently appear in Harper's, The New Yorker, Esquire, American Heritage, Vanity Fair, Spin as well as on late night television. Interest abroad is equally intense. Japan, France and Norway have all responded with awards but to this day the spectral Navidson has yet to appear let alone accept any one of these. Even the garrulous Weinstein brothers remain unusually reticent about the film and its creator.

Interview magazine quoted Harvey Weinstein as saying, "It is what it is."

The Navidson Record now stands as part of this country's cultural experience and yet in spite of the fact that hundreds of thousands of people have seen it, the film continues to remain an enigma. Some insist it must be true, others believe it is a trick on par with the Orson Welles radio romp The War of the Worlds. Others could care less, admitting that either way The Navidson Record is a pretty good tale. Still many more have never even heard of it.

These days, with the unlikely prospect of any sort of post-release resolution or revelation, Navidson's film seems destined to achieve at most cult status. Good story telling alone will guarantee a healthy sliver of popularity in the years to come but its inherent strangeness will permanently bar it from any mainstream interest.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours brought to you with the help of Olbas Oil - the decongestant that keeps the sportsdesk decongested.
fields.trailText: Bradford City will confirm Jim Jefferies as their new manager later today, according to Teamtalk.
fields.body:
Bradford City will confirm Jim Jefferies as their new manager later today, according to Teamtalk.

Newcastle, Derby and Middlesbrough are tracking Barcelona striker Jari Litmanen. All three clubs had scouts watching him in Finland's 3-0 defeat against the Republic of Ireland. However Litmanen, who earns £50,000 per week at Barca, doesn't seem that keen on a move to the Premiership. "I've heard talk of a number of clubs being interested in me, and England could be an option, but before I go anywhere the whole package would have to be right," he admitted.

Newcastle and Middlesbrough are also both interested in Hannu Tihinen, the £2m-rated Finland and Viking Stavanger central defender known as the "Iron Mountain".

Norwich are set to sign Stockport striker Ian Moore for £1m.

Barcelona are ready to replace their manager Lorenzo Serra Ferrer with the Argentine Carlos Bianchi, the former Reims and Nice coach who is currently at Boca Juniors.

webTitle: Debate: is Nice in need of a radical rethink?

fields.headline: Debate: is Nice in need of a radical rethink?
fields.standfirst: Professor Sir Michael Rawlins, chair of government health advisory body Nice, defends his organisation following today's Guardian comment
fields.trailText: This morning's Guardian business notebook comment described the management of the national institute of clinical excellence (Nice) as "wonderfully haphazard", stumbling from "one pitfall to another" and claimed that the institute needs a "radical rethink". Below we publish the Guardian comment piece, together with a response by Professor Sir Michael Rawlins, chair of Nice.

webTitle: Ensuring patients have the best possible care

fields.headline: Ensuring patients have the best possible care
fields.standfirst: Professor Sir Michael Rawlins, chair of the national institute for clinical excellence, replies
fields.trailText: Nice has now completed and published 14 evaluations of technologies ranging from replacement hip joints to the use of taxanes in breast cancer. All of these have helped end uncertainties about their appropriate use.
fields.body:
Nice has now completed and published 14 evaluations of technologies ranging from replacement hip joints to the use of taxanes in breast cancer. All of these have helped end uncertainties about their appropriate use.

Our advice on taxanes for breast cancer will ensure that these drugs are available to the 4,000 women who were previously denied access to them, increasing the NHS drugs bill by around £16m and ending the uncertainties of "post-code" availability.

Our guidance on rosiglitazone will ensure that up to 78,000 patients with type 2 diabetes have access to this recently licensed medicine and will cost the NHS £14m.

Indeed, we estimate that the totality of our guidance will cost the NHS in excess of £100m per year.

None of this justifies your claim that "Nice has had a terrible year". Any manufacturer of a first class product, with proven efficacy and cost benefits to the NHS, can look forward to the added value that a positive evaluation from Nice can bring.

Secondly, Nice has yet to conclude its appraisal of beta interferon and no recommendations have been made.

Thirdly, last year the health secretary asked Nice to "fast-track" an appraisal of Glaxo-Welcome's Relenza for use in 'flu. At that time, the company was unable to satisfy the institute that its use in the NHS would be clinically and cost effective. Virtually every commentator (including some from the pharmaceutical industry) concurred.

We were aware, however, that further data would be available for Nice to re-appraise Relenza in time for the 2000/2001 'flu epidemic. That re-appraisal is now almost complete and the results will be known next week.

Anyone reading your finance notebook comment would gain the impression that the board's decision to increase the transparency of our processes was done on the spur of the moment. In reality, it followed many months of discussions with the groups that represent patients, professionals and the healthcare industries. Nice values the close working relationship it has with pharmaceutical manufacturers.

Our methodology has evolved over a two-year period of consultation and discussion that included the industry and took into account UK and European legislation. The NHS is a customer of the pharmaceutical-industry, but works on behalf of the patients and the public, and it must bring a rationale to the use of its resources.

The NHS in England and Wales has asked Nice to provide this rationale in order that patients have the highest attainable standards of care within the resources available.

 Professor Sir Michael Rawlins is chair of the national institute for clinical excellence

webTitle: Durlacher bears the brunt

fields.headline: Durlacher bears the brunt
fields.trailText: After the market had spent two sessions in positive territory, the bears came out of the woods yesterday. With Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warning that inflation remains a threat to the US economy, traders decided it was time to adopt a negative mindset.
fields.body:
After the market had spent two sessions in positive territory, the bears came out of the woods yesterday. With Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warning that inflation remains a threat to the US economy, traders decided it was time to adopt a negative mindset.

For one reason and another Durlacher , the internet investment bank, bore the brunt of the ill feeling. Its shares, which reached 455.5p at the height of the dot.com frenzy back in February, fell 5.5p, or 12.5%, to 38.5p on a cocktail of unpleasant speculation.

Early in the session the shares fell to 36p as word spread that stockbroking powerhouse Merrill Lynch was attempting to place a huge line of stock in the market at 35p.

According to the gossips, Merrill was trying to offload the stock on behalf of an institution that closely follows the FTSE mid 250 index. Apparently the institution or bank is a forced seller because of a change in make up of the mid-cap index.

On Tuesday, Durlacher was removed from the mid-cap index to make way for Chubb , up 4p to 254p, and Kidde , down 3.75p to 63.5p - the two parts of what used to be the conglomerate Williams.

Although the stock recovered a little, it fell back later in the session on reports that Wowgo , an internet business in which Durlacher has a 19% stake, was facing severe financial difficulties.

Elsewhere, Autonomy , London's latest hi-tech darling, was under pressure, falling 125p to £32.00 after Japanese investment bank Nomura issued a bearish research circular.

Downgrading the stock to "hold" from "buy", the broker pointed out that contrary to popular opinion, Autonomy's information retrieval technology was not proprietary.

"Today, Autonomy's software is not, in our opinion, a must-have purchase, in the way that SAP or Siebold or Oracle's software is. To become successful Autonomy's software will have to become a must-have purchase," the broker said.

Elsewhere, the dealers were also sharpening the knives on Bookham Technology . After a couple of sessions of strong gains its shares fell back 140p to £14.70.

Word is that a negative circular is being prepared. Pub lishing group Reed International , off 13.5p to 675p, also came under fire on the news that a profit warning is in the pipeline while BT lost 8p to 669p on rumours that it will be ejected from the MSCI index today.

In the wider market, the FTSE 100 closed 1.9 points lower at 6,430.4, after a session spent mainly in positive territory on the prospect of lower interest rates.

These hopes stemmed from the latest quarterly inflation report from the Bank of England but were not enough to sustain leading shares as Wall Street headed lower late in the day.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 ended 2.1 weaker at 6,717.8 and the FTSE Techmark 100 slipped 46.82 to 3,147.55. Nonetheless there were some bright spots. Cable group Telewest picked up 7.25p to 120p after third quarter results which came in at the top end of analysts' expectations.

Controls and automation group Invensys added 7p to 160p, as buyers moved in ahead of next weeks results.

Lower down the corporate scale, airports operator TBI rose sharply late in the session on word that takeover talks have finally reached a conclusion.

If the gossips are to believed the deal will be unveiled this morning at around 100p. The stock closed 4.25p better at 79.5p.

Eidos , the computer games maker behind Lara Croft, moved up 4p to 204.5p, as dealers locked on to speculation that current trading is much stronger than anticipated.

webTitle: Nice stumbles from one pitfall to another

fields.headline: Nice stumbles from one pitfall to another
fields.standfirst: Guardian finance notebook: Nice work
fields.trailText: There is something wonderfully haphazard about the management of Nice - the optimistically named national institute for clinical excellence. The institute was established last year to vet medicines for the NHS, setting guidelines on the usefulness and cost effectiveness of controversial treatments.
fields.body:
There is something wonderfully haphazard about the management of Nice - the optimistically named national institute for clinical excellence. The institute was established last year to vet medicines for the NHS, setting guidelines on the usefulness and cost effectiveness of controversial treatments.

Its worthy aim was to improve consistency, preventing the regional variances dubbed "postcode prescribing". In reality, it has stumbled from one pitfall to another, arousing screams of exaggerated outrage from the pharmaceuticals industry at every step.

Feathers were flying again yesterday as Nice announced it was to begin publishing all its draft appraisals on drugs. These initial evaluations are drawn up after preliminary hearings, but are often radically altered in "final" rulings after further consultation. Nice's reason for publishing these drafts is disarmingly honest - nearly all of them have been leaked, despite a £60,000 investigation into security procedures.

The Association of British Pharmaceutical Industry is furious - it says preliminary decisions cast a blight on drug sales, affect share prices and are likely to deter firms from launching their products first in the UK.

The real problem is in the way Nice works: true to its name, it tries to be likeable and open, sending its initial appraisals to hundreds of selected doctors, patients and specialists for their views. This is at odds with procedures at bodies such as the competition commission, which handle similarly financially sensitive information. They manage to collect opinions without disclosing their early thinking.

Nice has had a terrible year. It has banned Glaxo's flu drug Relenza, sending Sir Richard Sykes into such a tizzy that he threatened to leave the country. It also imposed restrictions on beta interferons, upsetting multiple sclerosis sufferers.

Each ruling takes at least a year, and Nice has been characterised as an extra hurdle in an already heavily regulated drug approval system. While the government is improving relations with the industry, Nice is leaving a trail of acrimony in its path. The institute needs a radical rethink.

webTitle: Fulham sign £2m Latvian striker

fields.headline: Fulham sign £2m Latvian striker
fields.trailText: Fulham have signed the Latvian international striker Andrey Stolcers from Shakhtar Donetsk for £2m.
fields.body:
Fulham have signed the Latvian international striker Andrey Stolcers from Shakhtar Donetsk for £2m.

Stolcers, 26, is on loan at Spartak Moscow and is set to play for the Russian champions against Arsenal on Wednesday before joining up with Fulham.

"He is a very talented attacking player with great pace and ability," Fulham managing director Michael Fiddy said, "and we believe that he will be a huge addition to the squad."

webTitle: The day the roof fell in

fields.headline: The day the roof fell in
fields.standfirst: Health minister John Hutton gives statutory directions to Lambeth social services. Director Lisa Christensen says it's like being 'kicked in the teeth'
fields.trailText: 17 November: Health minister John Hutton gives statutory directions to Lambeth social services. Director Lisa Christensen says it's like being 'kicked in the teeth'
fields.body:
On Sunday night the ceiling in my kitchen fell down - just after I had spent a happy day cleaning the whole house (a rare event). I should have realised this was an omen for the week ahead.

On Monday I met with the social services inspectorate (SSI) for my routine monitoring meeting. All agreed how well the presentation of the inspectorate's report had gone and how thoughtfully council members had responded. However, at the end of the meeting I was in no doubt that we would be hearing more about the minister's views, following his briefing on the SSI inspection report and Barratt's report. Although SSI colleagues were "unable" to tell me when his views would be made known , my assumption was that it would be tied in to the publication of the joint review report on 11th December.

Surprise, surprise - the minister announced on Thursday this week that he was issuing directions to us about fulfilling our statutory duties to children.

It takes a little time to get over the sense of being kicked in the teeth. Where is the recognition of the improvements that have taken place - the management team that is now in place, the improvement against the performance assessment framework indicators etc etc?

Still, no point in dwelling on that ... instead, have to spend two days (as does my head of children's services) in briefing staff, dealing with press, radio and members and trying to remain upbeat and sharing my genuine confidence about our ability to deliver as required. This confidence is down to the fact that we are not being required to do anything other than we were planning to do anyway - and the timescales are also the same.

The net effect of this furore will probably only be to hamper my attempts to recruit and retain good staff. I fail to see how it will help to improve services to children in Lambeth. It's certainly diverted a good deal of management energy and time this week.

I'm off to sweep up some more plaster dust

 Lisa Christensen is social services director of Lambeth council in south-east London

webTitle: Pakistan finds its salvation in defence

fields.headline: Pakistan finds its salvation in defence
fields.standfirst: General Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who seized power in a coup last year, wants Pakistan to become a major arms dealer, writes Rory McCarthy
fields.trailText: General Pervez Musharraf, the army chief who seized power in a coup last year, wants Pakistan to become a major arms dealer, writes Rory McCarthy.
fields.body:
Pakistan is a troubled country. The military are back in power again, the economy is sinking and Islamabad is internationally criticised for its support of the militants in Kashmir and the hardline Taliban in Afghanistan.

But General Pervez Musharraf, the quietly spoken army chief who seized power in a coup in October last year, has a plan. Unafraid of the effect it might have on his country's international image, he wants Pakistan to become a major arms dealer.

The pride of Pakistan's state-owned defence equipment manufacturers, from missiles to tanks to artillery shells, is now on display at one of the world 's largest arms shows, the "Arms for Peace" exhibition in Karachi.

"There is big money in defence and we need to enter into areas where developed countries are not competing," said Gen Musharraf, as he toured the exhibition.

"Pakistan offers a poor man's option to obtaining weapons in a cheap and economical manner. This will generate economic activity in Pakistan and we will plan more such ventures in the near future."

In recent years Pakistan has been a major defence importer, buying Agosta 90B submarines from France and Sea King helicopters from Britain.

Now the military regime hopes to become a competitive arms dealer itself. Exports of machine guns, rifles, anti-tank rockets, mortars and ammunition earned $30.2m (£21.7m) last year.

First Pakistan will put into mass production its new Al-Khalid tank, which is armed with a 125mm smooth bore gun and equipped with auto-tracking and thermal imaging.

"We are indeed proud of this tank. Inshallah (God willing) it will be the main tank of the Pakistan Army," said Gen Musharraf.

15 Al-Khalid tanks are now being built in a pilot project with China and mass production is scheduled to begin next year.

Until now Pakistan has preferred to upgrade older tank designs, like the T-59 which has been modernised into the Al-Zarrar, rather than take on the expense and expertise needed to produce a new tank.

Gen Musharraf wants the Al-Khalid to be a direct rival to the Russian T-90S tank. Last month Russian President Vladimir Putin clinched a deal to sell T-90S tanks and Su-30 MKI fighter jets to India, Pakistan's archrival.

Islamabad will also set up a Defence Export and Exhibition Directorate in Rawalpindi, where the army has its main base, to show off defence equipment.

"We will soon expand our defence sales and exports appreciably," Gen Musharraf said.

His generals are negotiating the possible sale of their Super Mushak trainer aircraft to an unnamed Middle Eastern country and Agosta-90B submarines to Saudi Arabia and Malaysia. Pakistan bought three of the submarines from France under a technology transfer agreement.

The generals say that apart from India and perhaps Israel they have no qualms about selling weapons to any nation. Islamabad is hoping to target allies in the Middle East and poorer nations in Africa and south-east Asia.

At least 34 countries with a combined defence purchase budget of $20bn (£14.3bn) sent delegations to the arms fair, including Zimbabwe, Rwanda, the Palestinian Authority, Indonesia and Malaysia.

Gen Musharraf is also hoping to use the skills of some of Pakistan's more traditional weapons manufacturers in his new endeavour.

Since the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan 20 years ago, Pakistan has been awash with unlicensed weapons from Kalashnikov assault rifles to rockets and Stinger anti-aircraft missiles.

Cheaper copies of these weapons pour out of Darra Adam Khel in the lawless tribal areas of northern Pakistan, one of the largest unofficial arms markets in Asia.

In an attempt to tackle the daily shootings and regular bomb blasts that plague Pakistani society, the military want to regulate the Darra market, limit gun sales and hire the best gun makers to work for the state-owned defence industries.

For now the regime is meeting tough resistance from Darra and the tribal elders. But if he succeeds, Gen Musharraf will have found a unique way to improve security in Pakistan and at the same time bolster his troubled nation's sickly economy.

webTitle: BBC to restructure publicity department

fields.headline: BBC unveils revamp of publicity department
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: The BBC is to reorganise its communications department in a move that will result in "a small number" of job losses, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The BBC is planning a major reorganisation of its communications department in a move that will result in "a small number" of job losses.

The shake-up, which is being announced to staff today, will affect some 160 members of staff.

The BBC said that some staff whose jobs will disappear as a result of the restructure would be offered new positions in the department.

New head of publicity Vanda Rumney described the restructure as "a sensible adjustment to support the new structure of the BBC".

She added: "It will affect everyone in as much as we're now asking everyone to work cross-channel and cross-media.

"Whereas before people were working on BBC1 and BBC2 they will now work across many more channels as well as BBC Online."

The restructure will see the head of publicity for BBC1 take on additional responsibilities for drama, entertainment and sports. And the head of publicity for BBC2 will take on BBC Online and factual programming.

BBC3, the BBC's new digital channel devoted to the youth market, will share a publicity manager with Radio 1.

BBC4, a remodelled BBC Knowledge, will be put together with another BBC division. And there will also be a publicity manager dedicated to BBC News.

Ms Rumney said most of the new jobs would be filled by internal candidates, but that headhunters had been briefed to look for a new head of publicity for BBC1, formerly part of her remit.

The corporation will also set up a new strategic unit under head of corporate public relations Andrew Whyte to focus on long-term planning.

webTitle: Oversubscribed - Nike trainers

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ...Nike trainers
fields.trailText: ...Nike trainers
fields.body:
You can understand the panic - after just a couple of decades waiting for a trainer that has anything to do fashion, Nike has caused chaos among addicts by going all Bottega Veneta with its limited edition Woven range. These shoes - basically baskets for the feet, hand-woven in elastic - have, if you believe reports, caused queues and catfights this last week at branches of Office affiliates Offspring and Poste among those desperate to part with £150 for something that looks like a criss-crossed bandage. The trainers, limited to 200 pairs per never-to-be-repeated colour worldwide, are available in two editions - brown/khaki or black and red.

Offspring is running low on stock, with only very small sizes left, and hoping for another batch within the month. Browns Focus has just taken delivery of stock which should, on optimistic estimates, last to the end of the week. And insiders are already aware that Pauric Sweeney's cult Hoxton boutique will stock the Woven when it opens in December. This frenzy isn't limited to the high street, presumably helped by the rumour that the Woven originated in the Comme des Garçons design studio. On e-bay, bidding stands at $699 for a pair in blue with grape and cream tones, a sale that is about to make its anonymous owner very happy.

But while a limited-edition piece from a high-fashion house can be timeless, trend trainers scream for immediate attention, and fade in covetability the second you see someone else in them. Meanwhile, the scrabble to get hold of the item stops shoppers from thinking about whether the product suits them or not.

So, while the BV weave looks sexy and second-hand made into bodices or bags, the cocoon shape of the Woven is not going to make any foot appear slender and elegant. Do you want to look as if you're in an orthopaedic shoe? No? Then think again about the Woven.

 Offspring and Poste enquiries, 020-7251 6646; Browns Focus, 020-7514 0064; Pauric Sweeney, 020 7253 5150

webTitle: Welcome back to the wonderful world of matching accessories

fields.headline: Get set
fields.standfirst: You're just not properly dressed these days unless your bag and shoes are a perfect match, says  Alice Wignall
fields.trailText: You're just not properly dressed these days unless your bag and shoes are a perfect match, says Alice Wignall.
fields.body:
Armani is doing it, Versace is doing it, Chanel, Dior and Moschino are doing it, which means that pretty soon you will be too. Welcome back to the wonderful world of matching accessories. And no, that doesn't mean match as in the same colour or picked to look good together. It means match, as in cut from the same cloth. As in having to do some serious shopping to replace all the shoes, bags and belts you can't wear anymore because they aren't part of a set.

For most women, the prospect of matching accessories holds about as much appeal as wearing whale-bone corsets and up until now has been about as cool. As a trend it is rigid, contrived and a royal pain to achieve. And who really wants to walk down the street looking like the kind of person who expends mental energy on getting their bits and pieces colour-coded? As a personality trait, it is up there with the alphabetised CD collection and ironed underpants.

But the thing is, it does make sense. If this season is all about looking perfectly put together you are not going to be able to make a look work by accessorising with one-off impulse buys and flea-market finds. No (in the minds of the designers, at least) there will be no more falling out of bed and into the nearest piece of distressed denim. It is groomed and glossy all the way, which means looking as if every inch of your outfit has been planned days in advance. Hazel Curry, buying manager for women's designer wear at Selfridges, London, agrees: "Everyone has heard about lady-like chic and the return of sophisticated tailoring and separates. Luxurious looks are often over the top while bourgeois opulence is key."

If you think that the only people who have the time for such close attention to detail are those ladies who lunch, and perhaps your mother or grandmother, you would be right. And guess where designers have been looking for inspiration? Forties and fifties-inspired tailored suits are on the must-have list, as are super deluxe, jet-set looks. It means looking fabulous from head to foot. Coco Chan, contemporary designer collections buyer at Harvey Nichols, thinks we will eventually learn to love matching accessories: "It's an important look. People enjoy looking co-ordinated and put together and if it doesn't reflect the person inside it certainly makes you feel together."

You may have spotted this trend coming. Think of the legions of girls-about-town in their wall-to-wall Louis Vuitton, or of Kate Moss and her supermodel chums sporting bags, belts and shoes of shiny, shimmery gold and diamante. Accessories have been making a statement for the last few seasons, to the extent that the finishing touches became more important than the outfit itself. Fendi baguettes, pashminas, Prada shoes, Burberry anything, all made a big fashion splash, and not one constituted what you might describe as a proper item of clothing. Since the world went designer-logo crazy last spring it has got worse. As Curry says: "I am now finding more demand than ever for accessories in the Selfridges fashion departments. The most obvious is Burberry, but even designers such as Helmut Lang or Alessandro dell'Aqua are producing matching shoe/bag combinations".

So, saving up for the right shoes is no longer enough, unless you can stretch to the right belt and bag. Perhaps that is the key to carrying off the whole look. Fashion editors will use words such as rich, wealthy, glitzy and glam to describe this season's offerings, but it all comes down to one thing: money. Look rich, act rich, be rich. As Hazel Curry points out: "If you've spent a fortune on this luxe look you want everyone to know about it."

Matching accessories are the concept made flesh: for every pair of shoes you fancy, you will be taking a bag, belt or scarf home. Clearly, the time and money which has to be invested in matching mean that the look is designed to be worn by people unfamiliar with the concept of a credit limit. So unless you can afford to go for the whole shebang, steer clear or wait until the chains offer good copies.

Coco Chan sees a trend: "It's obvious consumption, harking back to the 80s. Logos and monograms are still very important, as are colours that suggest wealth and richness: camels, winter whites, gold and deep berrytones."

So will it take off? Giorgio Armani certainly thinks so. His current accessories include court shoes, clutch bags and whippet-thin belts, designed to match. Versace, Dior and Chanel, among others, have followed suit, and made matching accessories a big part of their autumn/winter looks. It is never going to be especially hip or edgy to follow this fashion edict, because it shows how much you care, and that's not cool. But, strangely, for a look that is so clearly a result of one too many afternoons digging about in the fashion archives, it does feel fresh and modern.

Chan says: "I think we're all tired of running around in little girlie frocks and mules, with flower clips in our hair. It is very satisfying and a boost to the confidence to feel groomed yet womanly."

Curry thinks the look is going to do well."The high street has become so skilled at interpreting the latest looks that it is inevitable that this trend will become mainstream very quickly. Although it is not possible to recreate the logo look with real authenticity, the newer, polished, sleek styles are already being snapped up. I believe women will love the opportunity to become high maintenance."

But have we really spent the last few months falling in love with gorgeous snakeskin stilettos, just to forsake them now because we are required to have a gorgeous snakeskin belt as well? So repeat after me: "Beautiful bag - I'll take it. Have you got shoes to go with that?"

webTitle: Bioform bra

fields.headline: Bioform bra
fields.trailText: Unless you have been hiding under a rock for the past few weeks, you cannot have missed the hype surrounding the new Bioform bra from Charnos, billed as the ultimate innovation for the larger-busted woman.
fields.body:
Unless you have been hiding under a rock for the past few weeks, you cannot have missed the hype surrounding the new Bioform bra from Charnos, billed as the ultimate innovation for the larger-busted woman. Instead of an underwire it contains an armature moulded on to a soft polymer wing to support the breast. Charnos has invested £2m in its production, but is it really the miracle bra that women have been waiting for?

We asked nine volunteers, whose sizes ranged from 32D to 38F, to test the bra. All were measured by a Charnos fitter and were asked to wear the bra for three full days. Our testers hoped the Bioform would revolutionise their underwear, but it did not live up to expectations. Laura, 32F, was "constantly aware of the Bioform. At first I thought I just needed to get used to it, but by the third day I hadn't. I was increasingly conscious of it digging in."

Fiona, 38DD, said: "It was rather shelf-like and solid, and I felt very uncomfortable." And comfort is the main requirement for larger-busted women.

Seymour and Powell had identified an "ouch zone" under the arm where bra underwires frequently dig into the wearer; the Bioform's plastic wings were designed to alleviate this. However, our testers found the wings only created another problem. Sarah, 34E, said: "It did fit well but the worst thing had to be the plastic bits at the side. I felt like the bra was sitting on my ribs. At the end of the day I just wanted to take it off."

The bra provides impressive uplift, but this was inconvenient for Carol, 38DD: "While I want them to look smaller I don't want them jutting out. Wearing a tight-fitting jumper was like, 'Hello, have you met my breasts?' " Of course, for some wearers this could be a bonus.

Although our testers were not too impressed by the bra, they did concede that it offered the uplift that other bras could not. Bordering on corsetry, this bra will hold you in and up come what may, but as one tester said: "You're normally not particularly aware that you are wearing a bra, but in this one I was."

 The Bioform bra is available nationally in back size 32-42in and cup size B-H, in black or white, £35. Enquiries: 0115-8508080.

webTitle: Comment: Poor children are not a popular cause

fields.headline: Ladders to the good life
fields.standfirst: Poor children are not a popular cause. They need someone pushing them up the political agenda
fields.trailText: Poor children are not a popular cause. They need someone pushing them up the political agenda.
fields.body:
Money rains down on child poverty programmes so thick and fast it goes barely remarked these days. A total of £450m will be dispersed to children's charities, spelled out by the chancellor and David Blunkett at a conference this week. Another day, another scheme - the Tories pour scorn, preparing to axe social programmes they hope no one will notice or understand, to meet their tax-cutting promises at the next election.

This £450m is a hefty sum. It is for preventative projects for 5-13 year-olds, those left out by Sure Start for babies and Connexions for 13-18 year-olds. The list of charity projects includes the National Pyramid Trust, which runs 90 therapeutic Pyramid clubs for emotionally and socially deprived primary children to encourage them in school and avert disaster later. Baby Think Twice in Stevenage sends teenage mothers into schools to warn about what life with an unplanned baby is like. There are homework clubs and schemes for excluded children. Big Brothers and Sisters in Bristol sends young volunteers back into schools to mentor a pupil through exams. The money is for hundreds of good ideas that sprung up from local need, not devised in Whitehall.

This is cement filling in the cracks in the great wall of programmes that promise to abolish child poverty in 20 years and halve it in 10. How is the grand plan going? Labour inherited 4m poor children, measured by the EU standard of families living below half average earning. The shocking legacy of the Tory years was one in three children born poor: a third of all the poor children in Europe are born British.

So far, Labour has lifted a quarter of them out of poverty, partly through sharply rising employment, mainly through a phenomenal rise in benefits. It is curious how little these increases have entered into the national consciousness. With so much talk about "a hand-up, not a hand-out" and "work is the best welfare", there has been an assumption that all the money has gone to the "deserving" working poor on the working families tax credit and nothing much to the scroungers and shirkers on benefits. The fact is that children of unemployed families have kept pace: their income support has risen by 72% since 1997. Yet this is still, somehow, not the New Labour image, not their big story. They don't tell it often enough themselves, ambivalent, as ever, about who they are telling about what.

Gordon Brown made an emotional speech, peppered with talk of a "crusade against child poverty" and a "war" to end its "scourge and tragedy". Tucked away in this he said: "I am delighted that a broad-based coalition - an alliance for children - is coming together to fight child poverty." This is something he has devised and brought together himself, a much-needed single umbrella for the (too) many competing children's charities which often duplicate what they do, and waste money on competitively lurid fundraising.

But behind his plan is something much stranger. He wants the children's alliance to go out and with one voice raise public indignation at child poverty. He said himself it must "press government to accelerate the process of ending child poverty". He wants it to act like Jubilee 2000 which twisted his arm to take a lead in abolishing third world debt. In other words, he has himself created a pressure group designed to whip him from pillar to post until he does what he wants to do anyway.

Bizarre, says the Child Poverty Action group, who are also a part of the children's alliance. "Does he really know what he wants?" asks its director, Martin Barnes. When his group put out a press release mildly grateful for the chancellor's pre-budget largesse, but inevitably asking for more, a Treasury aide told him sourly it was "unhelpful". Yet the chancellor wants sharper critics? The alliance is as yet hesitant and unfledged, undecided whether it can unite or dare make political demands for poor children. It is sounding distinctly spineless.

The chancellor needs them because the abolition of child poverty will not happen unless the people will it. It has to shoot up the political agenda. The recent clamour on fuel bills and basic pensions show how money flows inevitably to where the noise is loudest. Who shouts loud enough for children? If child poverty was such a burning issue, would the Tories have been elected four times in a row with never a backward glance at how the ranks of the poor swelled?

Each tranche of poor children will be harder to reach. The next large group will be the children of single parents. When the new deal for lone parents rolls out next year, its high target is to get 70% into work, meeting the average for all mothers. (Only 49% of single mothers currently have jobs). That would take another 600,000 children out of poverty, almost hitting the 10-year target. What of the rest? Secretly it is whispered that in a full-employment world, when the great pool of people living a lifetime on benefits is gone, then greater generosity to those passing through relatively briefly is no political problem. More jobs and higher benefits mean no more poor children.

But the 20-year Jerusalem is far off. By then, the idea is, the generation of babies born under Labour will be rescued by each special programme, pass through better schools and end up ready for a life of success and better jobs. But to get there, they will need to grow up without a poverty that would cripple their chances.

Slice it whichever way, all this costs money that must be spent unfailingly in good times and in dips. When the clamour is all for new trains, or state-of-the-art cancer scanners or letting richer old people have free residential care, there has to be a persistent, strident voice saying, "No, poor children must come first". The truth is, they are not a popular cause. Children's charities have trouble showing them. If they look scruffy, the public is just reminded they have bad parents. Neat kids don't look poor.

This new alliance is needed and it has to be tough, political, savvy and negative. Negative about less worthy demands on the public purse, for example. Where were the lobbies confronting the lorries with placards reading "Children before diesel"? And negative about the government when it muffles its message on poverty - unsure whether it dares declare how much money is being spent, let alone how much more needed.

Gordon Brown has been looking across the Atlantic with a shudder. What if his booming prudence is discounted the way US voters dismissed the Democrat economy as if it were the weather? Many chose the glitter of trillions of tax cuts instead. Even if the children's alliance becomes a strong, vociferous lobby, in the end it is politicians who have to get out there and persuade the people: in the next election the abolition of poverty will slug it out against the abolition of poverty programmes.
