The shocking legacy of the Tory years was one in three children born poor: a third of all the poor children in Europe are born British. So far, Labour has lifted a quarter of them out of poverty, partly through sharply rising employment, mainly through a phenomenal rise in benefits. It is curious how little these increases have entered into the national consciousness. With so much talk about "a hand-up, not a hand-out" and "work is the best welfare", there has been an assumption that all the money has gone to the "deserving" working poor on the working families tax credit and nothing much to the scroungers and shirkers on benefits. The fact is that children of unemployed families have kept pace: their income support has risen by 72% since 1997. Yet this is still, somehow, not the New Labour image, not their big story. They don't tell it often enough themselves, ambivalent, as ever, about who they are telling about what. Gordon Brown made an emotional speech, peppered with talk of a "crusade against child poverty" and a "war" to end its "scourge and tragedy". Tucked away in this he said: "I am delighted that a broad-based coalition - an alliance for children - is coming together to fight child poverty." This is something he has devised and brought together himself, a much-needed single umbrella for the (too) many competing children's charities which often duplicate what they do, and waste money on competitively lurid fundraising. But behind his plan is something much stranger. He wants the children's alliance to go out and with one voice raise public indignation at child poverty. He said himself it must "press government to accelerate the process of ending child poverty". He wants it to act like Jubilee 2000 which twisted his arm to take a lead in abolishing third world debt. In other words, he has himself created a pressure group designed to whip him from pillar to post until he does what he wants to do anyway. Bizarre, says the Child Poverty Action group, who are also a part of the children's alliance. "Does he really know what he wants?" asks its director, Martin Barnes. When his group put out a press release mildly grateful for the chancellor's pre-budget largesse, but inevitably asking for more, a Treasury aide told him sourly it was "unhelpful". Yet the chancellor wants sharper critics? The alliance is as yet hesitant and unfledged, undecided whether it can unite or dare make political demands for poor children. It is sounding distinctly spineless. The chancellor needs them because the abolition of child poverty will not happen unless the people will it. It has to shoot up the political agenda. The recent clamour on fuel bills and basic pensions show how money flows inevitably to where the noise is loudest. Who shouts loud enough for children? If child poverty was such a burning issue, would the Tories have been elected four times in a row with never a backward glance at how the ranks of the poor swelled? Each tranche of poor children will be harder to reach. The next large group will be the children of single parents. When the new deal for lone parents rolls out next year, its high target is to get 70% into work, meeting the average for all mothers. (Only 49% of single mothers currently have jobs). That would take another 600,000 children out of poverty, almost hitting the 10-year target. What of the rest? Secretly it is whispered that in a full-employment world, when the great pool of people living a lifetime on benefits is gone, then greater generosity to those passing through relatively briefly is no political problem. More jobs and higher benefits mean no more poor children. But the 20-year Jerusalem is far off. By then, the idea is, the generation of babies born under Labour will be rescued by each special programme, pass through better schools and end up ready for a life of success and better jobs. But to get there, they will need to grow up without a poverty that would cripple their chances. Slice it whichever way, all this costs money that must be spent unfailingly in good times and in dips. When the clamour is all for new trains, or state-of-the-art cancer scanners or letting richer old people have free residential care, there has to be a persistent, strident voice saying, "No, poor children must come first". The truth is, they are not a popular cause. Children's charities have trouble showing them. If they look scruffy, the public is just reminded they have bad parents. Neat kids don't look poor. This new alliance is needed and it has to be tough, political, savvy and negative. Negative about less worthy demands on the public purse, for example. Where were the lobbies confronting the lorries with placards reading "Children before diesel"? And negative about the government when it muffles its message on poverty - unsure whether it dares declare how much money is being spent, let alone how much more needed. Gordon Brown has been looking across the Atlantic with a shudder. What if his booming prudence is discounted the way US voters dismissed the Democrat economy as if it were the weather? Many chose the glitter of trillions of tax cuts instead. Even if the children's alliance becomes a strong, vociferous lobby, in the end it is politicians who have to get out there and persuade the people: in the next election the abolition of poverty will slug it out against the abolition of poverty programmes. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: New court decision favours Bush

fields.headline: New court decision favours Bush
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: A key court decision in Florida this afternoon has boosted George W Bush's chances of winning the presidency by ruling that the state does not have to accept the results of hand counts of votes currently underway in two heavily Democratic parts of the state.
fields.body:
A key court decision in Florida this afternoon has boosted George W Bush's chances of winning the presidency by ruling that the state does not have to accept the results of hand counts of votes currently underway in two heavily Democratic parts of the state.

Democrats had asked Leon county circuit judge Terry Lewis to bar final certification of the Florida vote until recounts in Palm Beach and Broward counties are complete. However the judge found that in deciding to impose a deadline, Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, had "exercised her reasoned judgement".

Al Gore's campaign will appeal against the ruling, and can draw comfort from yesterday's decision by a higher court to allow recounts to continue in defiance of the deadline.

However the verdict means that Ms Harris will almost certainly attempt to declare a winner in the state tomorrow, when remaining overseas votes have been counted. Democrats expect the overseas votes to favour George W Bush, who is currently ahead in Florida by 300 votes.

Should the recounts continue after tomorrow's declaration and put Al Gore ahead, his campaign will continue its court battle to have them included in the state's official results.

webTitle: The Blind Assassin by  Margaret Atwood

fields.headline: The Blind Assassin by  Margaret Atwood
fields.standfirst:
Bloomsbury £16.99. Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The innocent but all-too-knowing Iris Chase trawls through her family history in a sort of prewar Aga saga
fields.body:
My sister, Laura, drove her car off a bridge in 1945. The police said someone had seen her deliberately swerve; I told them it was an accident. Out of respect for my husband, Richard, they believed me. Who knows where to find the hurt?

The Blind Assassin by Laura Chase

She took off into the night to find him among the anonymous apartments in the tenement district. He pulled her close. "We haven't much time," he insisted. "Tell me a story," she replied. So he started to tell her of the city of Sakiel-Norn, the sacrificial virgins and the blind assassin. Laura has become a cult writer since her book was published after her death.

Scholars ask me for details. I give them none. My parents married in 1914. She gave him class, he gave her money. He was never the same after he came back to Port Ticonderoga from the war. He drank too much, but was still loyal to the men in his button factory. I was born in 1916, Laura in 1920. My mother died after a miscarriage. That changed everything.

My father had a bohemian friend, Callista, who came to give him comfort. She once introduced us to Alex Thomas; he was a revolutionary. He was later accused of bombing my father's factory, but Laura and I hid him. Laura was fond of him. I expect you might guess who the characters in Laura's book really are now.

The depression hit my father hard. "I think you should marry Richard Griffen," he said. "Laura needs looking after." I didn't love him but had no choice. Richard took me hard on our wedding night; he liked it like that. He never told me father had died till we got back from honeymoon. "Laura's unwell," he said. "I've put her in a sanatorium." I had lost her. I gave birth to Aimee; she didn't look anything like Richard. Can you guess the story now? Help me, because this is difficult.

Alex and I are the lovers in the book. I wrote it under Laura's name. I once thought that she and Alex were lovers, too. But their love was different. Her pain was not of Alex's making. She had regularly been abused by Richard.

You didn't leave your husband then. I did, and I paid for it. Aimee was taken away and I've lived in poverty since. I'm now an old woman. I don't ask for love or understanding. Just your time.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested É

webTitle: Arrested butler suspended from royal service

fields.headline: Arrested butler suspended from royal service
fields.trailText: Princess Margaret's butler was suspended from royal service yesterday after being arrested by police in London investigating the disappearance of a £1m wedding gift given to Princess Diana and the Prince of Wales.
fields.body:
A former butler to Princess Diana was suspended from royal service yesterday after being arrested by police in London investigating the disappearance of a £1m wedding gift given to her and the Prince of Wales.

The large, jewel-bedecked gold miniature of an Arab dhow given by the Emir of Bahrain in 1981 is understood to have disappeared from the princess's apartment at Kensington Palace in the aftermath of her death in 1997, and to have been recently submitted to the London art dealer Spink and Son for valuation.

Harold Brown, 48, in royal service for 30 years and currently butler to Princess Margaret, is understood to have been questioned at Charing Cross police station and released on bail. He will return for further questioning next week.

Another man not employed by the royal family, was also arrested and questioned this week on suspicion of handling stolen goods, and is on bail.

A Scotland Yard spokesman yesterday said an organised crime unit sqaud was investigating "the circumstances of the alleged disappearance of an artefact from a location in central London".

Mr Brown worked for Prince Charles and then following his marriage, for the royal couple. After their divorce he stayed with Princess Diana but was made redundant and became butler to Princess Margaret.

The model dhow, valued at £500,000 at the time of the wedding, remained on display at the palace following the divorce but is thought to have disappeared in the aftermath of Princess Diana's death.

It is understood the model - or one very similar - was removed from display at Spink and Son where it was being offered for sale.

webTitle: News anchors criticised in American election coverage

fields.headline: Hewitt renews attack on US news anchors
fields.standfirst: Nov 16: Hewitt slams US news anchors
fields.trailText:
2pm: Don Hewitt, executive producer of 60 Minutes, has renewed his attack on the three main news anchors on the US networks, reports Jessica Hodgson.

Nov 16: Hewitt slams US news anchors
Nov 16: Hewitt slams US news anchors
fields.body:
Don Hewitt, executive producer of 60 Minutes, has renewed his attack on the three main news anchors on the US networks, Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather.

Speaking at a Newsworld session on the presidential election coverage, Mr Hewitt launched a scathing attack on the role of television in US politics.

"We're turning the election into a television show," he warned. "[News anchors] should stop being the ringmasters of this circus."

Of the symbiotic relationship between politics and TV in the US, Mr Hewitt said: "Somebody's got to put a stop to it. In the so-called biggest democracy in the world, the biggest criteria is your ability to buy TV space."

Earlier in the week, he condemned the growth of "presenter-led" current affairs, laying the blame on the three anchors, and suggesting that a pooled news service for the three largest US news networks, CBS, ABC and NBC would help eliminate the growth of the cult of personality.

webTitle: Railtrack's statement on Gerald Corbett's resignation

fields.headline: Railtrack's statement on Gerald Corbett's resignation
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack plc
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Board of Railtrack announced today that it had, with regret, accepted the resignation of chief executive Gerald Corbett. Mr Corbett will step down from his post today.
fields.body:
The Board of Railtrack announced today that it had, with regret, accepted the resignation of chief executive Gerald Corbett. Mr Corbett will step down from his post today.

The board would like to place on record its thanks to Mr Corbett for the way in which he had managed the immediate aftermath of the Hatfield accident and had overseen the establishment of the network recovery plan.

Mr Corbett felt, and the board agreed, that having put in place the national recovery plan, the time was now right for someone fresh to lead the company forward.

Railtrack chairman Sir Philip Beck said: "The directors would like to thank Gerald for his enormous contribution to the company. Through his leadership, energy and enthusiasm the company has made major steps forward.

"In accepting his resignation the board has recognised that the time is now right for someone fresh to lead the company forward."

Steven Marshall, currently finance director, has been appointed chief executive with immediate effect. Mr Marshall joined Railtrack a year ago from Thorn where he held the position of chief executive.

Recognising the significant operational challenges that the company faces Jonson Cox, director of operations, becomes chief operating officer.

Sebastian Bull, currently corporate finance director, will assume the role of acting finance director. He will join the group committee and attend future board meetings.

The chairman, Sir Philip Beck, has asked the board to commence a search for a new non executive chairman, with substantial experience in leading a major public company, to take up the post following the annual general meeting in 2001.

Sir Philip Beck said: "Our new chief executive Steve Marshall brings a proven track record and a broad commercial and business experience from a number of customer focused companies. Prior to joining Railtrack a year ago, Steve was chief executive of Thorn plc. "Railtrack faces a challenging agenda and the Board has great confidence in Steve and the management team to deliver added value for stakeholders, while meeting our public service obligations."

webTitle: Railtrack chief quits

fields.headline: Railtrack chief quits
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett finally resigned today, a month after offering to step down in the wake of the Hatfield train derailment.
fields.body:
Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett finally resigned today, a month after offering to step down in the wake of the Hatfield train derailment.

The Railtrack board said it had "with regret" accepted Mr Corbett's resignation and that Steven Marshall, currently finance director, had been appointed chief executive with immediate effect.

In a statement, the company said that Mr Corbett felt, and the board agreed, that having put in place a national recovery plan after the Hatfield crash "the time was now right for someone fresh to lead the company forward".

Speaking outside Railtrack's London offices, Mr Corbett said his job was done. He said that he had been able to present a recovery plan to Tony Blair at yesterday's rail summit at Downing Street and was now "confident that Railtrack will deliver it."

Mr Corbett said that his resignation was for personal reasons and he was now looking forward to going on holiday to India, spending time with his family and perhaps trying to lose a little bit of weight.

"It is a demanding job, an important job and it has been a privilege to do it for three years," he said.

Mr Corbett, 49, first offered to stand down on October 18, a day after the Hatfield crash, in which four passengers were killed. But the Railtrack directors refused to accept his resignation and Mr Corbett stayed on to oversee a major programme of track repairs which has brought severe disruptions to the national network.

The Hatfield crash is thought to have been caused by a cracked rail on a high speed section of the main east coast line. The defect had been known about, but not repaired.

Railtrack chairman Sir Philip Beck thanked Mr Corbett for his contribution to the company.

"Through his leadership, energy and enthusiasm the company has made major steps forward," he said.

fields.trailText: Reaction to Gerald Corbett's resignation
fields.body:
Paddington survivor Pam Warren

"If he's gone, he's gone. We will still continue."

George Muir, director general of the association of train operating companies

"Gerald Corbett brought energy and dynamism to the rail industry. He achieved a great deal during his time as chief executive."

Louise Christian, a solicitor representing passengers in the Southall and Paddington crashes

"I know the bereaved families will welcome it. They felt he had nothing to offer." He talked to the press about 'thinking the unthinkable'. But when he gave evidence, he talked in euphemisms and cliches"

Mick Rix, Aslef general secretary

"Aslef welcomes Mr Corbett's resignation. We welcomed it the first time he made it and believe it should have been accepted then. Certainly everything Railtrack has done over the last few weeks has been cutting the throat of the railway industry."

Gerald Corbett

"In the last few weeks my own profile has been far too high for my own good, my family's good and also for the company's good."

webTitle: Bush and Gore may meet again

fields.headline: Bush and Gore may meet again
fields.standfirst:
It is more than likely that George W Bush and Al Gore will face each other in the 2004 US electoral contest - again, writes Martin Kettle
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: View from Washington: It is more than likely that George W Bush and Al Gore will face each other in the 2004 US electoral contest - again, writes Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
Enjoying America's 2000 election drama, but worrying what will be left in your life when it ends? Then fear not. Look forward instead to Cliffhanger II. Because the longer this year's disputed presidential contest continues, the more likely it becomes that the United States can look forward to a George W Bush-Al Gore rematch in 2004.

As the battle for Florida plays itself out - and it's certainly not over yet - some politicians and pundits are already beginning to look ahead to the next presidential election in four years' time. There is no shortage of experts to suggest that Mr Bush, who is only 54, and Mr Gore, a mere 52, could be scrapping it out again.

"Before election night or the next morning, I would have said the chances for a rematch were zero, that the loser would be quickly forgotten. But we're in a different world now," the political scientist Norman Ornstein said the other day.

We certainly are. The key to the new post-election dynamic would be that the eventual winner would be seen by half the country as the man who stole the White House. While the eventual loser will be seen as a martyr.

If Mr Bush wins, then Mr Gore will be the first man since 1888 to win the popular vote in a presidential election and yet lose the presidency. If Mr Gore wins, capturing Florida's 25 electoral college votes at the end of a succession of court challenges and recounts, then it will be Mr Bush's to claim "we wuz robbed".

So a rematch is now becoming the talk of Washington. The theory depends upon the loser bowing out gracefully, in a manner which would win him public gratitude for his concession while solidifying party support around him as the frontrunner for the 2004 battle. But heavyweights in both parties are already predicting a second Bush-Gore contest.

"Obviously, so much can happen between now and then. But you'd have to assume the presumptive nominee would be whoever lost this election. I can't imagine anyone else having a better claim at this stage," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the leader of his party in the US Senate.

"I'd watch for a rematch with these gentlemen, absolutely. If the loser goes out in a dignified manner, he's be a shoo-in for his party's nomination in four years," said Scott Reed, who was Bob Dole's campaign manager against Bill Clinton in the 1996 presidential election.

Another argument in favour of a rematch, some believe, is that the situation in the Senate and House of Representatives is now so evenly balanced that the winning candidate will have enormous difficulty in getting any major legislation carried. In those circumstances, the loser would be able to rally his supporters behind the call for a change at the top.

"This is going to be a very difficult four years for either Al Gore or George Bush to govern. The economy likely will slow. Neither will have a sense of a mandate. It is bound to cause problems for the incumbent party," said Senator Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, a Democrat.

"The loser will have millions of people nursing that grievance for four years, and that will prove invaluable," said Professor Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia.

"There's a lot of folks who say [that], in the longer term, we would be better if we lost," said one Republican who did not want to be named.

"The presidential honeymoon could be a one-night stand," said another.

There are precedents on both sides of the argument. Two-term presidents such as Andrew Jackson and Richard Nixon both recovered from losing a presidential election to claim the White House. On the other hand, other close losers have just faded into the background, like Thomas Dewey or Jimmy Carter.

There's another point of view, of course. If Mr Gore loses, he will have lost as an incumbent at a time of peace and great prosperity. That would be seen by many as an unpardonable failure that disqualifies Mr Gore from having a second run.

fields.bodyText: Enjoying America's 2000 election drama, but worrying what will be left in your life when it ends? Then fear not. Look forward instead to Cliffhanger II. Because the longer this year's disputed presidential contest continues, the more likely it becomes that the United States can look forward to a George W Bush-Al Gore rematch in 2004. As the battle for Florida plays itself out - and it's certainly not over yet - some politicians and pundits are already beginning to look ahead to the next presidential election in four years' time. There is no shortage of experts to suggest that Mr Bush, who is only 54, and Mr Gore, a mere 52, could be scrapping it out again. "Before election night or the next morning, I would have said the chances for a rematch were zero, that the loser would be quickly forgotten. If Mr Gore wins, capturing Florida's 25 electoral college votes at the end of a succession of court challenges and recounts, then it will be Mr Bush's to claim "we wuz robbed". So a rematch is now becoming the talk of Washington. webTitle: Using and abusing the law in Putin's Russia

fields.headline: Using and abusing the law in Putin's Russia
fields.standfirst: As the soap opera over ownership of Russia's two main television channels rolls on, Ian Traynor looks at the main victim of the affair - the law
fields.trailText: As the soap opera over ownership of Russia's two main television channels rolls on, Ian Traynor looks at the main victim of the affair - the law
fields.body:
Mikhail Lesin has a starring role in the endless soap opera over who will ultimately control Russia's two main television channels - the Kremlin or extremely wealthy ''disloyal oligarchs''.

One of the most telling incidents illustrating the realities of contemporary political life in Russia occurred a few weeks ago, with Mr Lesin, minister for the media, again taking centre stage.

He had just put his signature to a deal guaranteeing Vladimir Gusinsky, the media mogul and Kremlin foe, immunity from prosecution in return for agreement to surrender control of his media empire.

News of the arrangement sparked uproar and the Kremlin had to go through the motions of upbraiding the media minister. Not that he would have to resign, of course, after flagrantly interfering with the judicial process and deploying the law as a political instrument.

Instead Mr Lesin was punished publicly, if lightly, at a cabinet meeting, with the relevant bits televised and shown to the nation. Like an errant schoolboy caught passing smutty messages to the girls at the next desks, Mr Lesin was ordered to stand up before the rest of the cabinet class while the head teacher and prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, issued his rebuke.

Head bowed in contrition, Mr Lesin waited to be branded a dunce and ordered to stand in the corner with his face to the wall. Instead, Mr Kasyanov ended his sermon, then issued a peremptory ''now, sit down'' to the naughty minister who did as he was told.

It was an extraordinary piece of political theatre, a staged display of power, deference, and flouting of the law. Not that Mr Lesin's signature was worth much, anyway. This week the prosecutor's office issued an arrest warrant for Mr Gusinsky after he failed to show up for questioning about fraud.

All the same, that a government minister could sign a pledge guaranteeing immunity from prosecution in return for a business deal illustrates the uses and abuses to which the law is put in Russia.

Vladimir Putin came to the Russian presidency earlier this year pledging to establish ''a dictatorship of the law'' and a level legal playing field in a culture where the prosecutor's office, the courts, and the police have long been toys in the hands of the politicians.

On paper Russia is a law-based state. But then Stalin's Soviet Union was privileged to enjoy one of the most democratic constitutions ever written.

The Lesin signature, which could not have been written without the nod from the Kremlin, strongly suggests that Mr Putin is less than keen to see the laws of the land observed. Either that or he is too weak to do much about it.

Sergei Pashin, a Moscow judge and a liberal who has toiled down the years to introduce jury trials in Russia and correct rampant miscarriages of justice, has just been fired for defending a conscientious objector and getting up the noses of his colleagues.

When the Kremlin recently needed to appoint a loyalist Chechen mayor of the destroyed Chechen capital, Grozny, it opted for Bislan Gantemirov, a convicted fraudster.

The last time Gantemirov held the post, he was jailed for embezzling millions in Chechen reconstruction funds. The Putin team let him out of jail last year because they thought he could be useful to them in the Chechnya war.

Mr Putin's own choice of language repeatedly shows scant regard for the law. He talks of ''taking a cudgel'' to the likes of Mr Gusinsky or the other enemy media magnate, Boris Berezovsky. He branded Andrei Babitsky, the fearless Radio Liberty journalist operating in Chechnya, a ''terrorist''.

Some of Mr Putin's past actions, too, suggest a less than scrupulous attitude to the law. Earlier in his career when his boss Anatoliy Sobchak, the late mayor of St Petersburg, was wanted for questioning, Mr Putin personally organised the mayor's escape first to Finland then France.

When the Kremlin wanted rid of a prosecutor-general investigating corruption in the Boris Yeltsin entourage, Mr Putin, then domestic intelligence chief, personally presented the law officer with a clandestinely filmed video purporting to show the prosecutor romping in bed with prostitutes. The video was then given to loyal state television and broadcast to the entire country.

The prosecutor, Yuriy Skuratov, is long gone, his place taken by a Putin loyalist. Mr Lesin remains in the cabinet.

Mr Gusinsky and Mr Berezovsky, fabulously wealthy and unsavoury businessmen who are the unlikeliest of martyrs in the cause of press freedom, are in exile abroad, fearful of coming home because the last thing they expect in Vladimir Putin's Russia is a fair trial.

webTitle: Unity through intifada and satellite TV

fields.headline: Unity through intifada and satellite TV
fields.standfirst: From London to the Gulf, the intifada has given the Islamic world the sense of belonging they have spent years trying to achieve by other means, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: From London to the Gulf, the intifada has given the Islamic world the sense of belonging they have spent years trying to achieve by other means, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
I have a Moroccan friend in London who watches satellite TV mainly for the football. He's not much interested in politics or religion. Well, not usually.

Last weekend he didn't go out at all but spent most of the time watching live broadcasts from Qatar of the Islamic summit's debate on Palestine, occasionally shouting encouragement to the speakers, much as he does when his favourite team is playing badly.

Satellite television is what makes this intifada different from all previous Arab-Israeli conflicts. It is not just the sheer volume of coverage, nor the ability to see events almost as they happen, but how near it makes the conflict seem.

From Morocco to the Gulf, the war is happening in people's homes, and at times it's difficult to remember that the latest rocket attack on Bethlehem is not actually happening a few miles away in the next village.

The appetite to know more, and to absorb every detail, also appears insatiable.

I have watched people watching television in Yemen, in Jordan and in Egypt, and it's always the same. The moment the ads come on, or one programme about the intifada finishes, they flick through the channels to find another.

In just six weeks, the intifada has given Arabs, and the wider Islamic world, the sense of belonging and of common purpose that they have spent years trying to achieve by other means.

Along with this, there is also frustration. Everybody wants to do something. The question is what.

This is particularly worrying for Arab leaders, who risk losing credibility and (since most of them are not democratically elected) legitimacy if they fail to take action.

Although many people still doubt that Arabs and Muslims will ever get their act together, there are signs that something is stirring.

The first important change is that much of the old defeatism has gone; instead there's an awareness that Arabs and Muslims, collectively, have the potential to influence events.

"If Muslim countries pooled their vast resources together there would be no need to fight Israel, to engage in military operations against it, or to cry 'we will push Israel into the sea'," the Iranian President, Mohammed Khatami, remarked during the Islamic summit.

The second change is that a strategy is beginning to emerge which recognises that the key to a solution lies not in Israel but in the United States.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, unwittingly highlighted this earlier in the week when he paid tribute to President Bill Clinton. "The United States of America has been Israel's best friend and safe harbour in an often unfriendly international sea," he said.

But the US cannot remain Israel's best friend and, at the same time, serve as an honest broker in the peace process. Peace will come when the US realises that.

Although the resolutions of the 22-member Arab summit in Cairo and the 56-member Islamic summit in Doha have been widely dismissed as rhetoric, they do contain some practical measures which, if pursued seriously, could cause the Americans some embarrassment over the contradictions in their policy.

The calls for war crimes prosecutions and for an international presence in the occupied territories highlight two areas where (along with observance of UN Security Council resolutions) the US applies different rules to Israel than to most other countries.

But a more effective way to influence the US may be through its pocket. American businesses don't want their activities to be hampered by American foreign policy. The world's 1.2bn Muslims are a huge market and, of course, there's Middle Eastern oil which is vital to the US economy.

So far, little serious thought has been given to what can be done in the economic area, but one of the interesting things about it is that there is scope for action by individuals and small groups, as well as governments.

Last weekend a combination of Arabs and Israeli peace activists pressured the American car giant, General Motors, by fax and email over its sponsorship of a conference being held in an Israeli settlement. This seems to have worried General Motors, though it's unclear whether it actually withdrew its sponsorship.

Last Wednesday at the Central London Mosque, the International Muslim Rights Forum launched a campaign for an Islamic boycott of American goods which, they say, will continue until action is taken over war crimes.

The list targets 18 well-known companies and products: Ariel, AT&T, Chrysler, Citibank, Coca Cola, Estee Lauder, Fanta, Ford, General Motors, Levi, Marlboro, Maxwell House, McDonalds, Pampers, Revlon, Sprite, TWA and Wrangler. If that doesn't work, they say boldly, the next item to be added to the list will be the dollar itself.

Privately, the organisers admit there are difficulties. One of them told me afterwards that McDonalds burger bars are a franchise and in the Gulf they are often owned by members of the royal family who don't like having their premises picketed.

Such campaigns may be hopelessly over-ambitious but, in the current climate of opinion, nobody can say with certainty that they are doomed. And imagine the effect if one actually succeeded in catching the public's imagination.

Another point to bear in mind is that America's "best friend" policy towards Israel may actually be more fragile than it looks.

The policy began in the days of the Cold War, when Israel was seen as a bulwark against communism. That provided some justification for making Israel the world's largest recipient of US aid.

Today, the argument no longer holds good - though American politicians and public opinion have not caught up with it yet. The communist threat has gone, and the US has plenty of friends and allies in the Arab world - Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia among the most important of them.

In the meantime, the relationship with Israel is more of a hindrance to the US than a help. Connivance at Israel's non-compliance with UN resolutions complicates every attempt by the US to get other countries to comply with similar resolutions.

In the biggest recent test - the war with Iraq - Israel's value as a strategic asset was nil. Despite the billions of dollars poured into Israel over the years, the Americans had to spend more money to stop it joining in and wrecking the anti-Iraq alliance.

The reality now is that US policy towards Israel is not helping to create stability in the Middle East, but instability.

Sooner or later Americans will ask whether that is a reasonable price to pay for the support of Israeli claims over one square kilometre of land in Jerusalem and 200,000 settlers in the occupied territories.

webTitle: Scottish learning disability plans make slow progress

fields.headline: Scottish learning disability plans make slow progress
fields.standfirst: Learning disability agencies in Scotland are frustrated that promises to transform the country's services have not been followed through quickly enough, writes David Mitchell
fields.trailText: Learning disability agencies in Scotland are frustrated that promises to transform the country's services have not been followed through quickly enough, writes David Mitchell
fields.body:
Agencies working with people with learning disabilities had every reason to be cheerful when the Scottish executive unveiled a radical blueprint for developing services over the next 10 years. Yet six months on, very little seems to have happened.

Scotland's first review of learning disability services for more than 20 years set a deadline for closing all long-stay hospitals by 2005, proposed a "change fund" to help local authorities and health boards implement the review and promised direct payments to allow people to buy their own services by 2003.

Other key recommendations in The Same As You? review were:
 co-ordinators to support people in the community;
 establishing a Scottish centre for learning disabilities; and
 personal life plans for everyone who wants one

Personal life plans, which describe how people with learning disabilities, their family and professionals can work together to create a fuller life, will replace existing community care assessments.

The plans will set out personal assessed care needs including:
 short breaks for the person or their carer;
 meaningful work or other opportunities during the day;
 further education;
 housing and transport needs; and
 how each of these should be met

Apart from confirming the hospital closure deadline, there has been little progress on the plans. Tenders for setting up the Scottish centre for learning disabilities were only invited in October and no firm plans have materialised, despite a spending commitment of £36m over three years to help local authorities develop services.

Norman Dunning, director of Scotland's largest learning disabilities charity, Enable, says an implementation plan is urgently needed. "There is quite a lot of frustration because we haven't seen any action yet. It is a very good review, with lots of good ideas, but it is in grave danger of losing momentum. We need a definite statement of how much is going to be in the pot. We would also like to see ongoing expenditure on learning disability services in Scotland - currently £54 per head - at least brought in line with England at £59 per head."

For Enable, the review is a major step forward but it fears priority will be given to people leaving institutions at the expense of those already living in the community. "It's scandalous that hospital closures have moved so slowly in Scotland, so we're delighted to see a firm date for their end. But there are also too few opportunities for adults currently living with their families to achieve the ordinary step of independence," says Dunning.

Another concern is over plans for local registers of adults and children with learning disabilities as part of "partnership in practice" agreements between local authorities and health boards. Enable's consultation showed that, while carers saw it as a necessary evil, people with learning disabilities themselves didn't want a register. "Nobody is enthusiastic about it, and there must be proper safeguards, but if it is a way of getting resources then maybe it has to be there," concedes Dunning.

Social work directors, too, are concerned about the apparent lack of progress. "We welcomed this review as having a very positive influence on improving the quality of life for people with learning disabilities and their carers. But there does now appear to be this gap and it is important to have a clear implementation plan," says Kate Pryde, spokesperson for the Association of Directors of Social Work (ADSW).

ADSW is also seeking clarification over the plans to set up and maintain registers of people with learning disabilities, which it warns will require extra resources. "Does being on a register entitle people to services? If the intention is to develop a planning tool then this should be made explicit to families and carers," says Pryde.

One of the review's recommendations calls on the Scottish Society for Autism to work with the National Autistic Society, health boards and local authorities to develop a Scotland-wide network for people with autistic spectrum disorder.

Donald Liddell, chief executive of the Scottish Society for Autism, sees this as a milestone. "We feel enormously encouraged by it. "We are now beginning to prepare an action plan for early in the new year, so that local authorities can make use of the money which will be available from April. webTitle: 'We can change the future,' Clinton tells Vietnamese

fields.headline: 'We can change the future,' Clinton tells Vietnamese
fields.standfirst: Clinton plays diplomat, tourist and historic peacemaker in historic visit
fields.trailText: Standing in what was an enemy capital until 25 years ago, President Bill Clinton told the Vietnamese people that the United States joins with them in honouring the sacrifices of war so that "a painful past can be redeemed in a peaceful and prosperous future".
fields.body:
Standing in what was an enemy capital until 25 years ago, President Bill Clinton told the Vietnamese people that the United States joins with them in honouring the sacrifices of war so that "a painful past can be redeemed in a peaceful and prosperous future".

To a communist nation still suspicious of the West, Clinton pleaded for a more open Vietnamese society and economy.

He said the new generation deserves "the chance to live in your tomorrows, not our yesterdays."

"We cannot change the past," said the first American president to come to Vietnam since the war's end. "What we can change is the future."

In an unprecedented act, the authorities broadcast his speech live. His immediate audience was mostly students at Vietnam National University listening to a translation through earphones.

Passers-by along Hanoi's Hai Ba Trung street, a stretch of TV and stereo shops, stopped to watch - at least a few at every shop, over a dozen at some.

Clinton was first the diplomat, then the tourist, then the campaigner, grasping hands in the sidewalk crowd along Van Mieu Street after a walk around the walled grounds of the Temple of Literature, a 1,000-year-old museum, once a university dedicated to literature and philosophy.

But his high point came in talking at the university, where he cautiously tried an occasional phrase in Vietnamese. His wife and daughter sat in the audience.

In urging a more open Vietnamese trading economy and society, Clinton acknowledged that no one can force change on a nation determined to make its own decisions - a nation that fought off the United States when it tried to block communism here.

Speaking of the long war he opposed and avoided by manoeuvring around the draft three decades ago, Clinton said the suffering shared by Americans and Vietnamese alike in the war "has given our countries a relationship unlike any others".

The pain, he said, is shared through the 1 million Americans of Vietnamese ancestry, the 3 million US veterans and others who served here during the conflict, and "are forever connected to your country".

"Finally, America is coming to see Vietnam as your people have asked for years, as a country, not a war," Clinton said. He said it is a country "emerging from years of conflict and uncertainty to shape a bright future."

Clinton urged that it be a future built on free trade - and also on freedoms restricted by the communist regime. On the red carpeted stage behind him was a larger-than-life bust of the man who personified that regime and the American defeat of 1975 while he lived, Ho Chi Minh.

The president said the knowledge to be gained on campuses like Hanoi's will be vital in the future of globalization of economies, and so will the freedom to explore, travel, think, speak, worship and dissent.

"All this makes our country stronger in good times and in bad," Clinton said. "We do not seek to impose these ideals, nor should we. Vietnam is an ancient and enduring country."

"You have proved to the world that you will make your own decisions," he said. But his words were a summons to turn away from the barriers of the communist way.

"Let us continue to help each other heal the wounds of war, not by forgetting... but by embracing the spirit of reconciliation," he said.

War veteran Nguyen Van Kich, 67, said the speech was "very interesting. He talked about the past, but also talked about a better future for our relationship."

But Le Thanh Hai, a 40-year-old physician, thought Clinton should have said more about US forces' use of the chemical defoliant Agent Orange during the war.

Clinton started his trip at the mustard-yellow presidential palace just beyond the giant mausoleum memorial to Ho. A bust of Ho was the dominant feature of the ornate room where President Tran Duc Luong welcomed Clinton.

"I'm glad to be here," said Clinton, who arrived late Thursday night. "I'm looking forward to building toward the future."

The two leaders posed for photographs, then sat together briefly in a first exchange of pleasantries. "I've been very moved by the friendliness of the people on the streets," Clinton told Luong. "It is a very good omen for our relationship."

Clinton conferred privately with Luong, then the two presidents watched as US ambassador Pete Peterson and Vietnamese officials signed an agreement for co-operation in science and technology, including efforts to control AIDS and other diseases. They also signed a memorandum on labour co-operation, for worker safety, dealing with the disabled, skills training and other points.

The Vietnamese told Clinton they will sign an international convention aimed at curbing child labour abuses, White House Press Secretary Jake Siewert said.

The state-run People's Army newspaper said in an editorial Friday that the visit bode well.

"The Vietnamese people have built and developed relations with the US that look forward to the future, not to repeat the painful pages of the war," it said.

webTitle: Scots to set council tax rates for three years at a time

fields.headline: Scots to set council tax rates for three years at a time
fields.trailText: Scots to set council tax rates for three years at a time 12.30pm: The Scottish executive has called on local authorities to offer stability in council tax rates in return for greater freedom in setting council tax levels, writes Simon Parker.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has called on local authorities to offer stability in council tax rates in return for greater freedom in setting council tax levels.

The executive has promised to scrap spending guidelines for councils and replace them with three-year grant allocations.

The guidelines set upper limits on council spending, and their abolition has been welcomed by Scottish authorities. In return, councils will have to set their council tax levels over a three year period. The two moves are intended to ensure greater stability for local authorities and council tax payers.

However, the executive has warned that it expects authorities to show restraint in setting their council tax and ministers will retain the power to cap spending.

Scottish finance and local government minister Angus MacKay said: "This will give councils the resources, the stability and the flexibility they need to deliver better services for our citizens. And it will improve the accountability of councils to their council tax payers."

The executive claims these changes are the most radical in almost 20 years. It has also set out proposals for a simpler formula for distributing council funding.

Although Scottish ministers have yet to agree on a methodology, they have confirmed that councils will receive a guaranteed minimum increase in their grant over the next three years. Authorities will learn how large the increase will be and how it will be apportioned when the executive announces individual council grants early next month.

A Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) spokeswoman said: "The lifting of guidelines is an excellent move, and indicates the emphasis on outcomes rather than inputs in local government generally."

The convention has been heavily involved in putting together the reforms, which are based on a series of recommendations made by a joint executive/Cosla working group set up earlier this year.

webTitle: Berlin wall rebuilt for Brad Pitt's new film

fields.headline: Berlin wall rebuilt for Brad Pitt's new film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Michael Douglas takes a chance on up-and-coming Brittany Murphy before tying the knot with Catherine Zeta Jones this weekend; Laura Linney joins Richard Gere in ghostly story; Harry Knowles in a lava over casting from Scooby Doo film
fields.trailText: Plus: Michael Douglas takes a chance on up-and-coming Brittany Murphy before tying the knot with Catherine Zeta Jones this weekend; Laura Linney joins Richard Gere in ghostly story; Harry Knowles in a lava over casting from Scooby Doo film
fields.body:
 You know you're an A-list star when the Berlin Wall is rebuilt for your latest role. Ananova reports that the structure, complete with watchtowers, has been constructed on the set of Brad Pitt's new thriller, Spy Game, currently shooting in Budapest. The wall has been built on the cobbled street where many May Day parades took place during the days of the Communist administration.

 Michael Douglas has given actress, Brittany Murphy her big break by signing her up for his £40m thriller Don't Say A Word. The 23-year-old, last seen in the psychiatric hospital drama Girl, Interrupted, will once again play a mentally unstable patient opposite Douglas's New York psychiatrist. Ananova reports that Douglas's fiancée, Catherine Zeta Jones, was considered for the role.

 The showbiz wedding of the year, that of the aforementioned Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones takes place tomorrow in New York. The couple have sold the rights to their wedding to a celebrity magazine for £1m. This on top of the £600,000 paid for exclusive pictures of their son, Dylan, who was born in September.

 Laura Linney is to co-star with Richard Gere in his new action adventure, The Mothman Prophecies. The 26-year-old actress, best known for playing Jim Carrey's fake wife in The Truman Show, will start work on the film in January. The $60m supernatural spectacular focuses on a reporter who races to a small West Virginia town to investigate a series of strange events, including psychic visions and the appearance of otherworldly spirits.

 Harry Knowles' of cult film site Aint It Cool News is not at all happy about the actors being lined up for the new Scooby Doo film. To find out why, go to Ain't It Cool News.

webTitle: You bet your life: week fourteen

fields.headline: You bet your life: week fourteen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. How long can it last?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £165.21, Sean Ingle = £108.87, Paul MacInnes = £56.46, Football Unlimited punters collective = £47.77.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £165.21, Sean Ingle = £108.87, Paul MacInnes = £56.46, Football Unlimited punters collective = £47.77.

Scott Murray Blackpool v Telford United: Telford to win. £5 @ 5/1

Steve McMahon and his sorry bunch of goal-shipping losers are going through a tough time at present near the bottom of the Third Division table. Which, when you think about it, is not too far from solid, middling Conference side Telford.

This price has surely been driven too high simply because there's something called "a division" between the two teams. The only problem I can envisage with this bet is Telford's lack of goalscoring prowess: they're knocking them in at the rate of only a goal a game. Mind you, as Blackpool lost 7-0 last week, I don't think I'll spend too much time worrying about that.

Sean Ingle Monaco v Paris St-Germain: Paris St-Germain to win @ 2/1; Hamburg v Bayer Leverkusen: Leverkusen to win @ 2/1. Two £4 singles and one £2 double.

Look for value, and place only single bets. That, in seven words, is the gospel of Blue Square's high priest of gambling Patrick Murray. And I for one want to believe in it. I really do. But it's not that simple. "Be wary of betting on the Premiership," Mr Murray warns us. Fair enough, you think - until you try putting on a juicy-looking single from the lower leagues, and find that no bookmaker in the land will accept it.

So it's with a heavy heart that I turn, once again, to foreign fields for my selections. Bayer Leverkusen are a team on a roll - they are unbeaten in six, and have kept five clean sheets in the process. They also boast the second best away record in the Bundesliga. Throwing all data into the cement mixer, I reckon the 2-1 on offer for them to beat Hamburg - whose home form is patchy - is value.

A similar logic applies to my second selection, Paris St-Germain to beat Monaco. Last year's French champions are going through an awful spell: they've lost three on the trot and lie 13th in the French league. Paris St-Germain's form is admittedly nothing to write home about, but they lie third in the league and face a team whose confidence is at rock bottom, so again 2-1 offers value. Finally, with the stakes I've placed on my bets, if one comes off I will make a small profit, while if both win I will make £34.

Paul MacInnes is on holiday.

Piers Pennington, who is the head of advertising for the Association of Commonwealth Universities. Charlton v Chelsea. Charlton to win. £5 @ 5-2

My predecessors in the Punters Collective have reduced our funds to under £50, which means I'm rationed to a £5 bet. Just to prove somebody is listening to Patrick Money (sorry, Murray) I'll follow the rules scrupulously - no multiples, avoid the Premiership, look for value. Well, two out of three anyway.

Charlton's home record: won 5, drawn 2, lost none. Chelsea's away record: won none, drawn 3 lost 3. True, Charlton haven't played anybody good at home but, let's face it, they're not doing on Saturday, are they?

Chelsea can bring off draws at big imposing stadiums where their prima donna Europeans feel at home (Old Trafford, Villa Park, St James' Park), but show them a small ground with a real football crowd instead of corporate boxes (Bradford, Southampton) and they come over all unnecessary.

Patrick would ask himself whether if this game were played seven times Charlton would win more than twice. I see no reason why not. So it's value.

webTitle: Health bosses order hospital to tackle 'unsafe equipment' crisis

fields.headline: Health bosses order hospital to tackle 'unsafe equipment' crisis
fields.trailText: 1pm:: NHS officials have warned managers to 'sort out' problems over the safety of surgical equipment which could bring trauma surgery to a halt at a major hospital.
fields.body:
NHS officials have warned managers to "sort out" problems over the safety of surgical equipment which could bring trauma surgery to a halt at a major hospital.

The threat followed the publication today of a letter from 10 surgeons at Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust urging managers to cancel orthopaedic operations on accident victims because of fears that patients' lives were being put at "serious risk".

The letter will add to fears that despite unprecedented planning and multi-million pound investment, the health service is still heading for a damaging crisis this winter.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "This is completely unacceptable. The hospital should not have let this situation develop and we expect them to take very swift action - to sort out their sterilisation department, to make sure patients are safe and to deal with those who have had to wait for their operations.

"If they do not, we will consider action against the hospital managers involved."

The orthopaedic surgeons wrote to hospital chief executive Dr Peter Howlett about their concerns over the supply of sterile equipment for treating patients.

The hospital's sterilisation unit has not been working properly since June and doctors have become infuriated at the slow response of the management team in resolving the problem. Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust said: "The trust recognises and acknowledges the problems with the hospital sterilisation and disinfection unit which it has been actively working on since June.

"We acknowledge that we have made very slow progress with addressing the problems and have already slowed the process to ensure patient safety. The trust is working very hard to ensure that orthopaedic trauma surgery continues at the hospital."

Last week a patient was brought to the hospital with a multiple fracture needing surgery, yet it took the surgeon involved six hours to find the necessary equipment.

Routine orthopaedic surgery was stopped three months ago to ensure there was enough properly sterilised equipment for emergencies, but surgeons now say they cannot ensure the safety of accident victims.

The move would mean that accident victims who may need vital surgery could not be taken to the accident and emergency department of the hospital.

Morale in the orthopaedic department of the hospital is at "an all time low", the surgeons said. Their letter says: "Despite stopping elective orthopaedic surgery we have not seen any improvements in the supply of sterile instruments for trauma.

"Indeed, the situation has become worse - we have previously taken the view that cancellation of trauma would put the patients at greater risk than continuing the service.

"But this situation has now changed ... we now feel that patients' lives and well-being are at serious risk and this situation cannot be allowed to continue.

"We have therefore come to the decision that we must recommend that trauma takes for the Queen Alexandra hospital must cease."

The surgeons also raised concerns about the delay in typing up the medical notes of patients who have suffered broken bones. Staff shortages mean notes from the hospital's fracture clinic now take more than two weeks to be typed up.

The surgeons say notes should take a maximum of two days to be processed. The letter ends: "I am sure you will understand our decision has not been undertaken lightly.

"We are extremely disappointed that the concerns brought to our attention have not been addressed. Morale in the orthopaedic department is at an all-time low and our concerns have been expressed."

Local Conservative MP Michael Mates met health minister Gisela Stuart three times over the last two months to raise concerns about the problem.

He said: "I met the minister and she thanked me for possibly averting a crisis, but nothing has been done.

"I do not blame her, but I do blame the management team for being so slow to react - it is a disgrace."
fields.bodyText: NHS officials have warned managers to "sort out" problems over the safety of surgical equipment which could bring trauma surgery to a halt at a major hospital. The threat followed the publication today of a letter from 10 surgeons at Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust urging managers to cancel orthopaedic operations on accident victims because of fears that patients' lives were being put at "serious risk". The letter will add to fears that despite unprecedented planning and multi-million pound investment, the health service is still heading for a damaging crisis this winter. A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "This is completely unacceptable. The hospital should not have let this situation develop and we expect them to take very swift action - to sort out their sterilisation department, to make sure patients are safe and to deal with those who have had to wait for their operations. "If they do not, we will consider action against the hospital managers involved." The orthopaedic surgeons wrote to hospital chief executive Dr Peter Howlett about their concerns over the supply of sterile equipment for treating patients. The hospital's sterilisation unit has not been working properly since June and doctors have become infuriated at the slow response of the management team in resolving the problem. Portsmouth Hospitals NHS trust said: "The trust recognises and acknowledges the problems with the hospital sterilisation and disinfection unit which it has been actively working on since June. "We acknowledge that we have made very slow progress with addressing the problems and have already slowed the process to ensure patient safety. The trust is working very hard to ensure that orthopaedic trauma surgery continues at the hospital." Last week a patient was brought to the hospital with a multiple fracture needing surgery, yet it took the surgeon involved six hours to find the necessary equipment. Routine orthopaedic surgery was stopped three months ago to ensure there was enough properly sterilised equipment for emergencies, but surgeons now say they cannot ensure the safety of accident victims. The move would mean that accident victims who may need vital surgery could not be taken to the accident and emergency department of the hospital. Morale in the orthopaedic department of the hospital is at "an all time low", the surgeons said. Their letter says: "Despite stopping elective orthopaedic surgery we have not seen any improvements in the supply of sterile instruments for trauma. "Indeed, the situation has become worse - we have previously taken the view that cancellation of trauma would put the patients at greater risk than continuing the service. "But this situation has now changed ... we now feel that patients' lives and well-being are at serious risk and this situation cannot be allowed to continue. "We have therefore come to the decision that we must recommend that trauma takes for the Queen Alexandra hospital must cease." The surgeons also raised concerns about the delay in typing up the medical notes of patients who have suffered broken bones. Staff shortages mean notes from the hospital's fracture clinic now take more than two weeks to be typed up. The surgeons say notes should take a maximum of two days to be processed. The letter ends: "I am sure you will understand our decision has not been undertaken lightly. "We are extremely disappointed that the concerns brought to our attention have not been addressed. Morale in the orthopaedic department is at an all-time low and our concerns have been expressed." Local Conservative MP Michael Mates met health minister Gisela Stuart three times over the last two months to raise concerns about the problem. He said: "I met the minister and she thanked me for possibly averting a crisis, but nothing has been done. "I do not blame her, but I do blame the management team for being so slow to react - it is a disgrace."

webTitle: Canal plan to revitalise Mersey docks

fields.headline: Canal plan to revitalise Mersey docks
fields.trailText: Narrow boats may soon cruise past Liverpool's famous Pier Head along a new half-mile stretch of canal that would be one of the first of its type to be built in Britain for 200 years.
fields.body:
Narrow boats may soon cruise past Liverpool's famous Pier Head along a new half-mile stretch of canal that would be one of the first of its type to be built in Britain for 200 years.

In a scheme announced by British Waterways to coincide with the launch of the urban white paper, the £15m canal would link the terminus of the Leeds and Liverpool canal at Stanley Dock with the shops, museums and galleries at the Albert Dock.

Feasibility studies suggest alternative routes. With one, the canal would run alongside the traffic that speeds along the The Strand; with an alternative route, the canal would pass in front of the Liver and Cunard buildings and across one of the finest waterfronts in Europe. With both routes, passengers would be within easy strolling distance of the Mersey ferries.

The new canal would enter the Canning half tide dock in front of the Merseyside maritime museum and a few yards from the Tate gallery.

It is part of a £200m three-part scheme to revitalise Liverpool's docks area. British Waterways, which runs the country's 2,000 mile network of canals and rivers, has joined English Partnerships to consider the future management of the land and water around Albert Dock.

With three other partners, BW has also been shortlisted to redevelop the 36 acre Kings Waterfront site. Its plan proposes a mix of homes, offices and tourist attractions.

"We believe that Liverpool's docks and waterways have enormous untapped potential to deliver social change, environmental improvement and economic prosperity," said Dave Fletcher, BW's chief executive.

BW also expects the link would have a regeneration effect along the banks of the canal which is Britain's longest waterway and takes a 157-mile meandering route across the Pennines. At present fewer than 1,000 boats a year reach the Liverpool terminus.

Mike Storey, leader of Liverpool city council, described the plan as bold and imaginative. "The city needs projects of this calibre if it is to make the progress it deserves," Layth Bunni, chief executive of Liverpool Vision, the city's urban regeneration programme. "It is a visionary scheme that will help breathe new life into the waterfront."

webTitle: US court blocks execution of low-IQ killer

fields.headline: US court blocks execution of low-IQ killer
fields.trailText: The US supreme court has blocked the execution of a convicted killer whose low IQ is at the centre of a  debate over whether he should be put the death.
fields.body:
The US supreme court has blocked the execution of a convicted killer whose low IQ is at the centre of a debate over whether he should be put the death.

Johnny Paul Penry, condemned for the 1979 rape and murder of a 22-year-old woman while he was on parole for rape, is said to have such severe learning disabilities that he spends his days colouring with crayons and still believes in Santa Claus.

Texas governor and Republican presidential hopeful George W Bush had rejected requests by Penry's supporters for a reprieve.

However, last night the high court said it wanted more time to decide whether to hear arguments that Penry's learning disabilities had not been properly explained to the jury that convicted him. Several of Penry's relatives and a neighbour have also said that as a child he was brutally abused by his mentally ill mother, who is now dead.

The court said the stay would last until it decides whether to take Penry's case, which could happen in a few weeks.

"At least I'm alive," Penry said when told of the reprieve.

Penry, 44, was to become the 38th Texas inmate to be executed this year - the highest number by any state since the supreme court allowed capital punishment to resume in 1976. It was the third execution scheduled in as many nights in Texas.

Penry's case was at the centre of a landmark US supreme court decision on executing those with severe learning disabilities, and his impending execution drew protests from around the world. The European Union, anti-death penalty groups, the American Bar Association and advocates for those with learning disabilities urged Texas not to execute him.

His lawyers say he has an IQ of 50 to 60 and the reasoning capacity of a seven-year-old. But prosecutors said Penry was ignorant and did not have learning disabilities. Texas attorney general John Cornyn said Penry was "a schemer, a planner and can be purposefully deceptive". The court was Penry's last chance, after the Texas board of pardons and paroles on Tuesday denied his request for a 30-day reprieve and a commutation to a lesser sentence. The court's decision prevented the case from reaching Mr Bush, who would have had to rule yesterday on whether to give Penry a 30-day reprieve - all that it is in his power to grant, under Texas law - or to allow the execution.

Fourteen Texas state senators had written to Mr Bush urging him to issue a temporary reprieve - a step he has taken only once in his nearly six years in office. Mr Bush has presided over more executions than any other governor in the US, and Penry's low IQ, coupled with the fact that 13 states ban the execution of those with severe learning disabilities, means that the issue had become extremely politically sensitive as Mr Bush awaits the results of the disputed presidential election.

Penry had two competency trials and two murder trials, the second after the US supreme court threw out his original death sentence. The court said it was not cruel and unusual punishment to execute those with learning disabilities, but juries must take the issue into account when considering the death penalty.

About two dozen states allow the execution of killers with learning disabilities, although some are considering laws prohibiting the practice.

In August, Oliver David Cruz, whose IQ tested as low as 63, received a lethal injection in Texas for a 1988 murder in San Antonio.

webTitle: £180m plan to revive Corrie terraces

fields.headline: £180m plan to revive Corrie terraces
fields.trailText: Coronation Street has seen much better days. Once home to foundry and mill workers of east Manchester, manufacturing heart of the world's first industrial city, it has become a symbol of urban England's deepening malaise.
fields.body:
Coronation Street has seen much better days. Once home to foundry and mill workers of east Manchester, manufacturing heart of the world's first industrial city, it has become a symbol of urban England's deepening malaise.

When the factories closed, 20,000 lost their jobs in the 1970s and 1980s alone. The skilled workers left. But others remained in the vain hope of finding alternative work.

Then the unskilled drifted away, house prices slumped, and unscrupulous landlord bought blocks of properties - sometimes at £5,000 or less a house - to exploit the poorest in society dependent on housing benefit and unable to find council housing. Coronation Street plunged into decline.

Today, with the population dropping by 13% in eight years alone, the old communities of east Manchester - Ancoats, Openshaw, Beswick, Miles Platting - present the ultimate challenge for a city council and a government desperate to reverse greenfield building in favour of recycled or "brownfield" land.

Almost a third of the area is vacant in a conurbation that has more derelict land than any other part of the country. Those terraces that have not been demolished lie boarded up and vandalised. On the worst council estates nearby, almost half the housing is vacant. People are unhealthy, mortality rates are 50% above the national average, while almost 70% of under fives have dental disease.

Seeing no future in the area, some have simply left. Others, like Alan and Rose Williams, round the corner from Coronation Street, are trapped by collapsing property prices. The couple, who have three young children, paid £28,000 for their three-bedroom house in 1991, and spent £18,000 on improvements. It was recently valued at £10,000.

"We can't lose so much, so we'll have to stay in the hope things get better," says Alan. He is tiring of rubbish thrown over the back wall, the swearing and noise from nearby houses. "It's not good for the children hearing all that stuff," says Rose. "But they're very happy at school, doing well."

"This was once a belting area," recalls Alan. "A great community and so friendly."

Half a mile away, in an office above the run down Beswick shopping centre, Tom Russell has taken up the challenge to turn east Manchester around in a project ministers see as a model for other cities.

Chief executive of a company called New East Manchester embracing the city council and government agencies, Mr Russell will oversee £90m of public money, and a similar amount from the private sector, in a 10-year renewal programme. Plans speak of "an opportunity for regeneration on a scale and diversity unmatched in an English city".

The area has one great advantage, as the centre for the 2002 Commonwealth Games. With east Manchester's national cycling arena a success, a 48,000-seat stadium is taking shape nearby in a "sports city" complex.

It is hoped this will provided the spur to double the population to 60,000, with 12,500 new homes alongside the improvement of 7,000 older properties. A shopping centre, with covered market, is planned as the focus for the "new town". Mr Russell is talking to a consortium of national house builders in the hope of announcing contracts for the first 3,000 homes before Christmas: "They have told us they recognise the time is right to get into the regeneration game and look at areas like this, now the mood is turning against greenfield sites."

Hilary Armstrong, the regeneration minister, believes the plan will succeed where others have failed because it recognises "human renewal" must go alongside neighbourhood rebuilding. "There is a lot to celebrate but a lot to do," she said.

webTitle: Charlton show interest in Hartson

fields.headline: Charlton show interest in Hartson
fields.trailText: John Hartson may be up for another move -- or at least another medical. The Wimbledon and Wales striker, who has seen two proposed transfers fall through on fitness grounds already this year, is the subject of some interest from Charlton Athletic.
fields.body:
John Hartson may be up for another move -- or at least another medical. The Wimbledon and Wales striker, who has seen two proposed transfers fall through on fitness grounds already this year, is the subject of some interest from Charlton Athletic.

Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley admitted yesterday that he has discussed a deal with Wimbledon's Terry Burton that would involve Kevin Lisbie moving in part exchange for Hartson. But he denied that anything had been agreed. "I'm a bit surprised this has come out," Curbishley said. "I haven't even mentioned it to Kevin." Reports had suggested that Curbishley was ready to part with Lisbie, a 22-year-old Hackney-born forward, and £4m in order to get Hartson.

"I have had a couple of conversations with Terry and obviously we know each other well," said Curbishley. "He asked after young Kevin and I told him we had lots of injury problems with our strikers.

"I said if you want Kevin I will take John. Obviously they have to sell John to get someone in.

"That's how it was left. There are other people, like agents, involved."

Hartson has struggled with his fitness in recent seasons, and his knees have been a particular concern. Proposed moves to Tottenham and Rangers have fallen through in the past six months because of doubts raised by medical examinations.

webTitle: Fair for starters, but now the hard part begins

fields.headline: Fair for starters, but now the hard part begins
fields.trailText: Not bad, Mr Prescott. Not bad. The government's urban white paper scores a good seven out of 10. Or to put this another way, the white paper has adopted 70% of the forward-looking recommendations made by Lord Rogers's urban task force report,Towards an Urban Renaissance, 15 months ago.
fields.body:
Not bad, Mr Prescott. Not bad. The government's urban white paper scores a good seven out of 10. Or to put this another way, the white paper has adopted 70% of the forward-looking recommendations made by Lord Rogers's urban task force report,Towards an Urban Renaissance, 15 months ago.

These were concerned with raising the standard of environment and design in our city centres to make life better for those who live and work in them and to discourage the continuing urban diaspora.

By ennobling our cities, we can save the countryside we say we love but wish to smother with something like 4m trashy new homes over the next 10 or 15 years because we want to escape downgraded and dirty city centres.

The white paper offers practical solutions connecting the quality of urban design and transport infrastructure with the quality of life in our cities. Mr Prescott offers, for example, a dozen new private-public urban regeneration companies. These may well be be able to redevelop areas such as London's King's Cross, by making the complex mix of private, public and local authority landowners in such areas shareholders in a carrot-and-carrot operation. All players would benefit financially and environmentally.

Money, assuming the white paper becomes legislation, will no longer be pumped into regenerating particular areas of cities unless this is met by three-dimensional design plans rather than vague two-dimensional diagrams and lists of statistics; in other words, standards of urban design, from the look of buildings to the treatment of pavements, alleys and public squares will be forced to rise.

We may yet get away from the dismal bollards and tweedy brick paving with everything approach to urban design favoured by most British city authorities as they remain at least 20 years behind the standards of design set in, say, Barcelona or Copenhagen.

Whether the British can muster the talent and energy to match the government's new found desire to improve life in our city centres with the necessary high standards of design remains to be seen.

They will have to rise if Mr Prescott and his successors at the head of the DTR are to be able to deliver with any credibility the promised Al Gore-style annual report on the state of our cities to parliament. Sure, statistics about pollution and rubbish collection might be useful speech fodder, but the white paper does finally recognise that the physical design of our cities plays as much of a part in whether they are nurtured or neglected as any amount of cleaning and scrubbing.

Only last month the prime minister held a reception at 10 Downing Street supporting higher standards in the design of public buildings. Although the urban white paper does mean government departments working together across the monopoly board of our city centres, the proposals need the active and vocal support of the prime minister, the cabinet and Whitehall.

If we are to treat our cities with the intelligence and grace that the Spanish and the Danes, among others, have learned to, we still need get regeneration bodies from English Partnerships to local authorities to take design seriously. The signs are that the government is beginning to try, that ministries are talking to ministries and that Lord Rogers' s task force has been more than an elegant talking shop.
