webTitle: Resurrecting the city

fields.headline: Resurrecting the city
fields.standfirst: Brightening up the centre is not enough
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers, the chairman of the urban task force, got it right: yesterday's white paper on urban renaissance was a welcome advance, but only a start on a very long journey. It offers a vision of what our towns and cities, where 80% of us live, could be like in 20 years, but on a succession of crucial issues - land assembly, land clean-up, resource allocation and statutory powers - it falls short, as he said, of what is going to be required to engender a real urban renaissance.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers, the chairman of the urban task force, got it right: yesterday's white paper on urban renaissance was a welcome advance, but only a start on a very long journey. It offers a vision of what our towns and cities, where 80% of us live, could be like in 20 years, but on a succession of crucial issues - land assembly, land clean-up, resource allocation and statutory powers - it falls short, as he said, of what is going to be required to engender a real urban renaissance.

The challenge is familiar. A country with the world's first industrial cities has seen them in steep and accelerating decline as successive governments promoted new towns, out-of-town shopping malls and M4 golden corridor development. The population of Manchester and Liverpool has fallen by a third in the last 25 years. Over 500,000 jobs have been lost in 20 major cities. All is not bleak. Town centres are being revived. The first new homes for years are being provided for affluent single people by converting central warehouses. It is just beyond the centre that the trouble really sets in. Read Peter Hetherington's account today of east Manchester: derelict land, falling population, plummeting property prices. Yet this is where redevelopment must take place if the switch from greenfield to brownfield sites is to be made. The urban task force warned what would happen unless that is done: with 3.8m new homes needed by 2021, an area bigger than Exmoor would be concreted over.

Yesterday's white paper was the first on this theme for 23 years. Although delayed, many earlier government initiatives are more important than yesterday's, including the 10-year £180bn new transport strategy, the drive to raise inner-city school standards (vital if families are to be attracted back), the reduction in property and car crime. There is the promise of stricter planning laws and 12 new urban regeneration "companies". What is missing is a sense of whole-hearted commitment. Last week's tax concessions on urban redevelopment have shrivelled with the release of the details. There is no promise of a renaissance bill, to avoid piecemeal legislation and end the bickering between departments; planning obligations have still to be "reviewed". Not so much a renaissance, then, as a reawakening.

webTitle: What the US papers say: Papers get tetchy ten days on

fields.headline: Papers get tetchy ten days on
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Press review: Ten days on from what was supposed to be P for President day, writes Derek Brown, an understandable tetchniness of tone is creeping into the American papers.
fields.body:
Ten days on from what was supposed to be P for President day, an understandable tetchniness of tone is creeping into the American papers. A common, rather defensive, theme is that the interminable delays and legal wrangles show that, whatever critical foreigners might say, American democracy is in prime health.

The Amarillo Globe-News, for example, crisply rejects the notion that the confusing Palm Beach ballot paper merits a manual recount in that county. Hundreds of people, it acknowledges, now say they mistakenly voted for maverick rightwinger Pat Buchanan, when they really intended to pick Al Gore. But, the paper addes, "to assume that there was any kind of deceit involved is false. Confusing, yes; fraudulent, no".

The San Francisco Examiner picks up the theme, urging its readers not to take too much account of sneering foreigners: "The tense battle to determine the will of the people in an almost exactly divided nation is nothing to be ashamed of. And when the next tenant of the White House is handed the key, the United States will still have the world's longest unbroken democratic history - not a bad thing for the others to emulate."

From the heart of the action in the Florida state capital, the Tallahassee Democrat is also indignant about the cheap "banana republic" shots being fired at Florida and the USA: "It's a messy, sometimes rancorous process, and it's made Florida an easy target for armchair critics worldwide... Such hyperbole suggests, wrongly, that Florida is in a state of semi-anarchy, its citizens too inept to even vote properly.

"The underlying sentiment is that the Sunshine State needs to hurry up and get its act together so that the rest of the country can know who will occupy the Oval Office. Those critics should take a deep breath. Electing a president is serious business and the workings of democracy are sometimes slow and unpleasant. Instead of taking cheap shots at Florida, Americans and others should hope that this matter is handled with more care than expedience... We all want to know who our next president is. But finding out today or a week later isn't the point. Getting it right is."

The Las Vegas Sun runs a wicked little cartoon strip of George W Bush saying in three successive frames: "I don't trust government. I trust the people. Unless they're doing the recount." The paper castigates Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris for refusing to accept a manual recounting of votes, and praises Al Gore's suggestion that both candidates should abide by the result of such a recount: "It's evident Gore is committed to a fair resolution that recognizes the will of the people. There was a brief moment Wednesday when it seemed that reason might prevail in deciding who will win the presidency, but Bush and Harris obviously had different plans."

Columnist Thomas Friedman, writing in the Atlanta Journal, has a thought-provoking piece on why non-Americans are taking such a close interest in the manner, if not the outcome, of the election: "Foreigners are watching our election the way they watch the NBA finals on satellite TV - to see which team wins, but with the sound off, because the words mean nothing. Because for foreigners there wasn't much to listen to, since neither candidate offered any inspiring vision of America - any argument for why its values and institutions were important for the world, or why the world, with both its needs and aspirations, was important to America.

"Both Al Gore and George W. Bush need to understand, though, that the vapid inward-looking campaigns they ran have implications for America abroad. It has left the playing field out there wide open for those whose vision is to oppose America or seek its destruction. The America-haters have all the energy now in Europe and the Middle East. Our friends are mute and on the defensive."

The Minneapolis Star Tribune is scathing about the Republicans' latest arguments against a manual recount of votes: "In Florida, one day can carry you from the surreal to the sublime. The surreal came Thursday from attorneys on the Republican side, arguing in court that the delays in manual recounts were reason now to disallow the results. Having tried everything they could for a week to stop those counts, criticizing the delay now takes real chutzpah. The sublime came from the Florida Supreme Court, in a unanimous order authorizing Palm Beach and Broward counties to continue their manual recounts."

But, the paper warns rather wearily, the recount will not end the saga, because state law does not require the outcome to be included in the final result.

webTitle: New current affairs series for the BBC

fields.headline: BBC to launch new current affairs show
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Panorama reporter Paul Kenyon is to front the BBC's new single-issue current affairs series. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
Panorama reporter Paul Kenyon is to front a new single-issue current affairs series from February next year, as part of the BBC's bid to develop a new generation of strong, personality-led current affairs programmes.

Mr Kenyon, who is being groomed as a star journalist, will head the five-part, 30-minute show, which is to be screened in a peak-time slot.

BBC head of current affairs Peter Horrocks, a former Panorama editor, said it was a priority to develop its journalists as "people with a passion who develop the characters in the stories they are covering".

His remarks followed a session at Newsworld yesterday, in which Don Hewitt, executive producer of 60 Minutes, America's most prestigious news magazine programme, stressed the importance in current affairs of "telling good stories".

Mr Horrocks also defended the BBC's decision to use Mariella Frostrup to present the edition of Panorama about reality shows. He said: "I thought she did a very good job."

But he added that it had been "an experiment" for Panorama, which was going through a period of transition.

Earlier this week the BBC's director of programming, Mark Thompson, told an Royal Television Society audience that he had not ruled out moving Panorama again.

The flagship current affairs show was moved from its traditional Monday night slot to Sunday less than two months ago.

But Mr Horrocks said that the programme would have to stay where it was for "getting on for a year" for current affairs chiefs to decide whether the experiment had been a success.

webTitle: US election: Florida court rules vote recount continues

fields.headline: 'It's no longer counting, it's manipulation'
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Florida's supreme court has ruled that the manual recount of votes in three contested counties can continue despite Republican attempts to declare a winner of the presidential election tomorrow.
fields.body:
Florida's supreme court has ruled that the manual recount of votes in three contested counties can continue despite Republican attempts to declare a winner of the presidential election tomorrow.

Officials in Palm Beach County have now begun a crucial manual recount of 460,000 votes that is likely to boost the chances of the Democratic presidential candidate, Al Gore.

The party has threatened legal action if the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, refuses to accept the result. Ms Harris was Republican candidate George W Bush's campaign co-chairman in Florida and says the state's 25 electoral college votes will be allocated when the 2,600 postal votes are counted early tomorrow morning.

But the result is unlikely to come so soon. Republicans are countering the Democrat's threat of legal action with an attempt in the federal court in Atlanta to shut the recounts down.

The uncertainty comes from the supreme court ruling that there was "no legal impediment" to the recounts in Palm Beach, Miami-Dade and Broward counties but failing to address the thorny issue of whether Ms Harris should be required to accept them.

The federal court has also agreed to consider a related case filed by three Bush supporters who claim their rights are being violated because their counties are not recanvassing votes by hand.

The Republicans may demand recounts in Oregon, Wisconsin and New Mexico, which narrowly voted for Mr Gore, if the White House stays with the Democrats.

Mr Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph Lieberman, said the recounts were justified. "I think we've got to have some process to end this where the person elected president does not go in not only with a cloud over his head but with millions of people in America thinking that he got elected unfairly," he said.

The Republicans, however, are less convinced.

"It is no longer really counting, it is manipulation," said Mr Bush's running mate Dick Cheney.

webTitle: CIM research highlights power of ads on kids

fields.headline: CIM research highlights power of ads on kids
fields.standfirst: Nov 16: Marketeers turn on Brown
fields.trailText:
11.45am: New research suggests ads may have more power over children than their parents do, writes Claire Cozens.
Nov 16: Marketeers turn on Brown
fields.body:
The row over the effects of advertising on children intensified today with the publication of research suggesting that ads may have more power over children than their parents do.

The news adds weight to chancellor Gordon Brown's controversial comments this week about the damaging effects of advertising on underprivileged children.

The consumer survey, published by the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM), found that 36% of adult consumers in the UK believe that advertising is the biggest influence on children, while only 17% believed parents have the most power.

Peer pressure was believed to be slightly more persuasive than advertising, with 37% of respondents saying friends are the most influential factor.

But although a majority of respondents believed the law should be strengthened to protect children against ads, only 17% thought advertising to children should be banned completely.

Young people were particularly opposed to the introduction of stronger legislation.

CIM director of marketing Ray Perry said: "The group that finds advertising to children the least worrying are those consumers who have most recently experienced it as children themselves.

"This is indicative of the role that advertising to children has in informing them about products and educating them in the way that the media works."

The chancellor provoked outrage in the marketing industry this week when he said he was struck by how unfair advertising was on children from deprived backgrounds who could not afford the products being pushed.

Mr Brown's comments came at a time when the marketing industry is preparing its defences against the possibility of a Europe-wide ban on advertising to children.

Sweden, which takes on the presidency of the European Union next year, is known to favour such a move.

webTitle: Julie Burchill on Charlie's Angels

fields.headline: Once upon a time there were three little girls who went to the police academy...
fields.standfirst: ...and changed the lives of teenagers everywhere.  Julie Burchill  was one of them
fields.trailText: ...and changed the lives of teenagers everywhere. Julie Burchill was one of them
fields.body:
I don't know about you, but when I'm auditioning people to be my friend, there are a few questions I always try to run by them, casual-like. First, I'll want to know if they've ever said "Enjoy" in that sickening way only sad little castrates incapable of enjoying anything do. Then I'll want to know that they're not going to be dreary and boring about the loyalty thing, and that we both understand that if a better offer comes up and Kate Moss wants either of us to be her best friend on pain of never seeing the other one again, then naturally it's all off. But the third question is, inevitably, the tie-breaker. Answered right, I'll pass on the other two. And it is: Who was your favourite Charlie's Angel?

Now some people might think that this is a trick question. The coolest Charlie's Angel of all time was Tanya Roberts as Julie, the last draftee before the show's cancellation. Unlike the other girls who must have married their Carmen rollers, Julie had poker-straight hair and a voice full of guts and gravel compared to their breathy babeishness. Tanya turned out to be pretty damned cool, too; a tough, working-class, New York girl with a nice line in put-downs and - it eventually transpired in the Sunday papers - a liking for Cocaine Sex Parties With French Girls.

But that's beside the point. The draftees don't matter: if you say that Tanya was your favourite, or Shelley Hack, or even Cheryl Ladd, you're missing the point. Only Jill (Farrah Fawcett), Sabrina (Kate Jackson) and Kelly (Jaclyn Smith) really matter, really signify in the rich tapestry of pop culture. It's like Boss Cat also being called Top Cat, or ignoring the fact that there was more than one Darrin in Bewitched - if you have to ask you'll never understand. The correct answer is, of course, "Jaclyn!" - said with a gasp before and a sigh afterwards.

Jaclyn, Jaclyn - beautiful Jaclyn Smith, with the gimmicky name and the timeless beauty, as completely and uniquely herself as Helen of Troy or Sade Adu. A sphinx without a secret, an angel without wings, a Jewish girl from one of the richest retailing families in Texas, Jaclyn was always something of a mystery, which is a mystery itself in a business where the participants are only too happy to splurge every last detail of their private lives in our faces. All we knew about her, really, was that she'd been married to a man called Roger but they divorced, and all we know now is that she eventually married a Scots technician she met on the set of a TV film and had a baby which she called Gaston. But, hey, nobody's perfect.

You weren't meant to like Jaclyn best - Farrah, "Jill", was the sexy one, and Kate, "Sabrina", was the "clever" one (which meant she was flat-chested). But Farrah had a vulpine, masculine face beneath her spectacular blondeness and Kate had a witchy little voice. My friend had a theory that women liked Jaclyn because she was divorced - whereas Farrah was smugly married and Kate stroppily single, Jaclyn combined both the idealism and combativeness of the modern woman, thus resulting in her divorcee status. It was her character who was immortalised on the most resonant and haunting LP of recent years - Air's Moon Safari, with Kelly, Watch the Stars. I once recall the Air boys, in their charmingly halting English, explaining themselves: "Eet ees not Jaclyn Smeeth we are so fascinated by, eet ees Kellee. We think of Kellee as being the most perfect person, ever."

But for myself and most of the other teenage girls who grew up with Charlie's Angels, it was hard to tell where Jaclyn stopped and Kelly started, as indeed it was with the other actresses. Farrah really was a sports-mad airhead, we could tell, and Kate was obviously a bit of a cow. But it didn't matter; the original triumvirate of Angels, lasting only from 1976 to 1978, were as perfect as a circle. If Jill was sporty, Sabrina was analytical; if Sabrina was abrasive, Kelly was comforting; if Kelly was soft, Jill was crisp. When Farrah left after only one season - her character Jill Munroe being replaced by Cheryl Ladd, as Jill's younger sister Chris - the circle slumped and became a sort of squidgy oval. By the time Shelley and Tanya had been substituted, the show was a big, shapeless mess. When it was finally cancelled in 1981, after 109 episodes, everyone had had a gut-full.

It was all so different in the beginning. ABC was always the poor relation of American TV networks, ranking lowest ever since its creation and only ever managing a couple of really big shows, one of which was Happy Days. Obviously, they were delighted when Charlie's Angel became the top show of the 1976-77 season and the only new show on any network to become an out-and-out hit. By the end of the first run, 59% of all televisions in use when the show was aired were tuned into it: 23m households. And it never left the Nielsen top 10 for its first three years. There were further surprises when a breakdown of the audience showed that it had ranked fourth in metropolitan areas, seventh amongst college graduates and seventh with the highest-income group. The girls got 18,000 letters a week and ABC charged the highest advertisement rate ever for commercials: $100,000 a minute by the end of the first season.

A lot of rubbish is talked these days about girl power and how Charlie's Angels were there first, and an equal amount about how exploitative and sexist it all was. In truth, it was neither: neither saint nor sinner, dom nor sub. It was, instead, one of those sublime, silly, shimmering moments when popular culture gets it absolutely right, like Mony Mony, Coca-Cola or The Simpsons. Up until the 1970s, women on American TV shows had been housewives and mothers; even big stars asked us to suspend our credibility and buy them as dizzy broads forever being scolded by their hubbies. Then Mary Tyler Moore, who had spent the 1960s as the archetypal American angel of the hearth in the Dick Van Dyke Show, reinvented her self as a bold yet vulnerable big city career girl for The Mary Tyler Moore Show.

So great was the resonance of this show that Oprah Winfrey, by then the most powerful woman on TV, would be reduced to tears when she greeted a frail, much older Tyler Moore on an episode of Oprah. You'd have needed a heart of stone not to whimper along as Winfrey recalled how, during her impoverished and abused youth in a deep south shack, this paragon of white WASPishness had been her greatest inspiration in holding on to the dream.

That's how desperate we were then for TV heroines who weren't wives and mothers; Mary Tyler Moore, stuttering in fear before her fierce editor Lou Grant, seemed like the shining path. In this context, it's not surprising that the Angels - with their guns, judo throws and ability to escape from any situation unscathed, no matter how savage or sordid - seemed like salvation.

Would they have been the same if they'd been called The Alley Cats? This was what Aaron Spelling, who created the show as a vehicle for Kate Jackson, star of his series The Rookies, wanted them to be known as. Another abandoned blueprint was that they would be three undercover policewomen; in a typical act of puny yet pungent Lib-Lite, Jackson suggested that the trio should instead be private investigators who had not been able to advance in the male-dominated LAPD, and that Angels was rather less offensively stereotyped than Alley Cats.

It was Jackson, the most conventionally feminist-minded of the actresses, who suggested the gimmick of the ever-absent Charlie - and, though this has since been reinterpreted as a terminally chauvinistic touch, I think there is something to be said for the way it added to the male-free feeling of the show, to a degree unparalleled before or since. Even the "real woman" dramas of Kay Mellor feature the boyfriends and husbands of the heroines week in, week out; but Angel-land truly was an Adam-less Eden in which the only men were agents of evil or disposable dupes.

Once in a while you'd see them get off with some Brett Rockjaw at the end of the show, but next week, they'd be back on the couches together waiting for the word from Charlie, and none of the previous week's romantic nuances would ever be mentioned. At a time when the only test of maturity is whether or not you have an all-important boyfriend, the Angels indicated that it was really grown-up and glamorous not to bother with that stuff at all.

Or perhaps the motivation was more sinister, in the way that pop star scream idols were always instructed by the management to appear single at all times (it says a lot for John Lennon's "integrity" that he kept his wife Cynthia under wraps for years; Ronan Keating never bothered). Perhaps the Angels were made to appear permanently unattached so that male audiences would become more loyal and more partisan about their Angel.

While women watched to see women doing "men's jobs" in fancy frocks, men were apparently attracted by what came to be known as the "jiggle factor". Typically, at least one Angel will be put in a position where she must strip down to a bikini in the first 10 minutes, or thereafter bring the future of western civilisation into question. The episode titles were all a big tease, too, the first season containing the notorious Angels in Chains as well as Consenting Adults, Dirty Business, Lady Killers and The Blue Angels. The last was an investigation into the pornography industry, but the Angels kept those bikinis on.

Call me an old-fashioned girl, but I would much rather have been an actress in the days of tease and jiggle than now, when every role offered to women between the ages of 18 and 35 will at some point include a close-up gynaecological examination. But that, as they say, was then. This is now. Now there's a film. When Drew Barrymore took it into her head to produce a big budget Charlie's Angels movie a couple of years back, you could practically hear the horny hands rubbing all across Hollywood at the prospect of every guy's favourite fantasy - the catfight - played out between mega-babes.

(aka Angel Jill Munroe)

(aka Sabrina Duncan)

(aka Kelly Garrett)

(aka Kris Munroe)

(aka Tiffany Welles)

fields.bodyText: I don't know about you, but when I'm auditioning people to be my friend, there are a few questions I always try to run by them, casual-like. First, I'll want to know if they've ever said "Enjoy" in that sickening way only sad little castrates incapable of enjoying anything do. Then I'll want to know that they're not going to be dreary and boring about the loyalty thing, and that we both understand that if a better offer comes up and Kate Moss wants either of us to be her best friend on pain of never seeing the other one again, then naturally it's all off. But the third question is, inevitably, the tie-breaker. Answered right, I'll pass on the other two. And it is: Who was your favourite Charlie's Angel? Now some people might think that this is a trick question. The coolest Charlie's Angel of all time was Tanya Roberts as Julie, the last draftee before the show's cancellation. Unlike the other girls who must have married their Carmen rollers, Julie had poker-straight hair and a voice full of guts and gravel compared to their breathy babeishness. Tanya turned out to be pretty damned cool, too; a tough, working-class, New York girl with a nice line in put-downs and - it eventually transpired in the Sunday papers - a liking for Cocaine Sex Parties With French Girls. But that's beside the point. The draftees don't matter: if you say that Tanya was your favourite, or Shelley Hack, or even Cheryl Ladd, you're missing the point. Only Jill (Farrah Fawcett), Sabrina (Kate Jackson) and Kelly (Jaclyn Smith) really matter, really signify in the rich tapestry of pop culture. It's like Boss Cat also being called Top Cat, or ignoring the fact that there was more than one Darrin in Bewitched - if you have to ask you'll never understand. The correct answer is, of course, "Jaclyn!" - said with a gasp before and a sigh afterwards. Jaclyn, Jaclyn - beautiful Jaclyn Smith, with the gimmicky name and the timeless beauty, as completely and uniquely herself as Helen of Troy or Sade Adu. A sphinx without a secret, an angel without wings, a Jewish girl from one of the richest retailing families in Texas, Jaclyn was always something of a mystery, which is a mystery itself in a business where the participants are only too happy to splurge every last detail of their private lives in our faces. All we knew about her, really, was that she'd been married to a man called Roger but they divorced, and all we know now is that she eventually married a Scots technician she met on the set of a TV film and had a baby which she called Gaston. But, hey, nobody's perfect. You weren't meant to like Jaclyn best - Farrah, "Jill", was the sexy one, and Kate, "Sabrina", was the "clever" one (which meant she was flat-chested). It was her character who was immortalised on the most resonant and haunting LP of recent years - Air's Moon Safari, with Kelly, Watch the Stars. I once recall the Air boys, in their charmingly halting English, explaining themselves: "Eet ees not Jaclyn Smeeth we are so fascinated by, eet ees Kellee. We think of Kellee as being the most perfect person, ever." But for myself and most of the other teenage girls who grew up with Charlie's Angels, it was hard to tell where Jaclyn stopped and Kelly started, as indeed it was with the other actresses. Farrah really was a sports-mad airhead, we could tell, and Kate was obviously a bit of a cow. But it didn't matter; the original triumvirate of Angels, lasting only from 1976 to 1978, were as perfect as a circle. If Jill was sporty, Sabrina was analytical; if Sabrina was abrasive, Kelly was comforting; if Kelly was soft, Jill was crisp. When Farrah left after only one season - her character Jill Munroe being replaced by Cheryl Ladd, as Jill's younger sister Chris - the circle slumped and became a sort of squidgy oval. By the time Shelley and Tanya had been substituted, the show was a big, shapeless mess. When it was finally cancelled in 1981, after 109 episodes, everyone had had a gut-full. It was all so different in the beginning. ABC was always the poor relation of American TV networks, ranking lowest ever since its creation and only ever managing a couple of really big shows, one of which was Happy Days. Obviously, they were delighted when Charlie's Angel became the top show of the 1976-77 season and the only new show on any network to become an out-and-out hit. By the end of the first run, 59% of all televisions in use when the show was aired were tuned into it: 23m households. And it never left the Nielsen top 10 for its first three years. There were further surprises when a breakdown of the audience showed that it had ranked fourth in metropolitan areas, seventh amongst college graduates and seventh with the highest-income group. The girls got 18,000 letters a week and ABC charged the highest advertisement rate ever for commercials: $100,000 a minute by the end of the first season. A lot of rubbish is talked these days about girl power and how Charlie's Angels were there first, and an equal amount about how exploitative and sexist it all was. In truth, it was neither: neither saint nor sinner, dom nor sub. It was, instead, one of those sublime, silly, shimmering moments when popular culture gets it absolutely right, like Mony Mony, Coca-Cola or The Simpsons. Up until the 1970s, women on American TV shows had been housewives and mothers; even big stars asked us to suspend our credibility and buy them as dizzy broads forever being scolded by their hubbies. Then Mary Tyler Moore, who had spent the 1960s as the archetypal American angel of the hearth in the Dick Van Dyke Show, reinvented her self as a bold yet vulnerable big city career girl for The Mary Tyler Moore Show. So great was the resonance of this show that Oprah Winfrey, by then the most powerful woman on TV, would be reduced to tears when she greeted a frail, much older Tyler Moore on an episode of Oprah. You'd have needed a heart of stone not to whimper along as Winfrey recalled how, during her impoverished and abused youth in a deep south shack, this paragon of white WASPishness had been her greatest inspiration in holding on to the dream. That's how desperate we were then for TV heroines who weren't wives and mothers; Mary Tyler Moore, stuttering in fear before her fierce editor Lou Grant, seemed like the shining path. In this context, it's not surprising that the Angels - with their guns, judo throws and ability to escape from any situation unscathed, no matter how savage or sordid - seemed like salvation. Would they have been the same if they'd been called The Alley Cats? This was what Aaron Spelling, who created the show as a vehicle for Kate Jackson, star of his series The Rookies, wanted them to be known as. Perhaps the Angels were made to appear permanently unattached so that male audiences would become more loyal and more partisan about their Angel. Typically, at least one Angel will be put in a position where she must strip down to a bikini in the first 10 minutes, or thereafter bring the future of western civilisation into question. The episode titles were all a big tease, too, the first season containing the notorious Angels in Chains as well as Consenting Adults, Dirty Business, Lady Killers and The Blue Angels. The last was an investigation into the pornography industry, but the Angels kept those bikinis on. webTitle: Unsafe as houses

fields.headline: Unsafe as houses
fields.standfirst: A significant number of people live in unfit dwellings. This is unlikely to change without investment from public and private landlords
fields.trailText: Richard Rogers's report on our urban condition, the intellectual basis of the white paper out yesterday, asked why our cities could not be more like Barcelona or Amsterdam. His answer was public spending, which is why the government took such a long time to respond.
fields.body:
Richard Rogers's report on our urban condition, the intellectual basis of the white paper out yesterday, asked why our cities could not be more like Barcelona or Amsterdam. His answer was public spending, which is why the government took such a long time to respond.

But there is another reason why urban renaissance will always be more difficult to effect in this country: we are "old" in the sense that a large proportion of infrastructure, especially housing, was built a long time ago and, despite the best efforts of Herr Goering and the Luftwaffe, is still standing.

London housing is seriously dated compared to England at large, all those suburban drives in Pinner built when Stanley Baldwin was prime minister and, still striding across Streatham, nearly a quarter of the stock belongs to the era of Victoria and her son. The east of England is much newer by comparison but even there, in Norwich, Ipswich and the villages there is a substantial pre-1900 heritage.

Older homes cost more to maintain and that is one reason why a new Joseph Rowntree Foundation report* says nearly a third of all dwellings in England urgently need at least £1,000 spent on them. In Scotland things are worse, a third of dwellings need £3,000 of repairs. In Wales, where one in 25 dwellings needs more than £5,000 worth of urgent repairs, the problem is one of unfitness: one home in 12 lacks something as fundamental as hygienic means of preparing food - a proper kitchen.

Unfitness, not surprisingly, is most evident in 19th century terraces and conversions - detached dwellings in Northern Ireland - and in property left vacant. One reason why you can buy up streets in the Rhondda for the price of a Kensington broom cupboard is that they were jerry-built then and have not enjoyed much investment since.

Housing's glory days as a policy priority - remember Harold Macmillan staking his name on building 300,000 homes a year - are long gone. The very phrase slum clearance speaks of a bygone era; only about 1,000 houses are knocked down each year as a matter of public policy compared with 80,000 in the early 70s. With right to buy, housing became privatised and the trend continues as council estates are transferred to autonomous not-for-profit trusts and associations, some of them with sharp commercial instincts. On what they still have councils proportionately spend a lot more than owner occupiers or private landlords.

It is, however, private owners who have the key to our "crumbling castles". They often have neither the means nor the will to maintain their property. They may miss more complex technical problems or delay too long; research shows widespread misapprehension about likely costs.

People rarely seek the help of architects or structural engineers on repairs possibly because they would bring more problems to their attention; they rely instead on "informal repair diagnosis" by themselves, relatives, friends, contacts in the building trade, or Bill the bodger. Bill, researchers note, has an obvious conflict of interest if he is also asked to provide a quotation.

The psychology of house purchase is puzzling: many buy without a detailed survey and most owners have no long-term maintenance plan or any specific financial provision for future repair costs. Recent movers and others without a network of contacts are most likely to have problems finding a builder. Few people regularly check for repair problems, most just respond when the roof leaks or the ceiling falls in.

None the less home owners spend a huge amount - over £35bn a year - on DIY and builders. (Tenants, inevitably, are disinclined to spend). That is at least £354 per household per year, But do you include paint and light fittings in "repair"; does a new phone socket count towards enhancing a property's life?

We know poor owner-occupiers live in the worst conditions. More than one in 10 households with an income below £4,000 live in unfit dwellings; they are mainly older people, often women by themselves and young people setting up on their own. For households with £24,000 coming in each year the figure is one in 24.

Home owners can still get improvement grants, but only about 35,000 a year are now given out - half to elderly people - compared with 300,000 in the early 80s before the Tory pruning. Oddly, grant levels dropped much less elsewhere in the UK: it is a lot easier to get grants in Glasgow, Cardiff and Belfast than in London. Shetland with the Orkneys are the most generous areas.

Improvement comes in many forms - councils have been providing more help to adapt buildings for people with disabilities. Local authorities still operate area renewal where whole streets are scheduled - the most recent count showed 160,000 dwellings in such areas, mainly in the north and Midlands.

Experts are unsure about the long-run outlook. When does extensive disrepair make a house uninhabitable or fit only for demolition? There is, we know, no causal relationship between house price and house condition, especially in London. Disrepair is an instance of market failure. That is to say, the market would work better if a lot of old and poor people could be put out on the streets and their homes flattened or sold to developers.

*Housing conditions in 2000 www.jrf.org.uk Kerry Revell and Philip Leather, The state of UK housing, Policy Press

That is to say, the market would work better if a lot of old and poor people could be put out on the streets and their homes flattened or sold to developers. *Housing conditions in 2000 www.jrf.org.uk Kerry Revell and Philip Leather, The state of UK housing, Policy Press

webTitle: Restaurants: The Red Lion and Cedar Farm Cafe, Lancashire

fields.headline: The Red Lion and Cedar Farm Cafe, Lancashire
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Telephone: 01704 822208.

Address: The Red Lion, New Street, Mawdesley, Lancashire L40 2QP.

Pub grub is often a pre-frozen affair, either that or it's a cheese toastie and a packet of limp salt and vinegar crisps. The Red Lion, on the other hand, is an astonishingly busy village pub serving a rather nice pint of Theakston's, and downright brilliant food in the cosy, conservatoried dining room out the back. There's an early doors menu (6-7.30pm, Mon-Fri; 6.30-7.00, Sat) when it's £9.50 for two courses and £10.50 for three. The menu changes daily, but expect such delights as grilled black pudding with black peppercorn sauce, duck breast with apple and cider sauce, and strawberry and vanilla parfait for pudding.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Telephone: 01704 823396.

Address: Cedar Farm Cafe, Back Lane, Mawdesley, Lancashire L40 3SY.

Cedar Farm is a working pig farm with craft workshops and studios, a gallery, clothes shop, aroma room, deli, and espresso bar. The cafe, which is also licensed, has been open for 10 years, and is renowned for its soup, which comes in starter-sized portions with flavours such as celeriac and cider or butternut squash with lime and ginger, and main course sizes, which are deliciously gloopier almost-stews and chowders. But there are pasta dishes, bagels and wraps available too, and nothing costs more than £5.50. Puddings are hearty and toe-warming, of the poached plums and bread and butter pudding variety.

On the menu

Cassonade

What is it? Not too sure, to be honest.
Not admitting to fallibility are we? Not as such. In the dictionary it is defined as crystallised unrefined sugar.
That's clear enough. So what's the red pepper cassonade that cropped up on a fashionable menu the other day? Ask the chef.
I did. He said cassonade is a dried substance, usually, but not always sugar, which is defined by the size of the granules as well as the level of sweetness. Oh, do the hokey-cokey and shake it all about. Sounds like chef-poesy to me.
What does it taste like? Hot stuff.

Just out

Yellow beans

Form: Long pods like bobby beans or extra big French beans, and distinctly yellow.
Flavour: Very bean-like; fresh, slightly grassy; quite mild; really rather delicious.
Verdict: A handsome addition to the range of beans and domestic vegetables. But beware. The yellow bean conceals a hidden menace. No, not the ones you're thinking of. They need to be thoroughly de-strung. High tensile fibre runs down either side of each bean, which, if not removed, can cause very dramatic choking fits as the fibres link the bit of the bean you've swallowed to the bit if the bean still in your mouth. I know.
Price: £1.29 for 200g at Sainsbury's.

Food on the net

www.jewishfood-list.com

Chicken soup cravings? Does your mind keep wandering to thoughts of lox and bagels? Then this site is for you. With a list of gefilte fish recipes as long as your arm, and a frankly obscene number of hamentaschen recipes, you'll be able to quell those jewish grub cravings faster than you can say blintzes.

Pros: Squillions of recipes, including artichokes with okra vinaigrette and duck with pomegranate sauce. All recipes are labelled pareve, meat, dairy or pesach-friendly, and there's a handy link to an online guide to help you keep your kitchen kosher.
Cons: Kosher Komedy section, featuring such "gems" as "Let my people fress". Groan.

webTitle: Matthem Fort: It's time to claim back pickles from the WI

fields.headline: It's time to claim back our pickles
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort says that we've left them far too long to the Women's Institute
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort says that we've left them far too long to the Women's Institute.
fields.body:
Pickles have an image problem. "Pickled as a newt", "in a pickle" and "Branston" are just a little of the baggage that they drag in their wake. Yet mention a pickled onion, and the cockles of the heart begin to stir. The pickled onion, like the sausage and fish and chips, is one of the few universal foods of the country, and one for which there is the same half-humorous affection. But what about pickled walnuts, pickled samphire, pickled nasturtium buds, pickled carrots, pickled damsons? Well, what about them?

Essentially, pickling is a pretty simple business. You subject the food to be pickled to salt in its dry form or as a brine to draw out some of the water, which otherwise would dilute the vinegar into which you then plunge them (having washed off the salt), along with flavouring spices such as cloves, allspice and coriander and chilli if you feel like a hot pickle, and that's about it - the safe and simple method of preserving foods produced in times of abundance for times when they aren't. Early Britons would have used verjuice, a sour concoction made from crab apples, while earlier Romans and Greeks, and the Egyptians and Sumerians before them, would have used the same stuff only made from grapes. Vinegar is a relative newcomer to the cook's armoury.

By impregnating foods with acids, we protect them from the microbes that otherwise would sprout on them. The most usual form of pickling is the salt'n'vinegar method, but there is another branch of the art, which involves fermenting the food. Fermentation causes acid-producing bacteria to grow, which has the same effect as the vinegar in the long term. The fermentation method has never really taken off in this country, probably because it's too much fuss, but the Alsatian choucroute, German sauerkraut and the Polish bigos owe their existence to the method.

In fact, other countries take their pickles much more seriously than we do. Rather typically, the Americans (who are in something of a presidential pickle at the moment) have made the dill pickle into a fetish as well as part of their daily diet. There are 50 or so variations of the pickled mini-cucumber, over which Americans will argue much like the schools of philosophy in ancient Athens while they crunch 5m pounds of them every day. No wonder they were a part of the American army's rations during world war two (just as, incidentally, they had been in the rations of Napoleon's grand army).

The Japanese regard pickling as an art form, the Chinese see it as a measure of a woman's marriageability, and the Koreans have made kimchi - pickled veg in various forms - their national dish. Jewish and Muslim cultures in the Middle East are united in their love of pickled turnips. The Italians pickle sott'olio, dunking sliced melanzane in vinegar before immersing them in olive oil.

We, on the other hand, have rather left it to the Women's Institute to be the guardians of our great pickling traditions, just as they are the custodians of jam and cake making. Gone, maybe, the great sallats, salmagundis and other elaborate confections, to which pickles brought their distinctive piquancy.

Perhaps we became sidetracked by pickles' close cousins, chutneys, ketchups and relishes. Given how easy they are to produce, how delicious their flavours, and versatile their uses, perhaps it's time to claim our pickling inheritance back from the WI.

 Matthew Fort presents a programme on pickling on the Food Programme on Radio 4 at 12.30pm on Sunday November 19, repeated at 4pm on Monday November 20.

webTitle: ITN warns BBC of falling ratings over news shift

fields.headline: ITN warns BBC of falling ratings over news shift
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The BBC's decision to axe the Nine O'Clock News will cost it 1m viewers, ITN chiefs have warned. By David Rowan.
fields.body:
The BBC's decision to axe the Nine O'Clock News will cost it 1m viewers, ITN bosses have warned.

ITN editor-in-chief Richard Tait said the move to 10pm had placed "the whole BBC news strategy at the mercy of a ratings battle".

And he added that he and his colleagues at ITV were "relishing" the ratings battle that will be unleashed when ITV resurrects News at Ten in the new year.

"Next year, there will probably be a reversal of what happened when [ITN's] News at Ten moved and the BBC gained about a million people from ITN," Mr Tait told the Newsworld conference in Barcelona.

"I suspect we will see them moving back. And that will be a real problem for the BBC."

Describing the BBC's decision to move its main evening bulletin as "a bit of a punt", Mr Tait said that ITN's own research showed that the 9pm slot was more effective than 10pm at attracting audience share.

ITV attracted more than 11m viewers when it introduced a bulletin at 9pm to cover the floods.

"This shows there are simply more people around at 9pm," Mr Tait added.

Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news, also criticised the BBC for "scrapping the Nine O'Clock News and marginalising Panorama to a late Sunday night slot and cutting it from 38 programmes to 30".

Mark Byford, chief executive of the BBC World Service, defended the corporation's decision to move the news as a means of "rejuvenating" BBC1.

"This is not about scrapping the Nine O'Clock News, but about positioning the BBC's news services to get maximum reach, while addressing falling ratings," he said.

"By moving the news to 10 o'clock, we [saw that we] would be able to attract a larger audience. Ten o'clock is not marginalisation - it's actually at the heart of the schedule."

Tony Burman, executive director of news and current affairs for CBC, the Canadian public service broadcaster, added his own warning to both the BBC and ITN.

He said: "Eight years ago CBC moved its flagship 10pm news programme to 9pm. That lasted a year - it was disastrous. It's a real risk to any network to move such a substantial part of its news schedule."

Mr Burnam said he had advised ITN last year not to axe News at Ten.

webTitle: Spider-Man admits bugs bug him

fields.headline: Spider-Man admits bugs bug him
fields.trailText: Tobey Maguire is having to come to terms with a number of phobias on the set of the Spider-Man film.
fields.body:
Tobey Maguire is having to come to terms with a number of phobias on the set of the Spider Man film.

The 25-year-old actor is currently shooting special head and body shots for the cinema version of the comic book story about a nerdy student bitten by a radioactive spider, and has gone on record about the far from glamorous life of a crime-busting superhero.

"They did this head cast of me," Maguire told reporters, "and all I have is two little nose holes and they put one layer on and then let it harden and then another layer and then a plaster cast - the process took a half hour.

"But when it hardens it heats up and becomes hard and hot and heavy. I freaked out and had the guys take it off me. They did a body cast as well and that wasn't much better. I have hair on my legs and when they took it off it really hurt."

Aaah. Not only does Maguire have to come to terms with his claustrophobia and depilatory agony, but he's also trying to get to grips with his fear of insects before shooting begins in January.

Maguire admitted that despite his best efforts to get to grips with his fellow bugs, creepy-crawlies freak him out. "There was a grasshopper in my house and I considered putting a glass over it and carrying it outside. . . but I just freaked out and had to drop it. I was really disappointed with myself and I was pacing back and forth thinking: 'I'm gonna be Spiderman and I gotta be able to grab this bug and take it outside.' So I grabbed it again but it turned around in my hand and I freaked out again and dropped it, and decided to work on that part of my character another day. It was like psychological warfare."

Director Sam Raimi must be wondering what he let himself in for.

More about Spider-Man at Marvel Comics.

webTitle: Overexposed - metal eyelets

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ...metal eyelets
fields.trailText: ...metal eyelets
fields.body:
"Prada, Prada, must copy Prada" still seems to be the mantra among fashion designers across the spectrum. Despite scurrilous whispers suggesting the label is losing its cachet, what Prada has on its shelves this season remains a darned good indication of what other designers will be pushing in a few months time. Either that, or style ideas are strangely contagious in the fashion world.

Take the rather remarkable example of metal eyelets (large holes punched into the fabric, then defined with a metal circle). This season, Prada has made a whole set of bags in black leather with silver eyelets. Meanwhile, its fellow Italian luxe designer, Marni, has produced shoulder bags with, yes, metal eyelets decorating the strap.

The trend is not limited to the higher echelons of the fashion scale. Jigsaw already has some nippy little suede belts in store, (£18, 020-8392 5678) with the requisite eyelet detail.

And, lo and behold, this summer you will run the risk of falling through one of those eyelet things, so prevalent will they be on the fashion wheel. There's Christian Louboutin with his black leather/metal eyelet stiletto sandals, but you can get more casual ones from Nikki B at the West Village (020-7795 2604) whose leather wedges come in various colours. Clements Ribeiro, in a break from their sweetly simple norm, have taken the trend away from the domain of accessories and come up with entire leather outfits decorated with eyelets. And the usual high street suspects (New Look, Top Shop) are already jumping on the bandwagon.

The real question is, though, not why fashion folk would want to resemble dominatrixes but whether designers operate by telepathy so that everyone knows what the season's trend is. Or could it simply be a dearth of originality? Oh, Surely not.

webTitle: The titans of the fashion world are speaking their minds

fields.headline: Stitched up
fields.standfirst: Ouch! Suddenly the titans of the fashion world are speaking their minds, finds  Charlie Porter
fields.trailText: Ouch! Suddenly the titans of the fashion world are speaking their minds, finds Charlie Porter.
fields.body:
Honesty has never been a characteristic needed in fashion. We all know the tales: "Yes, sales are fantastic" (even though all of the stock is still left on the rails); "Of course I am happy at my atelier" (but we all know a one-way ticket has been booked on the London-bound Eurostar); "You know, yellow can be really flattering" (yeah, right). But recently, a new openness has swept through the houses, with designers speaking out like never before. Not only are these influential figures bitching on the record about their rivals, when before they would have muttered under their breath; they are also talking for the first time about their jobs in reality-speak, discussing their problems and fears rather than hiding in the fairy-tale dreams of glossy magazines.

Karl Lagerfeld, crowing from his position at the top of the designer hierachy, has let rip with a tirade of insults. "If you want to see a retrospective of Azzedine Alaia, just look at what he's doing now," says the Chanel and Fendi designer about a New York exhibition of Alaia's work. "Chloe? It's very flea market-like, isn't it? Or is it a T-shirt label?" he says about Stella McCartney's work (tellingly, he was the Chloe designer until the early 90s). And about his 60s contemporaries? "There was this place called Le Fiacre that had a gay cruising area downstairs and a trendy restaurant upstairs," he declares. "Valentino and Yves were there every night. Yves spent most of his time upstairs, but Valentino was downstairs - never upstairs." Touché.

Meanwhile, Giorgio Armani has become publicly dismissive of his rival Italian fashion houses. "Gucci is an assembler of things," he declares. "It seems that Tom Ford finds these little bits and pieces everywhere and puts them together. Above all, things that were made by other people." Armani also reignited the bitter war between him and the house of Versace, by quoting Gianni Versace as admitting: "I dress sluts."

Some designers reserve their anger for their bosses. "Fire me! 'Cause that's what I wanted anyway," Alexander McQueen taunts Givenchy in the current issue of Arena. "Yeah, I did want to leave, but I can't. I have to see my contract through." So begins an astonishing assault that confirms all of fashion-land's suspicions about his feelings for the house. Since McQueen started at Givenchy in 1996, it has been clear that the relationship has been a fractious one, never having the mutual respect experienced by LVMH colleagues John Galliano at Dior or Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton. With every season, the rumours of an imminent split have grown stronger, but McQueen has managed to keep his cool, until now.

In explaining his reasons for the feud, McQueen lets slip some secrets about how the industry works. The designer does not necessarily have control of what eventually goes on sale. "When the collections leave my hands," he states, "they go into the hands of other people and then whatever I've done on the catwalks has been dismissed. As you can see from the windows and the advertising. It just gets completely taken away."

As well as having to put up with in-house machinations, poor McQueen also gets it in the ear from two of the old guard: Yves Saint Laurent and Vivienne Westwood. "There are murderers at the couture houses," exclaims Saint Laurent, then separately states, "Givenchy's clients are coming to me now. There is no one. I don't see a single talent." Meanwhile, Westwood was typically curt with her comments. "His only usefulness is as a measure of zero talent." McQueen has replied to both of their attacks. "I kind of had high regard for her," he says, "but I think she's starting to sound as naff as Malcolm McLaren." And YSL? "It's sad. It's like pop stars. People should know when to pack it in."

This new honesty is extending to designers' private lives. While not exactly being out and proud, usually closeted fashion players have started to be more open about their homosexuality: McQueen says he is married to his partner, George, who appears to have had a profoundly calming influence on the once troubled designer, Tom Ford is happily settled with Vogue Hommes International editor Richard Buckley and Giorgio Armani has spoken for the first time about his personal relationship with his late business partner Sergio Rossi. Even Lagerfeld is more open, if dismissive. Asked when he last had sex, he brusquely states: "I can't remember, and even if I could I wouldn't tell you. You should save questions like that for Tom Ford - he likes to talk about that kind of thing."

This sudden frankness seems in part to be caused by the wave of retrospectives, retirements and acquisitions in fashion at the moment; designers of the older generation appear to be taking stock and reflecting on their situation. Armani has spoken at length to support his current 25th anniversary exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in New York. webTitle: New powers to halt flight from the cities

fields.headline: New powers to halt flight from the cities
fields.standfirst: Schemes for better housing design and planning
fields.trailText: Councils and government agencies have been promised new compulsory purchase powers to force through the redevelopment of derelict sites in a package of measures designed to breathe new life into towns and cities.
fields.byline: Peter Hetherington, regional affairs correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Councils and government agencies have been promised new compulsory purchase powers to force through the redevelopment of derelict sites in a package of measures designed to breathe new life into towns and cities.

Legislation to reclaim some of the 58,000 hectares of vacant land blighting urban areas is likely to be introduced after the general election in a widespread review of the planning system.

An urban white paper, hailed as the most comprehensive policy framework of its kind for almost half a century, also promised 12 new public-private sector urban regeneration companies - similar to existing bodies in Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield - and regional centres of excellence to improve the quality of housing design and planning. The first will be created in Manchester and London.

Town improvement zones will also be encouraged, backed with a new supplementary business rate after agreement with retailers, to curb the flight to the countryside and encourage people back into cities.

At the heart of the 160-page paper, partly a response to last year's report of an urban task force chaired by the architect Lord Rogers, is the dilemma of where to find space for an estimated 3.8m new households in England by 2021. Although the country's population of 49m is expected to rise by 7% in this period, the number of households is projected to rise by 19% because of a growing demand for single-person accommodation.

This is due to people living longer, a rise in divorce rate, and more young people staying single.

But with England "one of the most densely populated countries in the world", yesterday's report said the current rate of green field house building was unacceptable.

It lamented that new houses had been built at low densities averaging only 25 units per hectare, compared with up to 40 per hectare in Victorian England and in older suburbs. Other countries did much better, the report said.

It warned that the present level of greenfield building threatened the countryside "and fuels the flow of people away from urban centres towards the edge of cities and beyond".

To reverse the rural drift, the white paper underlined the importance of last week's decision by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to offer developers tax incentives for recycling urban land and buildings.

These include abolishing stamp duty on property transactions in poor areas, 100% capital allowances for developers converting space over shops into flats, and a 5% VAT rate - down from the present 17.5% - for people who turn older buildings into flats.

But environmental groups said the measures fell far short of creating a level playing field because new houses are zero-rated and outside the VAT net. The Empty Homes Agency, a charity partly funded by the government, believes the flat 5% rate should be levied on new homes and conversions.

Ashley Horsey, director of the EHA, said the tax measures would do little to bring an estimated 750,000 empty houses back into use.

The new 5% VAT rate was too restrictive because it was confined only to flat conversions and not to house improvements which will still be liable to the full 17.5%.

The opposition was also critical. Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, said the white paper would be remembered for missed opportunities. "Why no development tax?" he asked.

Archie Norman, shadow environment secretary, claimed the government was spending less on regeneration than the Tories.

He claimed the decision to plan for 900,000 new houses in the south-east would accelerate the drift to the countryside.

But the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, insisted that new planning guidelines would force developers on to urban sites. They would only be allowed to go to the countryside as a last resort .

Road away from ruin

1977 Urban white paper calls for new government programme to tackle decline

1981 Riots in Brixton and Liverpool. Michael Heseltine, environment secretary, loses battle for more government money to revive cities

1981 Docklands and Merseyside urban development corporations launched

1986 More development corporations launched. Spending on bricks and mortar rather than on people

1987 Margaret Thatcher makes her "walk in the wilderness". Extols virtues of Victorian philanthropists, but says extra government money will not turn cities around

1994 Michael Hesletine launches city challenge scheme. Invites councils to bid for regeneration cash. This move is criticised as a lottery

1998 John Prescott launches urban task force, chaired by Lord Rogers. Subsequently calls are made for special tax breaks to lure developers into cities in special priority areas, as well as curbs on greenfield building, and better design with special urban architecture centres

2000 Gordon Brown, the chancellor, meets Lord Rogers. In last week's pre-budget statement, he agrees to give cities tax concessions in order to kick-start development

webTitle: Murdoch seeks Saudi royal's backing for Sky Global

fields.headline: Murdoch seeks Saudi royal's backing for Sky Global
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Rupert Murdoch has turned to Saudi royalty in a bid to get his Sky Global Networks business off the ground, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch has turned to Saudi royalty in a bid to get his Sky Global Networks business off the ground.

Financier Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal is said to be interested in taking a stake in the company, which is made up of the satellite TV interests of Mr Murdoch's News Corporation.

The only backer for Sky Global so far is US cable group Liberty Media, with Microsoft also considering a stake in the venture.

Prince Alwaleed's financial backing could lead to Murdoch bidding for DirecTV, the television operation of General Motors.

The Saudi prince's interest comes at a crucial time for Mr Murdoch. Sky Global's eagerly anticipated flotation has been delayed until next year, mainly due to wrangles over French rival Vivendi's role in the company.

Vivendi is selling its 23% stake in Mr Murdoch's BSkyB. The sale threatens to bring down the value of Sky Global.

Mr Murdoch has also cited volatile market conditions as a reason for delaying the float, although Sky Global is guaranteed significant investor interest whenever it launches.

webTitle: Big hike in funding for universities

fields.headline: Big hike in funding for universities
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities in England yesterday gave a cautious welcome to a funding settlement worth an extra £497m in three years' time.
fields.body:
Universities in England yesterday gave a cautious welcome to a funding settlement worth an extra £497m in three years' time.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, heralded a hike of "almost a billion" - £978m - in planned higher education funding in 2003-04, compared with this year. But more than half of the money, including cash for improving access for working class and disabled students, foundation degrees and the "e-university" had been previously announced earlier.

The money will mean a real terms increase in funding per student for the first time since the 1980s, Mr Blunkett said, even allowing for plans to make an extra 78,000 student places, mainly part-time and below degree level, available over three years.

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, estimated the settlement would do no more than hold the 1% increase in per student funding previously unveiled for 2001-02.

Including money already promised, funding for universities will increase by £412m in 2001-02, £268m in 2002-03, and £298m the year after - almost £6.4bn in 2003-04, compared with £5.4bn this year.

Another £1bn for UK research, to be made available from 2002, was announced in July, and universities can bid for a share of £250m for research into genomics, e-science and technology.

About £330m of the extra money is earmarked for pay for university staff.

The higher education funding council for England will consult on how to distribute the money, but it is likely to be used to address pay discrimination against women academics. Some may also be earmarked to retain scientists.

Unions hope the guaranteed funding increases puts pressure on universities to reach a pay settlement early.

Mr Triesman said the £330m was about half the amount required to fulfil the recommendations of the independent Bett report on academic pay. "It's not enough money to do the job by any means. But we have moved out of a really quite long period of year on year cuts. The effect of year on year cuts produced massive difficulty which were never going to be overcome in a year or two."

Results of strike ballots among university lecturers will be declared next Wednesday. A one day strike is scheduled to take place on December 5 and will also launch further action, including an overtime ban.

Paul Mackney, general secretary of the National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education, which is backing strike action, welcomed the money. "Lecturers whose wages are 30% lower than in comparable professions will be expecting to see some of this extra cash."

The Transport and General Workers Union, representing 10,000 cleaners, caterers and other non-academic staff, said the increase would fall short of the £4.22 to £5.57 an hour rise recommended by Bett.

webTitle: C5 picks up award for news clarity

fields.headline: C5 picks up award for news clarity
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Channel 5's hourly news bulletin has been voted the country's best national TV programme at the Plain English Media Awards. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Channel 5's hourly news bulletin has been voted the country's best national television programme at the Plain English Media Awards.

It picked up the top prize after a panel of industry experts commended its ability "to get across lots of news in a short time, without dumbing down or making light of serious stories".

The Plain English Campaign, the pressure group that battles against gobbledegook, also voted the Daily Telegraph as best national newspaper.

John Lister, a senior spokesperson for the awards, said: "The Telegraph winning will come as a surprise to some people but they do write appropriately for their intended audience.

"They've done a particularly good job of highlighting how officialese and confusing forms affect people in all walks of life."

The annual awards ceremony recognises reporters working in newspapers, radio and television for their clear communication.

Other awards went to News North-West for best regional newspaper, Week In, Week Out from BBC Wales for best regional television programme, Sunday Service from BBC Five Live for best national radio programme and BBC Northampton for best regional radio station.

News North West picked up its award for concise reporting "for commuters who don't have time to wade through lengthy articles".

Week In, Week Out was praised for its courage in tackling potentially complicated issues and concentrating on how issues affect real people.

Sunday Service presenters were commended for letting everyone express their view and for 'not putting up with any bull'.

BBC Northampton, representing a town where Christmas lights were once referred to as 'festive embellishments of an illuminatory nature', was also highlighted for its use of simple English.

The Plain English Campaign is an independent pressure group formed in 1979 to fight gobbledegook and unclear public information. It is funded through commercial activities including editing and training.

The Golden Bull prize for the worst example of gobbledegook will not be announced until December 6 at the awards ceremony in London.

webTitle: Internet to get new addresses

fields.headline: Internet to get millions of new domain names
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The internet is to get a raft of new addresses amid fears that the world is running out of dotcoms, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The internet is to get a raft of new addresses amid fears that the world is running out of dot.coms.

Companies across the world have already registered some 20m names ending in .com, intensifying competition for the few remaining addresses.

This has created an internet goldrush that has meant some web addresses are now worth millions of pounds.

To ease the pressure on web addresses the organisation that regulates them has given its seal of approval to seven new suffixes including .biz for businesses, .name for individuals and .prof for professionals.

But the US-based organisation, called Icann (the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names & Numbers), turned down a proposed .kids suffix for websites aimed at children, due to fears it could be hijacked by pornographic sites.

The new names are the first major additions to the web lexicon since the system of domain names was developed in the 1980s.

The new addresses could begin to be used as early as next year.

There are already some specialist national suffixes in use, such as .gov and .edu for government and educational organisations. But .com, .net and .org are the only suffixes that can be used worldwide.

webTitle: TBWA/London wins Eurostar ad account

fields.headline: TBWA/London catches Eurostar ad account
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Eurostar has awarded TBWA/London its £5.5m advertising business, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Eurostar has awarded TBWA/London its £5.5m advertising business as it seeks to develop more consistent branding across Europe.

The train operator has suffered from lack of coherence in its advertising since its futuristic launch campaign through Young & Rubicam in 1994.

The account in the UK is currently held by St Luke's, which produced a quirky campaign fronted by Antoine de Caunes and a philosophising Eric Cantona.

More recently, the agency produced a series of ads using the strapline "As if by magic, Paris arrived". The strategy then changed again with a cartoon-style campaign introducing the phrase "Let's go conti-mental'.

TBWA's appointment comes after a shootout against incumbent agency Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R.

The decision follows a major shake-up at Eurostar, which resulted in the creation of the Eurostar Group and a shift towards a more European approach to the company's marketing.

webTitle: Child nutrition scheme will target health inequalities

fields.headline: Child nutrition scheme will target health inequalities
fields.standfirst: Apples and pears for school infants
fields.trailText: Ministers have launched the biggest programme in 50 years to improve children's eating habits and health.
fields.byline: James Meikle, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Ministers have launched the biggest programme in 50 years to improve children's eating habits and health as infant and nursery school pupils began receiving free fruit from the government.

Apples, bananas, pears and satsumas are being provided to 35 schools in London and the Midlands with hundreds more becoming involved next term. Ministers have ordered that all four to six-year-olds should be offered free fruit by 2004 as part of a campaign to increase children's daily intake of fruit and vegetables. Nutrition surveys have found that one in five children eat no fruit in a week and those that do eat just two portions of fruit and veg a day.

Evidence suggests eating five portions a day could cut deaths from heart disease, strokes and cancer by about a fifth. It can also help fight asthma, which now affects one in seven children. But children from poor families are only half as likely to eat fruit as other youngsters.

webTitle: Wireless surfing for £20 a month

fields.headline: Wireless surfing for £20 a month
fields.trailText: The move toward unmetered internet use shifted to new ground yesterday when British Telecom introduced unlimited mobile phone web access for £20 a month.
fields.body:
The move toward unmetered internet use shifted to new ground yesterday when British Telecom introduced unlimited mobile phone web access for £20 a month.

The service is being made available through BT Cellnet's Genie internet portal. Initially the offer is open only to post-pay users although a pre-pay version will be available shortly.

A version covering text messages only is available for £10 a month. Kent Thexton, managing director of Genie, said the company was throwing away the rule book. "The stakes are high. By 2003 more people will be connected to the internet via mobile devices than personal computers."

Wap (wireless application protocol) phones have been criticised for the slowness of net connection and paucity of services.

The industry expects the next-step technology, GPRS, to boost mobile internet access next year by providing far higher speeds and an "always on" service which means there is no need to dial up.

Pressures for unmetered internet access have been felt most strongly in the fixed-line market where a range of packages are now available. BT claims this is the first time that model has been adapted for the wireless market .
