webTitle: Seven out of ten, Mr Prescott

fields.headline: Seven out of ten, Mr Prescott
fields.standfirst: Fair for starters, but now the hard part begins, saysJonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: The urban white paper is a sign that Lord Rogers' task force has been more than an elegant talking shop, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
Not bad, Mr Prescott. Not bad. The government's urban white paper scores a good seven out of 10. Or to put this another way, the white paper has adopted 70% of the forward-looking recommendations made by Lord Rogers's urban task force report,Towards an Urban Renaissance, 15 months ago.

These were concerned with raising the standard of environment and design in our city centres to make life better for those who live and work in them and to discourage the continuing urban diaspora.

By ennobling our cities, we can save the countryside we say we love but wish to smother with something like 4m trashy new homes over the next 10 or 15 years because we want to escape downgraded and dirty city centres.

The white paper offers practical solutions connecting the quality of urban design and transport infrastructure with the quality of life in our cities. Mr Prescott offers, for example, a dozen new private-public urban regeneration companies. These may well be be able to redevelop areas such as London's King's Cross, by making the complex mix of private, public and local authority landowners in such areas shareholders in a carrot-and-carrot operation. All players would benefit financially and environmentally.

Money, assuming the white paper becomes legislation, will no longer be pumped into regenerating particular areas of cities unless this is met by three-dimensional design plans rather than vague two-dimensional diagrams and lists of statistics; in other words, standards of urban design, from the look of buildings to the treatment of pavements, alleys and public squares will be forced to rise.

We may yet get away from the dismal bollards and tweedy brick paving with everything approach to urban design favoured by most British city authorities as they remain at least 20 years behind the standards of design set in, say, Barcelona or Copenhagen.

Whether the British can muster the talent and energy to match the government's new found desire to improve life in our city centres with the necessary high standards of design remains to be seen.

They will have to rise if Mr Prescott and his successors at the head of the DTR are to be able to deliver with any credibility the promised Al Gore-style annual report on the state of our cities to parliament. Sure, statistics about pollution and rubbish collection might be useful speech fodder, but the white paper does finally recognise that the physical design of our cities plays as much of a part in whether they are nurtured or neglected as any amount of cleaning and scrubbing.

Only last month the prime minister held a reception at 10 Downing Street supporting higher standards in the design of public buildings. Although the urban white paper does mean government departments working together across the monopoly board of our city centres, the proposals need the active and vocal support of the prime minister, the cabinet and Whitehall.

If we are to treat our cities with the intelligence and grace that the Spanish and the Danes, among others, have learned to, we still need get regeneration bodies from English Partnerships to local authorities to take design seriously. The signs are that the government is beginning to try, that ministries are talking to ministries and that Lord Rogers' s task force has been more than an elegant talking shop.

webTitle: The urban white paper lacks a sense of wholehearted commitment

fields.headline: The urban white paper lacks a sense of wholehearted commitment
fields.trailText: Guardian comment: The white paper on urban renaissance is an advance, but only a start on a very long journey
fields.body:
Lord Rogers, the chairman of the urban task force, got it right: yesterday's white paper on urban renaissance was a welcome advance, but only a start on a very long journey. It offers a vision of what our towns and cities, where 80% of us live, could be like in 20 years, but on a succession of crucial issues - land assembly, land clean-up, resource allocation and statutory powers - it falls short, as he said, of what is going to be required to engender a real urban renaissance.

The challenge is familiar. A country with the world's first industrial cities has seen them in steep and accelerating decline as successive governments promoted new towns, out-of-town shopping malls and M4 golden corridor development. The population of Manchester and Liverpool has fallen by a third in the last 25 years. Over 500,000 jobs have been lost in 20 major cities. All is not bleak. Town centres are being revived. The first new homes for years are being provided for affluent single people by converting central warehouses. It is just beyond the centre that the trouble really sets in. Read Peter Hetherington's account today of east Manchester: derelict land, falling population, plummeting property prices. Yet this is where redevelopment must take place if the switch from greenfield to brownfield sites is to be made. The urban task force warned what would happen unless that is done: with 3.8m new homes needed by 2021, an area bigger than Exmoor would be concreted over.

Yesterday's white paper was the first on this theme for 23 years. Although delayed, many earlier government initiatives are more important than yesterday's, including the 10-year £180bn new transport strategy, the drive to raise inner-city school standards (vital if families are to be attracted back), the reduction in property and car crime. There is the promise of stricter planning laws and 12 new urban regeneration "companies". What is missing is a sense of whole-hearted commitment. Last week's tax concessions on urban redevelopment have shrivelled with the release of the details. There is no promise of a renaissance bill, to avoid piecemeal legislation and end the bickering between departments; planning obligations have still to be "reviewed". Not so much a renaissance, then, as a reawakening.

webTitle: Phone auction collapses

fields.headline: Phone auction collapses
fields.standfirst:
Government's £1.1bn windfall hopes dwindle as bidders shun airwave offer
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: 8am: The government's auction of licences for broadband fixed wireless services looks set to flop as half the licences remain unsold. David Teather reports.
fields.body:
The government's hope of reaping a sizeable windfall from the auction of fixed wireless spectrum seemed in doubt last night as it emerged that almost half the licences available will be left unsold.

The auction is due to resume again this morning after another day's recess was called yesterday - the third since the process began. The auction has so far raised £38.1m and has a long way to go if it is to reach anything like the £1.1bn estimated by some analysts.

The government made 42 licences available - three in each of 14 regions. Each licence allows phone companies to beam streams of internet data to rooftop aerials.

Seven of the regions, including the south coast, Derbyshire and much of the home counties, have so far received no bids at all.

There is a strong possibility that some of the regions will end up without any access to broadband fixed wireless services - which will allow an internet link at least 20 times faster than present modems.

According to the complex rules of the auction, companies are forced to make a certain amount of bids in each round or else lose "credits" - the number of licences for which they are allowed to bid.

The lack of activity means that only about 25 of the 42 could now actually be sold. That is likely to drift down further as the auction progresses.

Ministers are now faced with the prospect of deciding what to do with any unsold licences.

The government's enthusiasm for auctions was sparked by the competition for next generation mobile phone licences, which outstripped all expectations to net £22.5bn for the Treasury.

Four of the initial line-up of 10 companies competing for the fixed wireless licences had indicated to the Department of Trade & Industry that they intended to go for national coverage. Because of the credit system, that is now an impossibility for any bidder.

But a DTI spokesman refused to accept that the auction had been a flop. "The auction will still raise a significant amount of money and has been successful in placing a value on these licences," he said. A combined reserve price of £78m was put on the 42 licences.

The auction has attracted 10 bidders, including Eircom, Broadnet, owned by US cable company Comcast and Chorus, owned jointly by Liberty Media and Independent News & Media. Energis, Norweb and Winstar are also bidding.

The first to pull out was Unica, a business-to-business telecoms firm.

Winning firms will be able to offer broadband services at data rates in excess of 2Mbits a second, compared with a maximum of 2Mbits a second for next generation mobile phones.

They will be able to offer services including fast, "always on", access to the internet, video conferencing, video on demand, high capacity data transfer and the usual online shopping, banking and games.

The fixed wireless system works via a small box attached to the outside of a building receiving signals from transmitters. It is expected to be used by firms hoping to target smaller businesses, typically in areas where cable or fibre optic nets have not been built.

The most active competition has been in London. Energis is leading the race for licence one, with an offer of £4.54m, Broadnet is currently holding licence two, with £4.62m, and Faultbasic licence three, with a £4.54m bid.

Four of the initial line-up of 10 companies competing for the fixed wireless licences had indicated to the Department of Trade & Industry that they intended to go for national coverage. Because of the credit system, that is now an impossibility for any bidder. But a DTI spokesman refused to accept that the auction had been a flop. "The auction will still raise a significant amount of money and has been successful in placing a value on these licences," he said. A combined reserve price of £78m was put on the 42 licences. The auction has attracted 10 bidders, including Eircom, Broadnet, owned by US cable company Comcast and Chorus, owned jointly by Liberty Media and Independent News & Media. Energis, Norweb and Winstar are also bidding. The first to pull out was Unica, a business-to-business telecoms firm. Winning firms will be able to offer broadband services at data rates in excess of 2Mbits a second, compared with a maximum of 2Mbits a second for next generation mobile phones. They will be able to offer services including fast, "always on", access to the internet, video conferencing, video on demand, high capacity data transfer and the usual online shopping, banking and games. The fixed wireless system works via a small box attached to the outside of a building receiving signals from transmitters. It is expected to be used by firms hoping to target smaller businesses, typically in areas where cable or fibre optic nets have not been built. The most active competition has been in London. Energis is leading the race for licence one, with an offer of £4.54m, Broadnet is currently holding licence two, with £4.62m, and Faultbasic licence three, with a £4.54m bid.

webTitle: Blair promotes biotech industry

fields.headline: Blair promotes biotech industry
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair made an "unashamedly pro-science" speech when he  addressed a biotechnology conference in London today.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair made an "unashamedly pro-science" speech when he addressed a biotechnology conference in London today.

In the speech, Mr Blair was stressing the importance of investing in science and assuring the biotechnology industry of the Government's support.

He told scientists, investors and industry executives that biotechnology could be to the 21st century what computers were to the last 50 years.

And he warned the country that it cannot afford to become anti-science without risking missing out on an industry which could provide huge economic benefits.

Mr Blair said it would be "crazy" not to back scientific progress, adding: "Biotechnology is the next wave of the knowledge economy and I want Britain to become its European hub."

In Europe alone he predicted the industry would employ up to three million people within five years and be worth millions as it catches up with the US.

But he also stressed that investment and research must take place within a framework which always puts human and environmental safety first.

"Science without judgment can be dangerous, progress without science is unlikely ever to happen," the Prime Minister said.

Mr Blair was holding out the prospect of biotechnology changing medicine forever, allowing doctors to move from an emphasis on treatment to an emphasis on prevention.

He claimed it will allow medical experts to fight back against epidemics likes Aids and genetic diseases which blight the lives of children.

While Britain has led Europe in the field of research it was now time for the country to lead Europe "in spreading its benefits".

The speech, however, risks a new clash between the Government and environmental groups.

There is already unhappiness as the stance taken by Labour over genetically modified food where ministers have been seen being too enthusiastic in their backing of the industry.

And new support for biotechnology could raise fears among many that the pressure for progress in the industry is being put ahead of risks to human health at risk or harm the environment.

webTitle: T-Online hit by German watchdog ruling

fields.headline: T-Online hit by German watchdog ruling
fields.trailText: 8.45am: T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is reeling from another blow following a ruling by Germany's telecom's watchdog. By Dan Milmo
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is reeling from another blow to its business following a ruling by Germany's telecom's watchdog.

Regulator RegTP CORR said T-Online's parent company, Deutsche Telekom, cannot give bulk discount rates for using its phone network.

T-Online has benefited the most from Deutsche's scheme, as it gets most of its revenue from supplying internet access. Analysts have already questioned the viability of T-Online's business model.

RegTP also ordered Deutsche to offer unmetered access to all internet service providers, mirroring this week's Oftel directive to BT.

This ruling will hit T-Online hard, as it lowers costs for its rivals, who include AOL Germany and Freenet.

The luckless ISP is fast becoming the lastminute.com of Germany, with a plummeting share price which saw it hit an all-time low of E18.56 (1118p) yesterday, against a flotation price of E27 (1627p).

One of its saving graces is a 7m-strong customer base, but the majority of subscribers are located in Germany, and will be directly affected by the watchdog's ruling.

Boardroom upheavals have left the company without a chief executive since August, increasing negative market sentiment towards T-Online.

Investors are refusing to back a rudderless company, which reported a loss of E53.5m (£32.2m) in its latest nine-monthly results and has yet to signal a change in its much-disputed business plan.

webTitle: Share-tipping inquiry turns focus on City

fields.headline: Share-tipping inquiry turns focus on City
fields.standfirst: Nov 15: Mirror tipster given tribunal date
fields.trailText:
8.15am: The DTI inquiry into former City Slickers Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell is being widened to include senior City figures, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 15: Mirror tipster given tribunal date
fields.body:
The Department of Trade & Industry inquiry into former City Slickers Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell is being widened to include senior City figures who it is claimed benefited from the share-tipping scandal.

Sources close to the inquiry have claimed that "much bigger fish" than Mirror editor Piers Morgan have been implicated in the controversy.

It is understood that Mr Morgan will be summoned to give evidence to the DTI within the next four weeks.

Lawyers acting for Mr Hipwell are insisting that he cannot be called in to give evidence due to ill health. However, inspectors will travel to him if he is deemed too ill to appear.

As many as 30 journalists have been questioned so far and there is now little chance that the inquiry will conclude before January.

The DTI refused to comment on its investigations.

webTitle: Threat to veto denied as ministers close ranks on Europe

fields.headline: Threat to veto denied as ministers close ranks on Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The government last night brushed aside fresh pressure from the French presidency of the European Union to abandon the national veto over crucial policy areas involving VAT, excise taxes and the drive against EU-wide fraud.
fields.body:
The government last night brushed aside fresh pressure from the French presidency of the European Union to abandon the national veto over crucial policy areas involving VAT, excise taxes and the drive against EU-wide fraud.

"It's just pre-summit jitters, a negotiating tactic," said a senior Treasury source after the French draft text for next month's EU summit in Nice reached London - three weeks ahead of the summit - as Tony Blair spoke by video-conference with his French counterpart, Lionel Jospin, and dined at No 10 with Chancellor Schroder. The Downing Street spokesman also gave short shrift to the French text, stressing again that Britain is willing to concede some minor retreat from its national veto - as will other countries - in the interests of greater EU efficiency.

But it will not retreat in key areas including tax, social security, border control, defence and treaty changes themselves, he stressed. Officials point to Gordon Brown's success last winter in fighting off the planned "withholding tax" to prevent EU-wide tax evasion and avoidance - which would have hurt the City and probably been ineffectual.

Coincidentally, yesterday a Labour-controlled commons committee added to pressure on ministers by suggesting they are under-estimating the cost of converting sterling to the euro. A City accountant had said it could be as high as £35 bn - three times the rate assumed in most EU states, according to pro-Europeans.

As the summit endgame loomed Peter Mandelson and Mr Brown last night close ranks to reject accusations of a new cabinet split over attitudes to the European single currency and to agree that the time is not ripe to campaign for the euro this side of the coming general election.

In the wake of speculation that the Northern Ireland secretary had attacked the chancellor for thinking that Labour can persuade voters to back the euro on economic arguments alone, Mr Mandelson issued a statement to the Guardian.

"My remarks do not warrant the prominence they have been given as I have said before," he said in response to a report in yesterday's Financial Times about after-dinner remarks to businessmen. "I do not think there is any point expending campaign capital on the issue of the single currency before the issue is ready to be put."

In a significant closing of ranks on an issue which has caused trouble at the top end of the Blair cabinet, Mr Mandelson added: "It is desirable for us to set out a political and economic case for Europe as the prime minister was doing on Monday in his Mansion House speech. But the next election will not be fought on the single currency so I think everyone - and the media in particular - should relax on the issue."

Last night a spokesman for Mr Brown, who has persistently shown caution about the timetable for staging the promised euro-referendum until his five economic conditions are met, also rejected claims the pair are at odds on the issue.

"The use of words like angry, fury or even irritation are wide of the mark. The appropriate words would be 'entirely relaxed'," he said.

Mr Mandelson thinks that because the cabinet believes there is no constitutional bar to membership of the single currency, it is not so naive as to believe the political case will not need to be made to the general public.

He believes the party should not retreat from its views on the single currency, but should not be campaigning on the issue now. That has long been Mr Brown's view, but events - not least the euro's dismal performance on the world money markets, 30% down on its original value - have made this worse.

Like the Chancellor, Mr Mandelson thinks the single currency should not be deployed as an big issue at the general election.

It should only be raised to ensure that voters know that Labour, unlike the Conservatives, will preserve the public's right to choose on the single currency in a referendum.

As a subsidiary issue, he believes that if Labour says little on the currency for the moment the other side will exhaust themselves with their argument - a hope which William Hague moved to dispel when he said yesterday that Mr Mandelson had let the cat out of the bag.

webTitle: Ex-lover swindled me, says Elton John

fields.headline: Ex-lover swindled me, says Elton John
fields.trailText: Elton John faced his former lover and business manager across a crowded courtroom yesterday and accused him of betraying and "swindling" him.
fields.body:
Elton John faced his former lover and business manager across a crowded courtroom yesterday and accused him of betraying and "swindling" him.

John Reid, 51, who had a five year relationship with the star in the 1970s and was his manager for 26 years, sat listening intently as Sir Elton made his allegations.

Sir Elton, 53, who was giving evidence for the second day in his high court contract battle, said: "I thought he would kill for me in any circumstances. I trusted him and I thought he was by far the best person to manage my career."

But he said he now believed he had been "swindled" by Mr Reid and commented: "He wouldn't be the first man in the world to get his fingers caught in the till."

Dressed in a grey Versace suit and patterned grey tie, and watched by his long time partner David Furnish, he said: "I trusted him all those years. I trusted him implicitly."

The star is suing Andrew Haydon, 45, former managing director of John Reid Enterprises, which for many years was his management company, and the accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, which looked after his business interests.

He alleges that Mr Haydon was negligent in allowing JREL to charge him overseas tour expenses, including booking agents, accountants and producers.

Sir Elton's case is that the "several millions" which he paid out in touring expenses should have been borne by JREL under a management agreement.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (formerly Price Waterhouse) is accused by Sir Elton of negligence in managing his affairs.

Both defendants are contesting the allegations against them.

Mr Haydon denies negligence and claims that everything had been done in accordance with management con tract terms and conditions. PricewaterhouseCoopers said that it had looked very carefully at the criticisms made and rejected them and would be asking the judge to rule that the firm's employees had acted according to the highest professional standards.

The star said he had a "perfectly clear" recollection of an occasion in 1984 in St Tropez when he and Mr Reid finally sorted out their management agreement after a lengthy period of "haggling".

Part of that agreement, he insisted, was that JREL should bear touring costs.

He said: "It was a contract verbally between two people who had lived together for five years."

The court has heard that Sir Elton first met John Reid in about 1968 or 1969 and Mr Reid became his manager in July 1973.

Mr Reid acted as the star's manager until Sir Elton terminated the management agreement in May 1998.

The case continues.

webTitle: Eight years for 'gruesome' killing in which wife was dismembered

fields.headline: Eight years for 'gruesome' killing in which wife was dismembered
fields.trailText: A postman who killed his wife, cut up her body, and cooked her head in the oven, was yesterday cleared of murder but was sentenced to eight years for manslaughter on the grounds of provocation.
fields.body:
A postman who killed his wife, cut up her body, and cooked her head in the oven, was yesterday cleared of murder but was sentenced to eight years for manslaughter on the grounds of provocation.

Roger Frisby, 42, of Plumstead, south London, told the Old Bailey he snapped during a heated row with his wife, June, 36.

After hitting her a number of times over the head with a claw hammer he cut up her body, and threw her limbs off the cliffs near Dover before cooking her head, hands and feet in the oven. He later buried the head on Sidcup golf course in Kent, and threw the torso into a nearby river.

Frisby later told family and friends that his wife had deserted him and their two children, Ruby, four, and Lucy, six months. But he confessed to the killing when her skull was unearthed by a dog 15 months later.

The postman told detectives that he had baked the head at gas mark 8 for several hours in an attempt to disguise its identity.

The court was told that the couple had a stormy relationship. Mrs Frisby suffered from depression and drank heavily while her husband wanted a quiet life at home.

Judge Martin Stephens remarked: "This must be one of the most gruesome and unhappy cases any jury has had to hear. What you did goes beyond the comprehension of right thinking people."

The court heard that the couple married in 1994, but by the time of her death Mrs Frisby was unhappy and wanted to move the family to Scotland, but her husband refused.

He attacked his wife after she had been on a 24-hour drinking binge. He told police he snapped after she hit their eldest daughter.

During the trial, the jury was told that Frisby had taken detectives to spots where he said he disposed of the body, but nothing other than the skull had been found.

"I drove down to Dover with the children and the dog," Frisby told the jury. "I got the pushchair out of the car. Packed underneath were the bits. The baby was in the pushchair."

The children were given crisps and drinks as he emptied the bags over the cliff.

The next day, he baked the head. "I put her head in the oven. I tried to make it disintegrate, to break it up, to conceal it so it wouldn't look like a skull. I decided to bury it. I put it in a Marks and Spencer shopping bag. I put the torso in another bag and put them in the boot of her Escort car.

"I asked mum to look after the children while I took the dog for a walk. I pulled the things out of the boot and went for a walk into the woods.

"I buried the skull as best I could with a little hand trowel and I threw the torso into the river. I then went and picked up the children and took them home in the car."

After the case, Mrs Frisby's brother, John, left court without commenting. He had known Frisby for 20 years and introduced him to his sister.

Detective Superintendent David Dillnutt said: "The tragedy of the case is that two children have lost their mother and father."

The two girls are being cared for by foster parents until their future is decided.

webTitle: Democrats pay price for hesitation

fields.headline: Democrats pay price for hesitation
fields.standfirst:
Palm Beach Failure to begin recount may decide election in Bush's favour

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Palm Beach Failure to begin recount may decide election in Bush's favour.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
The hesitation and wavering of the three local officials who make up the Palm Beach canvassing board looked likely yesterday to cost Al Gore dearly in the post-electoral battle over ballots.

The canvassing board, whose job is to oversee elections in the county, voted in the early hours of Sunday morning to authorise a full recount of the 46,000 votes cast across Palm Beach in the presidential election. As Palm Beach is a majority Democratic county, and as hand recounts have tended to enlarge victory margins, such a recount could swing the historically close election in favour of Mr Gore.

However, on Tuesday the board suspended the count to await guidance on whether it was legal. Then it voted to restart it. On Wednesday it changed tack again and suspended the count amid confusion about its legal position and how the votes should be tallied.

By yesterday, every lost hour was a blow to Al Gore's hopes of eroding George W Bush's 300-vote lead following the automated count. "We have to start counting. We have to be counting by Friday," said one Democrat official.

The issue is one of timing. On Tuesday night, Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, certified Florida's vote and Mr Bush's 300-vote lead. At midnight tonight, or at the latest tomorrow morning, she is due to add in the absentee ballot sent in by Floridians living overseas, and certify the final Florida result, assigning its 25 votes in the electoral college, and therefore determining the election.

Most political analysts believe that the roughly 2,000 absentee ballots will be either evenly split or lean slightly to Governor Bush.

If there is still a manual recount under way at the time of Ms Harris's announcement, the Democrats will be able to portray her decision as premature and politically motivated.

Broward County began its recount and by yesterday was showing a slight but significant tilt towards Mr Gore.

But Palm Beach waited, and that hesitation may well cost the vice-president vital momentum, despite the fact that all three members of the Palm Beach canvassing board are registered Democrats.

The reasons for the delay have been a combination of legal confusion and mixed allegiances.

The board was given conflicting guidance by Ms Harris and Florida's attorney general, Bob Butterworth - a Democrat who argued that the county had every right to work out how to run its own elections. Late on Wednesday, Mr Butterworth's position was backed by the Florida supreme court, and yet the board still did not begin the recount.

The board was under intense pressure not to commit government officials to a week-long recount which might not even be eligible.

The board chairman, Charles Burton, is registered as a Democrat, but was appointed a judge at the end of a long legal career, by Mr Bush's brother, Jeb, the Florida governor. The second member of the board, Carol Roberts, is a county commissioner and a committed Democrat.

She drove the board towards its initial decision to hold a recount, but her dominance of the board appears to have waned over the past few days.

fields.bodyText: The hesitation and wavering of the three local officials who make up the Palm Beach canvassing board looked likely yesterday to cost Al Gore dearly in the post-electoral battle over ballots. The canvassing board, whose job is to oversee elections in the county, voted in the early hours of Sunday morning to authorise a full recount of the 46,000 votes cast across Palm Beach in the presidential election. As Palm Beach is a majority Democratic county, and as hand recounts have tended to enlarge victory margins, such a recount could swing the historically close election in favour of Mr Gore. However, on Tuesday the board suspended the count to await guidance on whether it was legal. Then it voted to restart it. On Wednesday it changed tack again and suspended the count amid confusion about its legal position and how the votes should be tallied. By yesterday, every lost hour was a blow to Al Gore's hopes of eroding George W Bush's 300-vote lead following the automated count. "We have to start counting. We have to be counting by Friday," said one Democrat official. The issue is one of timing. On Tuesday night, Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, certified Florida's vote and Mr Bush's 300-vote lead. At midnight tonight, or at the latest tomorrow morning, she is due to add in the absentee ballot sent in by Floridians living overseas, and certify the final Florida result, assigning its 25 votes in the electoral college, and therefore determining the election. Most political analysts believe that the roughly 2,000 absentee ballots will be either evenly split or lean slightly to Governor Bush. If there is still a manual recount under way at the time of Ms Harris's announcement, the Democrats will be able to portray her decision as premature and politically motivated. Broward County began its recount and by yesterday was showing a slight but significant tilt towards Mr Gore. But Palm Beach waited, and that hesitation may well cost the vice-president vital momentum, despite the fact that all three members of the Palm Beach canvassing board are registered Democrats. The reasons for the delay have been a combination of legal confusion and mixed allegiances. The board was given conflicting guidance by Ms Harris and Florida's attorney general, Bob Butterworth - a Democrat who argued that the county had every right to work out how to run its own elections. Late on Wednesday, Mr Butterworth's position was backed by the Florida supreme court, and yet the board still did not begin the recount. The board was under intense pressure not to commit government officials to a week-long recount which might not even be eligible. Apparently eager to avoid any controversy, she voted at the weekend for a recount, but has voted in every decision since to postpone it.

webTitle: High noon at the Hague

fields.headline: High noon at the Hague
fields.standfirst:
Faith in the market is not going to save us
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Ignorance is no longer any excuse. Most climate scientists now agree that human activity is the main cause of global warming. Millions from York to Rosetta in the Nile delta now have first hand experience of what it can do. Sea level rise and more frequent extreme weather are no longer theory but reality. Yet in spite of all this, there is still a widespread public apathy. There are no mass Seattle-style protests mustered at the convention now taking place in the Hague. The scale of this challenge appears to be simply too vast and too distant - we have 25-50 years before the direst predictions kick in - to penetrate popular consciousness. fields.body:
Ignorance is no longer any excuse. Most climate scientists now agree that human activity is the main cause of global warming. Millions from York to Rosetta in the Nile delta now have first hand experience of what it can do. Sea level rise and more frequent extreme weather are no longer theory but reality. Yet in spite of all this, there is still a widespread public apathy. There are no mass Seattle-style protests mustered at the convention now taking place in the Hague. The scale of this challenge appears to be simply too vast and too distant - we have 25-50 years before the direst predictions kick in - to penetrate popular consciousness. What will be needed over the next generation is a massive shift in individual consumer habits as well as popular pressure on the politicians. So far there is little sign of either.

That is clearly part of the explanation for the lack of impetus and urgency at the meeting at the Hague. What has so far emerged confirms the pessimism which has settled over the international effort to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The targets set at the Kyoto meeting in 1997 of 5.5% cuts on 1990 levels were dismissed as woefully inadequate even then by scientists who argued that they needed to be of the order of 60-80%. But even those targets are unlikely to be achieved. Emissions continue to grow at 1.3% a year and the US has publicly acknowledged that, given its booming economy, it will not achieve its Kyoto target. With only 4% of the world's population, the US is responsible for over 20% of its carbon emissions. This degree of international irresponsibility is only likely to increase if the election goes to George W Bush, who has said he does not believe there is such a thing as global warming.

Even worse, there is a danger that the environmentalists' worst apprehensions for the Hague may come true. They fear that the European Union is so desperate for agreement that that it will give in to the US. That would make a mockery of the entire Kyoto protocol: instead of cuts, it could lead to huge increases of emissions. The biggest source of contention is carbon sinks. The US (backed by Japan, Australia and Canada) wants to offset its emissions by planting forests which can sequester carbon. But the science of carbon sinks is terrifyingly imprecise, scientists warn. How much carbon is sequestered and for how long? Could it be reliably monitored? The whole benefit is lost if there is a forest fire. The most effective carbon sequestrating trees are not those which nurture biodiversity. Young trees do a better job than old - which raises the ludicrous possibility of chopping down old forests to plant new ones to be claimed as carbon sinks. Many hours this week and next will be devoted to such issues.

The sorry truth is that the international effort to curb global warming has been hijacked by the US and driven into a quagmire. The ideological commitment of the US to market mechanisms ensured that global warming would be tackled by creating a market to buy and sell the right to pollute the world's atmosphere. The US wanted to use the power of its dollar to buy its way out of cuts at home. It is the construction of this market which has led to four years of wrangling and obfuscating negotiations which could yet scupper agreement. The process has long since left all but the most ardent environmentalists confused. All along, Europe knew better. Its experience in the past of tackling environmental pollution is that regulation delivers greater cuts than market mechanisms. The conclusion must be that there are serious limits to what the market can achieve in the face of an environmental challenge of this magnitude.

Other absurdities have found their way on to the Hague agenda. Impossible though it may seem, there is a real danger that an international conference dedicated to saving the planet may relaunch the nuclear industry. The clean development mechanism - which may prove to be anything but clean - was designed to encourage rich countries to help poor ones develop by investing in renewable energy. A nuclear industry frustrated by western hostility has leapt on it as a new lease of life: an opportunity to build nuclear power stations in China and India.

The Kyoto protocol was always seen as a first step on a long road. After late night sessions next week, the politicians may have an agreement, but the signs are that it will do little to slow the quickening pace of global warming. Yet the historic significance of Kyoto remains undiminished. It launched the most ambitious experiment in global governance ever. It may have proved far less than a breakthrough than first envisaged but, quite simply, we cannot afford to fail. So this experiment will come to dominate the century. In the end, its chance of success depends less on the politicians than on their electorates finally grasping the implications of what faces them and resolving to change their lives accordingly.

webTitle: Gore's timing catches rival out of step

fields.headline: Gore's timing catches rival out of step
fields.standfirst:
TV appearance helps Democrat claim political high ground

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: TV appearance helps Democrat claim political high ground.
fields.body:
As the battle for Florida's electoral college votes continued unabated yesterday, the two men at the centre of the American presidential storm fought a hand-to-hand battle for control of the political high ground.

Al Gore and George W Bush have been sparing with their public appearances in the nine days since last Tuesday's election. Both have kept out of sight of the cameras, emerging only briefly to make short statements reiterating their respective positions while awaiting the outcome in the Florida courts.

On Thursday night, however, Mr Gore launched a pre-emptive public relations strike in the court of public opinion. It caught Mr Bush unawares, and it may play an important role in buying Mr Gore more time to continue his uphill efforts to claim victory in the race for the White House.

Shortly after 6.35pm local time, Mr Gore went before the cameras in his official residence in Washington with Joe Lieberman, the man he hopes will take over the tenancy, by his side. The timing was particularly cute, as even the Bush camp acknowledges. Coming just five minutes into the nightly half-hour national news bulletins on ABC and CBS, and less than half an hour before the NBC bulletin, Mr Gore effectively got himself a free five-minute party political broadcast with the maximum possible audience.

Mr Gore offered to break the deadlock over the Florida crisis with two moves. First, he said that if Mr Bush agreed to manual recounts in selected Florida counties, or in all of them, then Mr Gore would accept those results as final. Second, he proposed a one-on-one meeting with Mr Bush at which the two men would try to calm the mood of national uncertainty and begin the process of post-election reunification.

Mr Gore was not saying much he had not already said before. His representative in Florida, Warren Christopher, had made the same offer on hand recounts a day earlier. The proposal for a meeting was new, however, as was the overarching attempt in Mr Gore's statement to look beyond the end of the Florida dispute.

But the real purpose of the statement was to capitalise on Mr Gore's continuing public opinion advantage. Polls show that a majority of Americans cautiously accept the legitimacy of the recount process in Florida, at least for the moment. Mr Gore therefore wanted to consolidate that position with a primetime display of statesmanship and by making a proposal that Mr Bush would be bound to reject.

The Bush camp was caught napping. Within an hour of Mr Gore's move, Mr Bush and his entourage were in their cars, making a 90-minute dash from the Bush ranch near Waco to the Texas governor's mansion in Austin. Aides worked hurriedly on a draft response, all to enable Mr Bush to go in front of the cameras in a comparably august setting to the one chosen by Mr Gore.

Three and a half hours after Mr Gore had delivered his statement, Mr Bush stood in front of a portrait of General Sam Houston and rejected Mr Gore's proposal.

"The outcome of this election will not be the result of deals or efforts to mould public opinion," Mr Bush said in remarks which were also carried live on all networks. "The outcome of this election will be determined by the votes and by the law."

Republicans had begun to fret about Mr Bush's low profile this week. For the previous four days, the Republican candidate had been hunkered down on his ranch with advisers. Republicans in Washington have been warning Mr Bush that he has been losing ground to Mr Gore in the post-election sympathy stakes.

While Mr Bush himself may have missed a trick in the week's political manoeuvres, other Republicans are being more ruthless. Congressman Tom DeLay of Texas, the power behind the throne in the Republican party on Capitol Hill, has this week sent a memo to colleagues pointing out that the House and Senate can both reject a state's presidential votes if they decide that they are tainted.

Mr DeLay, who represents a far more conservative face of the party than Mr Bush, was a key figure in the impeachment process against President Bill Clinton. During that crisis, he sent colleagues an "impeachment book" which laid out the strategy that he wanted Republicans to follow. The new memorandum on the possible role Congress may play in any dispute over Florida's electoral college votes is said to be in a similar vein.

The mood of partisan tension on Capitol Hill stands in marked contrast to the appearance of statesmanship which both presidential candidates are seeking to sustain. A further sign of the mood among Republicans came yesterday when two of their leading congressmen, Billy Tauzin of Louisiana and Christopher Cox of California, announced they would be holding hearings into the way in which the television networks covered the election.

Republicans believe that early calls of victories for Mr Gore in several states, including Florida, helped to discourage voters from going to the polls in the final hours of election day.

webTitle: Bush ally takes world stage

fields.headline: Bush ally takes world stage
fields.standfirst:
Harris: Partisan lackey or a servant of the people?

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Katherine Harris: Partisan lackey or a servant of the people?
fields.body:
Katherine Harris, immaculately attired and thin-lipped as ever, swept into the basement of the 22-storey Florida Capitol building yesterday to apply her mind to the great issues of the day.

These are: how the state's property tax should be administered; new appointments to a community college board; and whether $57,799.55 is a reasonable demand for a company's five-year lease.

Only hours previously Ms Harris, 43, by now easily the best-known secretary of state Florida has had, was on the international stage, throwing another spoke into Al Gore's post-election election campaign.

But yesterday, at least for a time, it was back to business as usual for the Republican friend and colleague of the Bush brothers who has been described by Democrats as partisan, a lackey and a commissar.

She refuses to accept the results of recounts in three heavily Democratic counties which would probably reverse George W Bush's official 300 vote lead in the state, and intends to announce the winner tomorrow.

None of this was on the agenda for yesterday's meeting of Governor Jeb Bush's cabinet of which Ms Harris is a member, fashioning a role for herself over the past two years as a trade and culture envoy.

"The governor is focused on the business of the third-largest state in the nation," said Mr Bush's spokeswoman, Katie Baur. "They're addressing the issues that are important to the people of Florida. These are important issues to the people in this state and that's all that matters."

That was not all that mattered to the governor, who was supposed to have removed himself from the post-election turmoil because of his fraternal connection.

"She has the responsibility to carry out the law and part of that was that in seven days the ballots had to be certified," he said. "I think she's on solid ground." All that remained was for the overseas ballots to be counted.

Ms Harris has refused to accept the excuses of the four counties that want to continue with manual recounts, saying that the law would allow that to happen only had the original tally been disrupted by an act of god - such as a hurricane - fraud, or if the ballot machines had broken down.

Mr Gore's campaign says she was told by the courts that she could reject the submissions from Palm Beach, Broward, Miami-Dade and Collier counties only if she had a good reason to do so and that this was not the case.

The argument is heading for the Florida supreme court, which was receiving papers from Ms Harris and the Republicans on one side and Florida's attorney-general, Bob Butterworth, on the other, on whether the hand counts should continue. Mr Butterworth headed Mr Gore's campaign in the state .

Back at Capitol plaza in Tallahassee, Jeb Bush's cabinet meeting ground on, with satellite broadcast trucks on the streets outside and protesters making their silent daily rounds with placards reading Election Theft Underway and Gore + Daley = Vote Fraud!

Some local Republicans believed Ms Harris was not receiving the support to which she was entitled. "I think she's feeling a little alone," said Tom Lee, a member of the state senate. "Very honestly, I'm concerned our party may be throwing her to the wolves. She doesn't deserve that."

webTitle: Private Lives

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: I've asked my unfaithful wife to leave. She won't. What should I do?
fields.trailText: I've asked my unfaithful wife to leave. She won't. What should I do?
fields.body:
Recently I discovered that my wife had been unfaithful for the fourth time in our 17-year marriage. The latest affair is the continuation of something that had, I believed, ended six years ago. On discovery we ran the usual gamut of denial, excuses and promises, but it all rang very hollow. I have now asked her to leave so that my daughters and I can get on with our lives.

The problem is that she flatly refuses to go, insisting that her place is with the girls. It is my income and hard work that has paid our mortgage, the bills and virtually everything else. I have helped out at home more than any man I know. I am not about to let years of struggle and labour go now.

If our roles were reversed I would lose everything, like all the other men who "play away", but she seems oblivious of the consequences of her behaviour. My rage at how I have been treated is almost beyond control. Can readers suggest an outcome for this nightmare?

It's your own fault

Everything is "yours" and there is no mention of love anywhere in your letter, not even for your daughters. You sound so much like my husband a decade ago. He also refused to acknowledge my contribution to the family or to give any sign he appreciated me. When I eventually had an affair, out of loneliness as much as anything else, he too demanded that I leave. I knew I could not: he had not the faintest idea of how much effort it takes to bring up children and run a house.

As for your claim to help out more than any man you know - I've just asked several men how much they do in the house compared with other men they know, and they all say they do more! Frankly, you sound self-centred, sulky, acquisitive and lacking in emotional maturity. As your wife's affair is a resumption of one from six years ago, it's possible she just wants an occasional relationship with an adult she can relate to on equal terms. I know I did.

Either make a real effort to make your marriage work by questioning your attitude towards her, or get out and let her bring up the children. Incidentally, you expressed not the slightest concern about the impact on them of their mother leaving. No wonder she won't.
Name and address withheld

Your wife is unhappy

You could have been describing my life, more or less. Your wife is deeply unhappy and your marriage is indeed over, but she has nowhere to go. She is evidently a devoted mother and has sacrificed any career she may have had in order to care for your daughters. The trouble with this traditional arrangement is that the wife becomes financially dependent on her husband and, when the children grow more independent, she finds herself trapped, as the husband still expects the same "service" as before. The frustration is enormous.

I get the feeling that you'd like things to be nice and cosy as they were when the kids were babies, dinner was on the table, and your wife knew how to keep you happy. You forgave her before, to preserve that lifestyle, but now she's had enough. She would not dream of leaving her children, and probably sees living with you as the price she must pay for their financial security. As you've found, you can't just kick her out.

I'd try talking calmly to her about separation and reassure her that you'll support the girls. I know this will be hard, but put your anger aside and think of your daughters. Their welfare comes first.
Name and address withheld

If I were you, I'd leave

I am afraid you'll have to accept that women are always in the right. Your wife's excuses, denials and promises will continue indefinitely. There is no possibility of you continuing your family life without her. You will have to choose between staying with your family as it is and leaving. In the last two relationships I had, I was a victim of sustained bul lying and physical abuse. In each case, the woman concerned had complete belief in her own martyrdom to the universally oppressive male sex. This attitude is so entrenched now that there can never now be a male victim nor a female wrongdoer.

It is incredibly hard to accept, I know, but no man has any "right to family life" whatever. Your wife can and will do as she likes, while you will be left with a "take it or leave it" (and lose the fruits of all your labour) non-choice. Many men who have suffered as you have are now on the streets. If I were you, I'd leave. Your daughters will be taught to hate you shortly, anyway.
Name and address withheld

Ask the children

Don't leave - however desperate you feel. Four years ago, after a 20-year relationship, I left my husband because he refused to end his affair and also refused to leave himself. At the time my children were eight and nine. I thought it was better for them not to know what their father had done and the real reason I was leaving. They found out a year later.

The hardest thing for them was, at such an early age, to have to realise that mum and dad are people themselves as well as mum and dad. Added to this is the realisation that someone they love more than anything can hurt so badly someone else they love more than anything. How do you resolve that at 10 and 11?

Do talk to your daughters, whatever age they are, and try - I know how hard it is - to be objective about your wife. They will not thank you in the long run if you're not.

Reassure them that you have always loved them, do love them and will always love them, that parents can break up and it does not mean that the children are not loved or unwanted.

If you can face it, and both of you abide by the decision, ask them what they want. You can, after all, share their care as I do with my ex-husband - it's complicated but it works.
Name and address withheld

Next week

My partner and I have a beautiful 18-month-old daughter. Before her arrival, we had planned to have more than one child. As a relatively new father, however, I have now had a change of heart and would be perfectly content as part of small family of three. My partner, on the other hand, is very keen to try for a second child despite being mindful of the increasing risks entailed as an older mother: she is 37.

As one of three brothers, I realise our daughter would probably benefit from some other young company. Against this, however, I need some degree of personal space - something my partner shares - and know we both have clear limits. With the two of us working, I am fearful of the extra demands rearing another child will bring - despite the services of a good childminder, family and friends. While I feel guilty at wanting to renege on an earlier understanding, I now feel pressured into going along with my partner's wishes against my own. It is difficult to think of a mutually satisfying outcome. How have other couples dealt with this problem?

The latest affair is the continuation of something that had, I believed, ended six years ago. On discovery we ran the usual gamut of denial, excuses and promises, but it all rang very hollow. I have now asked her to leave so that my daughters and I can get on with our lives. The problem is that she flatly refuses to go, insisting that her place is with the girls. It is my income and hard work that has paid our mortgage, the bills and virtually everything else. I have helped out at home more than any man I know. I am not about to let years of struggle and labour go now. If our roles were reversed I would lose everything, like all the other men who "play away", but she seems oblivious of the consequences of her behaviour. webTitle: Yesterday at the talks

fields.headline: Yesterday at the talks
fields.trailText: EU and US officials were inching towards a draft agreement last night which could be put before ministers at the climate talks in the Hague.
fields.body:
EU and US officials were inching towards a draft agreement last night which could be put before ministers at the climate talks in the Hague.

The US is believed to have made small concessions over forests and nuclear power but is thought to be reluctant to accept a compromise forcing it to take action to cut domestic emissions.

How you can help

• Calculate how much carbon you and your business burn and try over a year to reduce it by 60%, the amount scientists believe is needed to avoid climatic disruption. A simple interactive website can be found on Special report: global warming

• Cut back on travel. One return flight to Rio de Janeiro burns as much carbon per passenger as 230 train journeys between Oxford and London. Trains are more energy efficient per person than cars, but less so than bicycles. The surest method of not burning carbon, however, is to walk. For an interactive guide to air travel use, go to:
www.gci.org.uk.

• Reduce dependence on oil and fossil fuels. Consider converting cars/fleets to liquid petroleum gas which is becoming a viable alternative with one new LPG outlet opening every day. For details of refuelling sites, grants available, and how to convert, visit:
www.est-powershift.org.uk.

•Increase energy conservation by insulating roofs, walls and windows. Consider low energy light bulbs and solar power. Details from:
www.est.org.uk
www.cat.org.uk
www.solarcentury.co.uk

• Switch your electricity supply to renewables. All energy companies now have schemes.

• Try to find local sources for food and other goods, reducing the need for travelling long distances. Resist buying items that have been air freighted to Britain.

• Recycle as much as possible. This reduces the need for high-energy processes such as waste incineration, aluminium, plastic and glass manufacture and also saves cutting down trees which store carbon.

webTitle: Pro-hunting judges cry off RSPCA legal fight

fields.headline: Pro-hunting judges cry off RSPCA legal fight
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: A high court battle between the RSPCA and hunt supporters has been delayed after two judges named to hear the case disclosed their involvement with hunting.
fields.body:
A high court battle between the RSPCA and hunt supporters has been delayed after two judges named to hear the case disclosed their involvement with hunting.

The disclosures by the pair has delayed the case, due to start last Tuesday, as the court's listing officer seeks a judge free and uninvolved in the issue.

The animal welfare charity is seeking authority to determine who can join.

Either Mr Justice Laddie or Mr Justice Evans-Lombe were listed to hear the case. But the former declared he was a member of the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance while Mr Justice Evans-Lombe admitted he allows hare coursing on his Norfolk land.

The disclosures have left court officials seeking a judge with no involvement with the RSPCA or country sports from among the other 16 in the chancery division to hear a case that could now be delayed until after Christmas.

Legal authorities have been particularly wary since Lord Hoffmann's unpaid role with Amnesty International was used to challenge a decision involving the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.

Applications by 600 would-be members have been suspended by the RSPCA since the pro-hunting Countryside Animal Welfare Group, which shares some of the aims of the Countryside Alliance, urged supporters to join the society.

The RSPCA claims it is the victim of entryism, and senior figures have privately accused the CAWG, led by Olympic equestrian Richard Meade, of attempting a coup.

An RSPCA spokeswoman said: "The RSPCA would not question the impartiality of a judge. It is concerned to ensure that justice is not only done but is seen to be done."

webTitle: Star adds sting to airfield expansion protest

fields.headline: Star adds sting to airfield expansion protest
fields.trailText: Sting, rock superstar and fervent champion of the world's rain forests, has turned his campaigning zeal to preserving the environment in his own backyard.
fields.body:
Sting, rock superstar and fervent champion of the world's rain forests, has turned his campaigning zeal to preserving the environment in his own backyard.

The former Police frontman has joined other wealthy residents of the secluded Wiltshire valley where he lives in an attempt to arrest the expansion of activities at nearby Boscombe Down, a military airfield that lays claim to one of the longest runways in Britain.

Using recently introduced human rights legislation the group has launched a pre-emptive legal challenge to the procedure under which the airfield's attempts to become home to the RAF's future strategic tanker fleet will be decided.

The group, which includes Earl and Countess of Chichester and the Countess of Iveagh, says the government is acting as judge and jury in the case because the proposed developments are not subject to the normal planning process.

Although the site's operator, an agency of the Ministry of Defence, is obliged to consult the local planning authority, the authority's findings are not binding. A public inquiry is at the discretion of the secretary of state.

Opponents of the expansion say that with government as landowner and decision maker, the minister cannot be independent or impartial. Sting, using his real name Gordon Sumner, with seven others, has filed an application for a judicial review of the decision making process.

Lord Chichester, who has lived in Little Durnford Manor in the tranquil Woodford valley for more than 30 years said that if the development were to go ahead it would make life intolerable for people in the surrounding area. "It will have a huge impact on the locality and yet the way it is being decided is totally undemocratic."

Their lawyer, Simon Ricketts, said: "Article six guarantees a fair hearing in front of an independent and impartial tribunal established by law for anyone whose rights are threatened by a proposal such as this."

Boscombe Down, near Amesbury, is run by the MoD's defence evaluation and research agency. At present the airfield's main function is evaluating military aircraft. It also trains military test pilots.

DERA wants to enable the site to take over from RAF Brize Norton as the station for the RAF's fleet of refuelling and troop-carrying aircraft.

The proposed development, including construction of hangars, hostel accommodation and a passenger terminal building, could see the number of flight movements rise from around 40,000 a year to 55,000.

DERA, which believes the proposals would provide an additional 500 civilian jobs at the airfield says the additional flights would involve the new generation of quick takeoff whisper jets.

But suggestions that they would be "less impactful" than the fast jets already tested and evaluated at Boscombe have failed to calm fears. Villagers say they are worried about noise and the possible impact on property prices in the area.

webTitle: Rhythm method 'often unreliable'

fields.headline: Rhythm method 'often unreliable'
fields.trailText: Couples relying on the rhythm method of contraception will need to do extra homework after new research indicating it may be even less reliable than was previously thought.
fields.body:
Couples relying on the rhythm method of contraception will need to do extra homework after new research indicating it may be even less reliable than was previously thought.

This suggests there are few days on which women are not capable of becoming pregnant, causing difficulties for those who avoid having sex during what they believe to be their most fertile period of the month.

This method is used by 1% of women in Britain, but by a higher proportion of those aged between 30 and 45, in preference to alternatives such as the pill, condoms or inter-uterine devices.

But the idea that it is easy to identify six days during the average woman's menstrual cycle when intercourse can result in pregnancy, those leading up to and including ovulation, are challenged in a study published in the British Medical Journal.

It concludes that the usual clinical guidance for doctors that the average woman is potentially fertile between days 10 and 17 of their cycle, two weeks before her period, does not take "striking" unpredictability into account.

Researchers in the US studied the cycles of 221 women in North Carolina planning a pregnancy to see when ovulation occurred. They found that only 30% of them had their fertile window between days 10 and 17. On average, at least 10% of women were in their fertile period on any given day between days six and 21.

Anne Weyman, chief executive of the Family Planning Association, said the "normal variation" not only between women but between any one woman's individual cycles, could make it difficult to predict ovulation accurately only by calculating cycle length.

webTitle: Canal plan to revitalise Mersey docks

fields.headline: Canal plan to revitalise Mersey docks
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: Narrow boats may soon cruise past Liverpool's famous Pier Head along a new half-mile stretch of canal that would be one of the first of its type to be built in Britain for 200 years.
fields.body:
Narrow boats may soon cruise past Liverpool's famous Pier Head along a new half-mile stretch of canal that would be one of the first of its type to be built in Britain for 200 years.

In a scheme announced by British Waterways to coincide with the launch of the urban white paper, the £15m canal would link the terminus of the Leeds and Liverpool canal at Stanley Dock with the shops, museums and galleries at the Albert Dock.

Feasibility studies suggest alternative routes. With one, the canal would run alongside the traffic that speeds along the The Strand; with an alternative route, the canal would pass in front of the Liver and Cunard buildings and across one of the finest waterfronts in Europe. With both routes, passengers would be within easy strolling distance of the Mersey ferries.

The new canal would enter the Canning half tide dock in front of the Merseyside maritime museum and a few yards from the Tate gallery.

It is part of a £200m three-part scheme to revitalise Liverpool's docks area. British Waterways, which runs the country's 2,000 mile network of canals and rivers, has joined English Partnerships to consider the future management of the land and water around Albert Dock.

With three other partners, BW has also been shortlisted to redevelop the 36 acre Kings Waterfront site. Its plan proposes a mix of homes, offices and tourist attractions.

"We believe that Liverpool's docks and waterways have enormous untapped potential to deliver social change, environmental improvement and economic prosperity," said Dave Fletcher, BW's chief executive.

BW also expects the link would have a regeneration effect along the banks of the canal which is Britain's longest waterway and takes a 157-mile meandering route across the Pennines. At present fewer than 1,000 boats a year reach the Liverpool terminus.

Mike Storey, leader of Liverpool city council, described the plan as bold and imaginative. "The city needs projects of this calibre if it is to make the progress it deserves," Layth Bunni, chief executive of Liverpool Vision, the city's urban regeneration programme. "It is a visionary scheme that will help breathe new life into the waterfront."

webTitle: 7 out of 10 for government's urban white paper

fields.headline: Fair for starters, but now the hard part begins
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: Not bad, Mr Prescott. Not bad. The government's urban white paper scores a good seven out of 10.
fields.body:
Not bad, Mr Prescott. Not bad. The government's urban white paper scores a good seven out of 10. Or to put this another way, the white paper has adopted 70% of the forward-looking recommendations made by Lord Rogers's urban task force report,Towards an Urban Renaissance, 15 months ago.

These were concerned with raising the standard of environment and design in our city centres to make life better for those who live and work in them and to discourage the continuing urban diaspora.

By ennobling our cities, we can save the countryside we say we love but wish to smother with something like 4m trashy new homes over the next 10 or 15 years because we want to escape downgraded and dirty city centres.

The white paper offers practical solutions connecting the quality of urban design and transport infrastructure with the quality of life in our cities. Mr Prescott offers, for example, a dozen new private-public urban regeneration companies. These may well be be able to redevelop areas such as London's King's Cross, by making the complex mix of private, public and local authority landowners in such areas shareholders in a carrot-and-carrot operation. All players would benefit financially and environmentally.

Money, assuming the white paper becomes legislation, will no longer be pumped into regenerating particular areas of cities unless this is met by three-dimensional design plans rather than vague two-dimensional diagrams and lists of statistics; in other words, standards of urban design, from the look of buildings to the treatment of pavements, alleys and public squares will be forced to rise.

We may yet get away from the dismal bollards and tweedy brick paving with everything approach to urban design favoured by most British city authorities as they remain at least 20 years behind the standards of design set in, say, Barcelona or Copenhagen.

Whether the British can muster the talent and energy to match the government's new found desire to improve life in our city centres with the necessary high standards of design remains to be seen.

They will have to rise if Mr Prescott and his successors at the head of the DTR are to be able to deliver with any credibility the promised Al Gore-style annual report on the state of our cities to parliament. Sure, statistics about pollution and rubbish collection might be useful speech fodder, but the white paper does finally recognise that the physical design of our cities plays as much of a part in whether they are nurtured or neglected as any amount of cleaning and scrubbing.

Only last month the prime minister held a reception at 10 Downing Street supporting higher standards in the design of public buildings. Although the urban white paper does mean government departments working together across the monopoly board of our city centres, the proposals need the active and vocal support of the prime minister, the cabinet and Whitehall.

If we are to treat our cities with the intelligence and grace that the Spanish and the Danes, among others, have learned to, we still need get regeneration bodies from English Partnerships to local authorities to take design seriously. The signs are that the government is beginning to try, that ministries are talking to ministries and that Lord Rogers' s task force has been more than an elegant talking shop.

By ennobling our cities, we can save the countryside we say we love but wish to smother with something like 4m trashy new homes over the next 10 or 15 years because we want to escape downgraded and dirty city centres. The white paper offers practical solutions connecting the quality of urban design and transport infrastructure with the quality of life in our cities. Mr Prescott offers, for example, a dozen new private-public urban regeneration companies. These may well be be able to redevelop areas such as London's King's Cross, by making the complex mix of private, public and local authority landowners in such areas shareholders in a carrot-and-carrot operation. All players would benefit financially and environmentally. Money, assuming the white paper becomes legislation, will no longer be pumped into regenerating particular areas of cities unless this is met by three-dimensional design plans rather than vague two-dimensional diagrams and lists of statistics; in other words, standards of urban design, from the look of buildings to the treatment of pavements, alleys and public squares will be forced to rise. We may yet get away from the dismal bollards and tweedy brick paving with everything approach to urban design favoured by most British city authorities as they remain at least 20 years behind the standards of design set in, say, Barcelona or Copenhagen. Whether the British can muster the talent and energy to match the government's new found desire to improve life in our city centres with the necessary high standards of design remains to be seen. They will have to rise if Mr Prescott and his successors at the head of the DTR are to be able to deliver with any credibility the promised Al Gore-style annual report on the state of our cities to parliament. Sure, statistics about pollution and rubbish collection might be useful speech fodder, but the white paper does finally recognise that the physical design of our cities plays as much of a part in whether they are nurtured or neglected as any amount of cleaning and scrubbing. Only last month the prime minister held a reception at 10 Downing Street supporting higher standards in the design of public buildings. Although the urban white paper does mean government departments working together across the monopoly board of our city centres, the proposals need the active and vocal support of the prime minister, the cabinet and Whitehall. If we are to treat our cities with the intelligence and grace that the Spanish and the Danes, among others, have learned to, we still need get regeneration bodies from English Partnerships to local authorities to take design seriously. The signs are that the government is beginning to try, that ministries are talking to ministries and that Lord Rogers' s task force has been more than an elegant talking shop. webTitle: Cyberspace is about to arrive on the doorstep

fields.headline: Cyberspace is about to arrive on the doorstep
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The day of the door-to-door salesman is not over. A US-based company is about to send an army of sales representatives to knock on doors, selling phone and internet services.
fields.body:
The day of the door-to-door salesman is not over. A US-based company is about to send an army of sales representatives to knock on doors, selling phone and internet services.

Christina Gold, chief executive of Excel, is a former Avon lady. She is convinced that the bulk of the British public has chosen to remain with BT because of confusion caused by the barrage of leaflets and cold calls from rivals.

Excel, which was recently taken over by the Canadian telecom group BCE, will trade in Britain as ETI, to avoid confusion with about 300 UK companies called Excel.

It is buying capacity from Energis, the telecom group that strings its backbone network over the National Grid's electricity pylons, and is outsourcing its back office work to an IBM-run call centre in Swindon.

Its sales force comprises independent representatives who recruit customers, frequently friends, family and neighbours, and take not only a recruitment bonus but also a share of the telecom revenue generated. They also recruit other people to go out and sell.

ETI has signed up 300 representatives and expects to have about 4,000 on the books by Christmas. The initial recruitment drive is being conducted by about 250 Excel representatives who have come from North America

The sales package promises competitive local call rates, a 25% saving over BT's standard rates for national calls and a 70% saving for international calls. In the second quarter of next year it plans to offer a £100 set-top box providing internet access through the television sets.
