webTitle: New powers to halt flight from the cities

fields.headline: New powers to halt flight from the cities
fields.standfirst:
12 more urban regeneration companies promised  Schemes for better housing design and planning  Push for 'improvement zones'

SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: 12 more urban regeneration companies promised  Schemes for better housing design and planning  Push for 'improvement zones'.
fields.body:
Councils and government agencies were yesterday promised new compulsory purchase powers to force through the redevelopment of derelict sites in a package of measures designed to breathe new life into towns and cities.

Legislation to reclaim some of the 58,000 hectares of vacant land blighting urban areas is likely to be introduced after the general election in a widespread review of the planning system.

An urban white paper, hailed as the most comprehensive policy framework of its kind for almost half a century, also promised 12 new public-private sector urban regeneration companies - similar to existing bodies in Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield - and regional centres of excellence to improve the quality of housing design and planning. The first will be created in Manchester and London.

Town improvement zones will also be encouraged, backed with a new supplementary business rate after agreement with retailers, to curb the flight to the countryside and encourage people back into cities.

At the heart of the 160-page paper, partly a response to last year's report of an urban task force chaired by the architect Lord Rogers, is the dilemma of where to find space for an estimated 3.8m new households in England by 2021. Although the country's population of 49m is expected to rise by 7% in this period, the number of households is projected to rise by 19% because of a growing demand for single-person accommodation.

This is due to people living longer, a rise in divorce rate, and more young people staying single.

But with England "one of the most densely populated countries in the world", yesterday's report said the current rate of green field house building was unacceptable.

It lamented that new houses had been built at low densities averaging only 25 units per hectare, compared with up to 40 per hectare in Victorian England and in older suburbs. Other countries did much better, the report said.

It warned that the present level of greenfield building threatened the countryside "and fuels the flow of people away from urban centres towards the edge of cities and beyond".

To reverse the rural drift, the white paper underlined the importance of last week's decision by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to offer developers tax incentives for recycling urban land and buildings.

These include abolishing stamp duty on property transactions in poor areas, 100% capital allowances for developers converting space over shops into flats, and a 5% VAT rate - down from the present 17.5% - for people who turn older buildings into flats.

But environmental groups said the measures fell far short of creating a level playing field because new houses are zero-rated and outside the VAT net. The Empty Homes Agency, a charity partly funded by the government, believes the flat 5% rate should be levied on new homes and conversions.

Ashley Horsey, director of the EHA, said the tax measures would do little to bring an estimated 750,000 empty houses back into use.

The new 5% VAT rate was too restrictive because it was confined only to flat conversions and not to house improvements which will still be liable to the full 17.5%.

The opposition was also critical. Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, said the white paper would be remembered for missed opportunities. "Why no development tax?" he asked.

Archie Norman, shadow environment secretary, claimed the government was spending less on regeneration than the Tories.

He claimed the decision to plan for 900,000 new houses in the south-east would accelerate the drift to the countryside.

But the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, insisted that new planning guidelines would force developers on to urban sites. They would only be allowed to go to the countryside as a last resort .

Road away from ruin

1977 Urban white paper calls for new government programme to tackle decline

1981 Riots in Brixton and Liverpool. Michael Heseltine, environment secretary, loses battle for more government money to revive cities

1981 Docklands and Merseyside urban development corporations launched

1986 More development corporations launched. Spending on bricks and mortar rather than on people

1987 Margaret Thatcher makes her "walk in the wilderness". Extols virtues of Victorian philanthropists, but says extra government money will not turn cities around

1994 Michael Hesletine launches city challenge scheme. Invites councils to bid for regeneration cash. This move is criticised as a lottery

1998 John Prescott launches urban task force, chaired by Lord Rogers. Subsequently calls are made for special tax breaks to lure developers into cities in special priority areas, as well as curbs on greenfield building, and better design with special urban architecture centres

2000 Gordon Brown, the chancellor, meets Lord Rogers. In last week's pre-budget statement, he agrees to give cities tax concessions in order to kick-start development

webTitle: £180m plan to revive Corrie terraces

fields.headline: £180m plan to revive Corrie terraces
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: Coronation Street has seen much better days. Once home to foundry and mill workers of east Manchester, manufacturing heart of the world's first industrial city, it has become a symbol of urban England's deepening malaise.
fields.body:
Coronation Street has seen much better days. Once home to foundry and mill workers of east Manchester, manufacturing heart of the world's first industrial city, it has become a symbol of urban England's deepening malaise.

When the factories closed, 20,000 lost their jobs in the 1970s and 1980s alone. The skilled workers left. But others remained in the vain hope of finding alternative work.

Then the unskilled drifted away, house prices slumped, and unscrupulous landlord bought blocks of properties - sometimes at £5,000 or less a house - to exploit the poorest in society dependent on housing benefit and unable to find council housing. Coronation Street plunged into decline.

Today, with the population dropping by 13% in eight years alone, the old communities of east Manchester - Ancoats, Openshaw, Beswick, Miles Platting - present the ultimate challenge for a city council and a government desperate to reverse greenfield building in favour of recycled or "brownfield" land.

Almost a third of the area is vacant in a conurbation that has more derelict land than any other part of the country. Those terraces that have not been demolished lie boarded up and vandalised. On the worst council estates nearby, almost half the housing is vacant. People are unhealthy, mortality rates are 50% above the national average, while almost 70% of under fives have dental disease.

Seeing no future in the area, some have simply left. Others, like Alan and Rose Williams, round the corner from Coronation Street, are trapped by collapsing property prices. The couple, who have three young children, paid £28,000 for their three-bedroom house in 1991, and spent £18,000 on improvements. It was recently valued at £10,000.

"We can't lose so much, so we'll have to stay in the hope things get better," says Alan. He is tiring of rubbish thrown over the back wall, the swearing and noise from nearby houses. "It's not good for the children hearing all that stuff," says Rose. "But they're very happy at school, doing well."

"This was once a belting area," recalls Alan. "A great community and so friendly."

Half a mile away, in an office above the run down Beswick shopping centre, Tom Russell has taken up the challenge to turn east Manchester around in a project ministers see as a model for other cities.

Chief executive of a company called New East Manchester embracing the city council and government agencies, Mr Russell will oversee £90m of public money, and a similar amount from the private sector, in a 10-year renewal programme. Plans speak of "an opportunity for regeneration on a scale and diversity unmatched in an English city".

The area has one great advantage, as the centre for the 2002 Commonwealth Games. With east Manchester's national cycling arena a success, a 48,000-seat stadium is taking shape nearby in a "sports city" complex.

It is hoped this will provided the spur to double the population to 60,000, with 12,500 new homes alongside the improvement of 7,000 older properties. A shopping centre, with covered market, is planned as the focus for the "new town". Mr Russell is talking to a consortium of national house builders in the hope of announcing contracts for the first 3,000 homes before Christmas: "They have told us they recognise the time is right to get into the regeneration game and look at areas like this, now the mood is turning against greenfield sites."

Hilary Armstrong, the regeneration minister, believes the plan will succeed where others have failed because it recognises "human renewal" must go alongside neighbourhood rebuilding. "There is a lot to celebrate but a lot to do," she said.

webTitle: Museum 'fined' in portico fiasco

fields.headline: Museum 'fined' in portico fiasco
fields.trailText: The trustees of the British Museum were accused yesterday of "dereliction of their duty to the building", and will in effect be fined up to £2m of a promised lottery grant for allowing the south portico of the new Great Court to be built in French instead of Portland stone, and with inferior workmanship.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The trustees of the British Museum were accused yesterday of "dereliction of their duty to the building", and will in effect be fined up to £2m of a promised lottery grant for allowing the south portico of the new Great Court to be built in French instead of Portland stone, and with inferior workmanship.

The only consolation for the trustees, and chairman Graham Greene, is that the rest of the £90m Great Court, under its acres of new glass roof designed by Lord Foster, is praised as "superlative".

Although Sir Neil Cossons, chairman of English Heritage, was sharply critical of the museum yesterday, he has crucially decided that the portico should not be demolished, despite the use of the wrong stone, and the quality of the masonry.

His predecessor, Sir Jocelyn Stevens, who retired from English Heritage last March, has repeatedly demanded that the portico be demolished and that Graham Greene resign. "This is one of the most important buildings in the country. They cannot be allowed to get away with this," he told the Guardian last week.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, also issued a statement of barely concealed fury. "I welcome English Heritage's statement today, especially the recognition - widely accepted - that the Great Court scheme as a whole is of the finest quality. There are, however, serious questions to be answered about the specifics of the south portico."

He called for the publication in full of the report into the affair by PricewaterhouseCoopers when it is finalised within the next few weeks.

The uproar over what the museum hoped would be a millennium triumph to rival Tate Modern, began 18 months ago when an anonymous tipoff revealed that the contractor, Easton Masonry, was supplying cheaper French Anstrude stone, rather than the specified Portland. The two stones are so similar that it took laboratory tests to prove this.

The museum's managing director, Suzanna Taverne, has revealed that the museum withheld £170,000 to make up for the price difference, but claims the trustees could not sue because although Portland was always intended, the contract specified Portland "or similar".

Ms Taverne was not available for comment yesterday, but has robustly defended the trustees' decision to let construction go ahead.

Although the public controversy has centred on the French stone, English Heritage was equally concerned by what it judged inferior masonry and carving - which has been partly, but not entirely, corrected.

A museum statement said it welcomed English Heritage's recognition that all feasible remedial work had been done, and promised to monitor the work "in perpetuity" in case of future deterioration.

The planning authority, Camden council, could still ignore the advice of English Heritage and order demolition, but that is now highly unlikely. Councillors will probably not consider the case until January, a month after the opening.

English Heritage has urged the heritage lottery fund to stop the part of the £15.75m grant towards the £90m project which relates to the south portico. A spokeswoman confirmed that over £1.3m had been held back, and is highly unlikely to be paid, although the decision must be confirmed by the trustees next month. The lottery fund also gave £30m, but for other aspects of the scheme.

The Guardian was invited to inspect the Great Court, just after the stone of both the portico and the neighbouring walls had been pressure washed. The carving of the portico appeared crisp and dramatic, and the colour a creamy white. It was far brighter than the stone of the surviving porticos, which has weathered for 150 years, but not disturbingly so.

The Queen opens the Great Court on December 6.

webTitle: Anglicans may set quotas for black and Asian clergy

fields.headline: Anglicans may set quotas for black and Asian clergy
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The general synod yesterday acknowledged institutional racism in the Church of England, and confessed its repeated failure to take issues of racial justice sufficiently seriously.
fields.body:
The general synod yesterday acknowledged institutional racism in the Church of England, and confessed its repeated failure to take issues of racial justice sufficiently seriously.

As part of a series of actions to combat racism, it plans not only to send bishops on racism awareness courses but to consider recruitment quotas for black clergy and teachers at church schools.

In a debate at synod (the church's parliament) in the wake of introspection following the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, bishops, clergy and several black lay representatives accused the church of discouraging participation by ethnic minorities and their promotion in church circles.

A recent report claimed that black worshippers felt themselves to be few, marginalised, and poorly treated, and that black clergy were under-represented even in urban dioceses.

Philip Giddings, a lay member of the archbishops' council, the executive cabinet of the church, told synod: "The facts and figures speak powerfully of the collective failure of the church to provide full opportunities for black and Asian people to take their full part in our life at every level.

"We may not intend to exclude them or discriminate against them, but that is the effect of what we do.

"This is not a case of following some fashionable, secular agenda of the church trying to be politically correct. On the contrary these are core gospel issues. Our attitudes, processes and behaviour are working to exclude black and Asian Anglicans."

webTitle: Rail chiefs pledge to compensate passengers

fields.headline: Rail chiefs pledge to compensate passengers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Rail passengers will be offered compensation for the delays and cancellations experienced during the recent crisis but the size of the payout has not yet been agreed, it was announced last night.
fields.body:
Rail passengers will be offered compensation for the delays and cancellations experienced during the recent crisis but the size of the payout has not yet been agreed, it was announced last night.

The promise followed a third meeting between rail industry executives and Tony Blair at Downing Street during which the prime minister emphasised the need for a rapid end to rail chaos and compensation to be arranged as soon as possible.

Mr Blair urged the rail executives, who included Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority and the Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, to make compensation for season ticket holders a priority during the 80 minute meeting, a Downing Street spokesman said.

An announcement from rail operators on a compensation scheme could come as early as next week.

Mr Blair was determined to keep the pressure on rail operators over the coming weeks to ensure progress was maintained, the spokesman said.

But despite a pledge that working timetables would be in place from next week, passengers were warned they could face continuing delays for the next few months at least.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, said Railtrack expected the bulk of the re-railing work following the Hatfield crash and the recent floods to be completed by the new year.

He said the industry's efforts would concentrate on providing better information for the public, a sustainable timetable by next week, a compensation package to be arranged as soon as possible and confirmation of which services would run at Christmas and the new year.

He added that the level of compensation passengers would get for the disruption they had endured was a matter of negotiation which was "very much for the industry to work out".

There have been fears that large amounts of compensation would be kept by train companies rather than passed on to customers.

But Lord Macdonald denied that there had ever been a row over compensation or over new timetables.

Speaking after the meeting, Mr Corbett said ensuring the rail network was safe and restoring services as quickly as possible were his two main goals.

He confirmed that Railtrack plans to carry out 12 months' worth of rail repairs over the next six weeks, subject to approval by the rest of the rail industry and the health and safety executive.

Railtrack has talked to train operators about closing key routes for repairs over the Christmas period ready for the January rush when travellers return to work, he added.

webTitle: Ilisu Dam project fails to meet guidelines

fields.headline: Ilisu fails to meet guidelines
fields.trailText: The Ilisu Dam project in Turkey, which the government is "minded" to support with £200m of taxpayers' money, does not meet the tests of acceptability for mega-dam projects set yesterday by the world commission on dams.
fields.body:
The Ilisu Dam project in Turkey, which the government is "minded" to support with £200m of taxpayers' money, does not meet the tests of acceptability for mega-dam projects set yesterday by the world commission on dams.

It fails because the Ilisu would flood the Kurd homelands without proper consultation or resettlement, destroy important archaeological sites, ferment discord between states by giving Turks control over the flow of water to downstream states of Syria and Iraq, and damage the environment.

The British government has not moved from its position declared last December that it would back the project if some environmental and resettlement conditions were met. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said yesterday that he would study the report carefully.

Mr Byers, along with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is known to be doubtful about the project but was overruled by Tony Blair last December. He again emphasised environmental concerns yesterday.

The commission chairman, Kadar Asmal, said: "We have not made a recommendation specifically about Ilisu ... but it does not take much intelligence to see Ilisu does not meet the guidelines for new dams."

webTitle: Brand name goods 'should cost less'

fields.headline: Brand name goods 'should cost less'
fields.trailText: Consumer watchdogs yesterday launched a campaign to cut the cost of branded and designer goods following a survey which shows the UK is one of the most expensive places to shop in the world.
fields.body:
Consumer watchdogs yesterday launched a campaign to cut the cost of branded and designer goods following a survey which shows the UK is one of the most expensive places to shop in the world.

The Consumers' Association unveiled its "cheaper brands" campaign after research showed basic goods in Britain can sometimes cost almost twice as much as in the US.

It is now calling for European trade restrictions, which are blamed for the disparity, to be lifted.

The CA argues that the EU's trade mark directive, which effectively forces retailers to import goods from the most expensive suppliers, should be scrapped.

It is being backed in its fight by supermarket giants Tesco and Asda, and the Parallel Trade Association, which represents "grey" importers who openly flout regulations to find customers a better deal.

To back its demands, the association yesterday revealed a list of common Christmas stocking items for which British consumers are paying over the odds.

On three of them - a Barbie doll, Calvin Klein boxer shorts and a chart CD - British shops were found to be charging a total of almost £50, com pared with under £33 in the US.

Sheila McKechnie, director of the Consumers' Association, said: "This European law is a smokescreen for price fixing as it is allowing brand owners to charge consumers high prices in the UK and the rest of Europe.

"Our message to the European commission is 'Come on, change this law and give us all a cheaper Christmas'."

The association wants all governments to press the European commission to change the directive so that traders can import cheaper branded goods from any country and retailers are allowed to undercut prices.

Tesco, meanwhile, yesterday announced it was launching a "grey market" Christmas list.

The supermarket chain is already embroiled in a legal battle with Levi's after it imported the clothing giant's jeans from Mexico, selling them to customers for just £30 a pair.

Tesco said it would expand its range of "grey" goods to include Pokemon T-shirts, Technics stereos, Polo boxer shorts, and Nina Ricci perfumes.

Asda revealed it was already stocking many grey market items, from perfumes to kitchen cleaners.

webTitle: Three embryos 'too many' for IVF treatment

fields.headline: Three embryos 'too many' for IVF treatment
fields.standfirst: Multiple births caused by couples stacking odds
fields.trailText: About half all triplets born in the United Kingdom are the result of IVF treatment with three embryos such as that undergone by the Thompsons.
fields.body:
About half all triplets born in the United Kingdom are the result of IVF treatment with three embryos such as that undergone by the Thompsons.

That is too many, say experts in the field. Babies are less likely to survive pregnancy, more likely to be born prematurely, and more likely to suffer long-term health problems.

The consequences for both the families and the national health bill are serious. The implanting of three embryos is the maximum allowed by law since 1990. In the mid 1990s it was common practice to do just that. Now it is far less so.

Technological and medical improvements, and overall increasing success rates, mean that in many cases, it may soon be common to transfer just one embryo . Last January the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, with the blessing of the government, issued new guidance which called for a national move to implanting only two embryos.

These could substantially reduce the cost of maternity and neonatal services, and, some have pointed out, free money to invest in more fertility treatment which can cost couples desperate for a child a small fortune. Probably fewer than 10% of couples get all the treatment on the NHS. By the time shared expenses, subsidised drugs or other financial deals are done, this may rise to just under one in five.

Much as triplets may be loved, and money may sometimes be no object, splitting affection three ways can be difficult. In total, up to 5,700 live births a year are down to IVF treatment, available in 75 clinics. Figures collected by the human fertilisation and embryology authority have indicated that when two embryos are chosen for implanting from more than four prepared there is about a one in four chance of a live birth.

Of these, about one in four will be multiple births, although it is four or five times more likely to be twins than triplets. When three embryos are transferred, the chances of multiple births rise to about one in three.

The authority last night said the Sheffield case broke neither the law or its code on transfers. These allowed some clinical freedom but the decision had to be reached with the patient's involvement.

Dr Gillian Lockwood, medical director of Midland Fertility Services, and a member of the ethics committee of the British Fertility Society, said decisions on the number of embryos should be reached early in the treatment, which including investigation and counselling, might last more than three months for one attempt. Leaving such decisions, including signed consent forms to the last moment, put far too much emotional strain on prospective mothers.

"A general rule of thumb is that a young woman under 37, say, particularly if she is having her first cycle of IVF and the embryos are of good quality should not have more than two.

"But for an older woman, who has had several unsuccessful cycles and whose embryos are of poorer quality, then most clinics would be more comfortable about transferring three embryos. Older women tend to get multiple pregnancies less frequently."

In most clinics with good treatment records and practice increasing the number of embryos from two to three had little effect on the pregnancy rate. Some clinics with less good rates might still feel it worth using the extra embryo to "bump things up".

Once clinics were in a position for the transfer of just one or two embryos to be entirely the norm, and a couple were more confident about their chances of the woman becoming pregnant, "they will be less keen to load the dice in their favour". Dr Lockwood added: "People want one or two babies, not a litter. It is only because IVF is so expensive for most people that they will try to get pregnant however they can."

But not all triplets could be avoided. "Mother Nature often insists on having the last laugh. You can just implant two embryos and one will spontaneously twin."

webTitle: The unacceptable cost of big dams

fields.headline: The unacceptable cost of big dams
fields.standfirst: Commission condemns ill-thought-out projects bulldozed through without consulting those whose homes and jobs they destroyed
fields.trailText: Many of the 45,000 big dams built across the world cost too much, were late, damaged the poor, and have failed to provide all the electricity and water for irrigation that their planners claimed they would, the world commission on dams reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Many of the 45,000 big dams built across the world cost too much, were late, damaged the poor, and have failed to provide all the electricity and water for irrigation that their planners claimed they would, the world commission on dams reported yesterday.

The main beneficiaries were often western construction companies which gained billions of pounds worth of business paid for by aid agencies such as the World Bank, and consequently added to the debt of some of the poorest countries.

But despite condemning ill-thought-out immense projects that were bulldozed through without consulting those whose homes and jobs they destroyed, the commission said dams are not all bad.

Properly planned, with the consent of those most affected, and provided that alternatives are investigated and found unacceptable, dams still have a place in providing development for poorer countries.

The report, launched by Nelson Mandela in London yesterday, is the first definitive assessment of big dam projects and is expected to act as a blueprint for further developments. It recommends that export credit guarantee departments do not support projects unless a number of conditions are met, including prior consent of those affected, proper compensation schemes and environmental safeguards. The commission is also concerned about conflicts arising from states building dams on shared rivers without consulting downstream neighbours.

Greenhouse gases

One surprise is that the report says claims that dams provide "clean" electricity and do not add to global warming are not always true. Some dams that drown forests and create large quantities of gas because of decaying vegetation may produce as much greenhouse gases as generating electricity with fossil fuels.

The number of people displaced by dams is estimated at between 40m and 80m, most of them in China and India. The costs of dams were on average 50% above their original estimate. Some designed to reduce flooding made it worse, and there were many unexpected environmental disadvantages, including the extinction of fish and bird species. Half the world's wetlands had been lost because of dams.

Kader Asmal, the commission chairman, said: "In general countries that have built big dams have paid a high cost to secure benefits while the people affected have paid an unacceptable and often unnecessary price. It has not been equitable or efficient. We are not in the business of moral or religious condemnation, we are trying to point out that shortcomings are not automatic and can be avoided."

Mr Mandela said the picture was not all bleak and dams had brought great benefits too. Although millions had suffered, millions more had made great gains in terms of water and electricity not available before.

"The problem is not the dams," he said. "It is the hunger. It is the thirst. It is the darkness of a township. It is the townships and rural huts without running water, lights or sanitation that we must cure."

Critics of dams immediately urged the World Bank and export credit agencies to halt all support for dams until the commission's recommendations were implemented.

"The report vindicates much of what dam critics have long argued. If the builders and funders of dams follow the recommendations of the commission the era of destructive dams could come to an end," said Patrick McCully, campaigns director of the US-based International Rivers Network.

Steve Fisher, from the dams commission, said the report showed that dams should be approved only if they demonstrably met the goal of human development. Small scale energy schemes, manufactured and constructed locally, created employment and reduced dependence on foreign capital, technology and expertise.

Kariba Dam, Zambezi river, Zambia/Zimbabwe

Built 1960, cost £1bn. Height of 128 metres and flooded 5,477sq km, making it the largest man-made lake in the world. Led to resettlement of 57,000 people who lost homes and livelihoods and suffered increased disease. Main beneficiaries were multinational corporations which needed power and water for copper mines. Also serves urban areas, farmers and 20 hotels on dam shores. Created commercial fisheries on the lake and 450 full-time jobs. Produces 1,266 megawatts of power.

The good, the bad and the dammed

Tarbela Dam, Indus river, Pakistan

1976, cost £6bn. Height of 148 metres, flooded 240sq km. Resettled 96,000 people. Loss of migratory fish species. Created largest irrigation scheme in the world: waters 18m acres, about 60% of cultivable land, providing jobs for millions of small farmers. Poor irrigation practices causing large scale salination of soil and loss of croplands. Produces 3,478 megawatts of power, 28% of the country's need.

Grand Coulee, Columbia river, USA/Canada

1941, cost £6.5bn. Height of 170 metres, with 260 sq km reservoir. Resettled 6,000 people mostly Indians not compensated for 45 years. Loss of fish species. Irrigates 1,400 farms, supplies water to industry and urban areas. Capacity of 6,809 megawatts of power and has made huge profits.

Tucurui Dam, Toccantis river, Brazil

1986, cost £4bn, £2bn over budget. Height of 78 metres, 2,430 sq km reservoir. 4,000 megawatts of power. Resettled 25,000-35,000. Some fish species lost. Aluminium industry consumes more than half the power.

webTitle: Cabinet targets law and disorder at election talks

fields.headline: Cabinet targets law and disorder at election talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Labour cabinet will meet at Chequers today to map out a political strategy running up to the next election, banking on a strong economy and imminent fulfilment of its five election pledges to defeat William Hague.
fields.body:
The Labour cabinet will meet at Chequers today to map out a political strategy running up to the next election, banking on a strong economy and imminent fulfilment of its five election pledges to defeat William Hague.

The bulk of the work on the manifesto analysis has now been completed, overseen by No 10 policy researcher Ed Richards.

It is expected that crime and fear of crime, and wider social disorder such as drunkenness and incivility, will play a large part in the manifesto, as well as in the Queen's speech.

Ministers believe middle England is beginning to recognose that acute crime is in decline, but more needs to be done to show that the government is on the side of ordinary citizens fed up by drunkenness, graffiti and street intimidation.

Strategists believe they need to address the issue of social dislocation partly by developing ideas set out in neighbourhood renewal strategy. They also want to take the New Deal into more difficult areas, including the 1m plus completely out of touch from the labour market.

Ministers plan to use the Queens speech in a fortnight's time and a raft of green papers, including one on the family and another on work-life balance, to show that Labour will not run out of energy or ideas in a second term.

Party officials are also pinning hopes on the novel thank you campaign - launched with nationwide posters this week in which ordinary citizens are given the credit for the reduction in class sizes and other achievements in the Labour record.

They hope the slogan will address the image of an arrogant out of touch leadership whilst stressing the government's achievements.

"We have been struggling to find a vocabulary of achievement that is also humble and this may be the answer," said one MP involved in preparing the campaign.

The fall in Mr Blair's personal popularity ratings has been the most worrying development for the party in recent months.

Some Downing Street strategists believe they will win the coming election easily with a strong message to voters on the economy, on investment in key public services like health and education, and even on Europe where they will contrast their promise of choice on the single currency with Tory isolationism.

"The economy, education, the health service and crime, these themes are enough to keep the 1997 coalition together," one No 10 insider predicted.

In a reversal of the electoral logic of the 1980s when Thatcherite tax cuts drove the agenda, Labour will campaign on a stable economy plus investment in public services which most voters want.

Labour fears that a drive to lower public expecations and create cynicism is William Hague's best bet. "Their strategy is to put people off, to create cynicism in the hope of getting in by the back door," one strategist said.

webTitle: Yesterday

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.body:
Good day

Drinkers of low alcohol beers. Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo announced that if the Tories win the election he will slash tax on the beers. He said the Conservatives would consider cutting the duty on all beers and lagers under 2.4% strength to just 8p a pint. That compares with the current average of around 38p.

Figure of the day

The Saville inquiry into the events of Bloody Sunday has cost nearly £30m so far, the government said in a reply to a written question.The figure includes more than £15m in payments to lawyers, £7m on IT and communications and £2m in salaries. Other costs are susistence and travel, accommodation, general office costs and witness and hearing costs.

webTitle: Syria to free 600 political prisoners

fields.headline: Syria to free 600 political prisoners
fields.trailText: Syria's new president, Bashar al-Assad, has ordered the release of 600 political prisoners to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the purge that brought his father Hafez to power.
fields.body:
Syria's new president, Bashar al-Assad, has ordered the release of 600 political prisoners to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the purge that brought his father Hafez to power.

The amnesty is believed to include members of the banned Muslim Brothers, the Communist Action League and other parties. Some of the detainees are said to be Lebanese.

"This is an encouraging first step towards the release of all political prisoners in the country," a spokesman for Amnesty International said.

Amnesty estimated that Syria had between 1,000 and 1,500 political prisoners before the releases were announced.

Since inheriting the presidency after the death in June of his father, Bashar, 35, has been pushing for a degree of political and economic reform in what was widely regarded as a hidebound police state.

The release of prisoners commemorated November 16, 1970, when the "Corrective Movement" purged its rivals in the Ba'ath party and Hafez al-Assad seized the presidency.

Patrick Seale, biographer of the late leader, said yesterday: "Dr Bashar is anxious to improve Syria's human rights image. Shortly after taking over he set up a committee to visit jails and examine cases.

"He also wants to heal the wounds of the past, especially with the Muslim Brothers."

Many of the Brothers were arrested in the 1980s during a suppression which included the 1982 massacre at the town of Hama. Under Syrian law, membership of the Muslim Brothers is still a capital crime.

The release of about 100 Lebanese political prisoners is also seen as a goodwill gesture towards Lebanon, where Syria maintains 20,000 or more troops.

Opposition to this military presence has been growing recently. Many Lebanese see no justification for it now that the Israeli army has withdrawn from the south.

webTitle: A death the Israelis cannot ignore

fields.headline: A death the Israelis cannot ignore
fields.standfirst:
Tel Aviv pledges inquiry after its guns kill the first European in seven weeks of bloodshed

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Harald Fischer's neighbours spent yesterday morning picking up his shredded remains after the popular German resident was torn apart by an Israeli missile during an eight-hour bombardment of their snug West Bank town.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Beit Jalla, West Bank
fields.body:
Harald Fischer's neighbours spent yesterday morning picking up his shredded remains after the popular German resident was torn apart by an Israeli missile during an eight-hour bombardment of their snug West Bank town.

Fischer, 67, a retired chiropractor from Gummersbach in North Rhine-Westphalia, has the tragic distinction of being the first European citizen - and first Christian - to die in seven weeks of bloodshed in the West Bank and Gaza.

One Palestinian man was shot in the chest near Hebron yesterday and died as Israeli troops blocked an ambulance from reaching him.

After more than 200 Palestinians killed by Israeli shells, sniper fire and rubber bullets, Harald Fischer's death may be the first that sees Israel held to account. The government said yesterday it would investigate his death, together with Germany's military attache.

In this prosperous suburb of Bethlehem, Fischer's death had the rare power to shock a community exhausted by the nightly punishment inflicted by the Israeli tanks stationed on the next ridge, guarding the Jewish settlement of Gilo, which was built on land confiscated from Beit Jalla.

Scores of people gathered at the spot where he was cut down, marked by a circle of stones and a few straggly bouquets of flowers. As the sun rose in the sky, neighbours scrubbed his blood and scraps of his corpse from a home five metres away.

The crowds swelled later in the day when Orthodox priests in black robes jostled with Palestinian gunmen, German diplomats and doctors in white coats to carry Fischer's coffin to the local Lutheran church.

Fischer was married in the same stone building. He arrived in the mainly Christian town in 1981 with Lifegate, an organisation that works with the handicapped, and stayed, marrying Norma, a local woman, and raising three children. He left five children from a first marriage in Germany.

On Wednesday night, when the Israeli firing began, the Fischers huddled in their living room on the far side from Gilo. Two bullets pierced the wardrobe in the bedroom Fischer shared with his wife, which looks out on the apartment blocks of Gilo, and another landed in their daughters' room.

At about 11.30pm, Fischer left the relative safety of his home when neighbours called to tell him people had been injured down the road.

"He was never afraid," said his oldest son, Danial, 17. "He always used to tell us that he lived through the second world war."

On Wednesday night, however, Fischer appears to have taken a direct hit from an Israeli missile. The attack was part of an Israeli assault on five West Bank towns overnight, in what Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, has called retaliatory acts for gunfire from Yasser Arafat's Fatah tanzim militias.

The leader of the Beit Jalla tanzim, who is directing the fire against Gilo, was also outside Fischer's home yesterday. "We know we are hurting local people by firing from this area, but we have no other option," said the man, who would give only his first name, Mike.

He said his men operate in cells of six to 12 fighters, and are armed with M-16s and heavy machine guns capable of hitting Gilo, which is about 500 metres away.

The attacks - which have inflicted only minimal damage - have caused terror and outrage among Israelis who consider the settlement, built on land occupied since 1967, to be practically a part of Jerusalem. Their clamour is forcing Mr Barak to take ever harsher measures against the Palestinians.

Yesterday, he said he would take the punishment up a notch by blocking millions of dollars in tax revenue Israel is bound to transfer to the Palestinians - about two-thirds of the total revenues of the Palestinian Authority.

On average, Israel had been transferring 240m shekels ($60m) a month in collected tax revenues, including money withheld from the salaries of Palestinian workers in Israel, to the Palestinian Authority.

"Life today as a result of this fighting, in Palestinian society, in the West Bank and Gaza is much more difficult than it is here," Mr Barak told Israel Radio yesterday. "People are not working. Money isn't being transferred. Many other things are not getting there - all for security considerations and this will continue as long as necessary."

That message will go unheeded in Gilo, ringed by military foxholes and two lines of concrete barriers. Its low-rise buildings have relatively few bullet scars, but its residents bay for Palestinian blood.

Despite the devastation wrought on Beit Jalla and nearby Beit Sahour, where more than 120 houses have been hit by Israeli missiles and machine-gun fire, Mr Barak said yesterday the Palestinians could expect to be hit harder, and for many days to come.

That is precisely what they are dreading in Beit Jalla. "There has been so much suffering and we want to see it stop. We have never been violent people. I don't know why this has happened to us," said Fischer's widow, Norma.

"Enough is enough. This has to stop. We cannot live in fear every night and every day."

Ian Black in Brussels adds: Mounting violence in the West Bank left its mark in Marseille yesterday, where EU foreign ministers were meeting their Israeli and Arab counterparts for the Euro-Med dialogue.

Arab ministers, frustrated by the dominance of the US, urged the EU to drop its neutrality in the face of Israeli "aggression". But Germany's Joschka Fischer said Europe was committed to "supporting the legitimate interests of both sides".

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: IFA fined £145,000
fields.body:
IFA fined £145,000

Independent financial adviser firm Meryl Court Technical Services has been fined £145,000 by the personal investment authority for rule breaches, it was announced yesterday.

The Bristol-based company was fined for compliance failings including recruiting as a financial adviser someone who had been made bankrupt, and for problems linked to the personal pensions mis-selling review, said the regulator.

The company "failed to organise and control its internal affairs in a responsible manner, to keep proper records, to have adequate arrangements to ensure that its investment staff were suitable, and failed to maintain well defined compliance procedures," said the PIA.

Swindon safe, says Honda

The future of Honda's Swindon plant is not at risk from the strong pound or the weak euro, the company said yesterday. Mark Davies, the UK general manager, said the ability to switch production quickly mitigated problems with chronically weak currencies.

BASF cuts back British jobs

German chemicals and pharmaceuticals group BASF AG is closing its research and development facility in Nottingham, with the loss of 200 jobs, as part of a global consolidation of its R&D.

Buyout fails at Kvaerner

Anglo-Norwegian engineering and construction group Kvaerner is to close the manufacturing facility of Kvaerner Energy in Clydebank, Scotland with the loss of 200 jobs.

The move follows the failure of talks with Newco, led by the plant's former marketing director Bob Helburn, over the sale of the factory. Newco and Kvaerner had agreed a buyout in August but Newco was unable to meet the conditions of sale.

EC looks into PO venture

The EC is opening a more detailed inquiry into plans by the Post Office, Dutch TNT Post Group TPAS and Singapore Post Private for two joint ventures. The firms plan a joint venture for international business and parcel mail, Delta NV. But the EC said Delta raised doubts over meeting single market rules.

ONdigital: correction

Contrary to a report on this page yesterday, ONdigital did not admit to an employment tribunal that it had made false claims about the success of its launch. See Corrections and Clarifications, page 27.

webTitle: Race pact costs Coca-Cola $192m

fields.headline: Race pact costs Coca-Cola $192m
fields.standfirst: Bias claims from 2,000 workers settled
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola, the world's largest soft drinks group, is to pay $192m (£130m) to settle charges of race discrimination made by 2,000 African American employees.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola, the world's largest soft drinks group, is to pay $192m (£130m) to settle charges of race discrimination made by 2,000 African American employees.

The group's lawyers said the settlement was the largest ever agreed in a race discrimination lawsuit brought on behalf of hundreds of individuals.

Under the terms of the deal, the company will spend about $113m on back pay and compensation for hundreds of African Americans who worked for the company between 1995 and last June, when Coca-Cola entered settlement discussions.

The wide-ranging terms include a review of the company's employment practices to be carried out by an outside task force. This panel will be able to issue binding recommendations for changes in employment practices. To avoid implementing these recommendations, the company would have to convince a judge that they were unsound from a business standpoint or technically unfeasible.

In a memo to all employees yesterday, Doug Daft, the chief executive, said that he wanted the company to set a gold standard in its behaviour towards minorities. The company is based in Atlanta, Georgia, which has a large African American population.

The company also agreed to pay $50m to the Coca-Cola Foundation, which offers community support programmes, and to spend several million dollars on pay adjustments for certain employees. Terms of the settlement were agreed by both sides before being put to an arbitration panel.

The soft drinks company, one of the world's best known brands, was damaged by claims from African American employees that they were denied pay increases, promotion and fair performance reviews. Campaign groups urged a boycott of Coca-Cola and took to the streets of Georgia to demonstrate.

Mr Daft told staff that settlement of the race discrimination suit had been his number one priority since being appointed this year. "Today we are closing a painful chapter in our company's history. Discrimination of any kind - even if it's unintended, tolerated or simply overlooked - has no place at the Coca-Cola company."

Among Mr Daft's first actions as chief executive was to appoint a senior African American to a board position designed to improve community relations.

webTitle: Balkans legacy may be a war crimes court that works

fields.headline: The Balkans legacy may be a war crimes court that works
fields.standfirst:
The lack of western commitment has failed tribunals of the past

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Martin Woollacott: The lack of western commitment has failed tribunals of the past.
fields.body:
It may be that the most important memorial to the recent wars in the Balkans will be a system of international justice for war crimes and crimes against humanity of some permanence and effectiveness. If so, it will be a case of failure in one sphere leading to success in another.

The international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia would never have been set up had western countries acted decisively to stop the violence there, and the same could be said for the Rwanda tribunal. Establishing the tribunals was a substitute for policies that would have prevented the crimes being committed in the first place. But it was a kind of gain, which contributed in turn to the agreement, however imperfect, on an international criminal court in Rome in 1998.

This advance toward global justice is, of course, far from irreversible. What happens in Serbia in the next few months, in particular, will determine whether a comprehensive accounting for the crimes of the past 10 years in that region takes place. If it does, the general prospect for international justice is improved; if not, it will be diminished.

The historical record is not encouraging. Nuremberg was a relative success but, as Gary Jonathan Bass shows in his new study of war crimes tribunals, efforts to try war criminals in the past were frequently aborted, abandoned, or allowed to degenerate into farce. When countries who had proposed such trials found them politically inappropriate, or discovered that the risks of pursuing those charged were high, or found the trials got in the way of negotiations to end conflicts or of making a new start with the new leaders of former enemy nations, they closed them down or let them die of inanition.

There is nothing new, for instance, about refusing to risk troops in arresting indicted men, as Nato forces in Bosnia did for a long time, or about wanting to moderate or abandon trials for fear of a nationalist backlash. In 1815, when the nations debated whether and how to punish Napoleon and his marshals, British naval officers were instructed not to risk a single sailor's life in apprehending him. After the first world war, trials in Leipzig and Constantinople of German and Turkish leaders, officers, and officials, the latter for their crimes against Armenians as well as on other charges, were abandoned when circumstances changed. Bass traces these themes through the years and ends by noting the "unhappy possibility" that the Hague and Arusha "will be forgotten as completely as Leipzig and Constantinople".

Yet, as Bass also demonstrates, there are grounds for optimism. The Hague tribunal, in particular, is an example of an international institution which acquired an independent life and which persisted in its task in ways that irritated and sometimes enraged its creators. The countries who had wanted to establish it in order to show they were doing something about the Balkan crisis did not want it to become genuinely operational and for a long time gave it no money, no intelligence, and no help in arresting suspects. That changed because a remarkable sequence of men and women, including Antonio Cassese, the first presiding judge, Richard Goldstone, the first chief prosecutor, and Lousie Arbour, his successor, refused to be sidelined.

They nagged and haggled and lobbied, sometimes in a very public way, for the means to do their job, and then did it. Arbour, for example, upset the Americans by indicting Slobodan Milosevic, who feared it might make negotiating with him more difficult, toward the end of the Kosovo war. The arrival in power of two foreign ministers, Madeleine Albright and Robin Cooke, who were strongly in favour of the tribunal, helped make it into a real force.

The difficulty now is balancing the need to help Vojislav Kostunica consolidate himself in Serbia with the need to pursue Milosevic and other indicted men in that country, and to gain the access to the documents and the witnesses allowing the indictment of many more in all parts of former Yugoslavia. Kostunica is engaged in a delicate process of reassuring parts of what used to be Milosevic's constituency, including the armed forces and police, compromising with some of its leaders, and at the same time competing with it for popular support ahead of the December elections.

To hand over indicted men would undermine this strategy and could lead to a surge of largely unreconstructed Serbian public opinion against him. His repeated line that cooperation with the tribunal is not a "priority" is a coded plea for Europe and the US to avoid public demands for the suspects to be sent to the Hague and not to make the aid that Serbia needs conditional on handing them over.

Western governments are mindful of his problems and know they will have plenty of leverage, especially economic leverage, over the Serbian government after elections in which they hope Kostunica and the opposition coalition will have reduced the influence of Milosevic's party and its allies. For the time being there is no strident pressure for action on those indicted. But there are real risks in leaving everything until next spring. It may be that the Milosevic forces will do better because he and others are still in the country. It may be that the elections will not produce a clear result, and there will then be arguments for continued compromise and delays. It may be that western governments will lose interest, as they have done before.

Meanwhile, war crimes work everywhere in former Yugoslavia is critically dependent on movement in Serbia. There have already been serious military and political ructions in Croatia over the likely indictment of a number of senior officers. It would be hard for the Croatian government to hand them over if there seemed no prospect that Serbs charged with similar or worse crimes were safe at home. If that happened, as one seasoned observer of the tribunal says, "they might as well close the doors".

The trial of senior figures is not the only consideration. Professor Cassese, in a lecture this week for the Centre for Human Rights at the London School of Economics, spoke of the danger posed by an inadequate or fraudulent process of "truth and reconciliation" in Serbia. To be acceptable, he argued, such a process, which Kostunica seems to favour, must not include the most senior figures - they must go to the Hague - must punish the worst offences and offer pardons only for lesser crimes, must emphasise full disclosure, and must be in full cooperation with the tribunal, not in any way a rival to it.

The combination of anger at what has been perpetrated and an insistence on due process is the essential combination in dealing with war crimes, according to Gary Bass. "You need both law and moral passion," he says. The difficulties which still face the tribunal suggest that both must be burnished in the months ahead.

Stay the Hand of Vengeance. Gary Jonathan Bass. Princeton University Press.

They nagged and haggled and lobbied, sometimes in a very public way, for the means to do their job, and then did it. Arbour, for example, upset the Americans by indicting Slobodan Milosevic, who feared it might make negotiating with him more difficult, toward the end of the Kosovo war. The arrival in power of two foreign ministers, Madeleine Albright and Robin Cooke, who were strongly in favour of the tribunal, helped make it into a real force. The difficulty now is balancing the need to help Vojislav Kostunica consolidate himself in Serbia with the need to pursue Milosevic and other indicted men in that country, and to gain the access to the documents and the witnesses allowing the indictment of many more in all parts of former Yugoslavia. Kostunica is engaged in a delicate process of reassuring parts of what used to be Milosevic's constituency, including the armed forces and police, compromising with some of its leaders, and at the same time competing with it for popular support ahead of the December elections. To hand over indicted men would undermine this strategy and could lead to a surge of largely unreconstructed Serbian public opinion against him. His repeated line that cooperation with the tribunal is not a "priority" is a coded plea for Europe and the US to avoid public demands for the suspects to be sent to the Hague and not to make the aid that Serbia needs conditional on handing them over. Western governments are mindful of his problems and know they will have plenty of leverage, especially economic leverage, over the Serbian government after elections in which they hope Kostunica and the opposition coalition will have reduced the influence of Milosevic's party and its allies. For the time being there is no strident pressure for action on those indicted. But there are real risks in leaving everything until next spring. It may be that the Milosevic forces will do better because he and others are still in the country. It may be that the elections will not produce a clear result, and there will then be arguments for continued compromise and delays. It may be that western governments will lose interest, as they have done before. Meanwhile, war crimes work everywhere in former Yugoslavia is critically dependent on movement in Serbia. There have already been serious military and political ructions in Croatia over the likely indictment of a number of senior officers. It would be hard for the Croatian government to hand them over if there seemed no prospect that Serbs charged with similar or worse crimes were safe at home. If that happened, as one seasoned observer of the tribunal says, "they might as well close the doors". The trial of senior figures is not the only consideration. Professor Cassese, in a lecture this week for the Centre for Human Rights at the London School of Economics, spoke of the danger posed by an inadequate or fraudulent process of "truth and reconciliation" in Serbia. To be acceptable, he argued, such a process, which Kostunica seems to favour, must not include the most senior figures - they must go to the Hague - must punish the worst offences and offer pardons only for lesser crimes, must emphasise full disclosure, and must be in full cooperation with the tribunal, not in any way a rival to it. The combination of anger at what has been perpetrated and an insistence on due process is the essential combination in dealing with war crimes, according to Gary Bass. "You need both law and moral passion," he says. The difficulties which still face the tribunal suggest that both must be burnished in the months ahead. Stay the Hand of Vengeance. Gary Jonathan Bass. webTitle: Stick with one job, ABI tells bosses

fields.headline: Stick with one job, ABI tells bosses
fields.trailText: A new demand for companies to split the roles of chairman and chief executive last night seemed likely to yield results from sports retail chain JJB.
fields.body:
A new demand for companies to split the roles of chairman and chief executive last night seemed likely to yield results from sports retail chain JJB.

The sports superstore is among 20 leading firms targeted by the influential Association of British Insurers.

The ABI has written to the firms asking for an explanation of why one man still controls both positions, but so far there is no indication the others are ready to make any changes to boardroom strategy.

The practice of having one director holding both positions largely disappeared in the last decade as a result of two corporate governance reports - but some still persist in defying the codes.

The ABI is now trying to force them into line. It has written to senior non-executive directors at those firms to inquire why one director is holding both positions.

The ABI's action comes after last month's controversy at Tomkins, where Greg Hutchins resigned as chief executive amid an inquiry into "corporate excess". Until recently he was both chairman and chief executive, and it was only the appointment of a strong chairman that brought the issue to light.

Among the companies to receive a letter from the ABI, whose members own approximately 25% of British shares, are Alliance & Leicester, Amvescap, Powergen, EMI and Old Mutual.

David Greenwood, the finance director of JJB, refused to confirm that the dual role held by the founder, David Whelan, would be divided.

But he admitted the issue will be discussed at a board meeting next month. "We accept the tide is changing and we will be addressing it in detail," Mr Greenwood said. Mr Whelan's deputy is managing director Duncan Sharpe, who is also his son-in-law.

The National Association of Pension Funds said it supported the move by the ABI. It has a policy of recommending its members vote against dual roles at annual meetings. It is understood to be keeping a watch on at least 25 big firms.

A&L yesterday justified the position of its chairman, John Windeler, by citing the eight to five balance on its board between non-executive and executives and said his role and that of his effective deputy was clearly defined.

Powergen, run by Edmund Wallis, said its deputy non-executive chairman Paul Myners, who heads the Gartmore fund manager and is also chairman of Guardian Media Group, had highlighted the balance between its non-executives and executive directors.

David Whelan JJB Sports

Salary and benefits £269,000 in 1999

What JJB said "We justified it in our annual report because of the extra cost in splitting the roles. We are sympathetic." The matter will be discussed at the December 4 meeting of the board.

Luc Vandevelde M&S

Total remuneration £2m, including all bonuses

What M&S said "At the moment it's the ideal solution for him to be hands-on; 80% of turnover comes from the UK, so Roger Holmes [who joins next year] is managing a major part of the group."

Eric Nicoli EMI

Total remuneration £921,000

What EMI said "Day to day executive responsibility for the running of the two main businesses lies with Mr Ken Berry, as chief executive of EMI Recorded Music, and Mr Martin Bandier, as chief executive of EMI Music Publishing."

webTitle: Spirent pays £1.1bn for US foothold

fields.headline: Spirent pays £1.1bn for US foothold
fields.standfirst: British firm says deal will boost profits as well as global profile
fields.trailText: Spirent, the telecoms test equipment supplier, said yesterday it was paying £1.1bn for Hekimian Laboratories, the US firm that monitors network quality.
fields.body:
Spirent, the telecoms test equipment supplier, said yesterday it was paying £1.1bn for Hekimian Laboratories, the US firm that monitors network quality.

The company, based in Crawley, west Sussex, has agreed with the family-owned Swedish conglomerate Axel Johnson a cash and shares deal, funded by a discounted rights issue.

Spirent believes the move will provide a much stronger foothold in the US where it is also considering listing on Nasdaq to increase its profile with American investors.

Nicholas Brookes, Spirent's chief executive, said the two were an "exceptional strategic fit" that would generate cash and enhance earnings in the first full year.

Hekimian would run as a separate entity under the Spirent Communications banner, while there were plans to recruit an extra 700 staff across the group this year.

"It's a natural market for us to expand into and Hekimian was the first choice," he said. "There were eight bidders and ours was not the highest price but we managed to pull it away"

The enlarged group will supply equipment and software to help ensure smooth running of networks, particularly new generation systems carrying internet data.

Its combined client list will include Cisco Systems, SBC Communications and Concert, the joint venture between British Telecom and AT&T.

Yesterday's news sent Spirent shares up 33p, or 5%, to 630p. This is some way off the year's high of 745.5p but comfortably ahead of the 296p low.

Mr Brookes said the US was crucial to the business but only around 5% of its stock was held by American institutions. "Most of the major equipment manufacturers are in North America and most of our business as well. It's the fastest-growing area of our business."

Hekimian, a 32-year-old company based in Rockville, Maryland, generated pre-tax profits of $36.3m in the eight months to the end of August on the back of $129.4m turnover, compared to profits of $19.1m for the whole of last year. The company has an order book of $120m.

The deal will see Spirent pay £500m in cash which will be financed by a five-for-24 rights issue of 140.7m new ordinary shares at 375p each. There will also be 108.4m new shares with an approximate value of £605.6m based on the theoretical ex-rights price of 558.7p per share.

Axel Johnson's chief executive, Goran Ennerfelt, will join the board of the enlarged company as a non-executive director.

The acquisition is subject to approval by Spirent shareholders on December 8.

webTitle: Blyth spirit can lead to greener Britain

fields.headline: Blyth spirit can lead to greener Britain
fields.standfirst:
Wind, waves and sun could revolutionise how we generate electricity - but the UK is sluggish

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Wind, waves and sun could revolutionise how we generate electricity - but the UK is sluggish.
fields.body:
If you want to see unexpected hope, head for Blyth in a high north wind. Here the east coast is bleak and low, and the spume-filled sea lashes the sandy bay. This is carbon country and the legacy of coal which contributes so much to global warming is everywhere.

Blyth in Northumberland was Europe's greatest coal port 40 years ago; now it is home only to a small fishing fleet. Unused seams stretch miles out to sea and the abandoned pits sprout mostly grass. The old coal-fired power station will close soon.

But the future is here: Britain's first offshore wind farm, comprising just two slender masts half a mile out in the bay, their rotor blades spinning hypnotically in the gale. The waves slam in on them reaching almost to their fog horns 15 metres up.

These, the largest offshore wind turbines in the world, have been tested for the past three months. This morning the first kilowatts start trickling into the grid. By next month, all going well, enough energy to power 1,500 homes a year will be on stream. In the next decade, up to 1,000 more turbines like these should be generating 400MW, or 1% of Britain's electricity. Most will be barely visible, more than three miles off the coast.

It will be nothing like Denmark, which by 2010 expects to be getting 50% of its power from the wind - much from offshore farms - "but it's a start", says David Still of Amec Border Wind which has linked with Shell and Powergen to build the turbines.

"The potential for jobs in this new industry is unlimited," he says. His vision is for the north-east's old factories and shipyards to make the steel blades, gearboxes and cabling and to do the construction work.

If Britain is to meet its self-set target of a 20% cut of carbon emissions on 1990 levels by 2010, it must develop offshore and other renewable energy as well as persuade industry and the public to shift from fossil fuels.

The government plans to increase renewables from 3% at present to 10% of electricity in 2010. If it is to reach the true 60% carbon emissions reduc tion target that scientists say is needed to stem global warming, the Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution envisages 200 offshore wind farms, 10,000 small wave-power turbines under the sea and thousands more in rivers and streams.

It might mean barrages across estuaries, solar power panels on roofs and big swaths of farmland growing willow and crops for small power stations fuelled by vegetable matter, as well as cars powered by fuel cells and more energy efficient housing and industry.

Everyone working in the "renewables industry", which is brimming with ideas and plans, says it can be done because most of the technology is well-proven. Conventional electricity generation, they point out, is inefficient, converting only about a third of the fuel's potential energy into usable energy.

On Teeside, 50 miles south of Blyth, the chemical industry is changing from a high energy user to an efficient low-carbon one. Three large companies have installed combined heat and power plants (CHP) that generate electricity and recycle the normally wasted heat. A new CHP plant can cut energy costs by 40%, reduce greenhouse emissions by 50%, increase energy efficiency by 20% and pay for itself in under five years. So far Britain has almost 1,400 plants but to meet its targets must more than double that in the next decade.

The government does not need to look far to see the benefits. Downing Street, the Foreign Office and most of Whitehall are now powered by CHP, as well as Buckingham Palace, many housing estates and parts of the city of Southampton.

The problem is that the government, which wants 10 gigawatt of CHP by 2010, has not fully excepted users from the new climate change levy and a deeply frustrated industry says that up to 30% of the expansion plans for the next 10 years are threatened.

It faces equal problems with transport, where carbon emissions are still rising, and traffic reduction measures are stalling. But fuel efficiency is improving with better engine technology and the first "hy brid" petrol and electric-powered vehicles in the pipeline.

Liquid petroleum gas (LPG) is expected to take off in the next few years. It sells for around 35p a litre compared to 85p a litre for petrol and even though there is a performance loss of some 20%, LPG can almost double fuel efficiency, especially in large vehicles.

No local authority can meet its national air quality targets without switching to cleaner fuels. It is impossible to do so by traffic reduction alone. Many council fleets and some buses are now running on natural gas, LPG and electricity.

Buildings contribute up to 47% of all Britain's greenhouse gas emissions. However, in the past 10 years, over 500,000 people have contacted energy efficiency advice centres and, says the National Energy Centre, saved an average of £57 a year as well as saving 745kg each of annual Co2 emissions. The most basic loft insulation, hot tank lagging or new boiler can save energy simply.

Parts of the building industry have long resisted higher energy efficiency standards, and it has been left to the EU, architects and more green-minded people to insist on serious wall and roof insulation, passive heating, solar panels, and double or triple glazing.

With 3m new homes planned in the next 20 years, it would make sense for the government to insist on higher standards. The US and Germany boast many homes and offices that can be heated on the equivalent of one single light bulb, but in Britain there are few.

One way buildings could become "carbon neutral" is by making them mini power stations with solar electricity. This industry is expanding rapidly with BP and Shell investing heavily abroad, but while other countries have ambitious solar programmes, Britain is committed to partly converting just a few schools.

Britain's entire daytime electricity needs could be met by cladding just 10% of buildings with simple solar panels.

Meanwhile, the world's first major marine turbine is about to be installed in the sea off Lynmouth, north Devon. More than 100 potential sites have been identified. It will need the sort of industrial backing that wind, solar and offshore power is beginning to attract from large companies, but it could provide up to 15% of the British electricity demand.

The average family or business can generate all its own electricity by the sun right now. It can run its car on electricity or low-emission gas. Within a generation it will probably have the option of hydrogen to fuel everything. Whether it chooses to is another matter.

webTitle: Scoot stays positive despite doubled loss

fields.headline: Scoot stays positive despite doubled loss
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Losses at Scoot.com, the internet business directory publisher, nearly doubled last year to £38.5m but the company claimed last night it was on course to be profitable within 12 months.
fields.body:
Losses at Scoot.com, the internet business directory publisher, nearly doubled last year to £38.5m but the company claimed last night it was on course to be profitable within 12 months.

Chief executive Robert Bonnier said Scoot was experiencing a "rapid acceleration of operating momentum" and pointed to a 29% growth in its subscriber base over the fourth quarter compared with 12 weeks earlier.

There had been a further 36% increase in subscribers to 40,812 from the beginning of October to November 10 and, if this continued, the British activities would be out off the red in six months. "The group could be EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) positive by the third quarter of 2001," he added.

Scoot had been aiming for profitability by the following year. Losses for the 12 months to September escalated because Scoot had rolled out its business in Europe and had extra expenses after its June takeover of small ads publisher Loot.

Shares in Scoot fell 2.5p to 83.25p yesterday but Nick Bubb, retail analyst with SG Securities, felt the losses were lower than expected and subscriber growth was strong. He accepted it was frustrating that "with current market sentiment, and in the absence of takeover talk, shares might not move ahead".

The stock price had been given strong momentum in the summer by expectations that Vivendi, the French media and utilities group which has a 22.4% stake in Scoot, would launch a full bid.

These hopes have now receded and been replaced by more negative talk. There has been speculation of a Department of Trade and Industry investigation into Scoot share trades plus court action by Mr Bonnier to counter what he claims is a dirty tricks campaign to discredit himself and his company.

Scoot used the results to announce a strategic agreement with Vizzavi, a joint venture of Vodafone and Vivendi. Scoot will become the preferred directory service of the multi-access portal and work with Vizzavi on technology and product development.

webTitle: Postal votes key to victory

fields.headline: Postal votes key to victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Sixty-seven small piles of uncounted postal ballots sent in by overseas voters from Florida hold the key today to an early resolution of the 10-day-old dispute over the outcome of the US presidential election.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington,  Michael Ellison  in Tallahassee  and Julian Borger  in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
Sixty-seven small piles of uncounted postal ballots sent in by overseas voters from Florida hold the key today to an early resolution of the 10-day-old dispute over the outcome of the US presidential election.

As tonight's midnight deadline neared for the potentially decisive overseas postal votes to be received by election officials in each Florida county, Al Gore and George W Bush continued to battle one another down to the wire in a series of legal confrontations that could keep the White House in play.

Yesterday Mr Gore's lawyers launched an assault on three fronts in their efforts to keep the counting process alive beyond tomorrow, when the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, has said she intends to add the results from the overseas votes to the totals she has already certified and declare what she hopes will be the final outcome of the November 7 election.

Overseas votes have been trickling in to each of Florida's 67 counties since the election. Estimates of the number available for counting after the midnight deadline vary, but most observers think between 2,200 and 3,000 ballot papers are involved - papers which could tip the balance in the contest for Florida's decisive 25 electoral college votes.

"Whatever happens in this court, the ballots cast in Florida will be counted. Historians will count them. Meanwhile, Broward county continued its own recount despite the legal confusion and early figures suggested a very slight tilt towards Mr Gore. However, Republican officials observing the recount claimed they had evidence that some punch card ballots had been altered by vote counters.
