webTitle: Exiles relish their day in the sun

fields.headline: Exiles relish their day in the sun
fields.standfirst:
Ex-pats in UK have vital role in close contest

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ex-pats in UK have vital role in close contest.
fields.body:
As the hours tick away and the midnight deadline for postal votes in the US election approaches, Frances Deak is growing increasingly anxious.

The retired headteacher and "refugee from Reagan" has been bolstering support for Al Gore as the UK voting information officer for Democrats Abroad. Like other Floridians based here, she is all too aware that a few thousand overseas ballots for her state could yet determine the next president.

"I have always felt that every vote makes a difference," she says. "But I've had people tell me they didn't vote because they thought it would be a foregone conclusion - and they're sorry. Some hadn't voted in 50 years because they felt their vote didn't count. Now they know differently.

"A lot of overseas voters get the idea that we don't matter. But there are six million of us now and people are paying attention. Politicians will start wooing us again."

Joseph King, chairman of the British branch of Republicans Abroad, says the 200,000 Americans here are increasingly keen to find out about their electoral rights. And American citizens resident overseas are actually more likely to vote than their counterparts in the US.

Charles Walker, 29, a Democrat from Tallahassee, says the nailbiting election night and subsequent chaos reinforced to young Americans the importance of participation.

"I was raised to vote but I never fully realised how important it is," says the information studies student. "A lot of the issues at stake are very close to my heart."

College-mate Aaron Walker, 21, is also relieved that he posted his vote early. Having worked as a student lobbyist he opted for George W Bush.

"And I'm very relieved I did," says the social science student from Miami. "A result this close makes you realise you matter. I think a lot of my generation will vote in future because of this election. Everyone's talking about it."

webTitle: Moscow to Mir: your orbit is ending

fields.headline: Moscow to Mir: your orbit is ending
fields.standfirst:
Russia aims to ditch 14-year-old space station in south Pacific

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The curtain came down on a proud if chequered era of Russian space exploration yesterday when the government ended weeks of equivocating and ordered the scrapping of the Mir space station.
fields.body:
The curtain came down on a proud if chequered era of Russian space exploration yesterday when the government ended weeks of equivocating and ordered the scrapping of the Mir space station.

The decision, taken at a session of the Russian cabinet which was told the 14-year-old space station could fail at any time, spells the end for another great Soviet icon which in recent years turned into a symbol of Russian decay.

After the cabinet meeting, Yuri Koptev, the head of Russia's space agency, said Mir would be brought down from orbit and sunk in the Pacific up to 1,200 miles (2,000km) off Australia's east coast on February 27-28.

A cargo rocket is expected to reach Mir in January to prepare it for burial at sea.

The prospects of Denis Tito, a Californian rocket scientist and businessman, fulfilling his dream to become the world's first space tourist all but vanished yesterday.

"I don't anticipate I'm going to Mir unless they schedule a final mission," said Mr Tito, who was due to blast off on January 18 for a 10-day visit.

The price of his cosmic round-trip ticket was to be £14m. He has been training for months outside Moscow.

Mr Koptev said the American's chances of reaching Mir were now minimal.

Designed to last three years, Mir has outlived its scheduled life span almost by a factor of five. But a fire on board the station, its involvement in the first space crash, failing steering and computer systems, air and oxygen leaks, and widespread fears that the station could hurtle out of control into Earth have seen its days numbered since 1997.

The Kremlin lacks the funds to keep Mir going, while the Americans and their space agency Nasa have been leaning on Moscow to scrap Mir and redeploy resources to the international space station, the multinational project now taking shape.

"At present, Mir's operation is in such a state that any of its systems could fail at any time," Mr Koptev said, adding that the cargo ship had already been sent to Mir "to ward against a possible fall to earth as early as December".

Since Mir's launch in February 1986, it has added five modules to the base unit and currently weighs more than 130 tonnes.

Most of that will burn up on descent, but debris will also spread across a wide swath of the Pacific as the station breaks up, and fragments could crash on to land.

Anatoly Kiselev, director of the Khrunichev centre that designed the Mir station, said that an area of the Pacific 6,000 miles by 125 miles had been mapped out for Mir's re-entry. There was, however, a small probability that bits of Mir could hit dry land, he said.

"It's practically impossible to guarantee 100% that Mir's descent will occur only in the secure area of the Pacific ocean specified," said Mr Kiselev.

It also was not feasible, he said, to calculate precisely how a 130-tonne spacecraft with huge panels would react when entering Earth's atmosphere.

If yesterday's decision is likely to keep Denis Tito earth-bound, it is also a big setback for the western investors who have been pleading with the Russians to keep Mir in orbit, promising to raise tens of millions of dollars to fund its continued operations.

A Netherlands-based company, MirCorp, had arranged a deal to gain the rights to commercial exploitation of the station. It was the firm that sold Mr Tito his ticket into space and intended to use the station for movie-making and television shows. There was even talk that James Cameron, director of the film Titanic, would buy a trip to Mir.

Other bizarre schemes to keep Mir up included last year's announcement that a British millionaire, Peter Llewellyn, who claimed to have been a bodyguard of the Queen, a secret agent, and a navy officer, was putting up £69m in return for a flight into space. Nothing came of that.

MirCorp put up the money for a repair mission to Mir earlier this year but has been unable to raise more, hastening the decision to bring the station down. A product of the space race and the cold war lost by the Russians, Mir ends its days as a casualty of failed commercial money-spinning schemes to keep it in orbit.

"We have an obligation to ensure the safe flight of the Mir orbital station at its final stage," the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, told a meeting of the cabinet yesterday.

Since June, the station has been unmanned but, in its 14-year life span, it was the site where various space-endurance records were established, and has hosted 62 astronauts from 11 countries other than Russia and has engaged in 23,000 scientific experiments, according to Russian experts.

Mr Tito now hopes to fly to the new international space station (ISS). His contract stipulates that he will go into space by the end of June next year.

"What this means to me is very likely a missed opportunity to visit Mir," he said, "and a possible opportunity to visit the ISS."

webTitle: Kostunica courts Serbia's old foes

fields.headline: Kostunica courts Serbia's old foes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, moved yesterday to restore diplomatic relations with the US, Britain, France and Germany, the countries that spearheaded last year's Nato bombing campaign in Kosovo.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, moved yesterday to restore diplomatic relations with the US, Britain, France and Germany, the countries that spearheaded last year's Nato bombing campaign in Kosovo.

"There is no harder moment for a government than a break up of diplomatic relations," the prime minister, Zoran Zizic, said. "And there is no better moment than establishing them."

In Washington, a national security council spokesman, Daniel Cruise, said: "We look forward to the necessary formalities being completed and relations being formally restored in the coming days."

Reopening ties with Washington is particularly significant because, unlike Britain, France and Germany which re-established limited consular, commercial and cultural functions after the bombing, the US had no diplomatic representation in Belgrade.

The move comes more than a year after former president Slobodan Milosevic cut ties at the start of Nato's 78-day air offensive, launched after Belgrade's crackdown on Kosovo's ethnic Albanians.

Since Mr Milosevic was forced from power after the September 24 election, Yugoslavia has rejoined the UN - after eight years in the wilderness - and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). Mr Kostunica has also attended an EU summit and held talks with several world leaders.

President Bill Clinton's Balkans envoy, James O'Brien, discussed restoring relations during talks in Belgrade on Wednesday. But Mr O'Brien said substantial US aid would only follow if Yugoslavia cooperated with the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

He confirmed that Congress was ready to approve $100m (£69m) for Serbia and $89m (£62m) for Montenegro.

Mr Kostunica has balked at efforts to send Mr Milosevic and a handful of his loyalists to stand trial in the Hague, but said they may face prosecution in Yugoslavia.

Yesterday the Yugoslav foreign minister, Goran Svilanovic, said that his government would allow the tribunal to work in Yugoslavia. He made no mention, however, of any change in Mr Kostunica's position on Mr Milosevic or anyone else wanted by the tribunal.

Britain is providing £11.5m in aid to support the transition to democracy and is a strong advocate of Belgrade's rapid return to world bodies such as the UN. The British trade minister, Richard Caborn, visited the country last week.

Since coming to power, Mr Kostunica has moved quickly to end Belgrade's international isolation. He addressed the European parliament in Strasbourg on Wednesday, clearly stating his wish for Yugoslavia to join the EU.

Last Tuesday, Belgrade hosted a two-day meeting of the stability pact for south-eastern Europe, which also recently opened its doors to Mr Kostunica's administration.

The renewal of diplomatic relations comes as US diplomat Richard Holbrooke hosts a conference of Balkan leaders today in Dayton, Ohio, marking the fifth anniversary of the Dayton peace accords which ended the war in Bosnia.

On the agenda is the next phase of the Dayton agreement, as well as the future status of Kosovo and Montenegro. Nato's secretary general Lord Robertson, Kosovan leaders and Montenego's president, Milo Djukanovic, will attend, but Mr Kostunicais sending his foreign politics adviser, Pavle Jevremovic.

webTitle: Payout to triplet parents in landmark IVF case

fields.headline: Payout to triplet parents in landmark IVF case
fields.trailText: A couple who had triplets after fertility treatment won an unprecedented compensation claim yesterday against the clinic which gave them three babies instead of the hoped-for one or two.
fields.body:
A couple who had triplets after fertility treatment won an unprecedented compensation claim yesterday against the clinic which gave them three babies instead of the hoped-for one or two.

Patricia and Peter Thompson sued the Sheffield fertility centre for breach of contract after the triplets, two boys and a girl, were born through in vitro fertilisation in March 1997.

The exhausting task of looking after three babies forced the couple, from Thrybergh, south Yorkshire, to give up the family news agency business and put a huge strain on their resources, they told the high court in Sheffield.

The couple signed an agreement at their initial consultation in 1996 that two embyros would be implanted. But the clinic told the court that Mrs Thompson had later agreed verbally with the doctor performing the procedure that three should be inserted to give a better chance of success.

Mr Justice Hooper accepted the Thompsons' evidence and ruled that the fertility clinic had breached its contract with the couple. "For reasons that I shall give later, the claimant has shown on the balance of probabilities that she did not agree to the replacement of three embryos," he said.

The Thompsons, who are on legal aid, were claiming compensation for lost earnings and the cost of raising the third child. They were able to sue for breach of contract because they paid for their IVF treatment, which cost them £1,600. Had they been treated on the NHS, that option would not have been open to them.

The law lords ruled last year that parents who have an unwanted child as a result of medical negligence cannot claim the cost of bringing up the child. But they left open the possibility that this might not apply in a breach of contract case. The amount of compensation will be decided at a later hearing.

The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority is concerned about the increase in multiple births through fertility treatment, because twins and triplets are more likely to be born prematurely.

"The guidance is to take all possible steps to minimise the risk of multiple pregnancies," said Jane Denton of the Multiple Births Society. "The key thing is that it is discussed fully with the parents."

Mrs Thompson said the paediatrician looking after the newborn triplets said: "This should not have happened."

The IVF expert Lord Winston said: "This is not a criticism of the Sheffield unit, but our policy for the last 14 years has been to transfer only two embryos at the Hammersmith. But we are unusual. Most clinics don't agree with such a rigid policy. It does mean we have a lower success rate."

Mr Thompson, 57, has three grown-up children from a previous marriage. He and his wife, now 34, tried IVF after attempting unsuccessfully for five years to have a child.

Mrs Thompson said she learned that three embryos had been implanted only after the 10-minute procedure.

She said: "I think two is more than enough for anyone to have, I just wanted two babies or a baby." In 1998, she unexpectedly conceived a fourth baby, a daughter, naturally.

She said: "I am delighted with our children, who are fit and healthy, but the effort of looking after three children rather than the maximum of two that we had planned is absolutely exhausting and stretches our physical resources."

webTitle: Clinton starts Vietnam trip

fields.headline: Clinton starts Vietnam trip
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton last night crossed the final frontier of both his presidency and the US psyche when he landed in the Vietnamese capital Hanoi, a city still regarded by many back home as enemy territory. As a symbolic gesture it was the most potent visit by a US president since Richard Nixon went to China in 1972.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton last night crossed the final frontier of both his presidency and the US psyche when he landed in the Vietnamese capital Hanoi, a city still regarded by many back home as enemy territory. As a symbolic gesture it was the most potent visit by a US president since Richard Nixon went to China in 1972.

While his putative successors scrapped ignominiously over events in Florida, Mr Clinton was able to play not merely world statesman but historic peacemaker.

Although Vietnam goes to bed early and the presidential plane arrived late, at least 30,000 midnight gawpers lined the streets between the airport and the presidential hotel to greet Mr Clinton.

Most were teenagers, not yet born when US bombers regularly attacked the city. They seemed enthusiastic but might have been as welcoming to anyone else: entertainment is thin here, and the last high-profile westerner to come to Hanoi was Jane Fonda, during her anti-war phase.

For Mr Clinton, this is the culmination of his eight-year strategy to ensure that Vietnam is regarded as a country as well as a war. If he succeeds, he may yet try to visit North Korea before he leaves office on January 20.

But the visit's success is not assured. Vietnam's communist leadership has been making a half-hearted attempt to give this event no more official build-up than they would give a fraternal visit from the presidents of Laos or Belarus.

However, some of the deep red banners strewn across the streets have had their messages changed. Quotes from Vietnam's founding father, Ho Chi Minh, such as "Unity, Unity, Unity - success, success, success" have been replaced by signs welcoming "Uy-liam gio'pheson Clinton and spouse".

However, like China, it is now committed to what might be called "commie-talism". If the president tries a walkabout in Hanoi today, he might have to do so in the gutter because the streets are full of mad motorbikers and the pavements are piled high with western consumer goods sold from thousands of tiny shops.

After the huge Soviet subsidies vanished in the late 80s, leaving the prospect of ideological purity coupled with starvation, the Vietnamese government and people reached a tacit understanding. Politics, it is understood, is left to the apparatchiks; in return the party will let everyone make some money. Closer ties with the Americans are crucial to that process.

The reaction to Mr Clinton's visit has been almost unanimously favourable. The only apparent dissident has been a 100-year-old rural matriarch interviewed by the BBC. Having lost several children in the war she damned the Americans wholesale and was deemed beyond correction by despairing party officials. Some slightly younger party hardliners are thought to share her views privately.

In essence, most Vietnamese have moved on. Lieutenant-General Vu Xuan Vinh, who commanded the anti-aircraft batteries on the Ho Chi Minh trail, now regularly meets his former enemies.

"In the heart there is still something we dislike," he said, "but in the mind we know we have to look into the future."

He has to make his points about human rights forcefully, but not too forcefully. He has to appease the Vietnamese over the use of toxic defoliants in the war, without acceding to every unproven allegation.

webTitle: Rogers voices anger at city plan

fields.headline: Rogers voices anger at city plan
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: New Labour's favourite architect yesterday delivered a biting critique of the government's urban policy shortly after John Prescott unveiled a long-awaited white paper to revive towns and cities.
fields.body:
New Labour's favourite architect yesterday delivered a biting critique of the government's urban policy shortly after John Prescott unveiled a long-awaited white paper to revive towns and cities.

Lord Rogers of Riverside, who led a government task force on urban renaissance, told the deputy prime minister that crucial ingredients from his group's recommendations had been overlooked.

The architect's principal concern was that what he called "vast areas of rural land" earmarked for housing should be brought out of the planning system.

He also felt that legislation was necessary, through an urban renaissance bill, to underpin the white paper - mainly to give a series of proposed regeneration companies extra clout in assembling land and compulsorily acquiring it.

Yesterday's 160-page document included £1bn worth of national tax measures to increase investment in urban areas and an exemption from stamp duty for all property deals in rundown areas.

Lord Rogers welcomed many aspects of the paper, but said: "I remain deeply disappointed by the failure to equalise VAT between old homes and new. We must create a level playing field to both promote urban regeneration and protect the countryside."

webTitle: £5m bill to damp down bridge's bounce

fields.headline: £5m bill to damp down bridge's bounce
fields.trailText: At a cost of £5m, London's bouncing bridge will bounce no more, and should reopen to pedestrians in six months time.
fields.body:
At a cost of £5m, London's bouncing bridge will bounce no more, and should reopen to pedestrians in six months time.

The "Blade of Light", a supremely elegant £18.2m footbridge linking the City of London with Tate Modern on the South Bank, became a victim of its own success in three days last June that shook the designers.

The bridge, a joint design by architect Lord Foster, Arup engineering, and sculptor Sir Anthony Caro, originally sketched on a paper napkin in a London wine bar, has been a beautiful dead end for the past five months.

In its opening weekend access to the bridge was first controlled by security guards and then, as alarmed crowds reported its bouncing, lurching movement, and thrill seekers flocked to experience it themselves, it was closed completely.

It was expected to carry 4m pedestrians a year. Estimates swung as violently as the bridge, but somewhere between 100,000 and 500,000 people crossed that first weekend.

Yesterday David Bell, chairman of the Millennium Bridge Trust, announced that Arup believes it has a solution, using two types of dampers to stop the bridge swaying. The dampers will be tested on the bridge for six weeks - Arup will bear the £250,000 bill - and if they are successful full work will begin.

The tests will use both viscous and tuned mass dampers. A plucked guitar string can be prevented from vibrating by placing a finger on the middle. A car journey along a bumpy road can be made smooth by fitting better shock absorbers. In crude terms, these are the two methods the engineers plan to use.

The bridge was not quite finished in time for its royal opening in May: the Queen and the new mayor of London walked halfway across the river and back again, without a falter.

The problems became unforgettably visible after the public opening on June 10. Television cameras recorded surreal scenes - pored over frame by frame by the engineers - of hordes of people waddling like ducks, teetering from side to side, clutching at one another or at the rails for support. Initial suggestions that mass hysteria was to blame proved wide of the mark. Assurances that the bridge was perfectly safe and was designed to withstand an earthquake reassured nobody.

Tony Fitzpatrick, one of the main Arup engineers on the project, who spent most of 24 hours on the bridge watching a design triumph turn into farce, memorably analysed the problem as "unintentional synchronised walking". Human beings, precariously balanced on two legs, are remarkably sensitive to tiny lateral movements. When people felt it they instinctively fell into step, and adopted a curious bow legged gait, like cowboys in a Western movie.

The problem for the engineers was to design a solution which would not destroy the beauty of the bridge, which was based on Lord Foster's childhood memories of the futuristic world of comic book hero Dan Dare. They rejected adding new struts or placing obstructions to change the way people walked across.

Arup's final solution is to damp down the vibration. A viscous damper, as its name implies, is like a piston filled with viscous oil. Any bounce is slowed down and smoothed out as the piston is braked by the oil. A tuned mass damper is a mass of material fitted with stiff springs "tuned" to the vibration frequency of the bridge. The bridge vibrations are soaked up by the mass.

Tuned mass dampers are often used to stop tall buildings or chimneys swaying dangerously.

The Millennium Bridge Trust said yesterday: "Everyone involved with the bridge is committed to a permanent opening at the earliest possible date" - but wisely declined to set that date.

Foster & Partners, Millennium Bridge architects

webTitle: Beware of the capital ideas

fields.headline: Beware of the capital ideas
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian
fields.trailText: John Prescott paid a welcome visit to the House of Commons yesterday to launch his department's new white paper, Our Towns And Cities: The Future.
fields.body:
John Prescott paid a welcome visit to the House of Commons yesterday to launch his department's new white paper, Our Towns And Cities: The Future.

This is a classic New Labour document, being printed on glossy paper and illustrated with colour pictures of the Elysium which is the new Britain. Happy people, many from ethnic minorities, gaze productively at computer screens. Pensioners get off a gleaming streamlined tram which has just delivered them promptly and inexpensively to their grandchildren.

In New Labour's dream world, canals are for strolling by, past bustling pavement cafes where laughing groups of people drink cappuccino in the sun. And they're definitely not full of dead cats, condoms or rusted supermarket trollies.

The prose has the same unreal quality. Nothing actually happens, nothing tangible is planned. But, we are promised, there will be "innovative developments", "local strategic partnerships" and "urban policy units".

Town councils will have "new powers to promote wellbeing". As members of society, people will need to be able "to achieve their full potential" while "protecting the environment, both local and global." To make sure this happens, the government's "policies and programmes are the building blocks," and just in case we might think this may never happen, we're promised that "visions for the future will be developed".

There will be a "key focus" here and a "coordinated effort" there. The government, in its wisdom, has "established a framework". The whole thing resembles those fantastical architect's drawings, in which slim, well-dressed figures stroll across tree-festooned piazzas, with no mention of empty burger boxes or gangs of glowering youths.

But Mr Prescott's statement, far from being the jumble of words we have come to expect, was an oral version of the same thing. I have noticed that the time to become suspicious about this government is when it breaks into capital letters. This invariably represents not the real world, but some new initiative, programme or quango.

He is setting up Regional Centres of Excellence. He has established a Neighbourhood Renewal Fund. He is considering an Urban Policy Board, and a Cabinet Committee is to hold an Urban Summit in the year 2002. Let's not forget the Integrated Transport White Paper, the New Deal for Communities and the Social Exclusion Unit. Capital letters were all over the shop, each in charge of a resonant abstraction.

We hacks were abjured yesterday by Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary to mark the difference between scepticism and cynicism. My attitude to Mr Prescott's statement was a balanced mixture of both.

At one point, for example, he reminded us that Lord Rogers had said, "people make cities, but cities make citizens". Tories giggled at this, crying "wozzat mean?"

"Think about it!" he bellowed back, though I'm afraid I was none the wiser. You could say, "people make cars, but cars make drivers", or "people make alcohol, but alcohol makes alcoholics".

This kind of talk spreads among the very people who use it. Mr Prescott got confused about the technical terms for a city. "The city of York already is a city, as is my own city of Hull is a city, and that I think is the definition of city and town."

Faced with these massive piles of abstract thought, there was little the Tory spokesman, Archie Norman could say or do. "The only time we ever see the deputy prime minister," he grumped, "is when he has a glossy brochure or a disaster to announce."

Or, I reflected yesterday, possibly both at the same time.

webTitle: Shane Watson on a girl's best friends

fields.headline: A support system you can rely on
fields.standfirst: On a girl's best friends
fields.trailText: This has been Paula Yates memorial month: the results of the autopsy came through last week, Channel 4 screened its documentary, The Real Paula Yates, and this week Hello! carries a Paula special. It has given us all another chance to reflect on the awesome power of heroin and if, like me, you sometimes wondered who her friends were and if they were looking out for her, your question has finally been answered.
fields.body:
This has been Paula Yates memorial month: the results of the autopsy came through last week, Channel 4 screened its documentary, The Real Paula Yates, and this week Hello! carries a Paula special. It has given us all another chance to reflect on the awesome power of heroin and if, like me, you sometimes wondered who her friends were and if they were looking out for her, your question has finally been answered.

In the same way that thirtysomething women took Princess Diana's death especially to heart, Paula's plight pressed all those single householder panic buttons: the fear (as identified by Bridget Jones) of lying dead in your flat for weeks being eaten slowly by the dog; the anxiety that, should your life fall apart, no one will notice.

We all have those moments when we lie in bed ticking off the friends we would want to be stuck with in the event of disaster, the ones who could turn out to be the stuff human bridges are made of. But for the single female, the question Are my Friends Good Enough? is not just an occasional brain teaser but a crucial practical concern. Have you got enough of the right ones to see you through, just in case? When you were picking, did you err too much on the side of fun and glamour (probably, you were young! How could you know you might need some sturdy ones capable of lowering you into the bath in old age?) Without the right friends, who is to say? A couple of knocks, a few too many good-time girls in your line-up, and you might end up like Paula, is what you think.

Friendships generally shift and alter with the stages of life. In your teens you want friends with energy, beautiful brothers and parents who let you smoke. In your 20s you like a cross-section ranging from severe body abusers to Mrs Beatons. And then, when people start pairing off and having children, the friendship road forks: those who are attached with offspring lose all powers of discrimination and cluster together with whoever has a two-year-old and lives nearby and the single girl has to start managing her friendships like a small business - balancing investment with high-risk ventures. Becoming an adult is about accepting that your friendships will be compromised by time, geography and sloth (not to mention them pairing up with someone that makes you want to sob out loud). For single females it's the same, only the impact is greater.

As it happens, Yates's three best friends all featured in the television documentary which gave us the chance to judge for ourselves if she had been well served. And blow me down if she didn't have her single girl's friendship network perfectly mapped out.

First there was the Roadie figure (Belinda Brewin, who accompanied her to Hutchence's funeral). Crucially, the Roadie must be unattached, available 24/7 and hard living - reassuring the single girl that she is not a freak of nature.

Then there was the Geisha, one Catherine Mayer. Geishas are the opposite ideal of their single friends - they usually look dramatically different (see Mariella Frostrup's friendship with "Black Eyes" Gina Bellman) and the single woman is slightly in awe of them. The Geisha's role is to inspire, leaving the day-to-day proceedings to the Roadie and the Nanny. Nanny is the maternal figure, cosy, conservative by comparison with her single charge and responsible for providing practical support.

Paula's Nanny was Josephine Fairley (Hello!'s source), who found her dead when she popped round to remind her it was her daughter's birthday. When the single woman has a crisis the Roadie matches her drink for drink, the Geisha dispenses wise words and the Nanny mops up the spills and waits to drive them all home. It's a common system, though not all of us have the full three back-ups, all of the time.

In fact, seeing Paula's friends, observing their level of devotion to duty, was enough to put the wind up the average single woman. Up until this point it's been assumed that the Roadie, Geisha, Nanny combo was a guaranteed safety net and yet Paula had the deluxe version. What if you've only got a clutch of regular Roadies, a reluctant Geisha and no Nanny? What if your friends never remember your birthday, let alone have keys to your house, as Paula's did? If Paula's friends (specifically the Nanny) are at a loose end, could they please get in touch.

What if you've only got a clutch of regular Roadies, a reluctant Geisha and no Nanny? What if your friends never remember your birthday, let alone have keys to your house, as Paula's did? If Paula's friends (specifically the Nanny) are at a loose end, could they please get in touch.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Wainewright The Poisoner | The Atomic Mr Basie
fields.body:
Peter Straughan's play Wainewright The Poisoner (9pm, Radio 4) was inspired by the poet laureate's biography of the 19th-century forger and judicial exile. Andrew Motion decked out his research with fictional speculation about the little-known life of this artist and man-about-town. Straughan's play, with Nigel Hawthorne in the main role, combines poetry, prose, fact and fancy to portray the plausible villain who apparently murdered any relation who came between him and his grandfather's legacy.

Malcolm Laycock launches a six-part series about William "Count" Basie, probably more influential than any other musician of the swing era. The handiest opportunity for The Atomic Mr Basie (10pm, Radio 2) came after the band employing the young pianist went bankrupt in Kansas City in the mid-20s. He was stranded, but the city's Democratic politicians were doing well out of Prohibition. They were happy to offer young Basie well-paid jobs in their brothels and speakeasies.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Prick up your ears
fields.trailText: Horizon: The Valley Of Life Or Death | Britain At War In Colour
fields.body:
Racing across Chicago with a foreskin in a coolbox (as opposed to attached to his person) is part of Bruce Patterson's job. He has to scoot from one side of the city to the other in under 45 minutes, the digital clock in his car marking time in glowing green bars, to ensure that the foreskin is still alive when it reaches its destination. Patterson is not, as you might think, a delivery driver for a pizza firm for cannibals ("So that's a medium four cheeses, with foreskins, spleen and extra tongue. It'll be with you in 45 minutes, or it's free"). Rather, he's a doctor whose efforts in ferrying foreskin may determine the fate of millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa.

Horizon: The Valley Of Life Or Death (BBC2) explored the notion that circumcised men were less likely to contract HIV than uncircumcised men. With an impressive array of contributors - from anthropologists and scientists to people with HIV - it managed to convey a frightening amount of scientific information without being overwhelming. And, more importantly, without too many shots of flashing blades and bleeding penises. Apparently, it's all to do with keratin (and you thought that was something only found in shampoos formulated and controlled by Laboratoires Garnier) and the layer it forms on most of the body's skin to protect it from micro-organisms. The foreskin doesn't have much keratin, so HIV can slip into the body much more easily. With circumcision doing away with a foreskin, HIV has a tougher time. Dr Barry Patterson was just one link in a worldwide chain of boffins seeking to establish such a thesis, and his foreskin exploits provided it with considerable support. Yet despite the melodramatic narration ("For the first time, HIV is being dripped onto a living foreskin!"), the actual moment of truth wasn't all that exciting. Especially as the foreskin in question was grey, like a bit of putty, leading one to speculate on the colour of the penis to which it was attached.

But for someone not particularly interested in science, Horizon was nonetheless intriguing stuff, and a persuasive demonstration of the scientists' and anthropologists' theory. It also gave the views of tribal elders - whose traditions precluded circumcision - a fair hearing. And there were people to despair of as well - members of an anti-circumcision group called NOCIRC. As well as thinking up a super-imaginative name for their organisation, they said dumb things, like the fact that a programme promoting circumcision was "a scientifically sanctioned holocaust against African males". They never explained exactly how it was a holocaust, but given that they probably think Barbie's supremacy over Sindy is akin to Stalin's triumph over Trotsky, that was probably for the best. All in, The Valley Of Life Or Death was a surprisingly accessible and seriously interesting documentary which showed a pinprick of hope in a hopeless world.

Next time you find yourself fuming silently at the old dear in front of you in the supermarket queue because she's taking an age finding her purse, or cursing the old codger who took the last seat on the bus, consider that he or she may have been a contributor to Britain At War In Colour (ITV). Ken, for example, survived the invasion of Sicily, saw his friends and comrades blown to smithereens, went on to fight at D-Day and hasn't lost his mind. Then there was Hugh, a most collected and beneficent man, who calmly stated that war turned people into beasts so they could fight, before detailing his own atavistic fall. Gywneth, meanwhile, explained how, as nurses, she and her colleagues were offered the chance to escape London in 1939 - but only two did; the others preferring to stay and help, despite the risks.

While we, as a society, don't like old people much, Britain At War In Colour was a reminder that they do deserve respect, honour and not an inconsiderable amount of admiration. The tales they tell may be rarely heard today, but they have never been more precious. Once the likes of Ken, Hugh and Gywneth die, along with all the other heroes across the country who sit on cheap sofas and watch Countdown, the rest of us will have lost something. We'll have missed opportunities to hear wonderful, poignant and heart-rending stories, and will only have ourselves to blame. So next time, behave yourselves in front of your elders and betters.

webTitle: What the PlayStation 2 ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the PlayStation 2 ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the PlayStation 2 ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: Shot in black and white, it features a nervous-looking, besuited man walking through the corridors of a strange interior. Firstly the walls seem to breathe fire, then he's beckoned towards a girl who's floating in outer space, and later he's assaulted by an object which appears out of his mouth as a human arm. The man follows the arm through a cloud of smoke and enters a room where he sees his own doppelgänger, a bloke bandaged from head to foot, and a duck in a suit. "Welcome to The Third Place," says the duck.

The jargon: PlayStation fans will no doubt know that the long-awaited PS2 unit goes on sale on November 24. This very odd commercial is promoting the launch of the console, but given that unless you've pre-ordered it already you probably won't get one before Christmas, it's also a brand-building exercise to position The Third Place as a PlayStation invention - somewhere you go to be creative and break the rules.

Personality: You're strictly 18-28 years old, and probably male. You're also very possibly a fan of David Lynch, the eccentric Hollywood director who filmed the ad.

Financial status: The unit is going to retail at £299 in the UK, which isn't exactly a snip, but it's the sort of amount that teenagers and first-jobbers are prepared to spend their meagre salaries on to keep up with the very latest gaming trend.

Telling lifestyle detail: You're not a geeky techno freak - you probably go clubbing and to the cinema, and possibly don't even play computer games that much. PS2 is about entertainment in the widest sense, says agency TBWA.

Other relevant data: When Lynch saw the script, he loved it, saying "I've been living in The Third Place for years and I understand what's going on." In fact, Lynch entered into the spirit to such an extent that it's him doing the duck's voiceover at the end.

webTitle: South Africa's top crimebuster charged

fields.headline: South Africa's top crimebuster charged
fields.trailText: The senior anti-corruption official in South Africa, who is investigating accusations of irregularities involving British weapons firms and has come close to bringing down at least one cabinet minister, has been charged with assault after allegedly attacking a woman in a Durban hotel room.
fields.body:
The senior anti-corruption official in South Africa, who is investigating accusations of irregularities involving British weapons firms and has come close to bringing down at least one cabinet minister, has been charged with assault after allegedly attacking a woman in a Durban hotel room.

Selby Baqwa, the public protector responsible for pursuing officials accused of graft or other abuses of power, has denied the accusation. Details of the charge laid by Dolly Mkuhisi have not been made public but hotel staff say security men were called after a disturbance in Mr Baqwa's room.

Ms Mkuhisi says the attack occurred while Mr Baqwa was attending an international ombudsman conference on October 30 this year. If the charge sticks, it will be a further blow to the government's efforts to clean up corruption and South Africa's image.

Several investigations have been launched into high level graft, abuse of power and other scandals such as the fixing of cricket matches by sportsman Hansie Cronje.

Mr Baqwa's spokeswoman, Nicolette Teichmann, implied that the public protector was the target of a smear campaign. "He is painfully aware of his responsibility both in public and in private. It is not unusual for people to sling mud at a person in his position."

Mr Baqwa is responsible for a number of inquiries, including the one into a £3bn weapons deal with British and other foreign arms manufacturers. The transactions resulted in allegations of kickbacks, nepotism and other irregularities.

The public protector has also caused the government embarrassment with an investigation of the justice minister, Penuell Maduna, who falsely accused the country's auditor-general of covering up millions of pounds of losses in a state fuel company.

Mr Baqwa found that Mr Maduna had breached two clauses of the constitution. He recommended that parliament punish him, but it has yet to act and President Thabo Mbeki has said Mr Maduna is safe in his job.

The case went some way toward diffusing criticism that Mr Baqwa was soft on the African National Congress (ANC) government while insisting that white policeman still wedded to the apartheid philosophy should be sacked.

The public protector has also spoken out against "worrying" levels of corruption, implicitly criticising the government.

An ANC spokesman said the state was obliged to pursue the Baqwa case if there was evidence: "The public protector is not above the law."

webTitle: Hero's welcome for freed star

fields.headline: Hero's welcome for freed star
fields.standfirst: Ecstatic crowds greet Indian film idol Rajkumar, released after three months as prisoner of bandit gang
fields.trailText: Looking remarkably cheerful and fit, Indian matinee idol Rajkumar returned yesterday from more than three months of captivity in the jungle to an ecstatic welcome in his home city of Bangalore - and described how at one point he told his captor: "Shoot me down."
fields.body:
Looking remarkably cheerful and fit, Indian matinee idol Rajkumar returned yesterday from more than three months of captivity in the jungle to an ecstatic welcome in his home city of Bangalore - and described how at one point he told his captor: "Shoot me down."

Rajkumar, 73, was seized with three others by the so-called bandit king Veerappan from a remote farmhouse in the southern state of Tamil Nadu on July 30. One of the four escaped in September while another, the actor's son-in-law, was freed last month due to poor health. Rajkumar and the other remaining hostage, also a relative, were released late on Tuesday night.

The actor said his time in the forest became a "terrifying experience" after the September escape.

"We didn't know what the consequences would be. We feared Veerappan might shoot us. After the escape he tied us up and handcuffed us."

"I said to Veerappan: 'Why are you doing this? Release the other guys. They are just youngsters. My life is over. I am old.' I said: 'Shoot me if you want. Shoot me down.' Veerappan considered for a moment what to do. Then he removed the handcuffs."

Rajkumar also revealed that two weeks before his release he was visited in the jungle by a doctor, who helped secure his freedom.

"She gave me a medical check-up and then quietly told me to play sick. She told Veerappan I had a heart problem and a low pulse rate. She persuaded him it would be counter-productive to hold me longer because my condition might get worse."

Asked whether his release might also have had something to do with a ransom, Rajkumar yesterday merely shrugged his shoulders and smiled. "I know my story," he said.

Officials privately confirmed that a large sum had been given to the bandit - reports say it was at least £2m. The money is said to have been paid gradually, starting soon after the abduction.

During his time in captivity, Rajkumar said he moved camp 60 or 70 times. "You get to see elephants. There are no villages or people around. My only companions were Veerappan and his associates.

"Whenever I thought about my family it was a painful experience. Most of the time I felt like crying because it was a helpless situation. I'm surprised and happy to be here," he added.

The star's return prompted frenzy in Bangalore yesterday. Fans waiting for his helicopter were unable to contain themselves and invaded the airport where members of his family were waiting to greet him.

Once back, Rajkumar addressed thousands of supporters from the steps of the state's assembly building. Cars, auto-rickshaws, and bicycles in the city flew yellow and red flags - the state colours - with Rajkumar's face in the middle. Outside his house there was mayhem.

Meanwhile, India's bruised political class was pondering what lessons could be learned from the debacle. The crisis paralysed the two state governments involved, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.

Sources said that a commando operation was now being planned to try to capture Veerappan. But the chances of success are not good. In 1990 a big military taskforce tried to catch the bandit, only for him to get away.

"He just retires and retires further into the forest. If we take an army to go and find him, we have to resupply it every 15 or 20 days with food, water and so on. He can just move around quickly," one top-ranking Bangalore police officer said last night. "It is going to take a long time before we can catch him."

webTitle: The old man of the sea

fields.headline: The old man of the sea
fields.standfirst: There are very few of them. But at least one bowhead whale was young when Napoleon bestrode the world. It sang its songs when Beethoven was alive. Britten and the Beatles came and went before it died
fields.trailText: There are very few of them. But at least one bowhead whale was young when Napoleon bestrode the world. It sang its songs when Beethoven was alive. Britten and the Beatles came and went before it died.
fields.body:
It was a bowhead whale, and it might still be alive today if it hadn't been for a hunter's harpoon. As it is, scientists believe it lived for 211 years - by far the oldest mammal, and perhaps the oldest animal, ever discovered.

The extraordinary truth was discovered when the eyes of the ancient whale, one of four dozen of the huge creatures whose remains were frozen after being killed between 1978 and 1996, were sent for analysis by Craig George, a researcher at Alaska's North Slope borough department of wildlife management.

Mr George already suspected that bowhead whales could live to be more than two centuries old. Present-day native Inupiat whalers had found stone and ivory harpoon heads from their 19th or 18th century ancestors embedded in the blubber of bowheads they had killed.

The breakthrough, reported in the latest edition of New Scientist magazine, came when a biochemist in San Diego, Jeff Bada, discovered a method of working out the age of marine mammals by analysing the decay of proteins in the onion-like layers of the spherical lenses of their eyes.

When Professor Bada and another scientist in Seattle, Judy Zeh of the University of Washington, used the new technique to find out how old the frozen whales were when they were killed, they found four males which were aged over 100 and one which was 211 years old.

The technique has a margin of error of 25 years. But even if the oldest whale was 186, it would still make it the world's longest-lived mammal species, far older than the previous champions, humankind.

The discovery raises troubling issues about the bowhead's vulnerability to extinction.

It also provokes profound questions about the nature of ageing in all mammals, a mysterious field beginning to attract increasing attention.

Most biologists do not believe wild animals grow old - old age is a phenomenon only seen in protected species such as humans or pet animals.

The key to how long an animal lives in the wild is how early it has to breed before something - a predator, disease, cold or famine - kills it.

Evolution

Animals like mice have evolved a live fast, die young approach. They eat a lot, have sex a lot, have lots of children and have extremely fast heartbeats because 90% of them die in their first year. Nature never needs to worry about designing them to cope with ageing.

In the wild, human beings were likely to die in their 30s, after they had reproduced. Nature never invested in repair mechanisms for the 40-plus age group because it wasn't worth it - as far as evolution is concerned, the sabre-toothed tiger should have got us by then. That's why we get old rather than just living longer.

But before human hunters came along, bowhead whales seem to have evolved in a world with remarkably few threats. At 80 tonnes, and growing up to 60ft long, they can stand up to any predators in their native waters between Alaska and north-east Russia.

They seem to suffer little from disease or parasites. They are so resistant to cold that it is estimated they could stay warm swimming in liquid oxygen. And they take life very slow and easy, meaning they burn less energy, thought to be the process which causes us to age. They sleep a lot, grow slowly, never travel faster than four miles an hour, and have calves only once every four years.

Wisdom

Over their centuries of life, the bowheads may even acquire wisdom. They move and hunt in groups, singing out warnings about pack ice to each other.

"The older guys are not only bigger, but wiser," Charles Krebs, a Vancouver population ecologist, told the New Scientist. "They know where to look for food and how to avoid predators."

It is a strategy that served the bowhead well until man came along. There are concerns that the bowhead's long, slow, low-birthrate lifestyle make them exceptionally vulnerable to the loss of even a few animals each year.

There were thought to be about 65,000 bowheads before industrial-scale whaling almost rendered them extinct. The end of the mass whaling era has brought a slow recovery in their numbers in the western Arctic, where the 8,000-strong population is growing at about 3% a year, but they still look vulnerable in the east, where the 500 or so survivors are still subject to legal hunting by native peoples.

Wild

If bowhead whales can live to be 200-plus in the wild, it raises the question of how long they would live if they led the kind of sheltered existence experienced by humans or zoo animals. Humans in the west now expect to live twice as long, on average, as their wild ancestors, and in extreme cases we will live to be four times as old.

The oldest known elephant lived to be 81 years old; horses have been said to live to be 60, and crocodiles and spiny anteaters have been reported as living to be over 50.

Ageing researchers distinguish between "lifespan", the time from birth to death, and "healthspan", the period of life when an animal is fully fit. Usually, for humans in the west, lifespan is longer than healthspan, but there is no suggestion that the oldest bowhead whales have the equivalent of wrinkles, Alzheimer's or arthritis.

No one has ever found a bowhead whale which died of old age. How old would they be if they reached that point?

Mr George responded: "I think we're going to see bowheads out there on the edge."

Slow progress: Tortoise is 170

Harriet the giant tortoise celebrated her 170th birthday this week. Harriet was one of three giant tortoises which Darwin imported to Britain from the Galapagos Islands in 1835. He estimated that she was born in around 1830, when William IV ascended the throne and Stephenson's Rocket first began to pull passenger trains.

But her professional career as specimen was short-lived. Once Darwin had finished studying her, he packed her off on a convict ship; by the age of 12 she was enjoying early retirement in the Australian sunshine.

As all 400lb of her testify, the emigrant thrived in her new home in the Antipodes. But it was only in the 1960s that a sharp-eyed keeper spotted something even Darwin had missed. Harriet, previously identified as a male called Harry, was undeniably female.
fields.bodyText: It was a bowhead whale, and it might still be alive today if it hadn't been for a hunter's harpoon. As it is, scientists believe it lived for 211 years - by far the oldest mammal, and perhaps the oldest animal, ever discovered. The extraordinary truth was discovered when the eyes of the ancient whale, one of four dozen of the huge creatures whose remains were frozen after being killed between 1978 and 1996, were sent for analysis by Craig George, a researcher at Alaska's North Slope borough department of wildlife management. Mr George already suspected that bowhead whales could live to be more than two centuries old. Present-day native Inupiat whalers had found stone and ivory harpoon heads from their 19th or 18th century ancestors embedded in the blubber of bowheads they had killed. The breakthrough, reported in the latest edition of New Scientist magazine, came when a biochemist in San Diego, Jeff Bada, discovered a method of working out the age of marine mammals by analysing the decay of proteins in the onion-like layers of the spherical lenses of their eyes. When Professor Bada and another scientist in Seattle, Judy Zeh of the University of Washington, used the new technique to find out how old the frozen whales were when they were killed, they found four males which were aged over 100 and one which was 211 years old. The technique has a margin of error of 25 years. But even if the oldest whale was 186, it would still make it the world's longest-lived mammal species, far older than the previous champions, humankind. The discovery raises troubling issues about the bowhead's vulnerability to extinction. It also provokes profound questions about the nature of ageing in all mammals, a mysterious field beginning to attract increasing attention. Most biologists do not believe wild animals grow old - old age is a phenomenon only seen in protected species such as humans or pet animals. The key to how long an animal lives in the wild is how early it has to breed before something - a predator, disease, cold or famine - kills it. Evolution Animals like mice have evolved a live fast, die young approach. They eat a lot, have sex a lot, have lots of children and have extremely fast heartbeats because 90% of them die in their first year. Nature never needs to worry about designing them to cope with ageing. In the wild, human beings were likely to die in their 30s, after they had reproduced. Nature never invested in repair mechanisms for the 40-plus age group because it wasn't worth it - as far as evolution is concerned, the sabre-toothed tiger should have got us by then. That's why we get old rather than just living longer. But before human hunters came along, bowhead whales seem to have evolved in a world with remarkably few threats. At 80 tonnes, and growing up to 60ft long, they can stand up to any predators in their native waters between Alaska and north-east Russia. They seem to suffer little from disease or parasites. They are so resistant to cold that it is estimated they could stay warm swimming in liquid oxygen. And they take life very slow and easy, meaning they burn less energy, thought to be the process which causes us to age. They sleep a lot, grow slowly, never travel faster than four miles an hour, and have calves only once every four years. Wisdom Over their centuries of life, the bowheads may even acquire wisdom. They move and hunt in groups, singing out warnings about pack ice to each other. "The older guys are not only bigger, but wiser," Charles Krebs, a Vancouver population ecologist, told the New Scientist. "They know where to look for food and how to avoid predators." It is a strategy that served the bowhead well until man came along. There are concerns that the bowhead's long, slow, low-birthrate lifestyle make them exceptionally vulnerable to the loss of even a few animals each year. There were thought to be about 65,000 bowheads before industrial-scale whaling almost rendered them extinct. The end of the mass whaling era has brought a slow recovery in their numbers in the western Arctic, where the 8,000-strong population is growing at about 3% a year, but they still look vulnerable in the east, where the 500 or so survivors are still subject to legal hunting by native peoples. Wild If bowhead whales can live to be 200-plus in the wild, it raises the question of how long they would live if they led the kind of sheltered existence experienced by humans or zoo animals. Humans in the west now expect to live twice as long, on average, as their wild ancestors, and in extreme cases we will live to be four times as old. The oldest known elephant lived to be 81 years old; horses have been said to live to be 60, and crocodiles and spiny anteaters have been reported as living to be over 50. Ageing researchers distinguish between "lifespan", the time from birth to death, and "healthspan", the period of life when an animal is fully fit. Usually, for humans in the west, lifespan is longer than healthspan, but there is no suggestion that the oldest bowhead whales have the equivalent of wrinkles, Alzheimer's or arthritis. No one has ever found a bowhead whale which died of old age. How old would they be if they reached that point? Mr George responded: "I think we're going to see bowheads out there on the edge." Slow progress: Tortoise is 170 Harriet the giant tortoise celebrated her 170th birthday this week. Harriet was one of three giant tortoises which Darwin imported to Britain from the Galapagos Islands in 1835. He estimated that she was born in around 1830, when William IV ascended the throne and Stephenson's Rocket first began to pull passenger trains. But her professional career as specimen was short-lived. Once Darwin had finished studying her, he packed her off on a convict ship; by the age of 12 she was enjoying early retirement in the Australian sunshine. As all 400lb of her testify, the emigrant thrived in her new home in the Antipodes. But it was only in the 1960s that a sharp-eyed keeper spotted something even Darwin had missed. Harriet, previously identified as a male called Harry, was undeniably female.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Armageddon | Sex: The Annabel Chong Story | Cape Fear | Braindead
fields.body:
Armageddon

(Michael Bay, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

An asteroid the size of Texas is headed for earth - send for Bruce Willis and his bunch of lovable roughnecks to save the day. Among them is Steve Buscemi's standard weirdo and Ben Affleck, a son-in-waiting, in love with Brucie's daughter, Liv Tyler. They may be the wrong stuff, but Nasa man Billy Bob Thornton has them make like astronauts, land on the rock, and bore nuclear-bomb holes into it. Awesome effects, incredibly loud, presided over by Willis, playing it so straight he must be kidding. Isn't he?

Sex: The Annabel Chong Story

(Gough Lewis, 1999)

10pm, FilmFour

Gough Lewis's intention was to make a portrait of an unusual person; he fell far short, making a freakshow out of a woman whose life seems as miserable as her justification is paper-thin. Annabel Chong is a Chinese woman who came to America as a student, got involved in low-grade porn, and took it upon herself to have sex with 300 men in one session. Not a nice film.

Cape Fear

(Martin Scorsese, 1991)

10pm, 3.30am, Sky Cinema

A screaming remake of J Lee Thompson's more restrained 1962 thriller. Robert De Niro is way over the top as Max Cady, the ex-con seeking vengeance on the lawyer responsible for putting him away. Cady, a rapist, attacks Sam Bowden (Nick Nolte) through his wife and daughter (Jessica Lange, Juliette Lewis), sadistically working on the family's pressure points. Enjoyable cameos from the original's stars, Robert Mitchum and Gregory Peck.

Braindead

(Peter Jackson, 1992)

1.25am, FilmFour

More than a touch of Night Of The Living Dead about this zombie-laden gorefest. Jackson, now working on The Lord Of The Rings trilogy, comes on here like the Jackson Pollock of blood-spattered horror movie-makers. Timothy Balme stars as a shy lad whose tryst with a girl (Diana Peñalver) at the zoo turns into a nightmare: his snooping mother (Elizabeth Moody) is bitten by a Sumatran rat-monkey and turned into a flesh-eating zombie. Things can only get worse.

webTitle: Pass notes: Sir Walter Ralegh

fields.headline: No: 1763
fields.standfirst: Sir Walter Ralegh
fields.trailText: Sir Walter Ralegh
fields.body:
Ralegh? Really? Or Rawley, or Rawleigh. But almost certainly not Raleigh.

Born: 1552, near Budleigh Salterton in Devon, since made famous by being mentioned in a Monty Python sketch.

Died: 1618, under the blade of an axe, on the orders of James I.

Laid his coat down over a puddle for Elizabeth I, didn't he? Almost certainly not, actually, but that is the legend. Never mind his illustrious life as a colonist, adventurer, reputed first importer of tobacco to England, poet, conspiracy foiler, alleged conspirator, lover and executee.

And why the history lesson? Sir Walter (the inanimate version) is on the move from his plinth near the Cenotaph to a new site in Greenwich.

Another initiative of Mayor Ken's statue-rearranging taskforce? Not this time - it's a Department of Culture thing. Ralegh is to make way for a memorial to the contribution of British women to the second world war. The London Evening Standard thinks it's political correctness gone mad, what with Elizabeth's favourite courtier having been a male imperialist tobacco baron and everything. (And while we're about it, whatever happened to the original meaning of the word "gay"?)

Favourite courtier? Didn't she throw him in the Tower? Something of an on-off favourite, actually, as viewers of the BBC history series Blackadder the Second will know. HMQ imprisoned Ralegh for having an affair with her maid. (Oddly, she reassessed his case around the time one of his ships presented her with a massive haul of Spanish gold from the New World.)

And James I just had a thing about smoking? Ralegh was framed for a conspiracy to kill the new king, in fact, and got the chop. His wife apparently carried his head around for three decades thereafter.

Not to be confused with: Sir Walter Scott, Domino Rally, Sir Francis Drake.

Most likely to say: "Don't worry, your majesty. I needed a new one anyway. Cigarette?"

webTitle: Inside Feltham young offenders' institution

fields.headline: Boys behind bars
fields.standfirst:
Rioting, suicide and a racist murder have made Feltham young offenders' institution the most notorious in the country. Now it has a new governor - its fifth in 18 months - but can he turn around the prison they call 'a finishing school for career criminals'? Paul Kelso crosses the wire
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Rioting, suicide and a racist murder have made Feltham young offenders' institution the most notorious in the country. Now it has a new governor - its fifth in 18 months - but can he turn around the prison they call 'a finishing school for career criminals'?  Paul Kelso  crosses the wire.
fields.body:
On the wall of the governor's office at Feltham young offenders' institution there are three picture hooks. Normally the governors' roll hangs here - an oak board bearing the names of those who have occupied perhaps the hottest seat in the prison service. On a chill morning earlier this week the hooks were vacant. "It's down in the workshop having my name added. The paint's not dry yet," says Nick Pascoe, the new boss of Britain's most notorious youth prison. From the window, through a thick mist, we can make out the top of the steel-mesh fence crowned with rolled razor wire that marks the boundaries of his estate; 96 acres housing up to 700 of the most disturbed, deprived and dangerous young men in the country.

The office may as well have a revolving door. Pascoe, who started three weeks ago, is the fifth man to take the job in the past 18 months. He was tempted back from his job at a private jail by Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, whose arrival we await. "I shall tell him I returned the company car this morning," Pascoe says with a wry grin. "That's the ultimate sacrifice, isn't it?"

Having to run his own car will be the least of Pascoe's worries. Within days of the new governor taking up his post a former Feltham prisoner, Robert Stewart, was convicted of murdering his 19-year-old Asian cellmate, Zahid Mubarek. Stewart, a 20-year-old racist psychopath with a cross and the letters RIP tattooed on his forehead, beat Zahid to death with a table leg in their 7ft by 10ft cell in the middle of the night in March. An internal inquiry found that ample evidence of Stewart's racist, violent tendencies and declining mental health had been missed or ignored by prison staff.

Stewart's conviction was the latest event in a miserable year for the jail. On a Saturday morning at the end of October, tensions spilled over and officers lost control of a unit housing 60 prisoners. In the four hours it took to regain control, the wing was trashed. In September, Kevin Henson, 16, ended his short, tragic life with a noose hung from an exposed pipe in his cell. Pascoe's task is to turn Feltham around. It will not be easy.

Serving every court in London and most of those in the south-east, Feltham is the largest young offenders' institution in the country; it sees 30,000 boys and young men between the age of 15 and 21 pass through its gates every year. Some stay briefly on remand; others are at the start of a long prison career. Feltham is short-staffed, 23-hour-a-day bang-ups are common, morale is low and the institution's reputation stinks. One experienced youth worker dismisses it as "a finishing school for career criminals".

Pascoe thinks of the place in less absolute terms. "Some of these men are dangerous and sophisticated criminals; others are totally unsophisticated and very damaged. The public expectation is that if you put them in a prison they will never reoffend. That's unrealistic. As a society have to decide what the purpose of imprisonment is - what do we want it to do?"

What Narey wants it to do is educate. "Of a total prison population of 60,000, around 40,000 are unemployable. What I want to do is give them basic education and constructive employment," he says in soft Teesside tones. "If they haven't got a job, of course they'll reoffend. They have no choice."

We are here to look at Feltham's new £6m education and reception unit for juvenile offenders, the 15- to 18-year-olds who are Narey's priority. Opened in August, it is a pristine pale-blue building with classrooms that any inner-city headmaster would give his chalk and board for. The smell of paint still lingers, not yet chased away by the ubiquitous prison odour of chips, rolling tobacco and sweat. The backing track of prison life - shouts and footfalls, jangling keys and slamming steel doors - is left outside. Narey grasps the hand of every officer and volunteer we pass and gives them the opportunity to bend his ear.

Inside the classrooms, groups of a dozen are studying information technology and basic literacy and numeracy. Most of the kids here got nothing out of school except bitter experience. Now the teachers at Feltham are trying to capitalise on the one advantage they have: a captive audience. The work is a grind and the potential for disruption massive, yet by tiny degrees the teacher maintains order and attention. One lad with a reputation for trouble is multiplying at the blackboard. He takes the arrival of the director general and friends as an opportunity to switch off. He tries to grab a handful of forms, then tries to sit when the teacher wants him to stand. She is having none of it and eventually he finishes his sums.

"What you just saw there was a little triumph," says Narey when we leave. "That lady got the lad to pay attention using nothing more than communication skills. Hundreds of potential incidents every day can be defused like that."

But this new education unit is far from the whole story at Feltham. On the other side of the fence that separates the juveniles from the 18- to 21-year-olds, the huge demands placed on Feltham are clear. In units housing up to 60 lads, half can be banged up all day, unlocked only to collect their meals.

Swallow unit is where Mubarek was killed. The cells run on two decks along two walls, and facing them are the servery and the officers' control room. In between is the association area, with a pool table, its baize almost worn through. The lads emerge for lunch. "We have to unlock slow because we've some characters in at the moment," says an officer. "They don't all get on as we might like." Those who are first in the queue collect a plate of thin chips; pale peas; a choice of pie, fish or corned beef; a bread roll and an apple. How's the food? "Shit," an inmate replies.

The cells have brightly painted red, blue and yellow doors. Inside they are a dreary cream, although an inmate painting team is busy brightening them up. The sheets are brown. One lad says his window leaks and points to some brown stains. "That's spit - people used it to stick posters to the walls. I can't get it off." Prisoners have to be inventive to stick up their lad-mag pin-ups. Toothpaste is a current favourite, although Narey encountered a man at Parkhurst who used semen. "Very effective," he says, with a grimace.

In cell 38, where Mubarek was killed, the two beds are 3ft apart. The toilet is in a doorless alcove. The only ventilation is the barred window, of which one pane opens. The lads in there now have a chess board set up on a table like the one Stewart snapped the leg from to kill Mubarek. They seem to get on.

So did Stewart and Zahid, according to the wing officers, most of whom were traumatised by the death. "When something like that happens the first thing you do is ask yourself, 'What more could I have done? Where there signs?' We saw his tattoo and you have hunches, but they honestly seemed to get on OK. They were together six weeks before he done it," says one officer. "The guilt is crippling... and then you know someone will be along looking for a scapegoat." Narey, listening hard, nods in agreement, but while the director general chats to some lads, the officer opens up. "We haven't the staff to get to know these lads properly. They're locked up 22-and-a-half hours a day then we unlock the doors. It can be like throwing a match into a box of fireworks."

A senior officer at Feltham, with 12 years' experience, explains the hidden cost of staff shortages and sickness, which runs at 18.5 days a year per officer: the lack of personal knowledge of the prisoners. "I remember once a colleague said to me one Saturday, 'Have you noticed Williams? Every weekend he's all tidy, his shoes are polished up and he's in his best gear. What's that all about?' It turned out every weekend he was waiting for a visit from his parents that never came. They used to visit but then they stopped. I looked into it and it turned out his parents had moved but the visiting orders were still being sent to the old address. We got them sent to the new address and they started visiting again. Things like that used to make the job worthwhile. The way we're going now we don't even have the time to realise we have got a fucking neo-Nazi thug in the same cell as an Asian lad."

Narey acknowledges the problems and says he will address them. He knows officers are angry, but says he will sack those who "swing the lead". He gives the impression that every suicide in a British jail cuts deep. There were 94 last year and reducing that number is his top priority. He also wants a public debate about the role of prisons. "A lot of people don't give a damn about what goes on inside prison walls, and only get engaged when they think we're running holiday camps. Well, I'd rather be criticised for giving them all a TV, for treating them well, than for being too harsh."

Both Pascoe and Narey say they would like young offenders' institutions to be places where their own teenage sons would be treated fairly, should they get into trouble. One day Huntercombe young offenders' institution, high in the Chilterns near Reading, will be the sort of place they have in mind. At this juvenile-only establishment, governor Paul Manwaring has established a "term" system. Prisoners study employment skills - painting and decorating, bricklaying, car mechanics - for 10 weeks, then have a "break week" in which they take art, drama or music classes, culminating in a prize day and performances.

Huntercombe is far from utopian, but in a resettlement class on the Mountbatten wing the fruits of the regime are apparent. Here, 10 kids within three months of release are taking a class aimed at preparing them for life on the outside. In contrast to many of the lads in the classrooms and on the wings both here and at Feltham, they are communicative and confident; they can see light at the end of the tunnel. Statistics say eight of them will be back, but for the moment they are looking forward, mainly to a McDonald's and to seeing their friends. The class volunteer and prison officer leave the room and I ask them if there is anything they want to say about prison. "Can we really say anything and you'll put it in the paper?" asks Frank. I nod. He grins and says: "Tell all our parents, 'Hello from Huntercombe!' "

I looked into it and it turned out his parents had moved but the visiting orders were still being sent to the old address. We got them sent to the new address and they started visiting again. Things like that used to make the job worthwhile. The way we're going now we don't even have the time to realise we have got a fucking neo-Nazi thug in the same cell as an Asian lad." Narey acknowledges the problems and says he will address them. He knows officers are angry, but says he will sack those who "swing the lead". He gives the impression that every suicide in a British jail cuts deep. There were 94 last year and reducing that number is his top priority. He also wants a public debate about the role of prisons. "A lot of people don't give a damn about what goes on inside prison walls, and only get engaged when they think we're running holiday camps. Well, I'd rather be criticised for giving them all a TV, for treating them well, than for being too harsh." Both Pascoe and Narey say they would like young offenders' institutions to be places where their own teenage sons would be treated fairly, should they get into trouble. One day Huntercombe young offenders' institution, high in the Chilterns near Reading, will be the sort of place they have in mind. At this juvenile-only establishment, governor Paul Manwaring has established a "term" system. Prisoners study employment skills - painting and decorating, bricklaying, car mechanics - for 10 weeks, then have a "break week" in which they take art, drama or music classes, culminating in a prize day and performances. Huntercombe is far from utopian, but in a resettlement class on the Mountbatten wing the fruits of the regime are apparent. Here, 10 kids within three months of release are taking a class aimed at preparing them for life on the outside. In contrast to many of the lads in the classrooms and on the wings both here and at Feltham, they are communicative and confident; they can see light at the end of the tunnel. Statistics say eight of them will be back, but for the moment they are looking forward, mainly to a McDonald's and to seeing their friends. The class volunteer and prison officer leave the room and I ask them if there is anything they want to say about prison. "Can we really say anything and you'll put it in the paper?" asks Frank. I nod. He grins and says: "Tell all our parents, 'Hello from Huntercombe!' "

webTitle: Telewest

fields.headline: Telewest
fields.trailText: Telewest, the cable television and telephony group, yesterday said it was on target to achieve 500,000 digital TV customers by the first quarter of next year.
fields.body:
Telewest, the cable television and telephony group, yesterday said it was on target to achieve 500,000 digital TV customers by the first quarter of next year.

The statement repaired some confidence in the business, which saw its share price devastated by a hiccup in its digital rollout earlier this year. Telewest had been forced to stop marketing the service because of a shortage of components for its set-top boxes.

The shares picked up 7p to 120p, although they still have a hill to climb before reaching their year high of 670p.

Chief executive Adam Singer said the company's problems were behind it. "We had an issue with our set-top boxes," he said. "It was just a delay of a few months and we are back on track."

In the first nine months, Telewest showed a modest increase in customer numbers from 1.4m to 1.6m.

The company has 315,000 digital customers, half of whom have migrated from Telewest's analogue customer base. Revenues increased by 41.2% to £814m although pre-tax losses widened from £357m to £475m.

Mr Singer said Telewest had been "unfairly tarred with the same brush" that has wreaked havoc on shares in the technology and media sectors. "We have higher penetration than Sky and have proven that we can take one-in-three customers from BT. We have a business that is working."
