webTitle: Mysis bucks the start-up trend

fields.headline: Mysis bucks the start-up trend
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Misys, the software firm, said yesterday it is to spend £10m launching a personal finance website next year despite the big losses and tumbling share prices that have engulfed entrants in the sector.
fields.body:
Misys, the software firm, said yesterday it is to spend £10m launching a personal finance website next year despite the big losses and tumbling share prices that have engulfed entrants in the sector.

It has set a target of selling 1m financial products - ranging from car and home insurance to Isas - on its new website, Theformula.com, by 2003. Misys says it is part of a £30m spend on e-commerce trading in 2000-01.

The launch of Theforumula comes a day after Interactive Investor International revealed reduced usage and widening losses at its personal finance website, and a week after Exchange Holdings threw in the towel on Moneyextra.com, its finance website.

Paul Charles, editor of Theformula, said: "Moneyextra and iii are little more than infomediary sites trying to build a transactional capability. There's not a site that is doing a complete, impartial, service across so many products in the way of Theformula."

Misys will use the technology behind its existing finance site, Screentrade, which sells home, car and travel policies.

Theformula will offer the same range of products as Screentrade, plus life insurance and Isas, when it launches early next year. It intends Theformula to be its standalone e-finance brand and to use Screentrade as a behind the scenes online brokerage for other portals. Theformula will be headed by Jasper McMahon, a former McKinsey management consultant.

webTitle: Governments and eurocrats face push for greater access

fields.headline: MEPs vote to shine a light on Brussels secrets
fields.standfirst:
Governments and eurocrats face push for greater access
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: European citizens stand to win far greater transparency from EU institutions after a landmark vote by members of the European Parliament yesterday threw down a challenge to secretive governments and eurocrats.
fields.body:
European citizens stand to win far greater transparency from EU institutions after a landmark vote by members of the European Parliament yesterday threw down a challenge to secretive governments and eurocrats.

By an overwhelming majority the MEPs backed new freedom of information proposals that would grant the right of access to most official documents from any institution in Brussels.

Meeting in Strasbourg, the parliament voted by 409 to three for a plan tabled by a British Labour MEP Michael Cashman.

Negotiations must now begin with the European Commission - the supranational executive of the EU - and the European Council, where the governments of the 15 member states cooperate.

If the parliament gets its way, official papers on issues such as BSE, radiation from mobile phones, and genetically modified organisms would be routinely available.

So would information about border controls, the police network Europol and all but the most sensitive papers on EU defence and foreign policy.

"This vote sends the signal that we are going to deliver something that gives far greater access," Mr Cashman said.

"This exercise is about restoring confidence and establishing accountability in the European project. Public confidence in official decision making is very low."

But there was criticism that the proposals did not go far enough and could still be watered down. "Parliament will have to continue to fight all the way to get any serious degree of openness from the council and commission," warned Graham Watson of the Liberal Democrat group.

The proposals call for a public register of documents, a minimal list of exemptions, and access to papers held by, and not just originating in, the EU's three big institutions.

They are being tabled to meet the requirement of the 1997 treaty of Amsterdam for the creation of a code of access to documents by May 2001 - a response to years of concern about a lack of transparency in the EU.

Criticism has focused on cumbersome procedures for classification and rules that allow officials "space to think" - to formulate policy before it is exposed to public scrutiny.

Tony Bunyan of Statewatch, a London-based civil liberties group, said last night: "The Cashman report has got the balance wrong between rights for citizens and rights for institutions."

Freedom of information is a sensitive issue in Brussels. The previous European Commission, under Jacques Santer of Luxembourg, was discredited and eventually forced to resign partly over issues of lack of transparency.

Romano Prodi, his Italian successor, has published a list of his correspondence on his website, though not the documents themselves, and has been sharply criticised by the EU ombudsman.

Britain insists it is taking an open approach to the new code, with diplomats privately blaming France, currently holding the EU's rotating presidency, for resisting. Italy and Germany are also reluctant.

Opponents of greater openness warn that Nato will be less willing to share its secrets with fledgling EU defence bodies if freedom of information procedures are too relaxed.

Britain says it is ready to scrap last summer's controversial decision to permanently exclude from public access whole categories of documents covering EU foreign policy, military and "non-military crisis management" - and any other document, classified or not, which refers to these issues.

The decision was pushed through by Javier Solana, the European Council's foreign policy supremo, and currently faces legal challenges from the Netherlands government and the European Parliament.

Parliament says EU institutions may refuse access to documents only where disclosure could significantly undermine the protection of public security in the union and member states; defence and military matters; and relations with third countries.

webTitle: Paris bailiffs on trail of rent-shy aristocrat

fields.headline: Paris bailiffs on trail of rent-shy aristocrat
fields.trailText: He may be the pretender to the throne of France and a direct descendant of Louis XIV, the Sun King, who certainly wasn't short of a bob or two, but Henri d'Orleans, the comte de Paris, is in trouble for not paying his rent.
fields.body:
He may be the pretender to the throne of France and a direct descendant of Louis XIV, the Sun King, who certainly wasn't short of a bob or two, but Henri d'Orleans, the comte de Paris, is in trouble for not paying his rent.

A spokeswoman for city hall in Paris said yesterday that bailiffs had been engaged to recover some £100,000 in back rent owed over the decade or so that the impecunious aristocrat occupied a small but sumptuous 17th-century council house in the chic 16th arrondissement .

The count left the Villa Boileau in an unseemly hurry a couple of years ago following an unfortunate scandal over the number of well connected and well off people then occupying luxurious city-owned apartments in central Paris for next to no rent.

"But we have now established that he very often failed to pay even when he was living there," the spokeswoman said. "He clearly had financial problems at the time. But now that his father's estate is finally being portioned out, there's no reason why he shouldn't fork out."

The count's father, another Henri, died last year at the age of 90 after fighting for most of his life to have himself recognised as the rightful heir to the throne. Sadly for his offspring, it now seems that he had spent most of his final decade getting rid of one of the grandest inheritances in French history so his children would benefit as little as possible, or preferably not at all.

Henri senior, the would-be Henri VI of France, inherited the fortune of the House of Orleans, worth a healthy £400m, in 1940.

The inheritance included a manor house in Brussels, a chateau in the Ardennes, a palace in Palermo, a ranch in Portugal, an estate in Louveciennes and most of Neuilly, as well as hundreds of paintings and £1.4m worth of diamonds that once belonged to Marie-Antoinette.

But after his death, all that was left was six monogrammed handkerchiefs and a pair of velvet slippers. As an understandably unhappy Henri junior said at the time, in spiriting away the family fortune the Comte d'Orleans had accomplished a feat unmatched even by the Revolution.

In recent months, however, a court-appointed lawyer, Helene de Camara, has been diligently searching through the late count's effects on behalf of his nine children, most of whom he appeared to loathe.

The resulting treasure trove - including jewels, canvases and, in one instance, a near-priceless medieval illustrated manuscript found stuffed down the back of a chest of drawers - have been auctioned off, raising some £10m.

And Henri, comte de Paris, is going to have to pay his rent.

webTitle: Slots in history

fields.headline: Slots in history
fields.standfirst: Vintage gaming machines up for auction
fields.trailText: Vintage gaming machines up for auction.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
John Carter's beloved slot machines, an industrial history of the 20th century at one old penny a go, are for sale.

Their shining confidence that all progress was good, the chromed cranes, ships and planes, the backgrounds of gleaming cityscapes, the art deco sun rays, even the artless promise on one "a cigarette awarded automatically", came to an abrupt end in the early 1970s.

"The electronic machines were coming in, and it happened to coincide with decimalisation," John Carter said.

Many in the collection of 209 machines which he will auction next Sunday are sole survivors of their type, the only ones to escape the scrapyards.

They are being sold to ensure the survival of Carter's Steam Fair, a travelling show of restored Victorian, Edwardian and early 20th century rides, which John and Anna Carter have assembled and toured since they met and married in art college.

The fair could have made them millionaires - it has appeared in innumerable films and Michael Jackson tried to buy the lot and ship it to California - but instead has been a job and a home to the Carters, and the three grown up sons who were taught practical engineering and fairground painting as soon as they could crawl.

Many of the slot machines are fortune tellers, including the sinister Sidney Knows - presumably named for its original owner, Sidney Levin - a mechanical figure who lifts his eyebrows and grins terrifyingly, and hands over "your future career card" for a penny.

Sidney somehow missed the day last July when John Carter, a giant of a man, found himself unaccountably weary after hours lifting barn door-sized panels on to a truck. He was referred to hospital, and told he had bone marrow cancer with 10 days to live. He beat that prediction, but at 18 stone is now a shadow of his former self.

The auction is cash only, admission by £5 catalogue, in the village hall at Waltham St Lawrence, Berkshire. The lots include an essential bag of 500 old pennies.

webTitle: Supposed Caravaggio imitation found to be the real thing

fields.headline: Spot the difference
fields.standfirst: Supposed Caravaggio imitation found to be the real thing
fields.trailText: A supposedly inferior copy of a Caravaggio masterpiece, St Francis in Meditation, is in fact the original painting, according to art experts involved in restoring the painting.
fields.body:
A supposedly inferior copy of a Caravaggio masterpiece, St Francis in Meditation, is in fact the original painting, according to art experts involved in restoring the painting.

The warmer, more popular version, feted for centuries as the original, was probably painted by Bartolomeo Manfredi, a contemporary of the Italian master, the Rome daily Il Messaggero reported.

Generations of scholars were convinced that the canvas, which hung in a Capuchin church on Via Veneto in Rome, was the real Caravaggio.

Many had considered it superior to a slightly more sombre version in St Peter's church in Carpineto Romano, a town near Rome.

The virtually identical works went on display together for the first time yesterday in Rome's Palazzo Barberini.

It was after using radiography techniques that two restorers - Rossella Vodret and Carlo Giantomassi - said they believed the gloomier painting was the Caravaggio. The mixture of reds, yellows and grains of malachite - a Caravaggio trademark - was present only in the St Peter's painting, they said.

Maurizio Marini, an expert on the artist, was reported as saying that while both works exuded sensory realism, the subtle differences in light and shade, plus the powder used, suggested that the St Peter's version could have been painted only by Caravaggio, probably around 1609, a year before he died at the age of 37.

Ms Vodret and Mr Giantomassi, said they had intended only to save the painting from decay, not uncover a mystery.

A scholar, Maria Vittoria Brugnoli, declared it the original after discovering it in St Peter's in 1968. It is thought to have been donated in the late 19th century by one of Carpineto Romano's most famous sons, Pope Leo XIII.

However, colleagues rebuffed Ms Brugnoli's claim and clung to the view, believed for centuries, that the original was the one hung in Via Veneto.

Uncertainty produced by the abundance of Caravaggio copies would continue to torment scholars and produce more surprises, Il Messaggero predicted. "The copy is of good quality, certainly its charm is even more attractive than the severity of the original," the newspaper said.

The painting features St Francis kneeling before a cross and holding a skull, contemplating death.

Long villified for a scandalous and murderous private life, Caravaggio was rehabilitated in the 19th century. Manfredi is recognised today as a master in his own right.

webTitle: Damper on Paris's Disney

fields.headline: Damper on Paris's Disney
fields.trailText: Storm damage at Euro Disney's Davy Crockett Ranch put a damper on attendances at the Paris theme park last year, cutting hotel capacity by 10% for four months as the building was closed for repairs.
fields.body:
Storm damage at Euro Disney's Davy Crockett Ranch put a damper on attendances at the Paris theme park last year, cutting hotel capacity by 10% for four months as the building was closed for repairs.

The ranch was hit by bad weather on Boxing Day and as a result the total number of visitors to the park fell 4% to 12m in the year to September.

However, Euro Disney received compensation from insurers of 20.4m euros (£12m) and the reinbursement helped the company increase its net profits by 64% to 38.7m euros.

The firm, which is 38% owned by America's Walt Disney Company, has its finances on a much more stable footing after a large-scale renegotiation of its debts. Its profits were boosted by lower interest payments and increased short-term investments after a rights issue in December.

Analysts have expressed concerns about the company's plans to construct a second theme park, Disney Studios, but were reassured by a statement from the company saying that construction was "on schedule and on budget", with opening due in 2002.

In the coming months, Euro Disney is planning to introduce on-line reservations and to expand its "Fast Pass" ticketing system, which has almost halved peak waiting times for star attractions such as Big Thunder Mountain and Star Tours.

The shares, which have drifted down from more than 70p over the last year, slipped 0.5p.to 36p.

webTitle: L&G adds to top women

fields.headline: L&G adds to top women
fields.trailText: Legal & General is to have more female directors on its board than any other FTSE 100 company after a shake-up yesterday that included the re-appointment of the chief executive beyond his retirement age.
fields.body:
Legal & General is to have more female directors on its board than any other FTSE 100 company after a shake-up yesterday that included the re-appointment of the chief executive beyond his retirement age.

David Prosser, the chief executive who last year tried to broaden his role by selling the group to NatWest, is to extend his position to 2006, two years beyond his 60th birthday. Finance director Tony Hobson will leave in February after 13 years and be replaced by Andrew Palmer, director of corporate business.

L&G also promoted Kate Avery, retail customer director, to the board. Along with Beverley Hodson, managing director of WH Smith UK retail, who was yesterday named as a new non-executive, Ms Avery will be one of four females in the boardroom.

This would appear to put L&G above top ranking Pearson in the recently compiled FTSE Female index, which measured the number of woman in Britain's boardrooms, although the publishing group is actually run by Marjorie Scardino.

L&G said Mr Prosser had been asked to stay on to tackle the introduction of low-cost stakeholder pensions next year which threatens to erode the profitability of insurance companies. Chairman Rob Margetts described the departure of Mr Hobson, the finance director, as the "end of an era".

Robin Phipps, director of retail business, takes on the roles held by Andrew Palmer, Mr Hobson's replacement.

webTitle: P&O suffers duty free hangover

fields.headline: P&O suffers duty free hangover
fields.trailText: P&O Stena Line's ferry passenger traffic continues to fall after the abolition of duty free but its profits have risen in the past quarter.
fields.body:
P&O Stena Line's ferry passenger traffic continues to fall after the abolition of duty free but its profits have risen in the past quarter.

Headline profits slumped by well over half to £18.4m in the first nine months of the year but third-quarter results, issued yesterday, show a rise to £19.8m, up from £14.6m in the same period of 1999.

Graeme Dunlop, chairman of P&O Ferries, which controls 60% of P & O Stena Line, said: "The underlying market position looks quite good."

Fuel costs were £1.5m higher in the third quarter and over the first nine months passenger numbers fell from 9.8m to 9.1m. But the joint venture between P&O and Sweden's Stena Line was able to push up ticket costs by up to 10% and increase passenger spend on non-duty free items.

Established in 1998 in reaction to competition from the Channel tunnel, P&O Stena saw its market share increase from 38% to 40% in the nine-month period and predicted stronger volume recovery in 2002.

Mark McVicar, transport analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said the latest quarterly figures were "quite good" in the circumstances. "These are the first results comparing one post-duty free quarter with another post-duty free quarter and profits are not spectacular but they have gone up."

Passenger numbers in the third quarter were down from 3.9m to 3.7m with tourist vehicles falling from 647,000 to 566,000 and freight units down from 294,000 to 272,000.

The cross-Channel freight market has been growing at 8% a year but the extra traffic has been absorbed by new capacity from Eurotunnel.

P&O Stena, which operates the Dover-Calais and Dover-Zeebrugge routes, has been trying to win back customers by upgrading onboard facilities.

It has brought in upmarket restaurant groups such as Langham's Brasserie to smarten up its image. Its latest promotion is a "bulk hulk", where crew members load up the car in the hull of the ship with alcohol, tobacco or perfume purchases while the customer relaxes in one of the restaurants or VIP lounges.

Although duty free has been abolished, passengers can take advantage of the difference between British and French tax rates on some of the 8,000 lines offered on the ferries.

Meanwhile, P&O Ferries, which operates independently across the North Sea and to destinations such as Ireland, said the number of passengers it carried in the year to date was down to 3.2m from 3.4m in the first nine months of 1999.

P&O also announced that its 50%-owned P&O Nedlloyd container joint venture has shown a leap in third-quarter operating profits from $59m (£42m) to $75m.


The effects

Fall in retail trading at airports such as Heathrow and Gatwick - down 20% immediately after abolition - has forced BAA to increase airport charges

Ferry passengers are paying higher fares as cross-Channel operators make up for lost duty free. Analysts believe they could be 20% up

Ferries are carrying 10% fewer passengers this year compared with last year

Alcohol and tobacco manufacturers are selling less on ferries and at airports and suffering from an increase in smuggling

webTitle: Laing to sell off construction arm

fields.headline: Laing to sell off construction arm
fields.trailText: After 150 years of building prestigious landmarks such as the Millennium Dome, John Laing yesterday announced plans to sell its struggling construction arm.
fields.body:
After 150 years of building prestigious landmarks such as the Millennium Dome, John Laing yesterday announced plans to sell its struggling construction arm.

The company said it was time to off-load the loss making division and concentrate on developing its property and infrastructure interests. But it said that talks with potential suitors were yet to take place and admitted the whole process was likely to take several months.

Adrian Ewer, finance director, said the "cyclical" and "volatile" nature of construction was threatening to impact on the company's asset-based divisions.

He predicted that the likely buyer was a leading European construction firm which was prepared to supply the financial support required.

"It's better for it to have new investors," he said. "We were acting as a constraint on it and restricting the business development. We were never going to let it develop properly because our focus is on asset-based businesses."

On the announcement, which industry observers had been expecting, Laing's shares rose 3.5p to close the day at 388p. This is well above the 173p year low but still off the high of 402p.

The sale of the division, which employs 2,500 full-time workers and a further 4,000 on contracts, is being handled by ING Barings.

The company is understood to have received a number of approaches in the past by firms based in Britain, although none came to fruition.

In September, Laing said the homes and property divisions had bailed out the poorly performing construction side which made a £19m loss in the first half of the year as a result of poor margins and reorganisation costs.

The company has been behind many of Britain's most well-known constructions, including London's Barbican centre, Stansted airport and the M6 motorway. But not all have been a success on the balance sheet. The £100m Cardiff Millennium Stadium project cost Laing £26m.

Chairman Sir Martin Laing, said the core businesses were "beginning to bear fruit". These include its Chiltern rail interests, the contract to maintain a major section of the M40 motorway and housebuilding development.

webTitle: Sainsbury shapes up

fields.headline: Sainsbury shapes up
fields.trailText: The former man from the Pru, Sir Peter Davis, has been working his magic ever since he joined struggling supermarket group J Sainsbury in March. At 267p when he arrived, the shares closed at a year-high of 427p last night after Deutsche Bank lifted its rating to "buy" and set a price of 500p.
fields.body:
The former man from the Pru, Sir Peter Davis, has been working his magic ever since he joined struggling supermarket group J Sainsbury in March. At 267p when he arrived, the shares closed at a year-high of 427p last night after Deutsche Bank lifted its rating to "buy" and set a price of 500p.

Deutsche accepts that food retailing remains extremely competitive and is likely to favour the most profitable players, such as Tesco and Wm Morrison, who enjoy the benefits of low operational gearing and therefore a higher resilience to pricing pressures.

Nonetheless, if - as Deutsche Bank believes - the competitive environment softens in the next two to three years, Sainsbury is the retailer best placed to benefit. In the new, softer marketplace Sainsbury will, says Deutsche, leverage its brand name, market share and store portfolio to good effect.

webTitle: At this price?  Babcock

fields.headline: At this price?  Babcock
fields.trailText: In his last set of results before stepping down on January 1 as chairman of Babcock International, John Parker hailed "the successful completion of the strategic initiatives" he announced in the summer and prodded the group further down the well-trodden road away from engineering into facilities management.
fields.body:
In his last set of results before stepping down on January 1 as chairman of Babcock International, John Parker hailed "the successful completion of the strategic initiatives" he announced in the summer and prodded the group further down the well-trodden road away from engineering into facilities management.

At first glance, he had little to crow about. Pre-tax profits for the first half were down from £11.9m to £10m, the group order book was down from £319m in March to £283m in September. But his re-engineering of Babcock is bearing fruit, with the shares heading towards the year's high of 122p, compared to a low of 72p, closing at 116p, down just 0.5p on the day.

One reason is that he has quit the poorly performing rail maintenance business, Railcare. The analysts' consensus is for £22m group pre-tax earnings in the full year.

Babcock is to focus on and expand its support and defence services activities. Essentially, that means its Rosyth dockyard where it has refitted the UK's nuclear submarines. As that business declines, Rosyth is moving into refitting surface ships.

Dr Parker sees strong growth potential in providing support services for the new defence logistics organisation which eats up a quarter of the military budget. Babcock has high hopes of winning the DLO contract to manage the Faslane nuclear submarine facility on the Clyde, expected to be awarded late next year.

These changes signal a substantial move from its engineering origins but the City is pleased, primarily because Dr Parker has rescued Babcock from a near-bankrupt outfit and turned it into a cash-rich business.

Last month, Babcock re-engineered its shareholder base, returning £30.6m to investors and consolidating its shares, and is slightly increasing the interim dividend. Dr Parker says it can still spend up to £100m on acquisitions. Consider buying into this promising stock.

webTitle: Channel 4's The Difference - serious debate or sensationalism?

fields.headline: Under your skin
fields.standfirst: Channel 4's new series The Difference tackles the thorny issues of race and genetic determinism. Or so the programme-makers would have us believe. In fact, says  Dave Hill, serious debate loses out to mere sensationalism
fields.trailText: Channel 4's new series The Difference tackles the thorny issues of race and genetic determinism. Or so the programme-makers would have us believe. In fact, says Dave Hill, serious debate loses out to mere sensationalism.
fields.body:
Has anyone announced yet that science is the new sex? If not, it's time they did. Bookshops burst with tales of evolutionary forces driving mysterious "mating strategies". Broadcasters and newspapers pantingly report that "scientists have discovered" why men don't iron, why women flutter their eyelashes, and why we wouldn't be the mighty mammals we are if extra-marital rutting wasn't "in our nature".

But the sexiness ascribed to such areas of science - broadly those concerned with genes and evolution - is not confined to what they reckon to reveal about sex and the sexes. In media circles they're also considered sexy for their potential for disturbing sensitivities and polarising opinions, especially when it comes to physical and intellectual variations between what we know as different races.

This is the hardcore stuff explored in a new three-part C4 series, The Difference. It contains contributions from a range of experts, with reports on why a small corner of Kenya could produce so many champion athletes, why cow's milk makes many black and Asian people sick, why aboriginal children are more successful than white ones at a visual memory game.

On paper it looks promising. But will The Difference deliver? Sadly for C4, the academics we invited to look at the programmes thought it could have been a great deal better.

For Steven Rose, professor of biology at the Open University, it's full of the failings in media coverage of science that he'd identified in a talk to BBC governors earlier this year: science and scientists referred to "as if they were one homogeneous whole"; an undue deference towards "claims of scientific expertise", notably in "increasing claims to have found genes 'for' almost every aspect of human life". Rose's work is intimately engaged with the big issues about genes, yet he has no time for the certainty, increasingly entering the cultural drinking water, that genetic explanations of human aptitudes and social behaviour should be considered sovereign.

Another natural scientist, Gabriel Dover, professor of evolutionary genetics at Leicester University, agrees that The Difference contains a lot of "plain bad science", with genetic explanations ("nature") consistently privileged over cultural ones ("nurture") in explaining the results of experiments, and the best material sold short because of an overriding longing to appear controversial.

As Richard Tutton, researcher in cultural studies of genetics at the University of Lancaster notes, it's shown that a person's presumed membership of a certain racial group may be a poor guide to their genetic inheritance - as a crude example, an outwardly white European person may have a strong strain of black African ancestry or vice versa. And yet, having killed off the common parlance categories of "race", The Difference resurrects them time and time again. Marilyn Strathern, professor of social anthropology at Cambridge says "It showed us that words like 'race' and 'intelligence' have to go out of the window, and that we have to find new words for describing our diversity. And yet the programmes are all framed in terms of breaking taboos about race."

According to Tutton, the series constructs a stark opposition between a crusading modern "science" at the frontiers of knowledge, and a lesser breed of faint hearts fearful of the social implications of that knowledge. These latter, says Tutton, "aren't properly identified, and their views are left largely unexplored".

So who are these blurry figures? What are they moaning about? Some do make an appearance - members of an ethnic minority community voicing deep unease about consenting to DNA sampling - but that's not good enough for sociologist Professor Hilary Rose, who points out that dissent against prevailing orthodoxies which emanate from powerful sources - here, the assumption that genetic research is inherently progressive - has always been depicted as emotional and incoherent rather than reasonable and rational. History reveals endless examples of how those with the least power have been cruelly exploited by scientists. "These people are always hailed as cultural Galileos," says Rose. "They often turn out to be cultural arseholes."

And does the vaunted "taboo" cited in The Difference really exist in the form in which it's presented? Is "pointing out difference" of itself "seen as racist"? Rights activists, health professionals and scientists of impeccable social ethics have long campaigned for the recognition and celebration of difference, sometimes for cultural self-assertion, sometimes so that diseases like sickle cell anaemia, which only affect black people, are properly acknowledged and researched. "People aren't frightened of scientists finding out about difference and diversity," says Rose. "But they do want to know who's doing the research, why they want to do it, and what's in it for them."

Maybe that's the blind spot at the nub of The Difference. On the one hand it reveals how genetic research may contribute to a fuller, deeper, fairer grasp of humankind in all its vast diversity. At the same time it clings to the old paradigms of "race", "intelligence" and, of course, "political correctness" as if terrified that without inflating a "taboo" to make everyone "face up to", all that lovely sexiness would simply slip away.

 The Difference, Sunday, 8pm, Channel 4

webTitle: Behind the screen

fields.headline: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Bet you can't wait for Crossroads to come back on? Television just hasn't been the same experience since those wobbly sets and green knitted woollen hats left the screen.
fields.body:
Bet you can't wait for Crossroads to come back on? Television just hasn't been the same experience since those wobbly sets and green knitted woollen hats left the screen. (Well, OK, Dr Who continued into the 1990s, but it just wasn't the same after Tom Baker, was it?) But the motel will be back on the box before the middle of next year, bringing laughs back to teatime soap-watchers everywhere.

What you also might not know is that the team making Crossroads over at Carlton is producing the show for about as much as they did first time around. Those task-masters at ITV ordered not just one teatime soap, but two, a few months back - and they insisted that all producers sign contracts to demonstrate their programmes within strict budget limits. But it works out at an annual income of about £10m for Carlton, so it's not all bad news.

The other sad fact about the doom motel, though, is that the architect behind Crossroads' revival won't be around to see his new baby hit the screen. You might not have had Lord Waheed Alli down as a typical Benny fan - but you'd be wrong. The Labour peer was head of Carlton Productions until earlier this week when the parent company's latest boardroom coup left him without a seat. Alli had joined Carlton with his production company Planet 24, which Carlton bought a couple of years ago. His brief was to improve Carlton's reputation for programme-making - so he decided to bring back Crossroads. Shame he isn't working there any more, you might think.

Another fruit of the Carlton cornucopia of delights - Inspector Morse - came to a fitting end on TV this week. Some 60 per cent of viewers tuned in to watch the demise of the wizened one. So ITV should be well happy. But not according to one insider who this week admitted to us: "It wasn't a fabulous production, to be quite honest."

You might not have had Lord Waheed Alli down as a typical Benny fan - but you'd be wrong. The Labour peer was head of Carlton Productions until earlier this week when the parent company's latest boardroom coup left him without a seat. Alli had joined Carlton with his production company Planet 24, which Carlton bought a couple of years ago. His brief was to improve Carlton's reputation for programme-making - so he decided to bring back Crossroads. Shame he isn't working there any more, you might think. Another fruit of the Carlton cornucopia of delights - Inspector Morse - came to a fitting end on TV this week. Some 60 per cent of viewers tuned in to watch the demise of the wizened one. So ITV should be well happy. But not according to one insider who this week admitted to us: "It wasn't a fabulous production, to be quite honest."

webTitle: Letters: Whittington hospital is culpable

fields.headline: For Jacob
fields.trailText: As Jacob Fogg's auntie, I would like question the Whittington hospital's denial of any culpability in the events of October 15 2000 (Meningitis child died after misdiagnosis, November 15).
fields.body:
As Jacob Fogg's auntie, I would like question the Whittington hospital's denial of any culpability in the events of October 15 2000 (Meningitis child died after misdiagnosis, November 15). Even on the day of Jacob's death, Ed and Em showed empathy for hospital staff. Not once did I hear them attach blame to an individual nurse or doctor. Instead, they questioned the system that had allowed their son to die.

I believe that the Whittington should now show my family the same compassion by conceding that wrong decisions were indeed made that night and that "prompt and appropriate care" was not in fact offered. A thorough review of the Whittington's procedural and resource issues will not bring back my beloved nephew, but it would help to prevent this tragedy from happening to other families. This would be a fitting tribute to Jacob, and all who depend on the NHS.
Ali Fogg
London
Alison.Fogg@precedent.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: You don't get our vote

fields.headline: You don't get our vote
fields.trailText: I have just sent a letter of congratulations to the Daily Telegraph for covering the demonstration by 10,000 students in London on November 15.
fields.body:
I have just sent a letter of congratulations to the Daily Telegraph for covering the demonstration by 10,000 students in London on November 15.

Your readers may be interested to know we were protesting about the increase in tuition fees and student debt. While you gave plenty of coverage to a handful of forlorn fuel protesters, you obviously felt that 10,000 people marching through the capital was not newsworthy.
Chris Burrows
University College, Worcester

 You claim Bush and Gore each represent half the nation (The disunited states of America, November 15). In fact, each represents only a quarter, the other half does not wish to be represented. An equally interesting graphic would show the proportions of non-voters in each group.
Vic Smith
Ickenham, Middx

 Should the Democrats' method for determining the number of votes in Florida be called an Al-Gore-ithm?
Chris Hancock
Sedgefield

 Bush predicted the election debacle on September 13 when he said: "They have miscalculated me as a leader."
Sophie Goldspink
London

 Reading Hugh Paddick's obituary (November 13) reminded me of my favourite Julian and Sandy episode from Round The Horne: having formed a political party their rallying song (set to the tune of The Red Flag) began: "The worker's flag is deepest puce, with fleurs-de-lys in pale chartreuse ..." Thus did they foresee the coming of New Labour by some years.
David Joss Buckley
London

 My young grandson wants to know why England's opening batsmen were out going to the sweet shop (England fall in a heap, November 16).
Tony Benson
London

webTitle: Letters: specialist photographic collections

fields.headline: Develop a museum here
fields.trailText: Surely one answer to Jonathan Jones's call for a "central, authoritative public photographic collection" (Snap decisions, November 15) is in fact to decentralise specialist collections around the country.
fields.body:
Surely one answer to Jonathan Jones's call for a "central, authoritative public photographic collection" (Snap decisions, November 15) is in fact to decentralise specialist collections around the country.

Frank Meadow Sutcliffe already has a museum dedicated to him in Whitby, while William Fox Talbot is commemorated at Laycock Abbey, but when Dimbola Lodge applied for lottery funding, it was told erroneously that this would conflict with other permanent collections of Julia Margaret Cameron's work on public display in Britain. We have yet to find them. As Mrs Cameron's descendants presented a large archive of her work into the care of the RPS, with the planned closure of their Bath premises, it would seem eminently sensible to place some of these at Dimbola. It would be a homecoming to the place where most of them were taken, developed and printed. In case Jonathan is worried that the West Wight is in the back of beyond - as he seems to with Devizes - I can assure him that central London is less than three hours away, by car or train, and that in the summer half the world seems to pass by.
Dr Brian Hinton
Curator, Julia Margaret Cameron Trust
Dimbola Lodge, Isle of Wight

webTitle: Letters: Lib Dem sell-out

fields.headline: More information on Lib Dem sell-out
fields.trailText: Lords Lester and Goodhart (Letter, November 16) claim their deal with the government over the freedom of information bill meets the Campaign for Freedom of Information's main demand. It emphatically does not and we are bitterly disappointed by it.
fields.body:
Lords Lester and Goodhart (Letter, November 16) claim their deal with the government over the freedom of information bill meets the Campaign for Freedom of Information's main demand. It emphatically does not and we are bitterly disappointed by it.

The amendments we support were tabled by Labour and Tory peers and opposed by Liberal Democrats. They suggest that their changes in effect introduce a "harm test" into most exemptions. But when invited to confirm this, Lord Falconer replied: "I do not necessarily accept the way Lord Goodhart puts it."

Some of the bill's exemptions require government to show that disclosure would "prejudice" interests such as defence or international relations. Even if it does, the bills public interest test offers a further opportunity of access. But wide classes of information, including the findings of safety inspectors and scientific advice on health hazards, can be withheld without evidence of harm. The public interest test is the sole basis for access.

The Lib Dem deal does improve the public interest test. But proposing the same amendment at an earlier stage, Lord Goodhart said: "I doubt whether in practice this will make an enormous difference" (October 17). Authorities will still be able to argue there is a general public interest in withholding information, because if the government had intended a harm test it would explicitly have inserted one.

Any order by the commissioner requiring government to disclose on public interest grounds can be vetoed by ministers. An order issued under a "prejudice" exemption cannot be vetoed. Liberal peers argued against inserting prejudice tests and against efforts to remove the veto. They have ensured that the final say remains in ministers' hands. We believe the government could have been forced to concede more than the LibDem peers settled for.
Maurice Frankel
Campaign for Freedom of Information

 It is contemptible for the Liberals to claim Tory peers would not have voted to improve the bill. The record of Tuesday's first division shows clearly we would have beaten the government if they had voted with us for open government, rather than for Jack Straw. The result of this Liberal sell-out will now be an act less open than the code of practice introduced by John Major.
Lord Strathclyde

webTitle: Peter Mandelson on the northen Ireland police bill

fields.headline: It's a start
fields.standfirst:
Peter Mandelson replies to the denunciation in the Guardian by a member of the Patten commission of his police bill

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson replies to the denunciation in the Guardian by a member of the Patten commission of his police bill.
fields.body:
Late last Saturday night members of the RUC intercepted a Real IRA mortar bomb at Derrylin near Enniskillen. The consequences if they hadn't hardly bear thinking about. The professionalism of those police officers almost certainly prevented another Poppy Day massacre and the serious personal injury and damage to the peace process that would have ensued.

That planned attack was not an isolated incident. Another police officer is still seriously ill in hospital after the previous week's attack at the police station in Castlewellan, and there are concerns about the possibility of further attacks on either side of the Irish sea in the run-up to Christmas.

Terrorism is still a direct, active threat in Northern Ireland. So why has the government chosen now to undertake the most fundamental reform of a police service attempted anywhere?

Because we believe that to defeat terrorism and accelerate the transition to a decent, peaceful, civic society in Northern Ireland you have to create a police service drawn from the whole community and whose writ extends to the whole community. Because, to be effective, a police service has to be representative. And effectiveness at root is what the new beginning is all about.

I understand the concerns of those who say that the police should not be distracted at a time of continuing violence. And that politics needs to be working in a stable environment before the kind of accountability mechanisms we envisage are introduced.

But police reform will help, not hinder, the task of making politics work. Because, as the Good Friday agreement recognised, it is a vital condition for mobilising the whole community to work in partnership with the police against those who are opposed to peace and stability.

That's why this week I have rejected calls by the Ulster Unionist party for a moratorium on police reform - and why on Wednesday night, despite stiff opposition, the government defeated attempts in the House of Lords to delay or dilute the reform programme.

With the legislation all but in place, the hard work must begin to implement this hugely ambitious programme of reform. In January, we hope to have the new policing board operating in shadow form - a board made up, for the first time in Northern Ireland's history, of representatives from all the major political parties - unionist, nationalist and republican.

In April adverts will appear for the first batch of new recruits - candidates who will be selected on a 50/50 basis, so for the first time Catholics will be fairly represented in Northern Ireland's police service.

In September those recruits will start training and the new police service will come into being. It will have a new name - Police Service of Northern Ireland. It will have a new uniform, including a new badge. It will have a new oath and a code of ethics. And it will have a new relationship with all sections of the community, not only through the policing board, but also local district partnerships in which local commanders will consult with local representatives.

That is why I have gone further than the Patten report and given the board responsibility for promoting economy, efficiency and effectiveness. It will be a board with greater power to hold the police to account than any other in the UK, or indeed elsewhere. The only caveat is the commonsense one that no inquiry should prejudice an investigation or prosecution.

Because the government believes it is the community that should be at the centre of the policing service in Northern Ireland. That is why we have accepted all the key Patten recommendations on community policing as a core function - dedicated neighbourhood policing teams, patrolling on foot, and community representatives attending training courses.

It is also why I believe it would be better if the policing board - the representatives of the people of Northern Ireland - could agree on the sensitive issue of the symbols of the new service.

A local consensus would be far better than any decision I would make. If that does not prove possible, I would certainly not want to impose a design which would be offensive to or deter recruitment from one side of the community or the other. That would defeat the whole purpose of what we are trying to achieve.

Because policing in Northern Ireland needs the full support of the whole community. That does not mean either ignoring the very real terrorist threat that remains, or allowing it to prevent the changes that must be made.

It is a balance the Patten report itself recognised. The speed at which we can move in some operational respects must depend on the level of threat, but we will set targets for progress in all areas. And monitoring the process will be the statutorily based oversight commissioner, Tom Constantine, the former chief of New York state police.

We are now entering a new era in policing in Northern Ireland - one in which both traditions, for the first time, will regard their police service as not belonging to one side or the other, but to both. This will not be achieved overnight. Yet more patience is needed. But, at last, the start has been made.

Peter Mandelson is the Northern Ireland secretary

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Letters: London First and  bond finance

fields.headline: Bond issue
fields.trailText: Seumas Milne says of the disagreement between the government and Ken Livingstone over the underground, "even the business lobby London First is pressing the government to explore a bond-financed public-sector option" (Stuck down the Tube, November 15).
fields.body:
Seumas Milne says of the disagreement between the government and Ken Livingstone over the underground, "even the business lobby London First is pressing the government to explore a bond-financed public-sector option" (Stuck down the Tube, November 15).

London First is pragmatic about the method of financing the improvements. The PPP would only cover upgrading and improving the existing system. Additional financing will be needed for new projects to take the system forward. London First has campaigned for the greater London authority to have borrowing powers to raise the necessary finance. In this context we have called for bond finance to be explored, whether or not the PPP goes ahead.
Irving Yass
London First

webTitle: The waters of £ethe

fields.headline: The waters of £ethe
fields.standfirst: The very rich forget where they spent it
fields.trailText: The very rich forget where they spent it
fields.body: When Jeffrey Bernard's life story was being planned, he had to appeal to Times readers to remind him where he had been for chunks of his life. According to allegations in the court case now under way, an entire decade in the life of Sir Elton John may have been snuffed out, like a candle in the wind one might say, because of his 80s addiction to alcohol and cocaine. He admits getting through £40m in just 20 months. "Money does strange things to people," he told the court. Sir Elton is so unabashed by conspicuous consumption that he may need some kind of sharp therapeutic jolt to bring him back down to earth. If you have a back-to-front name it is perhaps not surprising that you have an upside-down life as well. Perhaps it is time for Elton John to go back to being plain Reg Dwight, so we can happily welcome him back to the human race.

webTitle: Letters: Blueprints for patenting life

fields.headline: Blueprints for patenting life
fields.trailText: There is a countervailing international agreement to the World Trade Organisation's on patenting and intellectual property rights (The price of life, November 15). The convention on biological diversity is legally binding on 179 governments.
fields.body:
There is a countervailing international agreement to the World Trade Organisation's on patenting and intellectual property rights (The price of life, November 15). The convention on biological diversity is legally binding on 179 governments. Forty of these are now in Neuchatel, trying to agree the text of a subsidiary instrument, the international undertaking on plant genetic resources for food and agriculture (IU).

This IU has the potential to exempt an entire category of the earth's "commons" - the plant life forms used to provide food security - from privatisation and corporate control. It could restrict the "biopiracy" of which John Vidal wrote eloquently in your Patenting Life supplement (November 15) and continue to allow the free exchange, sale and communal ownership of life-sustaining genetic materials. The IU could also ensure that more than half a million samples of crop, forage and agroforestry species taken from farmers and held in trust in gene banks will be safeguarded in the public domain.

Yet the negotiations this week have become highly strained, with some countries refusing to accept those articles which would, in their view "conflict with" (ie limit) the dominance of intellectual property rights rules under the WTO. ITDG, its partners from developing countries and smallholder farmers have lobbied strongly for the IU negotiations to be completed swiftly. Developing nations, including the Africa Group, desperately want it. They know that 90% of the seeds which create food security for their people are currently exchanged between farmers, not traded by seed companies. But countries whose corporate industries benefit from WTO rules are holding the process back. It is urgent that the UK drives the EU into a positive, united position, which could be crucial to securing agreement.
Patrick Mulvany
Intermediate Technology Development Group
itdg@itdg.org.uk

 Intellectual property rights, especially patents, enable global knowledge cartels to coordinate and solve an enforcement problem. Any cartel member faces the problem that another may cheat and try to take more of the market than agreed. Emerging multinationals in the early part of the 20th century turned to intellectual property rights and complex licensing arrangements based on those rights to co-ordinate and enforce global cartels. Patent licences enabled them to group together to fix prices, limit production, divide markets and exclude competitors.

The problem of cartel formation by companies previously involved in chemicals or pharmaceuticals and now expanding into biotechnology continues. Witness the anti-trust litigation by US and international farmers against Monsanto, Dow, Du Pont, and Novartis for forming a cartel in the GM corn and soy-bean markets. Unfortunately, the alleged benefits of the biotech revolution will be delivered to consumers at great cost. Intellectual property rules in many ways represent the ultimate conspiracy against the public.
Dr Peter Drahos
Intellectual property research institute, Queen Mary College
P.F.Drahos@qmw.ac.uk

 Tim Radford (Patenting Life) poses the question whether two separate groups could patent the same piece of genetic information for two different functions. He rightly points out that if so, there could be no question of anyone "owning" a gene. This issue was addressed over five years ago in an acclaimed report by the Commons' science and technology committee. We recommended that only a combination of a gene and a known utility which is novel should be patentable, and that a combination of the same gene and a further novel utility should also be patentable.

Regrettably neither the present nor the previous governments have acted on that recommendation.
Lynne Jones MP

 The UK patent application you chose to illustrate how scientists "patent life" describes Michael Antoniou as one of the inventors - the same individual who you invited to warn us of the dangers of genetic interference in the agricultural industry during your online GM food debate, some months back. Do some experts believe the genetics revolution is bad for plants but OK for us humans?
David Stirling
London

 You are right to highlight the ethical and moral unacceptability of patenting genes and life. However, your example, of which I am one of the inventors, lays no claim to ownership of any gene. It describes a gene expression system for the industrial production of pharmaceutically important proteins and therefore does not constitute a "patent on life". Such molecular genetic tools are equivalent to building a machine out of metal. You cannot patent the metal because it's a natural product, but you can patent the machine, as it is clearly a new "invention".

Patenting a new gene per se, especially if its function is unknown, is wrong because it is the common property of everyone. It is important to distinguish this from therapeutic and diagnostic tools derived from genetic materials.
Dr Michael Antoniou
Guy's Hospital
michael.antoniou@kcl.ac.uk

But countries whose corporate industries benefit from WTO rules are holding the process back. It is urgent that the UK drives the EU into a positive, united position, which could be crucial to securing agreement. Patrick Mulvany Intermediate Technology Development Group itdg@itdg.org.uk  Intellectual property rights, especially patents, enable global knowledge cartels to coordinate and solve an enforcement problem. Any cartel member faces the problem that another may cheat and try to take more of the market than agreed. Emerging multinationals in the early part of the 20th century turned to intellectual property rights and complex licensing arrangements based on those rights to co-ordinate and enforce global cartels. Patent licences enabled them to group together to fix prices, limit production, divide markets and exclude competitors. The problem of cartel formation by companies previously involved in chemicals or pharmaceuticals and now expanding into biotechnology continues. Witness the anti-trust litigation by US and international farmers against Monsanto, Dow, Du Pont, and Novartis for forming a cartel in the GM corn and soy-bean markets. Unfortunately, the alleged benefits of the biotech revolution will be delivered to consumers at great cost. Intellectual property rules in many ways represent the ultimate conspiracy against the public. Dr Peter Drahos Intellectual property research institute, Queen Mary College P.F.Drahos@qmw.ac.uk  Tim Radford (Patenting Life) poses the question whether two separate groups could patent the same piece of genetic information for two different functions. He rightly points out that if so, there could be no question of anyone "owning" a gene. This issue was addressed over five years ago in an acclaimed report by the Commons' science and technology committee. We recommended that only a combination of a gene and a known utility which is novel should be patentable, and that a combination of the same gene and a further novel utility should also be patentable. Regrettably neither the present nor the previous governments have acted on that recommendation. Lynne Jones MP  The UK patent application you chose to illustrate how scientists "patent life" describes Michael Antoniou as one of the inventors - the same individual who you invited to warn us of the dangers of genetic interference in the agricultural industry during your online GM food debate, some months back. Do some experts believe the genetics revolution is bad for plants but OK for us humans? David Stirling London  You are right to highlight the ethical and moral unacceptability of patenting genes and life. However, your example, of which I am one of the inventors, lays no claim to ownership of any gene. It describes a gene expression system for the industrial production of pharmaceutically important proteins and therefore does not constitute a "patent on life". Such molecular genetic tools are equivalent to building a machine out of metal. You cannot patent the metal because it's a natural product, but you can patent the machine, as it is clearly a new "invention". Patenting a new gene per se, especially if its function is unknown, is wrong because it is the common property of everyone. It is important to distinguish this from therapeutic and diagnostic tools derived from genetic materials. Dr Michael Antoniou Guy's Hospital michael.antoniou@kcl.ac.uk

webTitle: American chip police get their girl

fields.headline: The chip police get their girl
fields.trailText: It was the unexpected call that any law-breaker dreads. The policeman stepped out from his hiding place and said: "Put down your fries."
fields.body:
It was the unexpected call that any law-breaker dreads. The policeman stepped out from his hiding place and said: "Put down your fries."

Ansche Hedgepeth, 12, had never been in trouble. But all that changed when she wandered into a Washington DC underground station last month eating a bag of french fries - and fell victim to "zero tolerance" policing.

Ansche was stopped, searched, handcuffed and arrested by police, who took her to a detention centre where she was fingerprinted and registered for compulsory community service and counselling. All for eating chips.

"We really do believe in zero tolerance," said a defiant Barry McDevitt, chief of the transit police for Washington's Metro, whose officers arrested 35 people during a week-long undercover operation targeting travellers ignoring a ban on eating, drinking and smoking in stations and trains.

When Ansche walked into the Tenleytown station on her way home from school on October 23, she found herself the latest victim of "zero tolerance" which some might now consider a ludicrously disproportionate policy that often ends up focusing on black Americans like her.

Ansche had bought a bag of fries before taking the escalator into the station. As she passed the ticket kiosk with a friend, a man stepped out and told her: "Put down your fries."

The plainclothes officer searched Ansche and asked her whether she had any drugs or alcohol. Then he pulled the laces out of her trainers and handcuffed her before taking her off to the detention centre.

"I can't believe there isn't a better way to teach kids a lesson," said her mother, Tracey.

webTitle: Bosnia's information bill leaves Britain standing

fields.headline: Bosnia's information bill leaves Britain standing
fields.trailText: Potentially embarrassing details of Britain's military, commercial and foreign policy initiatives in Sarajevo look set to be released in Bosnia under a new freedom of information bill that will be more more liberal than anything at home.
fields.body:
Potentially embarrassing details of Britain's military, commercial and foreign policy initiatives in Sarajevo look set to be released in Bosnia under a new freedom of information bill that will be more more liberal than anything at home.

Under the bill, drawn up to help restore democracy in Bosnia, details of troop placements, security issues and war trial investigations will be released to the press and public unless they are seen to cause "substantial harm".

The proposals for the bill come as Britain maintains a significant troop presence and is actively involved in chasing up war criminals in Bosnia.

The Bosnian bill compares with a British law due to be implemented next year which bans the release of information on security interests and severely restricts the release of material on defence and foreign policy.

In Britain, information on commercial deals will be normally withheld if it seen to cause harm. In Bosnia the same information will automatically be released within 15 days - unless a firm explains why it will cause it harm.

The bill is expected to open up details of contracts awarded for the reconstruction of Sarajevo after the Bosnian war. It could also make it easier for corruption to come to light.

The Bosnian bill will ensure that all facts, statistics and scientific and technical advice involved in decision-making will be released. The proposal to introduce a freedom of information bill in Bosnia was put forward by the OSCE but although Britain is part of the OSCE, it has not been consulted on the legislation.

Instead the Bosnians have taken advice from organisations in Britain, including the Campaign for Freedom of Information and Article 19. They have also drawn on models from the US, Sweden, Ireland, Australia, Canada and New Zealand, which have more radical legislation than Britain.

Mike O'Brien, the home office minister, said yesterday: "The constitutional situation in Bosnia is quite different to that of Britain. I would still maintain that our legislation is regarded as one of the most radical in the world."

webTitle: Sleaze case minister forced to quit

fields.headline: Sleaze case minister forced to quit
fields.standfirst: German transport chief shown red card over football club scandal
fields.trailText: The Germany chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, suffered a setback yesterday when his transport minister resigned, three days after a court found him guilty of aiding embezzlement in a corruption scandal involving the illicit funding of a football club.
fields.body:
The Germany chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, suffered a setback yesterday when his transport minister resigned, three days after a court found him guilty of aiding embezzlement in a corruption scandal involving the illicit funding of a football club.

The decision by Reinhard Klimmt, a member of the governing Social Democratic party (SPD), to step down from his cabinet post came less than 24 hours after Mr Schröder had faced down a political storm by backing the minister's declared intention to stay in office and appeal against the conviction in a higher court.

But a media outcry, coupled with protests from his Green coalition partners and from within his own party, evidently forced him to backtrack. In a statement yesterday, Mr Schröder said: "I have great respect for Reinhard Klimmt's decision to resign."

The government named Kurt Bodewig, a transport ministry state secretary, as his successor.

Klimmt was brought into the Schröder government last year, in a move designed to placate leftwing Social Democrats concerned about the government's faltering relationship with Germany's powerful trade unions and its commitment to social justice.

On Monday, a court in the state of Saarland found Klimmt guilty of aiding and abetting embezzlement and fined him DM27,000 (£8,300) .

At the heart of the case is a charity, Caritas Tragergesellschaft Trier (CTT), which racked up losses of more than £6m under a former director.

During an investigation into the charity's affairs, investigators discovered that CTT had been subsidising a local football club, FC Saarbrücken. Under a contract signed in 1997, when Klimmt was club chairman, CTT breached its charitable status by handing over nearly £200,000.

Claims have been made that the charity won favours from the regional administration in return and, in particular, that hospitals run by CTT were protected from budget cuts.

Prosecutors said they could find no evidence that Klimmt, a former head of the regional administration, had misused his influence, and there is no suggestion that he benefited personally from the fraud.

Klimmt at first accepted the court ruling. But on Tuesday he insisted the conviction was based on incomplete evidence and said he would appeal.

The affair has damaged the Social Democrats. Until yesterday they seemed to have captured the moral high ground from the opposition Christian Democrats who are still suffering from the fallout of a funding scandal involving their leading lights, including former chancellor Helmut Kohl.

"The chancellor has got a real problem," said the Christian Democrat general secretary designate, Laurenz Meyer. "He has finally been forced to bow to public pressure, but it's obvious that he knew about this scandal months ago. He could have acted much earlier," he added.

The Klimmt affair has also highlighted a growing rift between the Social Democrats and their Green coalition partners who were among the first to demand the transport minister's immediate resignation.

During a cabinet meeting on Wednesday, Mr Schröder was reported to have accused the Greens of using the affair to "promote themselves at the expense of the SPD". The Greens have recently relaunched themselves as critics of the ruling party, taking Mr Schröder to task over health, immigration and transport reform.

Their criticism was borne out on Wednesday, when independent advisers briefed to report on Germany's economic prospects argued that despite the government's success in disciplining the budget, the rest of its reform programme would fail to make "the desired lasting impression" on the economy "if carried out in its present form".

webTitle: A country diary: Slimbridge, Gloucestershire

fields.headline: Swanning around
fields.standfirst: Slimbridge, Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Slimbridge, Gloucestershire
fields.body:
The message from Claire at the Wildfowl and Wetland Trust HQ at Slimbridge flashed up onscreen in the third week of October. "The Bewick's swans are back," it said. "Come and see them." An invitation from the WWT is always welcome so I arranged a visit. The annual return of the Bewick's swans to their winter quarters here on the lower Severn is one of the dependable avian events of the autumn. Given their long migratory flight from the Siberian tundra, where they spend the summer breeding and rearing their young, it's always a notable day when the first of the autumn returners flies in.

They're tracked across Europe by other national conservation bodies, and a big delay with the main flights of swans occurred this year in the Netherlands where, at several sites, large numbers of swans were held back for some days by persistent south-westerly winds which are a direct head wind on this migratory route. Their yellow facial markings enable staff at the WWT to identify individual birds and the lifelong pairings in which they normally migrate as well as breed. One pair were fitted with back-mounted radio transmitters to permit an even more accurate tracking of their route to be plotted.

We watched from the observation lounge as the 4pm feeding trolley went out. Pochard and pintail and goldeneye dived for their tea. From the fields to the north west, a flight of eight Bewick's swans came in low, in loose formation, to splash down and get their share. More will have arrived by now, and, as the sun lifts in March, they will be off again to the tundra.

webTitle: How Lib Dem lobbyist stays within the rules

fields.headline: How Lib Dem lobbyist stays within the rules
fields.trailText: Lord McNally, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman in the Lords, is also vice-chairman of Shandwick Consultants, a lobbying firm. He could not hold such a post if he was an MP.
fields.body:
Lord McNally, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman in the Lords, is also vice-chairman of Shandwick Consultants, a lobbying firm. He could not hold such a post if he was an MP.

Earlier this year he promoted his own private member's bill to outlaw video, record, and computer piracy, hiring a room at Westminster and inviting fellow peers to hear the case put by the Alliance against Counterfeiting and Piracy.

Lord McNally receives no money from any of the 12 organisations affiliated to the alliance. But beneficiaries of his bill would also have included a number of his Shandwick clients, such as the BBC and the French group Vivendi, owners of Canal Plus and part owners of BSkyB.

When Lord McNally introduced his bill in the Lords he explained what the alliance was and declared the fact that he was president of the British Radio and Electronic Equipment Manufacturers Association, which has called for severe penalties for counterfeiters. But he did not mention his role with Shandwick. The bill has been withdrawn but ministers are considering measures that will replace Lord McNally's bill, probably after the next election. It could be argued that his bill has influenced government policy.

Mr McNally said yesterday that his promotion of the bill was "a matter of judgment.

"I can assure you I was not paid by any members of the alliance. As for Shandwick clients, we have 2,000 clients and it may have been that one of two would have benefited from this. But they were not involved in any of the discussions about the bill and probably did even not know about it being promoted."

He has registered Shandwick's client list in the Lords, which will become mandatory under Lord Neill's proposals. He welcomed the decision to allow peers to keep lobbying jobs, because unlike MPs their parliamentary work was unpaid. "I would be out of a job otherwise," he said.

webTitle: Obituary: Brian Boydell

fields.headline: Brian Boydell
fields.standfirst: Gifted musical polymath who bridged a generation in Irish arts
fields.trailText: Brian Boydell, the Irish composer and academic who has died aged 83, epitomised a transitional generation in his country's arts, something like that between WB Yeats and Seamus Heaney in the world of poetry. An Anglo-Irish Protestant (with a middle name commemorating his birth on St Patrick's day), and a firm pacifist, he felt particular pride in being chosen, in 1966, to compose the official cantata to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the 1916 Easter Rising.
fields.body:
Brian Boydell, the Irish composer and academic who has died aged 83, epitomised a transitional generation in his country's arts, something like that between WB Yeats and Seamus Heaney in the world of poetry. An Anglo-Irish Protestant (with a middle name commemorating his birth on St Patrick's day), and a firm pacifist, he felt particular pride in being chosen, in 1966, to compose the official cantata to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the 1916 Easter Rising.

Born in Dublin to a well-known maltster, James Boydell, and his wife, Eileen Collins, who was among the first women graduates of Dublin University, Boydell was educated at Rugby school, where he played the solo part of Rachmaninov's second piano concerto, and was organ scholar at Clare College, Cambridge, where he obtained a first-class science degree.

He studied composition (with Herbert Howells and Ralph Vaughan Williams) and oboe at the Royal College of Music. He joined the family firm, but soon left to teach art and science at Ireland's leading public school, St Columba's College, Dublin, and then to freelance as composer, singer, oboist, conductor, teacher, lecturer and broadcaster - in all of which he was outstanding. From 1944 to 1948, he was professor of singing at the Royal Irish Academy of Music, which subsequently awarded him an honorary fellowship.

In 1962, he became professor of music at Trinity College, Dublin, where, hitherto, all musical degrees had been external. He rapidly created a full, internal degree syllabus that commanded academic respect at home and abroad. This was a major turnaround in the fortunes of third-level musical education in Ireland.

As a performer, Boydell loved to direct madrigals; he, and seven like-minded friends, sang and recorded Renaissance music with international renown as the Dowland Consort from 1959-70.

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Boydell was regarded as the composer laureate of Ireland, with many commissions and calls to serve in consultative roles, including several terms on the Irish Arts Council. Always a romantic, he had grown up in the anti-romantic 1930s, when Webern and Bartok were avant-garde, and the Dolmetsches were pioneers of early music. In those days, Bloch, Berg, Prokofiev, Sibelius were modern and great influences.

Boydell's music has a definite persona; it is international and, at the same time, distinctively Irish, without striving after Irishness. His major works include three quartets, a Violin Concerto (1953), which (alongside Frederick May's string quartet) was arguably one of the two most important works composed in 20th-century Ireland; the highly-charged and motivated In Memoriam Mahatma Gandhi (1948), still played and appreciated for its political undertones; Symphonic Inscapes (1968), a major or chestral work of considerable distinction; Richard's Riot (1961), for virtuoso percussion and orchestra; and many choral works. One of his own favourite pieces was Masai Mara (1988), written after a family holiday in Kenya, and evoking the sounds and sights of the Africa.

After retirement in 1982, Boydell devoted his scholarly activity to the detailed history of music in Dublin, especially the charity performances at the pleasure grounds of the Rotunda lying-in hospital, publishing A Dublin Musical Calendar: 1700-1760 (1988) and Rotunda Music In 18th-Century Dublin (1992).

He had the ability to excel in whatever he turned his mind to - photography, alpine gardening, tinkering and hill-climbing with old Bugattis, and a pursuit with which he was not usually associated, painting. He exhibited with the important White Stag group, largely composed of conscientious objectors who had moved to Ireland during the second world war, and in the Irish Exhibition of Living Art.

A man fired with great enthusiasms, Boydell said he was interested in everything except horseracing and team games, particularly rejecting the false camaraderie of the latter. His enthusiasms were especially evident in his educational activities, which included voluntary work in schools for the Music Association of Ireland, and a popular series of television broadcasts for the fledgling Telefis Eireann service.

In the early 1990s, he inaugurated extra-mural classes for a non-musical public at the Royal Irish Academy of Music; these were heavily over-subscribed, such was the appeal of this apparently patrician but, in reality, utterly prepossessing man.

He leaves his wife, Mary, and two sons; a third son predeceased him.

 Brian Patrick Boydell, composer, teacher and writer, born March 17 1917; died November 8 2000

 Richard Pine has revised this notice by Charles Acton, who died in 1999
