He joined the family firm, but soon left to teach art and science at Ireland's leading public school, St Columba's College, Dublin, and then to freelance as composer, singer, oboist, conductor, teacher, lecturer and broadcaster - in all of which he was outstanding. From 1944 to 1948, he was professor of singing at the Royal Irish Academy of Music, which subsequently awarded him an honorary fellowship. In 1962, he became professor of music at Trinity College, Dublin, where, hitherto, all musical degrees had been external. He rapidly created a full, internal degree syllabus that commanded academic respect at home and abroad. This was a major turnaround in the fortunes of third-level musical education in Ireland. As a performer, Boydell loved to direct madrigals; he, and seven like-minded friends, sang and recorded Renaissance music with international renown as the Dowland Consort from 1959-70. Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Boydell was regarded as the composer laureate of Ireland, with many commissions and calls to serve in consultative roles, including several terms on the Irish Arts Council. Always a romantic, he had grown up in the anti-romantic 1930s, when Webern and Bartok were avant-garde, and the Dolmetsches were pioneers of early music. In those days, Bloch, Berg, Prokofiev, Sibelius were modern and great influences. Boydell's music has a definite persona; it is international and, at the same time, distinctively Irish, without striving after Irishness. His major works include three quartets, a Violin Concerto (1953), which (alongside Frederick May's string quartet) was arguably one of the two most important works composed in 20th-century Ireland; the highly-charged and motivated In Memoriam Mahatma Gandhi (1948), still played and appreciated for its political undertones; Symphonic Inscapes (1968), a major or chestral work of considerable distinction; Richard's Riot (1961), for virtuoso percussion and orchestra; and many choral works. One of his own favourite pieces was Masai Mara (1988), written after a family holiday in Kenya, and evoking the sounds and sights of the Africa. After retirement in 1982, Boydell devoted his scholarly activity to the detailed history of music in Dublin, especially the charity performances at the pleasure grounds of the Rotunda lying-in hospital, publishing A Dublin Musical Calendar: 1700-1760 (1988) and Rotunda Music In 18th-Century Dublin (1992). He had the ability to excel in whatever he turned his mind to - photography, alpine gardening, tinkering and hill-climbing with old Bugattis, and a pursuit with which he was not usually associated, painting. He exhibited with the important White Stag group, largely composed of conscientious objectors who had moved to Ireland during the second world war, and in the Irish Exhibition of Living Art. A man fired with great enthusiasms, Boydell said he was interested in everything except horseracing and team games, particularly rejecting the false camaraderie of the latter. His enthusiasms were especially evident in his educational activities, which included voluntary work in schools for the Music Association of Ireland, and a popular series of television broadcasts for the fledgling Telefis Eireann service. In the early 1990s, he inaugurated extra-mural classes for a non-musical public at the Royal Irish Academy of Music; these were heavily over-subscribed, such was the appeal of this apparently patrician but, in reality, utterly prepossessing man. He leaves his wife, Mary, and two sons; a third son predeceased him.  Brian Patrick Boydell, composer, teacher and writer, born March 17 1917; died November 8 2000  Richard Pine has revised this notice by Charles Acton, who died in 1999

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Paedophile namer in court
fields.body:
Paedophile namer in court

Stuart Carnie, 37, from Aberdeen, who was criticised by police and children's charities this week over his plans to name and shame paedophiles on the internet, is due to appear before Durham crown court today charged with conspiring to abduct a girl, 11.

Murder inquiry resurrected

Police were last night questioning a man, 28, in connection with the murder of Helen Fleet, 66, of Weston-super-Mare 13 years ago. New witnesses came forward after the case was on television in September.

Potholer missing

Rescue teams have been unable to find a potholer, a 49-year-old man from north Lancashire, who went missing five days ago in one of the most dangerous cave systems, extending from Cumbria to North Yorkshire.

Internet fan dies online

An internet fan died after suffering a heart attack while on a chatline, despite a rescue operation by online friends in America. Using the internet, they contacted a friend in the UK who phoned police after Derek Hall, 60, of Dunstable, Bedfordshire, collapsed.

Cannabis case must wait

A judge ruled yesterday that a Rastafarian charged with supplying cannabis must wait until December to learn if he can have his case reconsidered under the new Human Rights Act. Rasta Brown, 39, claims he is entitled to sell and smoke marijuana because it is part of Rastafarianism, which has protection under the new act.

EasyJet threat to golf company

John Gibbons, who has started an internet golf company called easygolf.co.uk is being threatened with legal action by the cutprice airline easyJet. The airline says it owns the word "easy" when it is used with a small e and is part of a business name.

Reaction force head named

A German general, Lieutenant-General Klaus Schuwirth, has been appointed to head the European Union's new military staff which will run the proposed joint European rapid reaction force, it was disclosed yesterday.

Anti-smoking guidance

Government watchdogs on medicines are to prepare guidance for GPs on the use of anti-smoking treatments including Zyban pills, nicotine patches, gum and nasal sprays. The national institute for clinical excellence will compare their cost and clinical effectiveness to help sharpen the campaign to reduce smoking rates, cancer and heart disease.

PC impaled on stake

A policeman died after falling off a wall and impaling himself on a garden stake, an inquest in Kettering heard yesterday. PC Glen Hitches, 39, from East Carlton, in Northamptonshire, was off duty at the time of the accident on August 4.

Russ Conway dies at 75

Pianist Russ Conway, 75, one of the Queen Mother's favourite entertainers, died last night at Eastbourne district general hospital, East Sussex, after losing his battle with cancer, his publicist, John Lloyd, announced. He had been suffering from stomach cancer which had spread to his brain.

Hamster killer jailed

Anthony Sharman, 27, of Bungay, Suffolk, who stabbed his former girlfriend's pet hamster to death and then posted it to her, was jailed for five months yesterday by Lowestoft magistrates.

webTitle: Obituary: Sandra Schmitt

fields.headline: Sandra Schmitt
fields.standfirst: Freestyle skiing champion cheated of Olympic chance
fields.trailText: Sandra Schmitt, the 19-year-old German world freestyle skiing champion, who was killed in the mountain railway fire at the Kitzsteinhorn near Kaprun, Austria, was on course to becoming an Olympic champion in the home of the sport.
fields.body:
Sandra Schmitt, the 19-year-old German world freestyle skiing champion, who was killed in the mountain railway fire at the Kitzsteinhorn near Kaprun, Austria, was on course to becoming an Olympic champion in the home of the sport.

Salt Lake City, Utah, which stages the 2002 Winter Olympics, may not be the state in which freestyle began; that was California in the late 1960s and 70s. But the United States pioneered that freewheeling form of aerials, ballet and moguls, in the last of which she excelled. Today, no US piste is without a section known as moguls, or bumps.

It is a product of smooth pistes, which become rucked up by repeated passage of skiers, and are then a challenge in themselves, especially for young legs and the challenge of being thrown high in the air if a mistake is made at speed. The International Skiing Federation was slow to become involved, and freestyle only made its entry as an Olympic exhibition event at Calgary in 1988.

Schmitt, from Morfelden, near Frankfurt, was then only seven years old, but her parents were keen skiers. In 1994, a German Ski Association trainer told them she could make a top racer. She showed her aptitude for skiing down 250 yards of bumps at writhing speed, and making the pair of jumps necessary to impress the five judges of her courage and skill - as well as her pace.

Two years ago, the athletes, Schmitt among them, decided the sport was going nowhere with the International Ski Federation - and they might go it alone. A compromise was established under which the half and full pipes of snowboarding were introduced for racers on two skis, and big-air acrobatic programmes - that gave the athletes more challenge while keeping insurance premiums to a minimum - would be tried.

To gain TV exposure and sponsorship, shorter courses would be set at the bottom of runs close to village centres, attracting, they hoped, a bigger public. Schmitt was one of the female skiers who would get star treatment - she excelled at "dual mogul", where racers go head-to-head down side-by-side courses. In 1997, aged 16, she gained sixth place in moguls and second in duals in the Europa Cup, or B level, of freestyle.

In 1998, she was in the German team for the Nagano Winter Olympics, finishing ninth. The following year was take-off, with a gold medal in the European Youth Championship moguls and, in the World Cup, 12th in moguls and fifth in the duals, including her first victory, at Steamboat Springs, Colorado. Then, to some surprise, but not her own, in Meiringen, Switzerland, she won the world championship dual moguls, and gained fifth in the moguls itself.

In 1999-2000, the promise came to further fruition. In moguls she won Deer Valley, Colorado, Madarao, Japan, and Livigno, Italy. In duals, she won again in Madarao, and, overall, was third in each discipline. More than 5,000 Japanese fans cheered her double in Madarao."Yes, it's a steep course, but I feel that I am never skiing too fast," she said. "I am always in control."

She finished the World Cup overall standings in third place, both in moguls and dual moguls, in spite of missing events because of schooling. Earlier this month, she heard she was top of the International Skiing Federation's dual slalom seeding list, which, for the forthcoming season, would have much helped her progress. On the day of her fatal ascent, she told Tatjana Mittermayer, a former German Olympic freestyle champion, that she would be joining her after some free skiing with her parents.

Training has proved difficult this season, with rain, snow and high winds. Four juniors from the Alpine sport school in Chiemgau, and two trainers, including Franz Ferstl, whose brother, Sepp, once won the Kitzbuehel downhill, were with her. So were four members of an Austrian hard-of-hearing racing squad. None was among the survivors.

 Sandra Schmitt, skier, born April 26 1981; died November 11 2000

webTitle: Richard Norton-Taylor on military intelligence

fields.headline: **** you too, pal
fields.standfirst:
I thought I'd won my struggle against the military asterisk

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Richard Norton-Taylor:I thought I'd won my struggle against the military asterisk.
fields.body:
Eight months ago, the Commons defence committee published a heavily censored report on military intelligence. It contained so many asterisks signifying information the Ministry of Defence insisted must be kept secret that much of it was unintelligible.

The committee accused the MoD of being excessively secretive and censoring information about British intelligence cooperation with the US which Washington freely reveals. For example, the MoD refused even to disclose under what treaty US spy planes are allowed to fly from British bases.

The Guardian took up the challenge. We asked the ministry under the code of open government introduced by John Major's administration (a code more liberal than Labour's freedom of information bill) if it would release at least some of the information it insisted must remain officially secret (including information since released by Washington and Nato about the number of tanks it did, or did not, destroy in Kosovo).

In an episode which would have delighted Kafka, MoD officials decided to claim they could not release the information since the committee had agreed to suppress it. Once evidence is provided to a Commons committee it becomes subject to "parliamentary privilege", we were told. It was therefore up to the committee and not the MoD to decide whether and how it was published. "I hope that explains the position," an MoD official responsible for "efficiency and machinery of government" said helpfully.

In July, the clerk of the committee passed the ball back to the ministry. "I have been instructed by the committee," he told the MoD, "to inform you that, for its part, it would be entirely happy to place in the public domain any evidence in its possession which the MoD itself is wiling to have released."

The committee eventually recorded (dryly): "After a somewhat drawn-out exchange of correspondence between this committee, the MoD and Mr Norton-Taylor, the MoD did review its classification and derestricted some further information."

This week the committee published a special report - the first time a Commons committee has taken such an initiative following a request by the media.

Was it worth it? Hardly. The MoD has agreed to disclose part of an answer given by Group Captain Stephen Lloyd, who was asked how dependent the ministry was on military intelligence provided by the US.

We are now allowed to know that Lloyd told the committee that Britain's military intelligence relationship with the US "dates back to the period of 1943. So it is a very strong and very long relationship."

He adds: "***."

We are still not allowed to know officially what kind of intelligence we provide to the US. A question to Lloyd about that remains ***. Yet it is widely known that we give the US a broad range of intelligence, not least through the electronic eavesdropping agency GCHQ, and US intelligence bases in Britain.

A GCHQ staff manual, reported in this newspaper in 1994, noted that the agency's contribution to the UK-US relationship must be "of sufficient scale and of the right kind to make a continuation of the Sigint [signals intelligence] alliance worthwhile to our partners". It added: "This may entail on occasion the applying of UK resources to the meeting of US requirements."

The special report also allows us to know that, according to Air Vice Marshal Joe French, the EU's plans for a common defence and security policy could affect the flow of US intelligence to Britain. Or, as he put it, far from illuminatingly, that is "inevitably one of the aspects that will need to be resolved."

Otherwise, the report remains studded with asterisks. And the MoD still refuses to disclose under what treaty US spy planes are allowed to fly from British bases.

In some passages, the interplay of MPs' successive questions, which were not deleted, and the answers, which were, render the asterisks otiose.

"Does the US make available any of the material that it gives to you to any other Nato ally?"

Lloyd: "***."

Would US intelligence be available in an operation where the Americans were not involved?

French: "***."

The questions turned to Kosovo. "Were we, the UK, in any way responsible for the targeting errors that related to the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade?"

French: "***."

Why the coyness? Has not the CIA admitted its mistake?

French was also asked whether RAF reconnaissance planes were asked to look for tanks and other targets. This remains secret. The questioning continued: "We saw them but we did not tell anyone?"

French: "***".

"Were they targeted?"

Lloyd: "***".

Then comes the climax. "We should not believe what we are told," concludes a member of the committee.

"***," replies Lloyd.

webTitle: Driver charged over tour bus deaths

fields.headline: Driver charged over tour bus deaths
fields.trailText: The driver of a coach which crashed in South Africa killing 27 mostly elderly British tourists and their tour guide a year ago has been charged with manslaughter after police concluded that his claims that the brakes failed were false.
fields.body:
The driver of a coach which crashed in South Africa killing 27 mostly elderly British tourists and their tour guide a year ago has been charged with manslaughter after police concluded that his claims that the brakes failed were false.

Titus Dube, 41, will appear in court in a fortnight to answer charges of culpable homicide and reckless driving after the coach plunged off the Long Tom pass, a winding mountain road near the town of Lydenburg.

The vehicle rolled at least once as its roof was ripped off and passengers were flung up to 20 metres away.

Twenty seven people were killed instantly and nine others were injured. Mr Dube, who fractured his spine and broke a leg in the accident, told the police that a red light was flashing on his dashboard and his brakes failed.

But investigators were immediately suspicious of the claim because skid marks almost 50 metres long next to where the bus plunged off the ravine.

They said the marks suggested the brakes had been applied and that the coach was travelling at high speed in an area where the limit was 60 km per hour.

An investigation showed that the light was related to an air conditioning problem and there was no discernible fault with the brakes. Police said the four year-old British-made luxury bus was well maintained and had been fully serviced four days before the accident.

Witnesses reported that the bus was travelling at high speed through a number of villages on the road to Lydenburg, and another driver said the coach had forced his car off the road.

Mr Dube's employer, Springbok Atlas, initially stood by him by pointing to his 20-year exemplary service record and describing him as a "model employee". But it fell silent after the tour operator, Thomas Cook Holidays, blamed the driver for the crash. The accident led president Thabo Mbeki to order a cabinet review of transportation policies which resulted in the lowering of the speed limit for buses and new standards inthe testing of public transport vehicles.

About 10,000 people die each year on South African roads.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Teenage Express columnist Kathryn Knight, who recently posed the challenging question "Were the Beatles really that good?" (yes, they were) hits top form again. "Did anyone actually bother to watch the last-ever episode of Inspector Morse last night?" she asks yesterday. Well, yes, Kathryn, they did. Just over 13m people, or 51.5% of the viewing population, watched, making it ITV's most popular weekday drama in nearly four years.
fields.body:
 Teenage Express columnist Kathryn Knight, who recently posed the challenging question "Were the Beatles really that good?" (yes, they were) hits top form again. "Did anyone actually bother to watch the last-ever episode of Inspector Morse last night?" she asks yesterday. Well, yes, Kathryn, they did. Just over 13m people, or 51.5% of the viewing population, watched, making it ITV's most popular weekday drama in nearly four years.

 Portcullis House, the MPs' office block, was built for just £230m, so there were bound to be problems. Yesterday the entrance atrium's water pools began leaking onto the floor below. Thankfully, the atrium's 12 ornamental fig trees, which cost £150,000, are unharmed.

 Fresh from helping Jill Dando detectives with their inquiries, Alastair Campbell extended his old journalistic gradations (Guardian staff are, with two exceptions, either Trots or wankers) yesterday, when during a lunch address to the press gallery he described Boris the Jackal Johnson as "one mean sonofabitch". Ali claims that the Jackal was so desperate for him to write for the Spectator - he once allegedly told him "I'm a Tory candidate, I know we're not going to win. Can you imagine Hague as PM?" - that he even threatened to unleash Benji the Binman Pell on his bins. "Bollocks," says an unfamiliar voice when we call the Jackal's office to check the allegations. "That's B.O.L.L..."

 You can't keep the Goldhawk Road out of it at the minute. Within a week of Lord Michael Henderson revealing it as home of my capacious-arsed waddling, I hear the road mentioned again in the brilliant new production of the Caretaker, directed by Patrick Marber, at the Comedy Theatre. Has anyone ever wondered how heavily Galton and Simpson were influenced by the play when a few years after Pinter's play appeared, they came to house Steptoe And Son off the Goldhawk?

webTitle: Carat wins Vodafone's European media

fields.headline: Carat wins Vodafone's European media
fields.trailText: 8am Vodafone Group has appointed Carat International to its pan-European media planning account, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Vodafone Group has appointed Carat International to its pan-European media planning account.

The win is an enormous one for Carat as Vodafone spends some £41m on advertising in the UK alone.

The move will come as a considerable blow to OMD UK, Vodafone's UK media agency, which was understood to have pitched for the business alongside Universal McCann and Mindshare.

Existing local agencies will continue to buy the campaigns by country while Carat International will handle the European media planning and the buying of international media.

The selection follows the appointment last month of McCann Erickson as Vodafone's first global advertising agency.

McCann and Carat will now work together as Vodafone makes its transition to a single global brand.

Thomas Geitner, Vodafone Group's executive board director responsible for global branding, said: "The appointment of our first European media planning agency is part of our strategy to establish a strong global brand and position ourselves as the world's leading mobile multimedia company.

"We chose Carat International because of its imaginative media selection and its plans for a branding campaign as well as its robust network and strong team."

Vodafone purchased the £105bn German telecoms company Mannesman last year.

It also paid £4.4bn for a UK mobile phone licence in May and continues to bid for other European licences.

fields.headline: Russ Conway
fields.standfirst: Accident-prone piano star ill at ease with popular fame
fields.trailText: The honky-tonk pianist and composer Russ Conway, who has died of cancer aged 75, enjoyed a great British chart success in the late 1950s and early 1960s. His biggest hit was Side Saddle (1959). He emerged during a hiatus in popular music, before exportable British rock took hold, that produced a clutch of successful piano players, including Winifred Atwell and Liberace, who, along with Conway, were to influence the work of Elton John in later decades.

The honky-tonk pianist and composer Russ Conway, who has died of cancer aged 75, enjoyed a great British chart success in the late 1950s and early 1960s. His biggest hit was Side Saddle (1959). He emerged during a hiatus in popular music, before exportable British rock took hold, that produced a clutch of successful piano players, including Winifred Atwell and Liberace, who, along with Conway, were to influence the work of Elton John in later decades.

Conway was a particular favourite. Tall, anonymously handsome and with shining white teeth - this at a time when complicated bridgework was largely a stranger to British dentistry - he had a particular appeal to women. He sold more than 30m records, had 17 consecutive top-20 hits, his own television shows, mansions, Bentleys and Rolls-Royces. He was always embarrassed at being compared to Liberace, the white-fur-coated and smirking American pianist.

In fact, Conway's and Liberace's music and lifestyles were quite different. It was not just Conway's looks that set him apart from the flamboyant American; his piano style was leaner, firmer and less pretentious, less nakedly appealing to blue-rinsed ladies. His glissandi were no less confident, but less self-indulgent, and he was equally as sure when handling A Nightingale Sang In Berkeley Square as Tiger Rag.

His lifestyle, too, though at one time luxurious by the cramped style of the times, was less pretentious, not reliant on screaming clothes; Conway favoured plain dark suits and ties, more in line with his humble background. Nor was he a natural in meeting the extravagant demands of showmanship, which, as a shy man, he always found stressful.

Throughout his life, he was prone to illnesses and accidents, which he saw as his body's reaction against the tyranny of the piano. He fell, broke a hip and was paralysed for several days; he had strokes; he sliced off the top of a finger with a bread-slicer - something which, ironically, became a Conway signature as television cameras zoomed into his hands on the keyboard - and he smoked up to 80 untipped cigarettes a day.

Close on 70 years of age, he jammed a finger in the door of his Rolls-Royce, but he never agreed with the pundits who pensioned him off. A few months later in Bristol, he was busy entertaining a belated 50th anniversary tea-dance to celebrate Victory in Europe Day, where he nonchalantly peeled off the bandage from his wounded finger before attacking the keys.

Born in Bristol as Trevor Stanford, the name he retained for his composing work, Conway was the son of a mother who died when he was 14, but who had been an amateur pianist and contralto in her day. Unlike his two brothers, who had musical education but no talent, Conway had virtually no musical education, apart from a single boyhood lesson. His clerical-worker father put his son through secretarial college after the boy left school at 14, and then got him a job as a solicitor's clerk. But, at 16, Conway made for the Merchant Navy training school and his first passage, on a Dutch freighter.

During the second world war, he earned the distinguished service medal in the Royal Navy for "gallantry and devotion to duty" in mine-sweeping in the Mediterranean. After four years in the RN, his long-running stomach ulcer saw him invalided out. The end of the war found him see-sawing between the Merchant Navy and dead-end jobs as a salesman, plumber's mate and barman.

Then a friend suggested he stand in for a holidaying club pianist. He played in pubs and clubs, and was seen by the choreographer Irving Davies, who was so impressed that he asked him to play piano for stars at rehearsals. He worked for Dennis Lotis, Dorothy Squires and Gracie Fields. But it was when Conway made it to the Billy Cotton Band Show, a fixture on BBC radio and television in the 1950s and early 1960s, that the rumbustious bandleader persuaded him to loosen up his playing, and helped create the disciplined freedom of the mature Conway style.

It was not playing but composing that indirectly led him to fame. A musical he had written for the comedian Frankie Howerd, Mr Venus, was a write-off, but it led him to writing the score for a TV musical, Beauty And The Beast. For it, he had to write a last-minute tune for one brief scene set in a ballroom. Sitting in the rehearsal room, Conway wrote 16 bars as an olde-world gavotte and scribbled "Side Saddle" beside it in the margin.

Though it was to become virtually his signature tune, the music industry was, at first, blind to the piece's potential. A publisher took all Conway's music for Beauty And The Beast - except Side Saddle, which he dismissed as "too old-fashioned". Another publisher, after its writer had honky-tonked it up, did not agree. Soon, Conway was a national figure, and China Tea, Roulette and Snowcoach followed.

In 1960, when he had his first television show, Russ Conway And A Few Friends, he was reputed to be earning £500 a week, then a huge sum, in record and sheet sales alone. He became an instantly recognisable face and sound, while the media found him politely evasive when discussing anything except his work. He moved from a basement flat in Maida Vale, where he personally answered his fan mail, to a mansion, where three full-timers did the job.

The music promoter who had called him "an atrocious pianist" was in a minority, but symbolised the stress Conway felt he was under. The stomach ulcer returned. In 1963, he had a nervous breakdown while playing at Scarborough, and then fell and fractured a hip, leaving him paralysed for three days; two years later, at only 38, he had the first of his strokes.

He had several times to give up playing, but never had to give up composing. He and his compositions were heard at seaside resorts and at theatres, including the London Palladium, long after his records had vanished from the charts.

At 65, Conway discovered he had cancer. Noting that others waiting to see specialists were either talkative and confident of surviving or silent and morose, he resolved to be part of the former group - and succeeded for many years. He lived on in Eastbourne and never married.

webTitle: Euro message lost as ministers get jitters

fields.headline: Euro message lost as ministers get jitters
fields.standfirst:
Insistence that veto will not be yielded in key areas is drowned out
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair braces himself for next month's European summit in Nice ministers are showing signs of jitters. It is hardly surprising that they are.
fields.body:
As Tony Blair braces himself for next month's European summit in Nice ministers are showing signs of jitters. It is hardly surprising that they are.

Public hostility to things European, above all the euro, deepens rather than subsides. William Hague and his zealous team can issue 26 pages of Euro-attack on ministerial speeches before those speeches are even delivered, as they did on Monday. They think it is their best election card.

Mr Blair made a speech on global inter-dependence at the Mansion House in the City (that is what his spin doctors said it was about in advance). But Mr Cook also made a speech attacking "Euro-myths" on straight bananas and cucumbers as well as negative press reporting. The media duly dubbed it a new campaign on Europe, though both stressed nothing had changed.

Ministers repeatedly try to sell a positive message on Europe. Mr Blair calls them in privately to instruct them to do so. The message gets drowned out by what is often near-hysterical xenophobia. So do genuine questions about the future of the EU which ministers ought to answer. Barely a day passes without what Harold Macmillan famously called "events, dear boy, events" conspiring to ambush the government. They come from all directions, including well intentioned, pro-European ministers like Robin Cook and Peter Mandelson

This week should have been a quiet one on the euro-front, at least in public. As usual in the run-up to such a meeting Mr Blair had a video conference with President Jacques Chirac of France, another yesterday with his socialist premier, Lionel Jospin. He later dined at No 10 with Chancellor Schroder of Germany on a flying visit.

But he also faced a flurry of media headlines generated by speeches made by Mr Cook and after-dinner remarks by Mr Mandelson. Yesterday there was a report by a Labour-dominated select committee about the cost (much exaggerated) of preparing to join the euro, the day before a gratuitous suggestion by Germany's foreign minister, Joska Fischer, that the time is coming when EU voters will elect Romano Prodi's successor as president of the European commission.

The malevolence and ignorance of parts of the media on this subject cannot be exaggerated. But the awkward fact is that Martin O'Neill's select committee did indeed suggest that euro conversion might cost £35bn. Mr Fischer did shoot his mouth off.

The brutal fact is that the agenda for Nice is about little or none of the above. It chiefly concerns that so-called "Amsterdam left-overs," the issues unresolved when EU leaders met in June 1997 - and Tony Blair won the bicycle race at his first summit.

They are about how to make the EU work more efficiently and take decisions more quickly in readiness for the day - long postponed - when the first of 15 applicant countries, led by Poland and the Czech republic, start to turn the EU 15 into 20 or even 30 members.

That means altering three things:

 the number of commissioners, so that not every state automatically has one except those which currently have two, including Britain;

 the way the council of ministers, the dominant force in the EU at present, counts its votes. Luxembourg with 400,000 people currently has two votes in council, Germany with 80m has 10;

 trickiest of all, there is the need to reduce the number of topics on which the national veto is exercised, to expedite decision making because 30 vetos would be a nightmare.

It is dangerous for Mr Blair precisely because it allows the Sun or Daily Mail to say Britain is poised to "give up the veto on 40 issues", as the Mail did yesterday.

It did not help that the French EU presidency's working text for Nice, which surfaced in Whitehall yesterday, persists in wanting to curb the national veto on sensitive tax matters like VAT, excise duties and the anti-fraud "withholding tax".

Labour has made clear it wants more majority voting (ie no veto) on many issues, such as the environment. But it will not yield on the five big issues of tax, social security, treaty changes, defence and border controls.

There is no reason to think that it will.

webTitle: TheStreet hits dead end in UK

fields.headline: TheStreet hits dead end in UK
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: TheStreet.co.uk yesterday joined the growing number of dot.com casualties when the website's US parent closed the business to help protect its own financial position.
fields.byline: David Teather  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
TheStreet.co.uk yesterday joined the growing number of dot.com casualties when the website's US parent closed the business to help protect its own financial position.

At around 3pm the UK website dispatched its final e-mail to users, replacing updates on events in the City with a farewell message: "It's another internet collapse." All 64 staff will lose their jobs, including editor Nils Pratley who had joined from Sunday Business.

The closure came after months of negotiations between management of the site and investors. The site had eaten its way through around £9.6m since launch in February and was burning £350,000 a month. It would have run out of cash at the end of the year.

Staff at the site were incensed. "People are furious with the US," said one. "We made every financial target they set us. We are particularly disgusted that no one from the US even turned up to justify or explain their decision."

In the grand tradition of Fleet Street, the majority of the staff made their way to the pub after the announcement, although with a dot.com twist, it was Smiths, a trendy bar in Smithfield.

Sources said venture capital investors led by Chase Capital Partners and Barclays Private Equity were keen to inject further funds but had been unable to agree terms with TheStreet.com, which held 63% of the venture.

TheStreet.com, under press-ure from its own shareholders, decided to buy out the UK investors for $3m and 1.25m shares, and close the site.

The move was part of a wider cost-cutting exercise at TheStreet.com, which announced 40 job losses from its US operation. Thomas Clarke, chief executive, said closure of the UK operations and the US job cuts would save about $18m a year. "In today's environment companies have two clear choices: chart a path to profitability or shut down. We're in this for the long haul."

Claudia Jay, managing director of the UK site, stressed that the closure would be orderly and staff would receive payment for their full notice periods plus a redundancy sum.

"I'm really, really sad because I'm immensely proud of what we have created. It was a really high quality site and had a lot of users who liked it."

Investors had come "very close" to doing a deal that would have provided funding to keep operating.

The UK site was making £200,000 a month in advertising revenues and £50,000 from other sources including syndication.

TheStreet.com believes the retrenchment combined with its $90m in cash will allow it to survive the downturn in internet stocks. Dave Kansas, editor-in-chief, said: "We believe this puts us in good stead to get through to the other side. It was a very difficult choice to make."

At yesterday's share price of just over $3, TheStreet.com was valued at $85.4m, less than the $90m in the bank at the end of the third quarter.

Few buyers have materialised since the company appointed Wasserstein Perella, the investment bank, to look for partners in January.

webTitle: Prisons chief under fire from MPs

fields.headline: Prisons chief under fire from MPs
fields.standfirst:
Disastrous action seen as an attempt to punish a liberal regime
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, was yesterday accused by the home affairs select committee of giving MPs misleading answers about the decision to mount a disastrous 80-strong raid on the Blantyre House prison last May.
fields.body:
The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, was yesterday accused by the home affairs select committee of giving MPs misleading answers about the decision to mount a disastrous 80-strong raid on the Blantyre House prison last May.

Sir Martin was one of a series of senior prison officers who failed to give accurate accounts of their role in the raid, seen by some as an attempt to punish the liberal regime run at the prison for resettling offenders.

The committee called for a complete overhaul of the prison service, including an end to self-inspection of prison service management. The proposal is likely to be spurned by the Home Office which mounted a strong defence of Mr Narey, claiming he had acted in good faith and on the basis of intelligence.

The report, revealing a battle throughout the prison service management between liberals and traditionalists, was being described yesterday as one of the most important into the prison service for a decade.

It is expected that the report will lead to a stronger policy in favour of resettlement prisons, edging convicts into the community, a policy already being examined by the Home Office and the performance and innovation unit from the Cabinet Office.

The commitee of MPs, including rightwing Conservatives, yesterday described the raid in May as disproprtionate, damaging and unjustified. The MPs asserted the night raid by over 80 officers from other prisons - some in riot gear - had destroyed the atmosphere of trust at the resettlement prison which has one of the lowest reoffending rates in the country.

Named serving prisoners, unusually, cross-examined by the committee, condemn the new atmosphere at the prison. They alleged that during the raid they were strip-searched, deliberately provoked, and that innocent financial documents were portrayed as sufficiently improper as to warrant their removal to special segregation units.

The committee also concluded that Mr Narey misled the committee and the public in his evidence by claiming the raid had found "a quite frightening amount of contraband".

A parliamentary written answer three weeks after the search alleged 98 finds of unauthorised articles, but was misleading since most of the supposed unauthorised items had been returned.

Mr Narey also told the committee the raid had caused £400 worth of damage, but subsequently felt compelled to correct the figure to £6,100.

Internal reports prepared by the prison service into the raid lacked independence from the chain of command and rigour of approach, the MPs found.

The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, was also condemned for failing to ask the chief inspector of prisons to investigate the raid.

The report alleged that the raid was being planned by area prison staff two days be fore the home secretary, Jack Straw, wrote to the select committee to reassure them that Blantyre's future was secure.

Mr Straw refused to condemn Mr Narey yesterday and said prison service staff had acted in good faith on the basis of intelligence available. He claimed the raid had found evidence of wrongdoing.

However, the Labour chairman of the committee, Robin Corbett, described the raid as heavy handed, unplanned, ill focussed and unjustified.

The MPs also implied that they did not believe explanations as to why the raiding party did not locate the key to the chapel, or encourage the board of visitors to stay during the raid. The chapel door was broken down, and the board of visitors left at midnight unaware that the raid was to last another five hours. The raiding party left before dawn without completing a proper search, adding to the impression that raid was punitive.

The committee condemned the sudden removal of the previous governor and his deputy on the day of the raid. Mr Narey claimed to the committee that his immediate removal without notice was a "planned career move", a description condemned as misleading by the committee.

They found Mr Narey was advised to remove the governor by the area manager covering the south east, Tom Murtagh. At first, Mr Murtagh claimed he was merely the courier, but later accepted he had pressed for his removal.

webTitle: Rogers anger at white paper omissions

fields.headline: Rogers anger at white paper omissions
fields.standfirst: Concern that rural  land will not escape development
fields.trailText: Architect Lord Rogers has criticised John Prescott's urban policy white paper, saying that crucial ideas from his own government-sponsored task force report on urban renaissance have been ignored by ministers.
fields.body:
New Labour's favourite architect yesterday delivered a biting critique of the government's urban policy shortly after John Prescott unveiled a long-awaited white paper to revive towns and cities.

Lord Rogers of Riverside, who led a government task force on urban renaissance, told the deputy prime minister that crucial ingredients from his group's recommendations had been overlooked.

The architect's principal concern was that what he called "vast areas of rural land" earmarked for housing should be brought out of the planning system.

He also felt that legislation was necessary, through an urban renaissance bill, to underpin the white paper - mainly to give a series of proposed regeneration companies extra clout in assembling land and compulsorily acquiring it.

Yesterday's 160-page document included £1bn worth of national tax measures to increase investment in urban areas and an exemption from stamp duty for all property deals in rundown areas.

Lord Rogers welcomed many aspects of the paper, but said: "I remain deeply disappointed by the failure to equalise VAT between old homes and new. We must create a level playing field to both promote urban regeneration and protect the countryside."

webTitle: TheStreet.co.uk boss "baffled" by US parent's closure decision

fields.headline: TheStreet.co.uk boss "baffled" by US parent's closure decision
fields.trailText: Nils Pratley, editor of doomed internet site TheStreet.co.uk, says he has no regrets and would be happy to remain an online journalist, writes Lisa O'Carroll.Management blamed after The Street.co.uk collapse
fields.body:
Nils Pratley, editor of the doomed internet site, TheStreet.co.uk, says he has no regrets and would be happy to remain an online journalist.

Back at his desk today after just two hours sleep, he said he was still baffled with the American parent group's decision to abruptly close the site with the loss of 64 jobs in the UK and 40 in the US.

"It was a huge great shock. We thought we were doing all that was expected of us," he said.

Mr Pratley, who had joined from the Sunday Business, firmly believes there is still a future for a service offering online independent financial journalism for amateur investors.

"I hope the collapse of the site does not mean that good financial journalists are put off altogether from a career online."

Street had 180,000 registered users but did not charge for its service.

Mr Pratley said he still believed such an advertising-supported service was viable and the closure was not a reflection of the wider malaise in the internet market.

He said the Americans had simply decided to cut their losses and retreat to a core business.

"We met every single financial target that was set for us. There is huge amount of disappointment that our US parent could not help us to continue as a going concern," he said.

He said there were "no detectable signs" of a closure in recent weeks, adding there was huge disappointment that no-one from America had come over to break the news personally.

webTitle: Reviews: Ballet: Ondine

fields.headline: Wildor the water sprite
fields.standfirst:
Ondine
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ondine
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.body:
Frederick Ashton's Ondine is a ballet about which few can make up their minds. After its premiere in 1958 it was greeted with mixed, half-hearted reviews. Even when it was revived in 1988, it was hailed neither as a disaster nor as a lost masterpiece. I still don't know whether I enjoy watching it.

The main problem is that Hans Werner Henze's score didn't suit Ashton, who had been hoping for music as "radiant" as the Mediterranean from which its heroine was born. He had wrestled with sections that were knotted and his discomfort shows in passages of dance that look rented by the yard.

What also undermines the ballet is that its feet are placed, unsteadily, in both the 19th and 20th centuries. Its plot tells the quintessentially romantic tale of a man who falls in love with a bewitching water sprite and thus ruins forever his chances of becoming a regular, happy guy.

Not surprisingly, Ashton makes frequent reference to the 19th-century ballet repertoire. Yet he was also trying to be modern, so lodged among his ballet's delicate archaism are a couple of blockbuster dance routines which look like a cross between Soviet populism and Broadway.

At the centre of this muddle, however, is the role of Ondine, and this is pure Ashton. No one else could have entered so naturally into the fantasy life of this naïve, capricious character; no one else could have found a language of such glancingly bright surfaces and wayward rhythms. With the right ballerina the role can carry the ballet and on Wednesday Sarah Wildor proved she was a natural.

Wildor's achievement is to create an Ondine who is not a pretty novelty but a genuine alien. On her first entrance into the mortal world, Wildor doesn't just impersonate Ondine's body language, she inhabits her nervous system. Terror, curiosity and enchantment eddy through her limbs in rapid succession, with barely a move that looks like a habitual human response. Even when she falls in love with Palemon she continues to occupy a different element, breath a more glittering air. And when that love is eventually doomed she looks as if a light has been switched off. Bedraggled and broken, she is like a character from an Andersen fairy tale: tragic but disturbingly remote.

As her Palemon, Jonathon Cope never tries to breach the tame outlines of the role but there are details in his performance which make it warm and solid. Cope does bewitchment very well and we can feel the desire in his fingertips as he touches Wildor. Most importantly, he is a superb partner so that Wildor appears to slip through his arms like a mermaid, just as Ondine herself slips elusively through this difficult ballet. The role, like the sprite, is a lovely thing without a real home.

In repertory until December 11. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: London film festival's small-screen finale

fields.headline: London film festival's small-screen finale
fields.standfirst:
Born Romantic
London film festival
**
fields.trailText:
Born Romantic
London film festival
**
fields.body:
David Kane's comedy Born Romantic, from BBC Films, is so bulging and groaning with award-winning British actors that some of them appear fleetingly, almost subliminally.

Sally Phillips has a tiny cameo as the mobileaholic girlfriend whose phone Craig Ferguson throws out of a cab window. Jessica Stevenson has about one exasperated line as someone who puts up David Morrissey in her flat while he looks for his lost love (Jane Horrocks).

Ian Hart is a garrulous and faintly malign minicab driver who sits Buddha-like in a caff, diverting fellow drivers John Thomson and Adrian Lester with his iffy tinted specs and dodgy excursions into philosophy and sexual politics. And Jimi Mistry is an incompetent "street mugger" who looks after his confused old dad (Kenneth Cranham) and falls in love with Catherine McCormack, a timid, mousy person whose job is to attend graves on behalf of family members who have moved away.

David Kane established a reputation with his amiable Britpic This Year's Love last year and this is similar material. It is centred on the Corazon, a London nightclub where the salsa is taught, and the convenient venue for all the characters to fall in and out of love, their inner turmoil disclosed by the questioning of Jimmy (Lester) the concerned cabbie who ferries them about.

Everyone in the cast gives a strong performance, especially Morrissey, an actor who grows in stature with each outing. Craig Ferguson is funny as Frankie, the absurd proprietor of an easy-listening club who fancies himself as a latter day Rat Pack swinger, unblushingly using expressions like "broad" and "ring-a-ding-ding".

But despite all the classy talent in the cast, there is something a bit flat about this movie, like a bottle of Coke that has lost its fizz. Kane's characterisation, with its variations of wackiness and pathos, never looks much like real life and Born Romantic often seems more a TV idea than a film. In fact, the whole scenario might grow better as a six-part comedy drama in the Cold Feet mould. Jack Rosenthal's The Chain finally evolved into a TV series; a Sunday night BBC drama slot might yet be the destiny of Born Romantic.

webTitle: Disco dancing King's verdict on economy

fields.headline: Disco dancing King's verdict on economy
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England warned yesterday that the economy is slowing down, confirming City expectations that borrowing costs have peaked.
fields.body:
The Bank of England warned yesterday that the economy is slowing down, confirming City expectations that borrowing costs have peaked.

Deputy governor Mervyn King, releasing the quarterly inflation report, said inflation was on course to meet the government's 2.5% target. He added that because of adverse weather: "The committee feel that data over the next few months might bear some resemblance to old- fashioned disco dancing - sharp movements in unpredictable directions creating much excitement accompanied by a good deal of noise."

Analysts said Mr King's comments indicated that the Bank was likely to keep rates on hold. A Reuters poll showed that a majority of analysts now believe rates will peak at their current 6% but will not start falling until next year.

Some City economists accused Threadneedle Street of massaging its forecast to avoid predicting an inflation undershoot that would renew calls for rates to be cut.

The Bank based its prediction that inflation would hit the 2.5% target in two year's time on sterling's recent decline against other world currencies. If it had followed its usual practice of using a longer time period to predict the currency's value, inflation would have been 0.2% below target.

"This looks suspiciously like a move by the more hawkish members [of the monetary policy committee] to prevent the interest rate debate from moving too strongly in the direction of rate cuts," said Jonathan Loynes at Capital Economics.

The Bank predicts that consumers will rein back on spending, allowing room for the government's boost to public spending.

With the Regent Street lights in London switched on this week (above) for the crucial Christmas sales period, there were few signs of a slowdown in the latest high street sales data released yesterday by the Office for National Statistics. This showed sales growth still running at 3.8% a year. Economists, who had expected sales to fall last month, said underlying consumer demand appeared to be solid.

 The European central bank kept borrowing costs among euro members at 4.75% yesterday.

webTitle: Could the euro be on the way up?

fields.headline: Could the euro be on the way up?
fields.trailText: You've heard it all before: the euro has hit rock bottom and now is the time to buy. But then it goes lower still. So don't pay any attention to recent predictions of a good year ahead for the beleaguered currency, right?
fields.body:
You've heard it all before: the euro has hit rock bottom and now is the time to buy. But then it goes lower still. So don't pay any attention to recent predictions of a good year ahead for the beleaguered currency, right?

Well, maybe. Fund managers and economists agree that currencies are notoriously difficult things to predict, but many think we may be seeing the beginning of a slow recovery for the euro. If they're right then now is indeed to the time to invest in the euro and European equities. So let's consider their reasoning.

First and foremost, economists agree the euro has been weak in relation to the dollar. The US economy has been booming for some time, making business buy dollars and invest in the US. If you're buying dollars, you're selling euros, making the currency weaker.

However, the US economy is slowing down and may continue to slow down. So dollars aren't the be-all and end-all anymore. In addition, European equities - shares in euro-zone companies - are deemed to have been undervalued for quite some time.

At some point the markets will correct this, boosting the share price of these European companies. Anyone with a stake in them will make a nice little profit. But unlike euro-zone shareholders, UK shareholders will benefit from the double-whammy of a rise in share price and a rise in the currency.

When something seems to good to be true it usually is, so naturally this scenario needs to be qualified. For it to happen, economist's predictions have to come true. The US economy will have to slow down, business will have to stop selling euros and markets will have to start seeing the true value of European companies.

And assuming this does happen, it won't happen overnight. Economists say investors will have to take a long to medium-term view and put their money away for three to five years at least. In addition, European share prices and the euro could go up and down at different times, cancelling each other's success out.

Investors willing to take the risk could do worse than invest in a European equities fund in sterling. If all goes to plan they should, in the words of Jeremy Batstone, head of research at Natwest, get the "icing on the cake": an increase in equity and currency. Lots of fund managers, among them Jupiter, Henderson and Aberdeen, have European equity funds.

But if all this sounds too confusing or too much of a risk, perhaps you should just buy euros now in anticipation of a cheap summer holiday on the continent. The currency is unlikely to fall much lower than its current level.

John Kelly, investment manager at Barclays Funds says: "The European Central Bank has intervened and bought euros four times over the past few weeks, which is really quite extraordinary. It's a sign that the bank thinks the currency has fallen far enough and probably means it will continue to intervene to maintain its level."

With such high level backing the euro's value should stabilise and eventually rise, making now the perfect time to buy holiday money. But, again, you've heard all that before haven't you?

fields.headline: The Necks
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.body:
The Necks approach their music as carefully as if it were a lit stick of dynamite. Before embarking upon an unbroken chain of sound which lasted for up to an hour during each set, this Australian threesome entered into a silence that might have spooked a more highly strung audience. In the darkness and quiet, three stately candles shone at the front of the stage. Behind, on a giant screen, were the windows of a residential tenement. Bit by bit, things started to happen.

A simple, plaintive ditty from bassist Lloyd Swanton ripened into a ditto. Tony Buck on drums rumbled, then clattered into view, softly, with all the guileless stealth of a dustbin lid. Minutes later, the piano set up a relay of intervalic fifths. The mood was pensive until an insidious, unsettling deep note, played open-string on the double bass, crept into the brew. At first it all felt a bit stilted but as the musical elements built and changed places by increments, the audience began to relax and get into the groove.

One might accuse the Necks of lacking closure but that is also at the core of their appeal: a willingness to roam. Described as low-key jazz fusion, their music glistens with a heap of other elements. Individually, they have collaborated on more than 160 albums, playing with, among others, Branford Marsalis and Midnight Oil as well as doing their own projects. As the Necks, they have just released their seventh album, Hanging Gardens.

There were points at which too many layers of repetition got itchy, but each time something would distract the attention or alter the mood. It was nothing so dramatic as a shift but, if you watched closely, a new urgency, a lull, a sudden sweetness. Chris Abrahams on piano was the main arbiter of temperament, his speed, precision and intelligence signalling why he is so in demand as a session player in his native Sydney.

The Necks repay patience; sometimes their music is irritating and troublesome, at others frenetic, ambient or groovy. Then there was the realisation that the screen behind the band was not static but a web-cam. Chinks of light appeared and disappeared in windows; people moved about, unconscious performers. Once alerted to the fractional movement on screen, it became hard to avert the eyes and we were voyeurs. That attention to detail magnified the music, as we listened for the subtle threads that wound through each set.

webTitle: Nationwide loses ground in mortgage lending war

fields.headline: Nationwide loses ground in mortgage lending war
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The mortgage price war has taken its toll on Nationwide, slashing its share of the new home loans market from 15.4% to 10.1%, it revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The mortgage price war has taken its toll on Nationwide, slashing its share of the new home loans market from 15.4% to 10.1%, it revealed yesterday.

Net mortgage lending in the six months to October 4 totalled £2.2bn, down from £3.2bn in the same period last year. Chief executive Brian Davis said: "People have fought back and there is more competition out there. We always expected there would be."

In the summer HSBC cut its standard variable mortgage rate by almost one percentage point; the Halifax's new phone bank, Intelligent Finance, launched with a competitive rate; and Barclays switched to a new system of interest calculation cutting monthly bills.

Announcing its interim results, Nationwide, Britain's biggest building society, said its residential mortgage lend ing had been "robust" in what has been a competitive market, and pointed out that its share of new advances of 10.1% was above its existing market share of 8.5%.

Mr Davis said the new figures partly reflected the fact that it is "not a big player" in the remortgage market, and added that he never thought the 15.4% share achieved last year was sustainable.

The society had more to celebrate on the savings front - it captured more than a sixth of all new savings money over the period, more than double its natural share of 6.9%.

More than 150,000 people have taken out the society's online e-Savings account since its launch in June despite it only being available to Nationwide current account holders.

Nationwide's pre-tax profits for the six months were up 15.2% to £253.8m, compared with £220.4m last time.

webTitle: Out of step in Threadneedle Street

fields.headline: Out of step in Threadneedle Street
fields.standfirst:
Is there method in this madness?
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The economy is set for a bout of "disco dancing", according to the Bank of England's deputy governor Mervyn King - although thankfully for everyone watching yesterday's presentation on the Bank's quarterly inflation report, he did not volunteer to demonstrate.
fields.body:
The economy is set for a bout of "disco dancing", according to the Bank of England's deputy governor Mervyn King - although thankfully for everyone watching yesterday's presentation on the Bank's quarterly inflation report, he did not volunteer to demonstrate.

Mr King was referring to the likely volatility of key economic data over the next few months, which the Bank believes will be bounced around the dancefloor by this autumn's bad weather and an uncertain outlook for the world economy. Threadneedle Street economists are familiarising themselves with concepts such as soil moisture content and other horticultural variables - a refreshing change, no doubt, from studying the minutiae of the labour market.

But John Travolta himself would have been proud of the fancy steps the Bank of England demonstrated over its exchange rate forecast yesterday.

Instead of basing its predictions for the path of sterling on the currency's behaviour during the 15 days prior to the forecast, as it has in past inflation reports, it chose to focus on a narrower, five-day window at the start of November. The period it chose just happened to coincide with a significant weakening in sterling's trade-weighted exchange rate - which had the effect of reducing the sterling assumption in the forecast, and thus increasing the profile of inflation.

Mr King played down the change at the presentation, pointing out that the Bank has altered its sterling forecasting assumptions several times since it took over responsibility for setting interest rates. The Bank believes the rise in sterling during October was an aberration, and that its decline in November is more in line with expectations.

But the City smelt a rat and accused the Bank of moving the goal posts in order to avoid producing an under-target forecast. We shall see.

The Bank's record on predicting sterling has improved, mostly because it has stopped basing its forecasts entirely on what it thinks should happen to the currency and accepted that since much of sterling's appreciation cannot be explained, its past behaviour is as much a guide to the future as economic theory.

Narrowing the exchange rate window to the period where the pound was behaving as the Bank believes it should - that is, falling against other world currencies - suggests it still believes it can accurately predict sterling's path.

The Bank also chose a period marked by two bouts of intervention in the markets by the European Central Bank to prop up the euro, which had the effect of weakening sterling. If the euro takes another tumble, Threadneedle Street's inflation forecast will appear increasingly out of line.

Nice work

There is something wonderfully haphazard about the management of Nice - the optimistically named National Institute for Clinical Excellence.

The institute was established last year to vet medicines for the NHS, setting guidelines on the usefulness and cost effectiveness of controversial treatments. Its worthy aim was to improve consis tency, preventing the regional variances dubbed "postcode prescribing".

In reality, it has stumbled from one pitfall to another, arousing screams of exaggerated outrage from the pharmaceuticals industry at every step.

Feathers were flying again yesterday as Nice announced it was to begin publishing all its draft appraisals on drugs. These initial evaluations are drawn up after preliminary hearings, but are often radically altered in "final" rulings after further consultation.

Nice's reason for publishing these drafts is disarmingly honest - nearly all of them have been leaked, despite a £60,000 investigation into security procedures. The Association of British Pharmaceutical Industry is furious - it says preliminary decisions cast a blight on drug sales, affect share prices and are likely to deter firms from launching their products first in the UK.

The real problem is in the way Nice works: true to its name, it tries to be likeable and open, sending its initial appraisals to hundreds of selected doctors, patients and specialists for their views. This is at odds with procedures at bodies such as the competition commission, which handle similarly financially sensitive information. They manage to collect opinions without disclosing their early thinking.

Nice has had a terrible year. It has banned Glaxo's flu drug Relenza, sending Sir Richard Sykes into such a tizzy that he threatened to leave the country. It also imposed restrictions on beta interferons, upsetting multiple sclerosis sufferers. Each ruling takes at least a year, and Nice has been characterised as an extra hurdle in an already heavily regulated drug approval system.

While the government is improving relations with the industry, Nice is leaving a trail of acrimony in its path. The institute needs a radical rethink.

webTitle: Reviews: Pop: Wondermints

fields.headline: Wondermints
fields.standfirst:
Borderline, London
****
fields.trailText:
Borderline, London
****
fields.body:
In the momentary silence following Global Village Idiot's harmonic but angular climax, some wag shouts "Surf's Up!" It's part request, part comment and everyone in the crammed Borderline smiles knowingly. Wondermints are a very "smiles knowingly" sort of band. Most of the Los Angeles quintet are Brian Wilson's backing band on his current Pet Sounds tour of the US, the day job that has prevented them from following up 1998's Bali, which finally saw a British release this year.

Their set is littered with Wilson touches, from Indonesian singer/keyboard player Darian Sahanaja's ability to turn as simple a song as Tracy Hide into a mini-symphony, to the way singer/guitarist Nick Walusko offers a Mike Love-style twist when he takes lead vocals.

Dig deeper and there's more to smile knowingly about. They cover Goffin and King's surreal Porpoise Song and the Turtles' Love in the City. More craftily, merging musical history, 1970s kitsch and a sparkling tune, they dedicate a swift jog through the UFO theme to Nick Drake's actress sister Gabrielle (or Gabriella as they rechristen her), a star of the series.

Those alienated by the trainspotting can still revel in Wondermints' quest for the perfect melody. Walusko's Dreamachine and Sahanaja's Hypnolove are sufficiently intricate almost to embrace prog-rock and the segue from Proto-Pretty into Playtex Aviary is genuinely thrilling, but, like Jellyfish before them, Wondermints have a light touch ensuring the melodic core of their songs is rarely sacrificed for musical dexterity.

Puppet Grrls R Go and Chris-Craft No 10, with its peculiar lyric concerning an "aqua fantasy", thunder along as if originally produced by Phil Spector, while In and Around Greg Lake seems to be four songs at one sitting, all of them fascinating and all the product of a shockingly tasteful record collection, circa 1969.

When, during the encore, babyfaced Mike D'Amica swaps his drums for guitar and sings the sweet Cellophone, it's clear Wondermints are no two-man operation. It's not wholly perfect. They have a rather lumpy and awkward stage presence for a band with three albums and a decade of shows behind them and there is a worrying tendency towards smugness.

But for the most part Wondermints simultaneously distil the past and, albeit warily, embrace the present. They promised to return next year with Wilson. Now that should really be something.

webTitle: Reviews: Jazz: Simon Fell

fields.headline: Simon Fell
fields.standfirst:
Clothworkers Hall, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Clothworkers Hall, Leeds
****
fields.body:
They were rioting at Leeds university and the man to blame was composer Simon Fell. The wizard of wilful discordance strolled on to the stage accompanied by a troupe of young, earnest music students and proceeded to baffle and enchant us with an hour and a half of violent sensuality.

Fell's Composition No.57: Kaleidozyklen, receiving its world premiere, is the latest in a long line of works that have seen him wrestling with a bewildering array of self-inflicted musical challenges, not least of which is how do you get a large orchestral group to improvise freely around a system of musical notation and not end up making a meaningless racket?

Somehow on this occasion, the university's contemporary music ensemble pulls it off. How they do it, or indeed what exactly it is that they are doing, remains a mystery. A written commentary is provided but it is full of phrases such as 'real-time xenochronicity' so there's not much help there.

The piece is split into five movements and there is a central director and five sub-conductors. Instruments include brass, woodwind, a harp, electric guitar, piano, violins, a big drum and a double bass. The latter, played by Fell, is horrifically assaulted from beginning to end; in fact some of his scrapings sound like someone desperately scrabbling at the inside of a coffin lid. Some members of the audience crane their necks, muttering 'how is he doing that?' while others just sit back and accept that there are some things they will never understand.

The general mood of the work is glacial. Broken symphonic fragments float out at us from an encroaching blizzard. The insidious second movement is like trying to get to sleep with a malevolent voice telling you that you need to go to the lavatory. The fourth movement is a skewed homage to Mahler, the score degraded by an insensitive computer software programme.

Throughout each movement the musicians' faces are rapt. Director Simon Baines, first violinist Shelley Jamison and clarinettist Rachel Cocks exchange feverishly intense stares with Fell and the five sub-conductors help us perceive form and swing in this shimmering tapestry with their bold and enthusiastic gesticulations. The warm response to the piece left Fell beaming with joy. "I hope you find it as disconcerting as I do," the composer wrote in the programme. Don't worry, Simon. We did.

webTitle: Orfeo ed Euridice

fields.headline: Orfeo ed Euridice
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Gluck's take on the Orpheus legend, the first of his truly important operas, is currently enjoying a ripple of popularity. Last month it was staged in Cardiff by the Welsh National Opera; here at the Barbican it was performed in concert by a German orchestra and choir, a Belgian conductor and three Argentine-born soloists.

Hearing an overseas band tackling this kind of music acted as a reminder that in Britain we have grown accustomed to works of this period (mid to late-18th century) being performed in a certain style. The authentic movement is dominated by a handful of conductors who prescribe their preferred manner of playing - and orchestras under Gardiner or Norrington can indeed make a sound not only appropriate to the period but also beautiful in its own right.

The Freiburg Baroque, however, seemed to eschew sweetness of tone in favour of sheer vigour and dramatic punch. The strings, playing most of the time with a strictly enforced embargo on vibrato, sounded far more astringent than their British counterparts might, their hastily dispatched chords during the overture being almost percussive.

The wind, too, played evenly and without vibrato, at times steadily enough to sound as though their lines were coming from an organ. Extra colour was painted in by the harp or the fortepiano, whose bright interjections of continuo lightened the atmosphere at Cupid's entry.

This orchestra is accustomed to playing without a conductor and it showed. It boasts a visibly strong leader and an obvious sense of communication between players. Indeed, there were times when the presence of René Jacobs seemed superfluous. Conducting without a baton, Jacobs seemed often to be coasting with the music rather than commanding it. Even so, he set and maintained the unflagging pace at which the drama unfolded and held together the ensemble with seemingly easy precision.

The focus of attention was on the three soloists, particularly on mezzo soprano Bernarda Fink who, taking the title "trouser" role, had by far the most demanding evening. For all his apparent bravery, Orpheus is a self-absorbed character, granted almost 20 minutes of grieving monologue before Cupid's first entrance.

Fink demanded the audience's attention, imbuing her music with a dark-hued introspection and intensity. Veronica Cangemi was a soft-toned, beguiling Euridice, at times almost too expressive, while Maria Cristina Kiehr, a much brighter soprano, sparkled as Cupid. As the light-hearted guardian angel, it was for Kiehr to deliver the traditional, if completely fabricated, operatic happy end.

webTitle: A brilliant Caretaker from Patrick Marber

fields.headline: A brilliant Caretaker from Patrick Marber
fields.standfirst:
The Caretaker
Comedy Theatre, London
*****
fields.trailText:
The Caretaker
Comedy Theatre, London
*****
fields.body:
Forty years after its premiere, how does Pinter's play stand up? With the resilience of a classic. Watching Patrick Marber's excellent revival, what astonishes one is the way a play, at once so familiar and so strange, yields new meanings through the chemistry of the particular actors.

The surprise casting is Michael Gambon as Davies, the itinerant down-and-out. Partly because of the prototype performance of Donald Pleasence, one always imagines the character, offered refuge in a junk-filled room, to be a wiry figure. But Gambon has the bulk and size of a Dickensian grotesque.

He offers the most physically repellent Davies I have seen - which, of course, makes all the funnier his attempts to cling to a pathetic dignity, as when he claims, "I've had dinner with the best." But what Gambon brings out specifically is the chameleon-like nature of the dispossessed. Trained to a life of survival, this Davies shifts from ingratiation to aggression. When he turns on the brain-damaged Aston and warns him "they can have you inside again", it is with a downright cruelty that springs from deprivation. You never pity Davies; what astonishes is the unsentimental accuracy with which Pinter records his plight.

It is a brilliant performance. But it never overshadows the other actors, nor does it prevent you realising that Pinter's play is both about the loss of identity that comes from social exclusion and the way we all cling to life-sustaining dreams. Davies's personal Nirvana lies in Sidcup where his papers are ostensibly housed. But when Rupert Graves's sleek, fly, property-owning Mick reclines on a sofa and talks of turning this tumbledown room into a penthouse, you realise that he is equally gripped by illusion. And as Douglas Hodge's kindly yet defiant Aston speaks of the shed he plans to build we are in the world of Gorky's or O'Neill's pipe-dreamers.

This is the key to the play's greatness: it is about three lost souls who never fully know who they are and who, while mercilessly exposing others' illusions, are all in the grip of private fantasies. That is why the play makes sense everywhere from Cairo to Caracas. But the tone of Marber's production, given a design by Rob Howell full of rotting verisimilitude, is set by Gambon, who assumes whatever persona is necessary.

Watching Patrick Marber's excellent revival, what astonishes one is the way a play, at once so familiar and so strange, yields new meanings through the chemistry of the particular actors. The surprise casting is Michael Gambon as Davies, the itinerant down-and-out. Partly because of the prototype performance of Donald Pleasence, one always imagines the character, offered refuge in a junk-filled room, to be a wiry figure. But Gambon has the bulk and size of a Dickensian grotesque. He offers the most physically repellent Davies I have seen - which, of course, makes all the funnier his attempts to cling to a pathetic dignity, as when he claims, "I've had dinner with the best." But what Gambon brings out specifically is the chameleon-like nature of the dispossessed. Trained to a life of survival, this Davies shifts from ingratiation to aggression.
